KAYE--Peter. 12/9/55 - 5/25/14 To my sweet husband and best friend - happy 60th. You are profoundly missed and forever loved. Mary 1/3
KAYE--Peter B.,12/09/55 - 5/25/14 Happy Birthday, Peter; a date we will never forget. If to be remembered is to live on, you will always be with us. 1/3

FECHTMANN--Margaret C.,of New York City and Montauk, on December 8, 2015. Retired Executive Vice President Met Life. Devoted daughter of the late George and Margaretha. Beloved sister of Catherine Berg (James), Virginia Blair (Robert), George (Lorraine) and John (Eileen). Cherished aunt and great-aunt. Friends may call Thursday, 7-9pm and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9pm at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Homes, Hicksville Chapel, 47 Jerusalem Ave. (corner of W. Marie Street). Funeral Service Saturday, 10:30am at Parkway Community Church, Hicksville. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Junior Achievement of New York. 1/3

GROSS--Clifford H.,passed away on December 6, 2015, peacefully after a long struggle caused by a stroke. Survived by his sister, Clara Jellinek and his niece, Nancy Vizer (George), and son-in- law Solomon Moses. He is also survived by his nieces and nephews Isaac (Eva) Moses, Rebecca Goldberg (Shalom), Jonathan (Becky) Moses and Joshua Vizer (Dr. Alisa), Samantha Herscher (Eric) and seven great grandnephews-nieces. He is survived by his former wife, Alexandra, and stepchildren Inna and Eugene and their children, and he had an especially good grandfather relationship with Charles. His beloved wife, Frances predeceased him after 33 years of a life shared together while he served our country as a Foreign Service Officer in Germany (West), Budapest, Vienna, Paris, Sofia, Teheran and the Soviet Union. Because of his wife's illness he retired from the Foreign Service and resumed working for the State Department. He was a graduate of CCNY, the Russian Institute at Columbia University and Middlebury College. Clifford and Frances supported many charitable enterprises with work and monetary gifts; primary among these was the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum and Temple Sinai, both in Washington, DC. He served proudly in the U.S. Marine Corps in the Pacific area and Japan during and after World War II. We cherish the memory of his extraordinary good humored jokes and his dedication to the welfare of others. Goldsteins' Rosenberg's Raphael-Sacks. 1/3

MALLOY--Howard. The Board of Governors and members of Rockrimmon Country Club are profoundly saddened by the passing of their beloved friend and esteemed member for 53 years. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to all members of the Malloy Family. Robert J. Bluestone, President 1/3

BARANSKI--Joan Sullivan Born April 6, 1933; died November 8, 2015, in Cambridge MA. Longtime resident of New York City, widow of the late Kenneth E. Baranski. Survived by her sister Ruth McElheny of Cambridge MA, brother Joseph C. Sullivan of Andover MA, brother-in-law Victor K. McElheny, sister-in-law Marybeth Sullivan, several nieces, nephews, grandnieces and nephews. 1/3

MITCHELL--Faye Konigsberg, widow, devoted mother of Shelley, and Andrea (Denzil) Ash, dear sister of Matilda Greenspan, and adored aunt of Sandy and Steven Greenspan, and Jay (Elsa) Konigsberg, died Saturday, December 5, 2015. In lieu of flowers, send contributions to VNS or JASA. She truly was A Woman of Valor. To know her was to love her. 1/3

HILL--Alfred. The Columbia Law School community mourns the death of our colleague and friend, Professor Emeritus Alfred Hill, who passed away on December 5 at the age of 98. Al was a valued member of the Columbia community who made significant scholarly contributions in the areas of constitutional law, corporations, securities regulation, federal courts, torts, and conflict of laws. A graduate of both Brooklyn Law School and Harvard Law School, Al began his teaching career in the early 1950s after nine years as an attorney with the SEC. He joined our faculty as a visiting professor in 1962. After receiving a standing ovation from students at the end of his first lecture, he was quickly offered a permanent position. Known for his sense of humor, fairness, and inquisitive nature, Al had a talent for shedding light on dry and complex legal concepts. His colleagues and students continuously marveled at his enthusiastic and compelling teaching style during his nearly 30 years at the Law School. As a scholar, his opinion was widely sought, and he could often be found in the company of other Columbia Law School intellectual giants, including Professors Hans Smit and Kenny Jones. Al was a generous mentor and teacher to generations of Columbia Law School students. In retirement, Al remained a voracious reader and history buff, and he enjoyed baking bread. Our hearts go out to his loving wife, Dorothy, to his daughter and son-in-law, Amelia Hill-Oliva and Cesar Oliva, and to his two grandsons, Michael Hill-Oliva and Kevin Hill-Oliva. The Columbia Law School family shares in this great loss. There will be a gathering of friends at Al's home on Saturday, December 19, from 2-4pm. 1/3

ZWERLING--Florence, died peacefully at home on December 6, 2015 at the age of 94. She was the much adored and devoted mother of Jeff (Donna) and Robin and grandmother of Jayme, Errin and Callie. Flo was predeceased by husband Gustav. She spent her career as a speech and hearing pathologist. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or Lymphoma Research Foundation. 1/3

SHAGAN--Stephen H. "Steve," 88, passed away peacefully in his sleep on November 30, 2015, at his home in Los Angeles, CA. Born in 1927 in New York City to Barnet "Barney" and Rachel Shagan, Steve is survived by his son Robert (Paul). Beloved husband of 61 years of marriage to Elizabeth "Betty" F. Shagan (1930-2013), Steve will be remembered for his kindness, intelligence, creativity, honesty, strength, generosity, humor, integrity and perseverance; as well as the love he felt for the cats that he and Betty cared for over the years. When not dedicating time to his craft, Steve enjoyed traveling, keeping up with his favorite baseball and football teams' scores, horseracing, reading and spending quality time with his family and close friends. Steve's career as a best-selling author, film and television writer and producer spanned nearly six decades; including nominations for two Academy Awards, a Golden Globe Award and a Primetime Emmy Award. In 1974, Steve won the Writers Guild of America Award - Best Screenplay, Drama for "Save the Tiger," based upon his novel of the same name. Cumulatively, Steve published eight critically acclaimed novels, wrote 10 screenplays and produced over 48 films, television episodes and made for TV movies, combined. Private family services will be held at Newton Cemetery in Newton Center, MA. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the World Wildlife Fund. 1/3

ZACHAROPOULOS--Joan, age 71, passed away peacefully on December 5, 2015 at her residence surrounded by her family. She had been courageously battling cancer for two years. Joan was born on January 2, 1944, in College Point, Queens, NY. After pursuing a nursing career in her younger years, then raising a family of three children, she, along with her husband, founded two thriving businesses where she continued to devote her time, love, and energy until her very last days. She will be survived by her loving husband George, her children Melina, Nicholas and Theodore, and her grandchildren, Vincent, Stella, Dominic, Sophia, Joan, George and Eliana. Visiting hours will be from 2-4pm and 7-9pm on Wednesday, December 9th at Higgins Funeral Home, 321 S Main St., New City, NY 10956. The funeral service will be Thursday, December 10th at 9am at Saints Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Church in West Nyack, NY. 1/3

GORNEY--Sondra, widow of Jay Gorney, composer of the anthem of the Great Depression, "Brother Can You Spare a Dime," and a victim of the McCarthy blacklist. Sondra Gorney was an actress, producer, author, public relations executive, philanthropist, and a strong supporter and advocate of women's rights in the theater world. She was a beloved mother, grandmother to Tatiana, aunt, cousin and friend. She was a member of Equity and SAG/AFTRA, the League of Professional Theatre Women, the New York Sheet Music Society, and on the board of the New York Coalition of Women in the Arts and Media. In 2014 the League of Professional Theatre Women, presented a special education award to her. Until 96, she never missed a meeting! Sondra married film and theater composer Jay Gorney. Together they co-produced many plays and several editions of the musical revenue "Meet the People." In New York, they established the first musical play department at the New School and the American Theatre Wing professional training program. Their love for music and theater resulted in a devoted and creative marriage that lasted until his death. They had two children, Karen and Daniel Gorney, along with Jay's son, Rod, from his first marriage. They moved to New York after Jay was one of the first to be blacklisted and later appeared before the House Un-American Activities Committee. After retiring from a 33 year career in public relations, Sondra returned to acting, performing Off-Broadway, as well as in film and TV. Her credits include roles in "The Producers" and in TV's "Law and Order." Her most recent performance was as Mrs. Hobson in Stuart Vaughan's "The Scarlet Letter" at the Gene Frankel Theatre. She also had a four-year run in "Grandma Sylvia's Funeral" (Soho Playhouse). Until 96, she attended the Master Class for Professional Actors. Sondra was the author of two books: "After Forty, How Women Can Achieve Fulfillment," and "Brother, Can You Spare a Dime - The Life of Composer Joy Gorney." A few months before her death, she completed writing her last book, an autobiography entitled "It's My Turn Now." Sondra died on August 10, 2015. A memorial will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, December 10 at 7pm, 180 West 76 Street, NY, NY 10023, telephone 212-362-6600. 1/3

ROSENHOUSE--Jeanne R.,died December 8, 2015, at the age of 96. Loving mother of Billie (Martin Gold), Michael (Terri), and Daniel (Pam Waldman), proud grandmother of David (Corinne Schiff) and Jonathan Gold (Heather Cristol); Shoshana; and Gabriel (Alana Kinarsky); and four great-grandchildren. She was pre- deceased by Seymour, her husband of almost 50 years. Her deeply held humane values are an inspiration to all who knew her. Service at 10am, Thursday at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. 1/3
ZAX--Harry. Born December 9, 1915 in Paterson, New Jersey. Loved by his family, Leonard, Helen, David and Laura 1/3
COHEN--Albert C. October 25, 1922-December 5, 2015. Decorated WWII pilot, owner of Creighton Shirt Co., philanthropist, husband to Joan. 1/3

TOWNSEND--Eleanor Meneely, M.D.,a psychiatrist in New York City died at her home December 2nd, age 83. A retired member of the faculty of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons she was associated with both Presbyterian and Harlem Hospitals and for many years was director of The Harlem Center for Child Study. She attended The Brearley School and was a graduate of Sarah Lawrence College and Columbia University P&S. She was a psychiatry consultant for various institutions including Prisoners Legal Services. She was the daughter of Clinton Blake and Eleanor Meneely Townsend. She is survived by her husband of 53 years, Monroe Chasson and her daughters, Kate Chasson of Winter Park, CO and Sarah Chasson of Chevy Chase, MD, Frank G. Zarb, Jr, three grandchildren, and her brother Clinton (Bill) Townsend of Canaan, ME. 1/3

GERBER--Stacy Philip Oct. 10, 1945 - Dec. 10, 2014. My beautiful husband, gone too soon. Love you forever. Michael Dillinger 1/3

FURSE--G. Ronald, of Essex CT and Fishers Island NY, died peacefully on December 8, 2015. He was born in Irvington, NY on June 26, 1921 and lived most of his life in Sussex, England. He worked for Fiduciary Trust Company in New York City and London. He attended Eton College, Cambridge University and served as a Captain in the Welsh Guards. A service will be held on Saturday, December 12th at The First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, CT at 3:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: H.L. Ferguson Museum, P.O Box 554, Fishers Island, NY 06390. 1

ROSENBERG--Stephen, of Union, NJ, passed away on December 8, 2015. Born on May 18, 1943 in Queens, NY, he married Lucille on June 23, 1968. Stephen attended Columbia University and Harvard Law School, working as an attorney for 47 years. He is survived by his wife, children, Jonathan and Michele, and their spouses and his six grandchildren. Donations can be made to Temple Emanu-El, Westfield, NJ. Services by Menorah Chapels at Millburn, Union, NJ. 1/3

POLLACK--Lester, 82, peacefully at home in NYC on December 9, 2015. Lester earned his bachelor's degree from Brooklyn College. After graduating from NYU Law School in 1957, he practiced law, rising to partner before joining Loews Corporation, where he ultimately became Executive Vice President. After leaving Loews, he became Vice Chairman and Co-Chief Operating Officer of the United Brands Company and a Partner at Oppenheimer & Company. He later co-founded Odyssey Partners in 1982, and founded Centre Partners Management, a private equity firm, in 1986. Lester was not only a leader in business, but also a devoted philanthropist and humanitarian. He was deeply committed to the Jewish community, including chair of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, president of the Jewish Community Relations Council of New York, chair of the Associated YM-YWHAs of Greater New York, and honorary chair of the Anti-Defamation League. Lester is survived by Geri, his wife of 59 years, son Bruce and his wife Susan, daughter Wendy Isaacs, grandchildren Shayna, Jordan, Kayla, Justin and Rachel, brother Herbert Pollack and his wife Sandy. He was also uncle, relative, friend and colleague of many. Service Friday, December 11th, 11 am at Park Ave. Synagogue, 50 E. 87 St., NYC. 1/3

SIMON--John J.,86, of Westport, CT, died on December 8, 2015. Survived by Laura Lee Simon, beloved wife of 65 years; children, Terri, James and Andrew; seven grandchildren; and sister, Patricia Scheines. Voracious reader, classical music lover, passionate civil libertarian. Services at Abraham L. Green Funeral Home, Fairfield, CT, on Thursday, December 10, at 1pm. 1/3

Snyder, Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir, IM Leah Siegel, Exec Dir, AFIM 1/3

DOWNING--Daniel P.,on December 8, 2015, born Kenmare, County Kerry Ireland. Beloved husband of the late Sheila M. Loving father of Patrick (Brian), Mary, Daniel, Patricia, Teresa, and Sheila. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Calvary Hospice Bronx, NY. 1/3

LAMBERT--Joseph A. Died peacefully in New York on December 1, 2015. He was the beloved son of the late Mildred and Cecil. Survived by his devoted brother, Steven (Barbara), and nephew, Corey. Services private. 1/3

GUITANO--Anton, of New York City, who in June of this year retired as the Chief Operating Officer of CBS Corporation's Local Media unit, passed away peacefully on December 8 at the age of 65. He had been diagnosed with cancer earlier this year. Anton was born on July 5, 1950 in Brooklyn, N.Y. to Blanche and Whitney Guitano. He grew up in Brooklyn along with his brothers, Ricardo and Glenn, before attending St. Peter's College in Jersey City, N.J., where he earned his Bachelor of Science degree in accounting on a full academic and athletic scholarship. After beginning his career with Price Waterhouse, Anton joined CBS in 1978 as a member of the company's internal audit department. Over the course of his distinguished 37-year career with CBS, he rose through the ranks to become Financial Controller for the CBS Television Network; Vice President and General Auditor for CBS, Inc.; Executive Vice President of Operations and Chief Financial Officer for CBS Television Stations; and Chief Financial Officer and Senior Executive Vice President, Operations, for CBS Radio. In 2009, Anton was named Chief Operating Officer of CBS Local Media and was responsible for overseeing the financial and operational success of CBS Corporation's local television and radio stations as well as the stations' websites and other digital platforms. Anton also served as CBS's representative on the Federal Communications Commission's Advisory Committee on Diversity for Communications in the Digital Age. Anton is survived by his loving wife of 15 years, Eileen, a member of the CBS Television Network finance department; his mother, Blanche; his brother, Glenn; his children, Jessica (Michael), Jennifer (Cory) and Jason (Maria); and three adoring grandchildren, Sydney, Nathan and Jade. He was preceded in death by his father, Whitney; brother, Ricardo; and first wife, Leslie. Visitation will be held on Thursday, December 10 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Cargain Funeral Home, 418 U.S. Route 6, Mahopac, N.Y. A Mass of Christian burial will be held on Friday, December 11 at 10 a.m. at St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church, 225 East Lake Blvd., Mahopac, N.Y. In lieu of sending flowers, friends who wish to honor Anton's memory may send donations to either the American Institute for Cancer Research (www.AICR.org) or the Preston Robert Tisch Brain Tumor Center (www.cancer.duke.edu/btc). 1/3

Leggitt, III) of San Francisco, CA, and son Robert Livingston Clarkson, III (Teresa C.) of Spofford, NH, granddaughters Tasha C. and Cassandra C. Clarkson and great-granddaughter Livingston Celia. Funeral Service 1pm on December 12 at St. John's of Lattingtown. Memorial contributions to Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. 1/3

POLLACK--Lester. We mourn the passing of our founder, Lester Pollack, but celebrate his many accomplishments in the New York and international community through his charitable endeavors, in the academic world, in his numerous activities at NYU, in the domestic and international political arenas in the promotion of peace and in the business world through his founding of Centre Partners and Odyssey Partners, as well as his guiding role at Loews Corporation and United Brands. Our sincere thoughts are with his beloved wife Geri, his son Bruce and his wife Susan, his daughter Wendy and grandchildren, Shayna, Jordan, Kayla, Justin and Rachael. Your Friends and Colleagues at Centre Partners 1/3

POLLACK--Lester. The people of Loews Corporation mourn the passing of long-time friend and executive Lester Pollack. Lester was a trusted advisor whose sage counsel was sought frequently in the early days of Loews. His impact on the company was immeasurable. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Geri and his family. Lester will be missed. 1/3

POLLACK--Lester. The National Center on Philanthropy and the Law (NCPL) at New York University School of Law mourns the death of Lester Pollack, beloved Director and friend of the NCPL. Lester was a generous philanthropist and devoted leader, giving seemingly unlimited amounts of time, energy, and resources to causes he believed in. Lester served as the Chair of the NCPL Board of Directors from 1998 until his passing on Wednesday morning. The NCPL and the community it serves are grateful for Lester's extraordinary life and his transformative impact on the nonprofit sector. We will miss him. We join Lester's family and friends in mourning his loss. 1/3

RIVERA--Robert M. (Robert Storm), age 60, died suddenly November 27, 2015. A solid, reliable, humble man; spiritual and kind. He never spent a day without music: a Latin percussionist and dancer. He served on the security team at Bloomberg, LLP for two decades. Beloved partner of Stasia Pasela; brother of Eddy and Maria Rivera, Violet and Frank Contreras; nephew of Gladys Cruz, Brunny Cruz; uncle of Joseph M. Rivera and Eddy Rivera Jr., Debbie Manzella and Frank Contreras Jr. Memorial and Celebration of Life Service, Saturday, December 12 at 1:00pm at St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th St. (2nd Avenue). In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Robert M. Storm to Arts Horizons, www.artshorizons.org. 1/3

POLLACK--Lester. Founding member, 1950, of The Jinx Social/Athletic Club, Brooklyn, NY. Lester never forgot his roots or his friends. He will be sorely missed. 1/3

TAYLOR--Arthur R.,80, former President of CBS Inc. and tenth President of Muhlenberg College, died Thursday, December 3, 2015 with his loving wife Kathryn and family by his side at Lehigh Valley Hospital - Cedar Crest in Allentown, PA. A resident of Salisbury Township, PA and Salisbury, CT, Taylor was born July 6, 1935 in Elizabeth, NJ. He earned a full scholarship and was a Magna Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa graduate from Brown University, where he also received his Masters Degree, and later served as a Trustee and Trustee Emeritus. Taylor had an extensive and varied business career which encompassed Finance, Communications, Civic and Political Endeavors, and Education. He served on the boards of numerous global corporations and civic and educational organizations and received many awards and honorary doctorates. Arthur's life was distinguished by the hundreds of people from all walks of life whose lives he touched, who loved him and relied on his caring guidance and advice. He loved them all in return. Arthur is survived by the love of his life, his wife Kathryn Pelgrift Taylor, his daughters Martha T. Josephson (Jon Carter), Anne T. Madden (Sean), and Sarah T. Rountree (John), his sister Marilyn T. Rocks and his four beloved grandchildren David, Zoe, Jack and Brody. A memorial service will be held 2pm, Friday, December 18, 2015 at the First Presbyterian Church in Allentown, PA. Services by J.S. Burkholder Funeral Home, www.jsburkholder.com 1/3

POLLACK--Lester. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations mourns the loss of its esteemed Past Chair, Lester Pollack. He was held in highest regard by leaders here and abroad, and widely recognized for his integrity and acumen. Our heartfelt condolences go to Lester's wife, Geri, and children Bruce and Wendy. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Stephen Greenberg, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman/CEO 1/3

KELLOGG--Dyane Dye Wood (1918-2015). Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, and friend, Dyane Dye Wood Kellogg, 97, passed away Sunday, December 6, 2015. Born July 2, 1918 to Fred Dye and Esther Monroe in Detroit, MI. She graduated from Indiana University with an AB in Fine Arts and French, and MA in Spanish from the Universidad Inter-Americana in Saltillo, Mexico. She was a passionate historian, Certified Genealogist, and award-winning author. An avid traveler, she visited over 100 countries on all seven continents gaining her entry into both the Circumnavigators Club and the Travelers Century Club. A member of nearly twenty lineage societies including Colonial Dames of America and Daughters of the American Revolution, as well as, both MENSA and Intertel. Dyane and her devoted husband, Fred, held residences in both New York City and Little River, SC. She is survived by her husband Fred Kellogg, Jr., daughters, Dr. Diandra Wood and Paula Neal, and granddaughter, Jordan Neal. Dyane also leaves behind numerous friends and family that were so grateful to be a part of her life. Services will be held Friday, December 11, 2015 at 11am at Church of the Incarnation, 209 Madison, New York, NY 10016. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the New York Public Library. 1/3

OBERWAGER--Susie. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the passing of Susie Oberwager, who was devoted to Israel and the cause of higher education. Together with Karl (z"l), her beloved husband of 53 years, Susie Oberwager established the Philipp Rothbart and Helene Gottheil Rothbart Endowment Fund at Hebrew University in honor of her dear parents. This benevolence created scholarships for deserving students. The humanitarian couple was honored in 2000 as Benefactors of the university, and attended the moving ceremony on Mount Scopus. Susie and Karl emigrated to the U.S. from Romania, and maintained a steadfast devotion to the global Jewish community throughout their meaningful lives. We extend our deepest condolences to the Oberwager family. May Susie be remembered among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. POLLACK--Lester. The NYU Community deeply mourns the loss of our proud alumnus and generous benefactor, Lester Pollack LAW 1957. An attorney by training, he went on to an illustrious business career in which he held leadership positions in a broad range of industries-- entertainment (Loews Corporation), food (United Brands), and finance (Oppenheimer & Co.)--before becoming founder and chair, and later chair emeritus, of Centre Partners Management, a leading private equity firm. Energetic, forward-thinking, and a true leader, Lester was a philanthropic supporter of many institutions, but he was especially devoted to his beloved alma mater, to which he gave unstintingly of his time and resources. A major supporter of the NYU School of Law, he will be especially remembered for his generous support of the Lester Pollack Center for Law and Business, a joint venture of the law school and the NYU Stern School of Business that-- through his foresight and generosity--is a leader in its field. He served for nearly three decades as a Trustee and, later, as a Life Trustee of NYU, and at the time of his passing was Chair Emeritus of the NYU Law Board of Trustees. Among the many honors bestowed upon him by NYU was the prestigious annual Albert Gallatin Medal, recognizing his outstanding contributions to society. He will be sorely missed. On this sad day, our thoughts and prayers go out to his wife, Geraldine "Geri" Pollack; his children, Bruce Pollack and Wendy Isaacs; his grandchildren; and all of his loved ones and friends. William Berkley, Chair, NYU Board of Trustees John Sexton, President, NYU 1/3

POLLACK--Lester. The NYU School of Law mourns the death of Lester Pollack, alumnus, trustee, benefactor, and treasured mentor. Lester counts among the Law School's most dedicated and visionary leaders. His commitment and generosity led to the creation of the Pollack Center for Law & Business, a unique joint venture between the Law School and NYU Stern School of Business providing interdisciplinary legal and business education. In addition to serving for decades as a member of our Board of Trustees and for ten years as its Chair, Lester was President and Director of our Law Alumni Association and Chairman of the Board of our National Center on Philanthropy and the Law. The Law School community is grateful for Lester's extraordinary life and transformative generosity. We will miss him deeply, and join his family and friends in mourning his loss. Anthony Welters, Chairman of the Board Trevor Morrison, Dean 1/3

PICKFORD--Richard Jr.,77, passed away at the Gosnell Hospice in Scarborough, ME after a brief illness on November 24, 2015. Born in Astoria New York City on March 7, 1938, he served in the US Air Force as Airman 3rd Class. Lived in Chelmsford, MA and worked at Caldor's for 28 years. Moved to Portland, ME after retirement. He enjoyed reading, bird watching, photography and boating on Wadleigh Pond. He leaves his wife, Susan and son, Richard both of Portland and a son, John and wife Lisa and two grandchildren of Brunswick, ME; a brother Edward and wife Pam of Orono, ME; five sisters and many nieces and nephews. 1/3

MASTERS--Polly Jo. We mourn the passing of Polly Jo Masters of Ancramdale, NY who died peacefully at home on December 4, 2015 surrounded by her children, at the age of 91. The family thanks the community of caregivers and friends who encircled her with love, companionship, laughter and music since 2008: Diane F., Keavy B., Joni F., Elizabeth M., Gaye P., Peggy O., Lolly S., Anne C., Julia H., Jackie H., Mandy L., Mary S., Carol P., Brian C., Becky R., David H., Harold H., Terry B., and Gregg B. Born in Beckley, West Virginia on March 14, 1924, she was the daughter of Dr. John H. McCulloch and Effie Lajo Stalnaker. After graduating from the University of Kentucky fate ushered her through the doors of Beckley's WJLS radio station in 1947 where, as "Side-Saddle Sue," she hosted a weekly radio program. She played banjo and ukulele, singing cowboy music, reading local news and engaging in easy humor. A year or so later she departed for New York City, where she pursued a career in musical theater. She sang cabaret, stage managed many productions including "Oh, Captain!" and was a principal in the summer traveling company of 'Brigadoon.' In 1951, she and a business partner, the director George Quick, renovated several old stables and barns on the Vanderbilt Estate in Hyde Park, NY, establishing the Hyde Park Playhouse. While in Hyde Park she also assisted the late Eleanor Roosevelt with the NY State Literacy Project. When theatrical success required a press agent, she and Quick hired a young writer, Hilary Masters. Polly and Hilary fell in love, married and ran the Playhouse for the next seven years. In 1960 they sold the Playhouse and moved to their new home on Woods Drive in Ancramdale, New York. From the mid-1960s she was very active in her community. She volunteered for the American Cancer Society, worked with the local PTA and was a friendly and welcoming face at the polls during election time. In 1968 she ran successfully for President of the Pine Plains Board of Education, becoming the first woman in local history to hold that honour. She held that post until 1975 and was, among many other things, instrumental in the conception and building of the Stissing Mountain Junior-Senior High School, also the first of its kind in the region. From 1979 until the mid-1990s she contributed a regular column for a local newspaper, the Roe-Jan Independent, under the heading "One Side to Everything." She wrote about politics, local and national education, television, rural homeownership, the origins of linguistic memory and the diminutive interior dimensions of the original Ancramdale Post Office. She is pre-deceased by her brother, John H. McCulloch Jr., her parents and her former husband, Hilary Masters, whom she divorced in 1985. She is survived by her sister-in-law, Carolyn McCulloch of Beckley, WV, as well as her three children, Joellen Masters of Lexington, Massachusetts, Catherine Masters of Deer Isle, Maine, John D.C. Masters of Paros, Greece and a grand-child, Kaolin R.E. Pitcher of Portland, Maine. She was a mother, a grandmother, a prescient community leader, a lover of Broadway musicals and English mysteries, a fount of knowledge and a source of no- nonsense unending love and support to all. She covered the ground she walked on. The family will announce a memorial gathering at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the Polly Masters Educational Fund for Young Women at Pine Plains Stissing Mountain High School. Services are under the direction of the Peck and Peck Funeral Home, Copake, NY. To send an online condolence, please visit peckandpeck.net. 1/3

POLLACK--Lester, 82, peacefully at home in NYC on December 9, 2015. Lester earned his bachelor's degree from Brooklyn College. After graduating from NYU Law School in 1957, he practiced law, rising to partner before joining Loews Corporation, where he ultimately became Executive Vice President. After leaving Loews, he became Vice Chairman and Co-Chief Operating Officer of the United Brands Company and a Partner at Oppenheimer & Company. He later co-founded Odyssey Partners in 1982, and founded Centre Partners Management, a private equity firm, in 1986. Lester was not only a leader in business, but also a devoted philanthropist and humanitarian. He was deeply committed to the Jewish community, including chair of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, president of the Jewish Community Relations Council of New York, chair of the Associated YM-YWHAs of Greater New York, and honorary chair of the Anti-Defamation League. Lester is survived by Geri, his wife of 59 years, son Bruce and his wife Susan, daughter Wendy Isaacs, grandchildren Shayna, Jordan, Kayla, Justin and Rachel, brother Herbert Pollack and his wife Sandy. He was also uncle, relative, friend and colleague of many. Service Friday, December 11th, 11 am at Park Ave. Synagogue, 50 E. 87 St., NYC. 1/3

MARKSOHN--Edie. Edie Marksohn, born Edith Marantz (1914-2015) Died peacefully at her home in Oyster Bay Cove, NY on December 9th, 2015 at 101 years of age surrounded by her loved ones. Pre-deceased by her husband of 65 years, Walter Marksohn. Sister of deceased brothers Saul B. Marantz (founder of The Marantz Stereo Company) and Charles E. Marantz. Survived by her four children and their spouses, Helena, Jerome (Jerry) and his wife Doris, Steven and his wife Beverly, Bart and his wife Jan, her nine grandchildren and their spouses, Jennifer and her husband Josh, Brian and his wife Deras, Beau and his wife Anna, Cody, Ellis, Vincent, Jesse, Kai, Zenner, and her five great-grandchildren, Kirana, Eli, Lilah, Teddi-Gray, and Ziggy Mae. Edie was the co-founder of the WE Transport bus company -- a pioneer in the transportation of children with special needs. The company, which began on Long Island in 1959 with the family station wagon, has grown to over 1600 buses while employing more than 2300 people in multiple states. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations in her memory be made to St Jude (stjude.org), The Smile Train (smiletrain.org), or any charity of your choice. The funeral service will be at 11:00 on December 11th, 2015 at: Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY 11797 Telephone: 516.921.5757. Burial in Locust Valley Cemetery. 1/3

GRAY--Sherman, 97, died peacefully on December 2nd at his home at Princeton Windrows in Princeton, N.J. Known for his kind and gentlemanly manner, Mr. Gray was a member of a family of Scotch-Irish descent that arrived in New England in the early 1600's and later participated in the American Revolution and in Shay's Rebellion. Among his ancestors are Roger Sherman of Connecticut, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, and General William Tecumseh Sherman. The son of Prentiss Nathaniel Gray and Laura Sherman Gray, Mr. Gray and his older sister Barbara grew up in Larchmont, NY and Salt Lake City, UT and vacationed in Jackson Hole, WY where the family owned the D- Triangle and G-Ray ranches. At a young age, he went on hunting trips and explored Alaska with his father and sister and climbed the Tetons with legendary mountaineers Glenn Exum and Paul Petzold. In the 1930's he and his father attempted a reintroduction of pronghorn antelope into the Jackson Hole area. Pronghorn calves were to be brought to the Hole and raised in captivity until old enough to be released into the wild. The plan hinged on the conversion of the Gray's large Packard sedan to a "stock" car by ripping out the back seats and padding the interior. The two of them collected a small posse of pronghorn calves from a ranchman hours away whom his father had convinced to capture newborns the previous spring. The ride home was chaotic. Ever resourceful, they built a much-needed cage for the back of their car for the second trip. There are now pronghorns in Jackson Hole; however, Mr. Gray did not believe that this is a result of their efforts though the whole enterprise was "lots of fun and makes for a good story". Mr. Gray attended the Malcolm Gordon School in Garrison, NY and then went on to St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and to college at Harvard. At Harvard he was on the varsity hockey team and was the captain of the 1941 varsity crew that went undefeated for the three years he rowed, winning a "Clean Sweep" over Yale and the Grand Challenge Cup at Henley, England. He was a member of the Delphic Club and the Hasty Pudding Club. After graduation, he married Barbara Bintz of Salt Lake City, UT. The marriage would last 72 years until her death last year. Mr. Gray was a Navy pilot during WWII, flying PBY- type aircraft on patrols around the Aleutian Islands in the northern Pacific. He participated in battles for Attu and Kiska islands, though he maintained that the fog and a persistent diet of cornflakes were his greatest challenges. After the war, Mr. Gray started his financial career with J. Henry Schroder Banking Corp. and later moved to Merrill Lynch where he established Merrill's first overseas offices in Geneva and London. He and his family made several moves overseas and back to their home in Sands Point, Long Island, NY- first to Switzerland and later to London where he spent much of his career and met many of his closest friends. Always an avid sportsman and conservationist, Mr. Gray was a long time member of the Boone and Crockett Club, the Angler's Club of NY, the North Woods Club and Parkside Angling Club. He was also a member of the Brook Club in NYC and the Nassau Club in Princeton. Following his father's relief efforts in Belgium during WWI, he became an avid supporter of the Belgian American Educational Foundation. Mr. Gray's wife Barbara B. Gray died in December 2014. He was also predeceased by his first daughter, Pamela Gray Martindale of Newport Beach, CA. and Jackson, WY. He is survived by his daughter, Elizabeth Gray Lilleston of Navesink, NJ, and his son, Prentiss Gray of Morristown, NJ; Elizabeth's three daughters: Jessica of Philadelphia, PA, Amanda of Bangor, ME, Pamela of Bethesda, MD, Pamela's son, Kai Noe, and Prentiss's three sons; Matthew, Zachary, and Nathaniel, all of Morristown, NJ. Beginning in his sophomore year in college, Mr. Gray became an enthusiastic lifetime participant in the longest- running in-depth study of adult development which has been featured in The Atlantic magazine. In accordance with Mr. Gray's wishes, in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Harvard Study of Adult Development c/o Mass General Development Office, 125 Nashua Street, Suite 540, Boston MA 02114 or by calling (617) 643 -3879. 1/3

HITTMAN--Ralph, born October 10, 1918, died peacefully at home on December 8, 2015 at the age of 97. Born and raised on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, Mr. Hittman served as a noncommissioned officer in the US Marine Corps during the second World War. He had a lifelong affiliation with Boys Brotherhood Republic of New York City, having participated in its programs as a boy. In his forty-three years as executive director, Mr. Hittman oversaw the operation of Camp Wabenaki and the construction of a new BBR City Hall at 888 East Sixth Street. He was married to and is survived by his wife of 75 years, Rose (Bader) Hittman, and was a loving father to sons, Michael, Jeffrey, and Stephan, as well as a doting grandfather to Julie, Eliza, and Gianna, and great- grandfather to Nathaniel, Louisa and Jonas. He impacted the lives of many and will be greatly missed. Services Friday, 10am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

GUITANO--Anton, of New York City, who in June of this year retired as the Chief Operating Officer of CBS Corporation's Local Media unit, passed away peacefully on December 8 at the age of 65. He had been diagnosed with cancer earlier this year. Anton was born on July 5, 1950 in Brooklyn, N.Y. to Blanche and Whitney Guitano. He grew up in Brooklyn along with his brothers, Ricardo and Glenn, before attending St. Peter's College in Jersey City, N.J., where he earned his Bachelor of Science degree in accounting on a full academic and athletic scholarship. After beginning his career with Price Waterhouse, Anton joined CBS in 1978 as a member of the company's internal audit department. Over the course of his distinguished 37-year career with CBS, he rose through the ranks to become Financial Controller for the CBS Television Network; Vice President and General Auditor for CBS, Inc.; Executive Vice President of Operations and Chief Financial Officer for CBS Television Stations; and Chief Financial Officer and Senior Executive Vice President, Operations, for CBS Radio. In 2009, Anton was named Chief Operating Officer of CBS Local Media and was responsible for overseeing the financial and operational success of CBS Corporation's local television and radio stations as well as the stations' websites and other digital platforms. Anton also served as CBS's representative on the Federal Communications Commission's Advisory Committee on Diversity for Communications in the Digital Age. Anton is survived by his loving wife of 15 years, Eileen, a member of the CBS Television Network finance department; his mother, Blanche; his brother, Glenn; his children, Jessica (Michael), Jennifer (Cory) and Jason (Maria); and three adoring grandchildren, Sydney, Nathan and Jade. He was preceded in death by his father, Whitney; brother, Ricardo; and first wife, Leslie. Visitation will be held on Thursday, December 10 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Cargain Funeral Home, 418 U.S. Route 6, Mahopac, N.Y. A Mass of Christian burial will be held on Friday, December 11 at 10 a.m. at St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church, 225 East Lake Blvd., Mahopac, N.Y. In lieu of sending flowers, friends who wish to honor Anton's memory may send donations to either the American Institute for Cancer Research (www.AICR.org) or the Preston Robert Tisch Brain Tumor Center (www.cancer.duke.edu/btc). 1/3

ELLIS--William Scott, 92, died of pneumonia on November 30, 2015. Bill was born in Somerville, MA, graduated from Boston Public Latin School, Harvard College and Harvard Law School, and served in the U.S. Army medical corps during WWII. He helped to establish the U.S. National Student Association and the International Union of Students and was elected Vice Chairman of the latter. He was also involved in the World Student Christian Federation and the U.S. Student Christian Movement. These activities put him in contact with many leaders such as Olof Palme, later Prime Minister of Sweden, Zakir Husain, later President of India, and many others whose friendship and guidance he deeply valued. After serving as an Assistant U.S. Attorney, he was a co-founder of the law firm Ellis, Stringfellow, Patton & Leibovitz. In the mid-1970s a U.S. District Judge appointed him Administrator of an affirmative action Consent Decree with a mandate to increase minority employment among New York City newspaper deliverers to 25%. He continued in that role until 2006, achieving and exceeding that goal, and steered the Consent Decree to a successful conclusion. The rest of Bill's practice was dedicated to similar issues as well as the representation of religious and student organizations and general practice. Bill never retired, but continued practicing law until prevented by illness. He was very active in his local church and was a member of the Board of Directors of the Executive Council of the Lutheran Church in America. Bill lived a life of purpose, generosity and dedication to social justice, and he treated all those around him with kindness and respect. He will be deeply missed. Bill is survived by his wife of 58 years Anne, his son and daughter-in-law Paul and Mary, and his son Jonathan. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, December 12th at 11:30am at Advent Lutheran Church, 2504 Broadway, New York, NY. 1/3

WEISMANN--Dietrich. Dietrich "Dick" Weismann, 77, of New York City, passed peacefully December 9, 2015 in his home after a ten year struggle with Alzheimer's Disease. Born in Newark, NJ on October 18, 1938, Dick Weismann went on to become an outstanding portfolio manager and Partner at Neuberger Berman, where he worked for more than 30 years. After retiring in 2003, Mr. Weismann started a family office investment firm, Weismann Associates LLC. Dick adored his family and is survived by his wife, Philippa Weismann; his son, Paul Weismann; his daughter Lucy Veltri; and his six grandchildren. Dick was passionate about helping those less fortunate through policy research. He was a longtime trustee and subsequent Chairman of the Board of the Manhattan Institute, a highly influential think tank dedicated to free markets and finding solutions to address problems in our cities. Dick was also a strong supporter of education options for low-income families, and through grants and other philanthropic gifts, helped many wonderful institutions such as Incarnation School in Washington Heights. He was an avid sailor and a highly competent private pilot with an instrument rating for 20 years. Dick will be buried Sunday, December 13 next to his mother in Sag Harbor, New York. A memorial service will be held in New York City in January 2016, details to be announced. 1/3

STERN--Louise (nee Altman), passed away peacefully at home with her son and caretakers by her side on Friday, December 11. She was born on June 23, 1938 in Brooklyn, New York to Edith and David Altman, who predeceased her. Louise grew up in Lawrence, New York. She is also predeceased by her brother Melvyn Altman. Louise is survived by her two sons Robin and Marc, her brother Dr. Alan Altman and his wife Judi, her cherished granddaughters Jessie and Zoe Paradis Stern, her daughter-in-law Julie Paradis, her sister-in-law and brother-in-law Maura and Joel Surnamer, nephews Matthew and Joshua Altman, and Glen and Eric Surnamer and many lifelong friends. Louise was a Co-Founder and supporter of the Breast Health Resource Program at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was an active and longtime member of the Mount Sinai Hospital Auxillary Board. A memorial service to celebrate Louise's life will be held at 11am Monday, December 14 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, New York City. Interment will take place at New Montefiore Cemetery in Long Island following the service. The Stern and Altman families would like to extend their gratitude to those involved in Louise's care, including Dr. David Muller of Mount Sinai Visiting Docs and her devoted caretakers, Selena Ewart, Yolanda, Natalia and the many visiting nurses. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions be made to the Mount Sinai Breast Health Resource Program, The Mount Sinai Development Office One Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1049 New York, NY 10029. 1/3

POE--Fred. On November 27th, Fred Poe, founder of Poe Travel of Little Rock, Arkansas' best-known travel agency, died of natural causes in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 81. In September 1975, Poe Travel was the first U.S. travel agency to send a group of American tourists to China. In keeping with his pioneering spirit, Mr. Poe counted 168 countries visited; A country being defined as one which issues its own postage stamps. Poe attended Phillips Exeter Academy, Little Rock (Central) High School, and Vanderbilt University. 1/3

DOBBS--Mattiwilda. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of soprano Mattiwilda Dobbs, who was the first African-American soprano to sing with the company when she made her Met debut in 1956 as Gilda in Rigoletto. Critics praised the delicacy and precision of her interpretations of the six roles she sang over the course of her Met career, which also included the title role in Lucia di Lammermoor, Olympia in Les Contes d'Hoffmann, Zerlina in Don Giovanni, and Oscar in Un Ballo in Maschera. She joined the Met's Board of Directors in 1989 and served as a Member of the Association until her death. We extend our condolences to her family, friends, and many admirers. Ann Ziff, Chairman of the Board Judith-Ann Corrente, President & CEO Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director 1/3

HOOKER--Roger W.,Jr., of Palisades, NY, passed away on December 8, at 74. He served as Deputy Secretary to Governor Nelson Rockefeller and Assistant Secretary to the U.S. Department of Transportation under the Ford administration. Before returning to the private practice of law, Roger was General Counsel to the U.S. arm of Grand Metropolitan, PLC, as well as its predecessor, Liggett Group, Inc. An ardent supporter of the arts, Roger sat on the boards of the American Dance Festival, the Rockland Center for the Arts, and the Baryshnikov Arts Center. He was paralyzed in a 2009 back operation and lived the last seven years of his life facing profound adversity with uncommon alacrity, kindness, and an exceptional sense of humor. He is fiercely loved and missed by his wife, Joan; his two daughters, Kate and Sarah, both of Brooklyn, NY; his brother Henry, of Santa Cruz, CA; a horde of nieces, nephews, and in-laws; and a huge group of friends collected from every place he spent time, including his birthplace of Niagara Falls, NY, Palisades, NY; Princeton University; Columbia Law School; NYC; Washington, D.C.; Durham, NC; and Woolwich, ME. A celebration of Roger's life will be held at 2pm on Saturday, December 19, at the Rockland Country Club. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Spinal Cord Injury Program at Helen Hayes Hospital or the arts organizations above. 1/3

ROSENBERG--Sheryl Gura, November 8, 1951 - December 10, 2015, died peacefully at home. Beloved mother of Ivana and Jahna, sister of Nicholas. Loved her daughters, cats, Israel, friends, and the Ramaz - K.J. community. Funeral services 9:30am, Sunday, December 13th at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NYC. 1/3

SCHWELL--Lila Ann Richman, 71, of White Plains, NY, died of complications from pneumonia on Wednesday, December 9, 2015. Born August 15, 1944 in Bronx, NY to Catherine and Richard. Beautiful, beloved wife of Howard for nearly 50 years. Devoted loving mother of Nicole and Lowell. Predeceased by her precious daughter Jolie. Proud grandmother to Jack, Dillon, and Olivia. Adored sister and sister-in-law to Phil and Evelyn and Ruby and Bernard. Much loved by her entire family and all who knew her. Her beauty was evident inside and out as she touched the lives of so many. Lila graduated Hunter College and was a school teacher before she began a career in real estate. She was successful in all she undertook. Words cannot express the overwhelming grief we are all feeling from our tremendous loss. Services are being conducted by The Zion Memorial Chapel: (914)-381-1809. 1/3

PICKFORD--Richard Jr.,77, passed away at the Gosnell Hospice in Scarborough, ME after a brief illness on November 24, 2015. Born in Astoria New York City on March 7, 1938, he served in the US Air Force as Airman 3rd Class. Lived in Chelmsford, MA and worked at Caldor's for 28 years. Moved to Portland, ME after retirement. He enjoyed reading, bird watching, photography and boating on Wadleigh Pond. He leaves his wife, Susan and son, Richard both of Portland and a son, John and wife Lisa and two grandchildren of Brunswick, ME; a brother Edward and wife Pam of Orono, ME; five sisters and many nieces and nephews. 1/3
EILBOTT--FRED. March 21, 1922, Munich. Died December 7, 2015, New York. Survived by wife, son and four grandchildren. 1/3

MAHLER--Herbert W.,died peacefully on December 10, 2015 at age 80 after a courageous battle against pancreatic cancer. He was the founder and CEO of Mahler & Emerson Inc. and is survived by his beloved wife of 51 years, Nancy, sons Peter and Alexander, and adored granddaughter Alexandra Lydia. Service private. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Lustgarten Foundation would be appreciated. 1/3

BARKER--William David. Died at home in Manhattan on December 3, 2015 after a courageous battle with bladder cancer for six years. Loving husband, father and grandfather, he is survived by his wife Madonna Stack; daughter Stephanie Barker Colantino; and sons Geoffrey, Brett and John; as well as five grandchildren. His passion was shooting landscape and street photography which he pursued after he retired as a Wall Street bond trader. He also was proud that he had served in the United States Marine Corps. An Episcopal Mass will be celebrated on Monday, December 14, 2015 at 10am at the Church of the Ascension, 5th Avenue and 10th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Bill's memory to support the Bladder Cancer Research Fund at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Attn: Kirstin Burdett, 633 Third Ave, 12th fIr, New York, NY 10017 or go online at: http://mskcc.convio.net/ goto/WilliamBarker. 1/3

STERN--Louise. We deeply mourn the passing of our loving "Lulu" who was such a wonderful part of our lives and who will be in our hearts forever. Our condolences to Robin, Mark, Alan, Judy and the girls. Love, Madeline and Stephen Barkin and Ellen Meyer 1/3
ALKOFF--Jerry 122/37 - 10/11/14 Home is the sailor, home from the sea. Miss you. Rene 1/3

SINGER--Samuel, of Brooklyn, NY passed away on December 10, 2015. Devoted husband of Gloria, married for 46 years, and father of Steven (Julie). Services will be held at Kehila Chapels, 60 Brighton 11 St., Brooklyn, NY. 1/3
HOFFMAN--Raphael. 12/13/1932 - 6/29/2014. We miss you. Linora, Monica and Melissa 1/3

SEIDEL--Linda Namer, passed away on December 9 at the age of 68. She was the beloved wife of Barry, loving mother extraordinaire of Evan (Sari) and Erica (Becky), and adoring nana of Madison and Ben. Linda leaves behind her dear sister Gloria Slutzky (Ira), sister-in- law Alida Seidel, and nieces and nephews Steven (Marjorie) and Elizabeth (Eric). She was a devoted great-aunt, wonderful friend, outstanding mentor and a trustworthy confidant. Linda traveled the world but found her heart and home with her family and in a special place just over the Brooklyn Bridge. Our wonderful Red Queen will be deeply missed. Services were held on Friday at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

TORNQVIST--Linnea Dagmar (Lindborg) April 5, 1941 - November 24, 2015. Died peacefully at home in Madison, WI. Born in Chester Springs, PA. Graduated valedictorian from Ellis School in Newtown Square, PA. B.A., with honors, University of Pennsylvania. M.A., Spanish, Bryn Mawr College, PA. Doctorate of Education, Rutgers, NJ. Instructor at Eastern Baptist College, PA, and in the English-ESL Dept. at Kean University, Elizabeth, NJ. Linnea loved to sketch, read, listen to classical music, and waltz. Extremely creative and artistically talented. Fluent in English, Spanish, and Swedish. Enjoyed summers in Cape May, world- wide vacations, and operas at the Met in New York City. Linnea was pre-deceased by her husband, Erik, and by a sister. Linnea is survived by two daughters, one son, one brother, one niece, one nephew, and two grandchildren. Linnea leaves behind a host of dear friends who will cherish memories of her warm friendship and her hand- drawn Christmas cards. 1/3

DIAMOND--Regina S.,of Great Neck, NY died peacefully at age 92 on December 6, 2015. Devoted wife of Vernon (1918-2011), and beloved mother of Jeffrey, Edward and Shelley. Proud grandmother to seven wonderful grandchildren and four great- grandchildren. We love her and will miss her. 1/3

BECERRA--Maria, 91, of New York City, NY on December 10, 2015. Daughter of the late Rafael Alberto and Maria Flores Becerra. She was devoted to the arts, particularly the opera, and enjoyed the many museums of New York. She was a beautiful, curious and intelligent woman who enjoyed staying current on political issues. Very kind and generous to her family and friends; she will be missed. 1/3

Loving Father, Grandfather and Brother, he is survived by a son Michael, a daughter, Kelly Ann Gutierrez, a sister, Elizabeth Schroeder and four grandchildren, Caitlyn and Terry Gutierrez and MacKenzie and Madison Maher. RZASA--Richard John, age 55, of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, died on Sunday, December 6, 2015 at the Mayo Clinic Hospital in Jacksonville. Rich was born in Brooklyn, NY on February 25, 1960, the son of Agnes and John Rzasa. Throughout his teenage and college years, he worked on the weekends with his father in the family's construction/roofing business. He attended Chaminade High School in Mineola, NY and graduated with a BS and MBA from NYU (Stern School of Business), where he also was a member of the Dean's Advisory Panel. His dream was to work on Wall Street, which he did successfully for 30 years. He worked for Lehman Brothers from 1985 to 1999, where he rose through the ranks from programmer/analyst to Senior Vice President reporting to the CIO. His crowning moment was when he left Lehman to become the CIO at TD Waterhouse in September 1999, a position he held until they merged with Ameritrade in 2006. Rich enjoyed a lifetime of music, starting with guitar sessions at the age of six. His interest evolved from playing in a band at a very young age to later entertaining his friends at the KMS golf charity outings. Another passion was playing golf which took him to courses in Scotland, Ireland, Spain, Mexico as well a few across the U.S. After many years in IT, he and his wife retired in 2012 to Florida from Jersey City, NJ to enjoy the warmth and play some golf. His friendship with Bob and Chris Hurley and his admiration of their work at St. Anthony High School in Jersey City inspired him to become involved in the school's scholarship fund for students. He worked hard and enjoyed life to its fullest with his wife, family and friends. He was a generous loyal friend to many who knew him as 'Raz', he will be terribly missed. He is survived by his wife, Sybil, of 22 years; sister, Joanne (John); brother, Robert, and his children, Elizabeth and Christopher; mother-in-law, Moy Kwei Fong; brother-in- law, John (Nora); brother-in- law, Teddy (Lucy); brother- in-law Stephen (Jackie); brother-in-law Donald; nieces, Lara, Alicia, Samantha; nephews, Sean and Michael. His family would like to thank the staff at the Mayo Clinic for his care during his last days. Contributions can be made in Rich's name to St. Anthony High School, Mayo Clinic or to a charity of your choice. A private celebration of life service will be held in the near future. 1/3

In lieu of flowers, donations to The Lustgarten Foundation would be appreciated. 1/3

HENNIGAN--John, 68, of NYC on December 9, 2015. Beloved brother of Mary (Daniel) McGuire, William (Cathy) Hennigan, Brian (Karen) Hennigan and Ellen (John) Collins. Fond uncle of many. ALLEN--Edward G.,32, of Millbrook, NY died on December 5, 2015 of injuries sustained in an auto accident. He is survived by his beloved wife, Emily Egan Allen and their daughters, Codie and Tatum. Ed was a graduate of The Taft School and Middlebury College where he majored in economics and was a captain of the football team at both schools. He followed his passions into his professional life becoming a math teacher and coach at the Millbrook School, and later its Athletic Director. Ed will forever be remembered as a selfless educator, dedicated coach, and above all, a devoted and loving father and husband. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Friday, December 18, 2015 at 11am at the Millbrook School, 131 Millbrook School Road, Millbrook, NY, 12545. Contributions in Ed's memory may be made to the Coach Ed Allen Scholarship Fund which has been established at the Millbrook School. 1/3

WEST--Howard. Howard West, longtime business partner of fellow Seinfeld producer George Shapiro, has died of a stroke at UCLA Medical Center on December 3, 2015. He was 84. West and Shapiro, had one of the longest friendships and business relationships in the history of Hollywood. The two boys from the Bronx had known each other since grammar school and then went on to work together for 41 years at personal management/production company Shapiro/West. "I first met Howie in the schoolyard of Public School 80 in the Bronx when we were eight years old," Shapiro said. "Howie was the new kid at school as he just moved from another Bronx neighborhood. Howie was alone in the schoolyard, sitting on a step near one of the school entrances. I invited him to join me and my friends to play basketball, stickball, curb ball, and touch football. It was love at first sight, and we became best friends since that day. We were partners in buying comic books, we bought our first car together, worked as busboys, and lifeguards/stagehands at the Tamiment summer resort in the Pocono Mountains, where he worked with writers Neil and Danny Simon, choreographer Herb Ross, comedian Dick Shawn, and singer Barbara Cook. It was a great beginning for our showbiz career." (PS 80 in the Bronx is also the alma mater of Garry and Penny Marshall, Ralph Lauren (nee Ralph Lipschitz), Calvin Klein, and Robert Klein). After graduation from Long Island University and then serving in the Army, West reunited with Shapiro in the William Morris Agency mailroom, and it wasn't long before both began repping talent. West's clients at William Morris included Neil Diamond, Glen Campbell, Anne Murray, Ruth Buzzi, Paul Lynde, Jerry Reed and Greg Garrison (who produced/directed The Dean Martin Show and The Dean Martin Celebrity Roast). He specialized in television packaging, putting together such shows as The Glen Campbell Goodtime Hour and The Bobby Darin Show. In 1974, he left the William Morris Agency to help form Shapiro/West. Shapiro recruited West by offering him the presidency of the firm and the parking space closest to the office entrance. West, who also then began repping Marty Feldman, executive produced the comedian's The Last Remake of Beau Geste, which he also developed with the comedy star. He also produced "In God We Trust," which he and Feldman once again developed. In addition to Jerry Seinfeld, Carl Reiner, Peter Bonerz (who was an actor on Newhart before directing multiple episodes of Murphy Brown and Home Improvement), Shapiro/West's client roster included/includes Feldman, Andy Kaufman, director Alan Myerson, Gabe Kaplan, Robert Wuhl, Bill Persky and Sam Denoff (who produced The Dick Van Dyke Show with Reiner and created That Girl for Marlo Thomas), Dick Clair and Jenna McMahon (who wrote for Carol Burnett, created Mama's Family, Facts of Life and It's a Living), Ken Spears & Joe Ruby, Tom Tenowich and Ed Scharlach ("Mork & Mindy"), Sam Bobrick (the prolific playwright who also created NBC's Saved By The Bell and wrote for such classic comedy shows as Get Smart, The Andy Griffith Show, and The Dick Van Dyke Show), and writer Norman Barasch ("Send Me No Flowers" on Broadway, TV shows "Rhoda", "Benson", "Chico & The Man"), and Austin & Irma Kalish (writers for "All In The Family", "Bob Newhart Show", "Maude", etc.), Steve Gordon (writer/director of "Arthur" starring Dudley Moore. West also guided the successful career of Bill Lawrence who produced Spin City, Scrubs, Cougar Town. Lawrence's new series "Undateable" is in its third season on NBC and the one-hour series Rush Hour (based on the hit film) was picked up by CBS. Together, Shapiro and West were part of the producing team behind the beloved comedy series Seinfeld, for which they won multiple Emmy, Golden Globe and Peabody awards and was named best sitcom of all time in 2012 after a nationwide poll taken by 60 Minutes and Vanity Fair. COHN--Jules. (June 18, 1930 - December 9, 2015). Survived by his wife, Nancy Goldner, his nephew Eric Cohn, and many cousins. He loved Judaism, Kafka and all kinds of music. He had great intellect, curiosity and compassion for others. He was my soul-mate. Nancy Goldner 1/3

SAVAGE--Neve Richard. Neve Richard Savage died on December 7th, at his home in Portola Valley, CA. The cause was Prostate Cancer. Neve is survived by Ann, his beloved and loving wife of 45 years, his three beloved children of whom he was so proud, Sarah-Jane, Megan and Truan, his brother, Robert and his daughter-in-law Claire. Neve was born in 1944 in Harrow, England and graduated from St Peter's College, Oxford University with BA and MA degrees in Modern History. He joined the advertising business in London during the "swinging 60s"; he had his suits tailored in the original Carnaby Street. Neve met Ann at Garland- Compton Advertising in 1968; in 1970 they moved to New York City where they were married in 1972 and became U.S. citizens in 1983. For nearly 30 years Neve worked at various international advertising agencies including Compton Advertising, Saatchi-Compton, Cadwell Davis Savage (where Neve was a partner), Wells Rich Greene and Ogilvy & Mather, on some of the world's largest accounts: Procter & Gamble; Pan Am, Johnson & Johnson, Unilever, SmithKline Beecham and more. In 1994 Neve joined McCaw Cellular in Seattle which became AT&T Wireless. Thereafter, Neve was one of the original management team that helped build the successful online advertising start up AvenueA/aQuantive, ultimately bought by Microsoft in what, at the time, was their largest ever purchase. Neve spent the last 8 years of his business life as a Vice President at Netflix which he described as the best, most enjoyable and most rewarding job of his career. Neve retired in 2012. Neve was known for his distinguished beard, dry wit, vigorous debate and a treasure chest of bon-mots from which he often provided the appropriate word or comment to lighten, enlighten or end a discussion. Except at home where Ann's last word was always after Neve's--the true last word! Neve's eclectic loves and interests included his family, travel to over 50 countries, history, antique pewter, movies, hiking (he and Ann walked 192 miles across England in 2007), the state, history and people of Vermont where he had a second home for 35 years and where his ashes will be interred, news and newspapers, 50s-60s rock 'n roll, the English language (quotes; epigrams; idioms; cliches; aphorisms, rhyming slang), association football, cricket, rugby and British comedy. The satirical British magazine Private Eye could bring him to tears of laughter. Neve's few dislikes included being late, he or others (on one of Neve and Ann's first dates Neve had left when Ann arrived 10 minutes late though Ann quickly found him and they remained together for 47 timely years); capers and olives; opera, and theater seats that pushed his knees into his chest. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Neve's name to the Prostate Cancer Foundation. 1/3

BARKER--William David. Died at home in Manhattan on December 3, 2015 after a courageous battle with bladder cancer for six years. Loving husband, father and grandfather, he is survived by his wife Madonna Stack; daughter Stephanie Barker Colantino; and sons Geoffrey, Brett and John; as well as five grandchildren. His passion was shooting landscape and street photography which he pursued after he retired as a Wall Street bond trader. He also was proud that he had served in the United States Marine Corps. An Episcopal Mass will be celebrated on Monday, December 14, 2015 at 10am at the Church of the Ascension, 5th Avenue and 10th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Bill's memory to support the Bladder Cancer Research Fund at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Attn: Kirstin Burdett, 633 Third Ave, 12th fIr, New York, NY 10017 or go online at: http://mskcc.convio.net/ goto/WilliamBarker. 1/3

BERNSTEIN--Samuel Edward, formerly of Stamford Connecticut, passed away December 4th in Sarasota, Florida of cancer. Born September 30, 1932 in Bridgeport, Connecticut, Sam was the eldest child of Edna Kohnstamm and Walter Bernstein. He graduated University of Bridgeport, having received a full basketball scholarship. Sam worked as an accountant, and as Comptroller of the CBS phonograph division and for Princeton Knitting Mills. He owned and operated Born Free/Montego Bay, a women's sportswear firm based in Manhattan and Brooklyn, and founded Olympic Development and Sunrise Builders. Sam was an extremely driven, hardworking, dedicated man who adored his loving wife and best friend, Marjorie. His kind words, generous heart and sense of humor brought a smile to those who knew him. Sam is survived by his wife, Marjorie, of 43 years, sister, Jane, brother, Peter, daughters, Janeane and Karyn, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and nieces and nephews. A private service was held at Palms Memorial Park in Sarasota, Florida. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to a charity of your choice. 1/3
HOFFMAN--Raphael. 12/13/1932 - 6/29/2014. We miss you. Linora, Monica and Melissa 1/3

MALLOY--Howard Phillip, of Stamford, CT passed away on December 7, 2015 at the age of 92. A man of high integrity, exceptional talent, intellect and wit, he will be greatly missed. 1/3

EVANS--Ina R.,91, of Chapel Hill, NC by way of New York, St. Croix, US Virgin Islands, passed away peacefully in her home in Chapel Hill, on December 7, 2015. A loving wife to Jerry, who predeceased her, a loving mother to Craig and Lisa (deceased), a grandmother to Jennifer, Justin, Sarah, and Ryan. From the world of fashion to the museums of Chapel Hill, where she was the Director of Volunteer Services at Ackland Art Museum. She was the founder of the Ethical Humanist Society of the Triangle. Ina lived a full life making the the most of every day. She was a gentle, intelligent woman who was beloved by all who met her. She will be missed. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Cornucopia House and UNC Children's Hospital. PICKFORD--Richard Jr.,77, passed away at the Gosnell Hospice in Scarborough, ME after a brief illness on November 24, 2015. Born in Astoria New York City on March 7, 1938, he served in the US Air Force as Airman 3rd Class. Lived in Chelmsford, MA and worked at Caldor's for 28 years. Moved to Portland, ME after retirement. He enjoyed reading, bird watching, photography and boating on Wadleigh Pond. WEISMANN--Dietrich. Dietrich "Dick" Weismann, 77, of New York City, passed peacefully December 9, 2015 in his home after a ten year struggle with Alzheimer's Disease. Born in Newark, NJ on October 18, 1938, Dick Weismann went on to become an outstanding portfolio manager and Partner at Neuberger Berman, where he worked for more than 30 years. After retiring in 2003, Mr. Weismann started a family office investment firm, Weismann Associates LLC. Dick adored his family and is survived by his wife, Philippa Weismann; his son, Paul Weismann; his daughter Lucy Veltri; and his six grandchildren. Dick was passionate about helping those less fortunate through policy research. He was a longtime trustee and subsequent Chairman of the Board of the Manhattan Institute, a highly influential think tank dedicated to free markets and finding solutions to address problems in our cities. Dick was also a strong supporter of education options for low-income families, and through grants and other philanthropic gifts, helped many wonderful institutions such as Incarnation School in Washington Heights. He was an avid sailor and a highly competent private pilot with an instrument rating for 20 years. Dick will be buried Sunday, December 13 next to his mother in Sag Harbor, New York. A memorial service will be held in New York City in January 2016, details to be announced. 1/3

KARP--Aileen. Born April 1, 1931 of Atlantic City, NJ, Mamaroneck, NY and Palm Beach Gardens, FL. O'TOOLE--Thomas F.,78, died peacefully on November 28th at his home in Hingham, MA. Mr. O'Toole graduated from Villanova University and later followed his dream and went to New York where he earned his masters from Columbia University. While teaching at St. David's School, he began his decorating career by taking night classes in Interior Design. He then joined B. Altman's Executive Training Squad before working as a store designer for Bonwit Teller. Quite spirited and always elegantly dressed in tailored sport coats and colorful ties, Mr. O'Toole was a well known and familiar face in the decorating world, where he was known for his bold style and forceful charm. He opened his own small firm in 1971 and early in his career he was recommended to Ralph Lauren for the first Beverly Hills Polo Shop. He cited the success of this opportunity in propelling a 45-year long prolific career decorating in Manhattan and beyond. In 2014, he closed his business and moved from his Manhattan and Long Island residences to retire in Hingham, MA. Survivors include his longtime companion, Brian Conklin, and his two brothers, Tim, of Frederic, MD., and Tony, of Thurmont, MD. In the spring of 2016, a memorial service will be held in Long Island to celebrate Mr. O'Toole's life. Memorial contributions may be made to the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club or the Sag Harbor Community Food Pantry. 1/3
