THOMAS--Thomas Neil. "Thom" Thomas died on December 2, 2015 in Los Angeles, CA. Playwright, TV and film writer, teacher, director, mentor and precious friend to many, Thom was actively working on stage and film projects until diagnosed with leukemia two weeks before his passing. He was born on August 31, 1935 in Lawrence, PA, near Pittsburgh. He graduated from Carnegie Mellon University, and his long career in the performing arts began with directing plays and musicals in the Pittsburgh area, and with teaching acting and directing at the Pittsburgh Playhouse and Point Park University. In 1975 he moved to New York City to concentrate on playwriting, with several plays produced in regional theaters, Off-Broadway and in London, England. In 1981 he was offered TV writing work that resulted in moving to Los Angeles where he and his beloved partner of 42 years, Janis Purins, settled in the Silverlake area and were married last year. A Celebration of Life event for Thom is to be held in New York City, Los Angeles, and Pittsburgh after the New Year. To request information, please email to: fot-ny@earthlink.net. Donations to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society may be made in Thom's memory: http://events.lls.org/ pages/calso/ InMemoryOfThomThomas. 1/3

HARDY--Lillian Studebaker, passed away in New York City on November 29, 2015, at the age of 91. Lillian was a painter and a generous supporter of the arts. She resided in New York City, Aspen, CO and Durham, CT. Lillian was born in South Bend, Indiana, on June 10, 1924, to John M. Studebaker III and Lillian Bartlett Studebaker. She was a descendent of one of the five Studebaker brothers who founded Studebaker Brothers Manufacturing Company. Lillian was educated at the Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, CT, and studied painting at Sarah Lawrence College. Her paintings were exhibited in Aspen and New York City. In 1945 Lillian married Gordon A. Hardy in South Bend, IN. Gordon was President and Dean of the Aspen Music Festival and School and Dean of Students at Juilliard. Together with Gordon, Lillian supported music students at Aspen through the establishment of a scholarship fund. Lillian was passionate about good food and wine, modern art and travel, especially to France and Italy. She took particular delight in spending time with her large family and in entertaining friends. She gave generously to causes important to her. Lillian Hardy is survived by her sister, Mary Winder of New Haven, CT, daughter Susan H. Suechting (Ralph) of Elk Mound, WI, and son Christopher B. Hardy (Merilyn) of Coeur d'Alene, ID, daughter- in-law Suzanne Gabriel of Brooklyn, NY, eleven grandchildren and five great- grandchildren. She was predeceased by her husband Gordon and three sons, Gordon, Jack and Jeffrey. A memorial service will be held on December 27, at 2:00pm at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, E. 73 Street and Madison Ave. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the John S. Hardy Cancer Research Fund, University of Michigan, 1000 Oakbrook Drive Suite 100, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-6815 or to Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in support of the Saint Andrew Society, 921 Madison Ave, New York NY 10021. 1/3

RAYMOND--George M.,age 96, died December 3 at home in Irvington, NY. Among many accomplishments, he co-founded the city planning firms of Raymond & May and Raymond, Parish, Pine & Weiner; chaired the planning department at Pratt Institute; co-founded the Friends of Music; and chaired the Westchester Housing Opportunity Commission. A Memorial service will be held on January 2, 11:00am, Downingwood, Irvington, NY. 1/3

GRAY--Sherman, 97, died peacefully on December 2nd at his home at Princeton Windrows in Princeton, N.J. Known for his kind and gentlemanly manner, Mr. Gray was a member of a family of Scotch-Irish descent that arrived in New England in the early 1600's and later participated in the American Revolution and in Shay's Rebellion. Among his ancestors are Roger Sherman of Connecticut, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, and General William Tecumseh Sherman. The son of Prentiss Nathaniel Gray and Laura Sherman Gray, Mr. Gray and his older sister Barbara grew up in Larchmont, NY and Salt Lake City, UT and vacationed in Jackson Hole, WY where the family owned the D- Triangle and G-Ray ranches. At a young age, he went on hunting trips and explored Alaska with his father and sister and climbed the Tetons with legendary mountaineers Glenn Exum and Paul Petzold. In the 1930's he and his father attempted a reintroduction of pronghorn antelope into the Jackson Hole area. Pronghorn calves were to be brought to the Hole and raised in captivity until old enough to be released into the wild. The plan hinged on the conversion of the Gray's large Packard sedan to a "stock" car by ripping out the back seats and padding the interior. The two of them collected a small posse of pronghorn calves from a ranchman hours away whom his father had convinced to capture newborns the previous spring. The ride home was chaotic. Ever resourceful, they built a much-needed cage for the back of their car for the second trip. There are now pronghorns in Jackson Hole; however, Mr. Gray did not believe that this is a result of their efforts though the whole enterprise was "lots of fun and makes for a good story". Mr. Gray attended the Malcolm Gordon School in Garrison, NY and then went on to St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and to college at Harvard. At Harvard he was on the varsity hockey team and was the captain of the 1941 varsity crew that went undefeated for the three years he rowed, winning a "Clean Sweep" over Yale and the Grand Challenge Cup at Henley, England. He was a member of the Delphic Club and the Hasty Pudding Club. After graduation, he married Barbara Bintz of Salt Lake City, UT. The marriage would last 72 years until her death last year. Mr. Gray was a Navy pilot during WWII, flying PBY- type aircraft on patrols around the Aleutian Islands in the northern Pacific. He participated in battles for Attu and Kiska islands, though he maintained that the fog and a persistent diet of cornflakes were his greatest challenges. After the war, Mr. Gray started his financial career with J. Henry Schroder Banking Corp. and later moved to Merrill Lynch where he established Merrill's first overseas offices in Geneva and London. He and his family made several moves overseas and back to their home in Sands Point, Long Island, NY- first to Switzerland and later to London where he spent much of his career and met many of his closest friends. Always an avid sportsman and conservationist, Mr. Gray was a long time member of the Boone and Crockett Club, the Angler's Club of NY, the North Woods Club and Parkside Angling Club. He was also a member of the Brook Club in NYC and the Nassau Club in Princeton. Following his father's relief efforts in Belgium during WWI, he became an avid supporter of the Belgian American Educational Foundation. Mr. Gray's wife Barbara B. Gray died in December 2014. He was also predeceased by his first daughter, Pamela Gray Martindale of Newport Beach, CA. and Jackson, WY. He is survived by his daughter, Elizabeth Gray Lilleston of Navesink, NJ, and his son, Prentiss Gray of Morristown, NJ; Elizabeth's three daughters: Jessica of Philadelphia, PA, Amanda of Bangor, ME, Pamela of Bethesda, MD, Pamela's son, Kai Noe, and Prentiss's three sons; Matthew, Zachary, and Nathaniel, all of Morristown, NJ. Beginning in his sophomore year in college, Mr. Gray became an enthusiastic lifetime participant in the longest- running in-depth study of adult development which has been featured in The Atlantic magazine. In accordance with Mr. Gray's wishes, in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Harvard Study of Adult Development c/o Mass General Development Office, 125 Nashua Street, Suite 540, Boston MA 02114 or by calling (617) 643 -3879. 1/3

STERN--Louise. We deeply mourn the passing of our loving "Lulu" who was such a wonderful part of our lives and who will be in our hearts forever. Our condolences to Robin, Mark, Alan, Judy and the girls. Love, Madeline and Stephen Barkin and Ellen Meyer 1/3

GRAHAM--Nancy Martin, died December 3, 2015 at her home in Charlottesville, VA. She was born October 18, 1921 and grew up in NYC and Glen Cove. In 1939 she rode as a model for Captain Vladimir S. Littauer's book, "Be a Better Horseman." In 1941 Nancy married John Winston Graham, an Army Air Corps pilot, in Puerto Rico. He died in a training flight three months later. Fulfilling a promise to him, she enrolled at the Embry Riddle School of Aviation in Miami. She earned her commercial and flight instructor ratings in November 1942 and was hired to train WWII pilots. In the 1960's she added commercial glider and helicopter ratings, becoming Whirly Girl #

STERN--Louise (nee Altman), passed away peacefully at home with her son and caretakers by her side on Friday, December 11. She was born on June 23, 1938 in Brooklyn, New York to Edith and David Altman, who predeceased her. Louise grew up in Lawrence, New York. She is also predeceased by her brother Melvyn Altman. Louise is survived by her two sons Robin and Marc, her brother Dr. Alan Altman and his wife Judi, her cherished granddaughters Jessie and Zoe Paradis Stern, her daughter-in-law Julie Paradis, her sister-in-law and brother-in-law Maura and Joel Surnamer, nephews Matthew and Joshua Altman, and Glen and Eric Surnamer and many lifelong friends. SCHAYES--Dolph. The entire Maccabi USA Family mourns the loss of our dear friend and staunch supporter, Dolph Schayes - a Legend of the Maccabiah. WEIGER--Ralph James. Ralph James Weiger, a prominent community and industry leader passed away on December 1, 2015 in Sonoma, CA at the age of 90 from a cardiac arrest in his daughter's arms. While living in Summit, NJ, Ralph was the CEO/President of Midas International Corporation. After a very successful career growing Midas and leading other companies, including Jiffy Lube and Big O Tires. Ralph became President of the International Franchise Association. He was awarded its Hall of Fame Award in 2002. In 2014, he received an Honorary Doctorate of Engineering from Purdue University, his alma mater. Ralph retired to Prescott, Arizona where he lived for 22 years serving and giving back to his community and receiving many honorary awards. Ralph led the development of Mayo Clinic Arizona Transplant House. He had Board roles in many organizations, including the Yavapai County Big Brothers Big Sisters, the Yavapai County Foundation, and, Arizona Community Foundation. Ralph's most wonderful contribution in life was the role model and unconditional love that he gave to his children and grandchildren. He inspired his children with a sense of duty and commitment, as well as a spirit of adventure. He is survived by his children; Lucy, Barbara, and Jimmy, their families and their mother, Eleanor Marshall-White. 1/3

SEIRAFI--Reza, MD. Formerly of Scarsdale, NY, and Fort Lauderdale, FL, passed peacefully in his home in Naples, FL, on Sunday, December 6, 2015. He is predeceased by his loving wife of fifty years, Charlotte Fischer Seirafi. He is survived by his six children and six grandchildren. Reza was born in Tehran, Iran, to Ali and Ozra Seirafi on September 1, 1926. After completing his medical degree at The University of Tehran, he completed his Research Fellowship at the Medical School at New York University, and his Thoracic and Vascular Residency at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, OH. Dr. Seirafi was an attending physician at The Bronx Hospital, in Bronx, NY, St. Joseph's Hospital and St. John's Hospital in Yonkers, NY. At Yonkers General Hospital, he served as the Attending Vascular and Thoracic Surgeon and held positions of Chief of Thoracic Surgery and Director of Department of Surgery, as well as President of the Medical Board. A private ceremony was held at the Neptune Society in Southwest Florida last week. 1/3

SHORENSTEIN--Douglas W. (February 10, 1955-November 24, 2015) Douglas W. (Doug) Shorenstein, 60, of San Francisco, CA passed away November 24, 2015, at home surrounded by his loving family. He was Chairman and CEO of Shorenstein Properties, a devoted husband and father, a giant in the real estate industry, a generous philanthropist and a committed civic leader. Doug's family was his greatest joy. He delighted in attending his children's sporting events and traveling with his family throughout the world. He was an expert skier, a voracious reader, an avid practitioner of vinyasa yoga and a passionate art collector, especially of Southeast Asian and Nepalese art. Friends remember Doug as a generous and valued mentor and confidante, and particularly enjoyed gathering with him for an evening of conversation over a good meal and great bottle of wine. Doug began his career as an attorney at Shearman & Sterling in New York City, and returned to San Francisco in 1983 to join the family business founded by his father, Walter. Under his leadership, the company grew into one of the largest and most respected private real estate firms in the United States, investing in almost 60 million square feet of high-quality office buildings, including trophy properties like Park Avenue Tower in New York, Hamilton Square in Washington, D.C. and The John Hancock Tower in Chicago. More recently, he had great success transforming older buildings into high quality creative spaces for modern tenants, including the Starrett Lehigh Building in New York, Market Square in San Francisco, River North Point in Chicago and The Reserve in Los Angeles. With his father, Doug led the successful effort in 1992-1993 to form an investor group to keep the San Francisco Giants in San Francisco. In 2007, he was elected to the Board of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, and served as its Chairman in 2011 and 2012, providing, in the words of Bank President and CEO John Williams, "outstanding leadership." In 2011, he was inducted into the Bay Area Council's Business Hall of Fame. Marc Benioff, founder and chairman of Salesforce.com, called Doug "one of the greatest leaders of San Francisco." Doug was an exemplary civic leader and philanthropist, supporting and serving on the boards of local groups such as UCSF Medical Center, the United Way of San Francisco and the Committee on Jobs, as well as prominent national industry groups and institutions, including The Real Estate Roundtable, Environmental Defense Fund, Yale School of Management, Vanderbilt University, and The Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. Doug is survived by his wife, Lydia, three children, Brandon, Sandra and Danielle, and a sister, Carole Shorenstein Hays. 1/3
EILBOTT--FRED. March 21, 1922, Munich. Died December 7, 2015, New York. Survived by wife, son and four grandchildren. 1/3

LEVIN--Evelyn (nee Cron), passed on December 10. Beloved wife of the late Lester Levin, daughter of Morris and Anna Cron, sister of Martin (deceased) and Rhoda (Stuart Friedman), mother of Jeffrey (Diane), Marc (Deborah Rubin), Lori (Ross Hyams), grandchildren Michael (Samantha), Allison, Robert, Benjamin, Haley, Zachary and great-grandchild Isabella. 1/3

FEINBERG--Mortimer R.,Ph.D., passed away peacefully of natural causes on December 10, 2015. Born August 26, 1922 in New York City, Mort combined a career as an academic with his role as a Consultant and advisor to many of the world's most successful corporations and individuals. A pioneer in the field of industrial psychology, Dr. Feinberg educated, enlightened and advised a stellar roster of global chief executive officers, heads of state, and leaders of thought for nearly six decades. He successfully combined a keen technical expertise with a unique sense of humanity, touching campuses and board rooms from Brooklyn to Dubai. As an academic, Dr. Feinberg is a Professor Emeritus of Baruch College of the City University of New York. There he served as the Director of Advanced Management Programs, Assistant Dean, Professor and former acting Chairman of the Psychology Department and Professor of Management. A tireless lecturer and keynote speaker, Dr. Feinberg highlighted the agenda for organizations and institutions such as the Young Presidents Organizations, the Israel Management Center, and the Indo-American Society. He served as conference leader for public and private corporations such as GE, AlliedBarton, Rockefeller Group International, Chase Bank, Pritchard Industries, Crescent Petroleum, and Insitu. In all, his service as a lecturer and conference leader took him to over 30 countries around the world. Dr. Feinberg's accomplishments were broadly recognized, having received numerous honors and awards. He held an Honorary Doctor of Aviation Business Administration from Emory- Riddle Aeronautical University. In addition he was a Fellow of the American Psychological Association, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and is listed in Who's Who in America. A renowned author of six-books, as well as countless business articles and technical papers, Dr. Feinberg's insights have appeared in The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, Business Week, Fortune, and Forbes Magazines. In addition he was a guest on national radio and television programming such as NBC's Today Show and the Oprah Winfrey Show. His "Effective Psychology for Managers" and "Why Smart People do Dumb Things" have become required reading for professional business managers. In addition, Dr. Feinberg met and interviewed four standing U.S. Presidents to discuss their psychology of leadership. Fueled by an insatiable desire to impact positively the welfare of every individual who came across his path and armed with a style uniquely his own, Dr. Feinberg combined wit, a depth of experience, and compassion to provide point - on advice to those he counseled. He was predeceased by his loving wife of nearly 60 years Gloria, and is survived by his beloved sons Drs. Stuart and Todd (Marlene) Feinberg, grandchildren Rachel (Jason) and Dr. Joshua Feinberg and great-grandson Jake. Funeral services will be held today, Sunday December 13, 2015, 10:45am at Hellman Memorial Chapels, 15 State Street, Spring Valley, NY. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. 1/3

SHAGAN--Stephen H. "Steve," 88, passed away peacefully in his sleep on November 30, 2015, at his home in Los Angeles, CA. Born in 1927 in New York City to Barnet "Barney" and Rachel Shagan, Steve is survived by his son Robert (Paul). Beloved husband of 61 years of marriage to Elizabeth "Betty" F. Shagan (1930-2013), Steve will be remembered for his kindness, intelligence, creativity, honesty, strength, generosity, humor, integrity and perseverance; as well as the love he felt for the cats that he and Betty cared for over the years. When not dedicating time to his craft, Steve enjoyed traveling, keeping up with his favorite baseball and football teams' scores, horseracing, reading and spending quality time with his family and close friends. Steve's career as a best-selling author, film and television writer and producer spanned nearly six decades; including nominations for two Academy Awards, a Golden Globe Award and a Primetime Emmy Award. In 1974, Steve won the Writers Guild of America Award - Best Screenplay, Drama for "Save the Tiger," based upon his novel of the same name. Cumulatively, Steve published eight critically acclaimed novels, wrote 10 screenplays and produced over 48 films, television episodes and made for TV movies, combined. Private family services will be held at Newton Cemetery in Newton Center, MA. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the World Wildlife Fund. 1/3

Maura, Joel, Glen (Juliet) and Eric (Kelly) 1/3
POLLACK--Lester. With love to Geri and her family, we remember Lester and all of the good times during our friendships of over 60 years. Barbara and Louis Linda and Howard Anne and Al 1/3
STERN--Louise. You are our oldest and dearest friend. We will miss you forever. Joanie and Bob 1/3

WASSERBERG--Ira A January 12, 1927 - December 7, 2015. Husband of Louise (Yesley), father of David, Emily, and Andrew, grandfather of Yoni, Noam, and Sebastian. Urologist, artist, proud WWII vet, world traveler, believer in the written word. He will be missed. 1/3

ARTHUR--William. William ("Bill") Robert Arthur passed away peacefully at his home on Tuesday, December 1, 2015 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. He was 82 years old. Bill was born on July 27, 1933 in Ironton, OH and was raised in Ft. Thomas, KY. He was the only child of Daisy and Robert D. Arthur. He graduated from Highlands High School in 1951 where he lettered in football, basketball and baseball. He graduated from Duke University in 1955 with a degree in economics. While at Duke he was on a ROTC scholarship and was an active member of the Sigma Alpha Epsilon ("SAE") Fraternity. Upon graduating from Duke, he served in the military in the Army Counter Intelligence Corps. After his military service, Bill had a long and distinguished career with Merrill Lynch, Inc. lasting over 30 years. Starting as a stockbroker in Washington DC, he earned promotions into management (Columbus, OH and NYC) and ultimately achieved the position of Chairman of Merrill Lynch International. As Chairman of Merrill Lynch International, Bill traveled extensively and played a strong leadership role in Merrill's worldwide growth and expansion, especially in Southeast Asia and China. During this time Bill and his family resided in Summit, NJ and subsequently relocated to Hong Kong for five years. In 1989, Bill retired to the Country Club of North Carolina in Pinehurst, NC and in 2006, he relocated to Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Bill was a passionate golfer and was an active member of the Baltusrol Golf Club in New Jersey. He loved to travel with his family and go on golfing trips with good friends. He especially loved playing Pebble Beach in California. He was a big fan of Duke University's Football and Basketball teams as well as the Washington Redskins team. He loved art and a variety of great music-- especially Emmy Lou Harris and Jazz. He was a history buff and an avid reader. He was incredibly well read and current on international and domestic affairs and business. His mind was sharp and curious, and his heart was generous. He will be greatly missed by his many friends and family. He is predeceased by his former wife, Marilyn Mayberry Arthur, who passed away on November 11, 2014. He is survived by his daughter, Alice Lorraine-Lori (Tom Stroud), his son, David (Jennifer Mee Arthur) and his only grandchild, Edward William Arthur-Ted. Contributions in Bill Arthur's memory may be made to the Nasher Museum of Art at Duke University, 2001 Campus Drive, Durham, NC 27705, 919-668-4063. https://www.gifts.duke.edu/ nasher--gift. 1/3

Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3
HALLOW--Gregory. Sept. 2, 1924 - Dec. 14, 2000 Dad, I will always remember your love, kindness and humor. Margot 1/3

CHANG--John B.,M.D., Vascular surgeon and educator, died on December 1 in Great Neck, NY at 79. Dr. Chang was one of the best-known and most respected vascular surgeons in the world. He was the founder and director of the Long Island Vascular Center in Roslyn, NY. Dr. Chang trained at Seoul National University and immigrated to the United States in 1967, with his beloved wife Lucy. He completed his U.S. surgical residency and vascular training at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New York. His surgical skills and deep caring for patients resulted in a blossoming clinical and surgical practice, culminating in the care of tens of thousands of patients from 1973 to 2015. His expertise with the surgical procedure of carotid endarterectomy remained unsurpassed. Dr. Chang trained hundreds of surgery residents, many of whom went on to leadership positions. His residents held him in great esteem, not only for his clinical skills and surgical teaching, but also for his caring, generosity, and mentorship. Dr. Chang was a perceptive and talented individual of great integrity who inspired everyone to live up to his standards of fairness, compassion, and respect for his patients which he demonstrated throughout his career. Dr. Chang lectured throughout the world, published over 150 scientific articles, and authored the comprehensive textbook Angiology. He held academic appointments at Hofstra Northshore-LIJ School of Medicine and Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Dr. Chang served as Chairman of the Board of the International College of Angiology for decades, a labor of love that brought together colleagues from around the world and was also their journal's Editor-in-Chief. He organized countless conferences and symposia worldwide and founded the Asian Vascular Society. He was the President of the Honorary Society of Police Surgeons for the New York Police Department and strongly supported the Catholic Church culminating in his Elevation to Grand Cross, Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem. Dr. Chang was a devoted and loving husband, father, brother, uncle, and grandfather. He is predeceased by his father and mother and survived by four younger brothers, his sister, a large extended family; his wife Lucy, his sons Victor and Robert, and his three grandchildren; countless friends and colleagues; and thousands of loving, grateful patients. Friendship and family were highly valued by John Chang. His caring and respect for his patients encouraged many loving connections to develop and branch out like the limbs of a tree. These relationships lasted for a lifetime. He dedicated his life to being the finest doctor, surgeon, educator, leader, humanitarian, friend, and family man that he could be. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Donations may be made to the International College of Angiology - John B. Chang Memorial Fund at www. intlcollegeofangiology.org or The Society of Honorary Police Surgeons Scholarship Fund, c/o Jacob Dimant, M.D. Treasurer, 400 East 56th St., Apt 29B, New York, NY 10022. 1/3

MOGHRABI--Zuhayr A. "I'll love you my darling for- ever and 22 days." Born July 4, 1932, Dr. Moghrabi passed away on December 7, 2015 of natural causes. He was the first Chancellor of the University of Sharjah in the U.A.E. He was Professor of Law for 35 years at the New York Law School where his outstanding contributions included introducing International Business Law, Energy Law and Islamic Law courses. He received extensive education from the American University of Beirut, University of Tulsa in Chemical Engineering, Columbia University and New York Law School. He was a man with a great sense of humor. When asked "With all those degrees why do you want to be a lawyer?" He responded "Why not? Lawyers are the best hams!" A devotee of opera, he finally found his Kismet in Rosalind Elias, mezzo-soprano of the Metropolitan Opera. Zuhayr means flower, Rosalind means beautiful rose and together they made a magnificent bouquet. GOLDSTEIN--Sheldon S. A giant of the real estate industry and founder and Chairman of The Lynmark Group in Suffern, NY, passed away on December 4 at his home in Piermont, NY surrounded by his loving family. He was 86. Born on November 13, 1929 in Brooklyn, he was one of three sons of Jack and Ceil Goldstein. His parents as well as brothers Arthur and Martin preceded him in death. On December 23, 1950 he married Arlyne Brickner, the love of his life with whom he shared 65 years of marriage and survives him. Shelly - as he liked to be called - served his country in the Philippines as a member of the United States Army from 1950 to 1952. For over 56 years, his vision kept The Lynmark Group in the forefront of real estate development. The family-owned business spanning three generations of fathers, sons and grandsons has constructed and developed real estate projects in 19 states and internationally in Anguilla, British West Indies. With over 60 years of real estate experience, his knowledge of development and financing led to board memberships on Hudson United Bank & Trust Company as well as his role in organizing the First Women's Bank in New York City in 1975. His many industry affiliations include past Chairman and Trustee of the New York State University Construction Fund, State Director of the New York State Builders Association and Past President of the Rockland County Builders Association. Over the years, he and his wife Arlyne have been contributors to many philanthropic organizations including Camp Venture in Haverstraw, NY, the Eugene M. Levy Recreation Center for Camp Venture children, Brookland Park, a ten-acre park in the Village of Suffern, NY, and a cardiac care waiting room at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, NY. A lifelong supporter of the Jewish faith and the State of Israel, he and his wife honored the memory of their parents by building in their names and continue to sponsor a day care center in Kerem Ben Zimrah, Israel and a library in Dalton, Israel. In addition the family donated toward the construction of the Jewish Community Center in Rockland County, NY, which provides athletic facilities and a recreation center for the entire community. Giving back to others and to the community was as much a part of Shelly's life as his work. In addition to his beloved wife, Arlyne, he is survived by two sons and their families - Jeffrey Goldstein and his wife, Susan, Mark Goldstein and his wife Lainie. Five grandchildren - Joshua and his wife Rachael, Zachary, Daniel and his fiance Anna, Dylan, and Dakota. Three great-grandchildren - the children of Joshua and Rachael - Lindsay, Joseph and Alicia. Donations may be sent in the name of Sheldon S. Goldstein to JCC of Rockland, 450 W. Nyack Road, West Nyack, NY 10994 or UnitedHospice of Rockland County, 11 Stokum Lane, New City, NY 10956. 1/3

John was a long time professor at St. John's Law School. He graduated from Harvard in 1969 and Harvard Law School in 1974. Service will be private. 1/3

GIBNEY--Helen Elizabeth, loving wife of attorney Wilson J. Gibney (deceased), mother of Pamela Gibney and Paula (Christopher) Tennyson, grandmother of Christopher Wilson Tennyson and Megan Gibney Tennyson, passed in her home December 12. Born in Manhattan, 1919, to Irish immigrants, Thomas Hayes and Delia Gleason, Helen was devoted sister of Mary, Kitty, Tessie, and Tommy (all deceased). She loved family, faith, bridge, golf and the Yankees (most of the time). Consider donations to: Wilson J. Gibney Scholarship, Fordham Law School. Services: Graham Funeral Home Rye, NY. 1/3

MAHER--William J.,of New York City, NY passed away on December 11, 2015 after a long battle with Oral Cancer. Mr. Maher was born on June 16, 1942 in New York City, son of the late William and Dorothy Maher. He enjoyed a highly successful career in Labor Relations, Human Resources and Executive Search. Loving Father, Grandfather and Brother, he is survived by a son Michael, a daughter, Kelly Ann Gutierrez, a sister, Elizabeth Schroeder and four grandchildren, Caitlyn and Terry Gutierrez and MacKenzie and Madison Maher. Reposing at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, New York City, NY. Visiting Sunday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial 10am, Monday at St. John The Evangelist Church, 55th Street and First Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Oral Cancer Foundation, 3419 Via Lido #

GELBER--Anita. January 13, 1931-December 11, 2015. Born in the Bronx, NY. Cherished wife of Sam. Beloved sister of Frances. Treasured mother of Michele, Les, Stephen, and Marguerite. Honored grandmother of Pam, David, Rachael, Jessica and Johanna. In lieu of flowers, donations to Alzheimer's Foundation of America. 1/3

MILLER--Jean Chandler, of New York City, formerly of Darien, CT, died peacefully at home Saturday, December 12, 2015. She was 86. Jean was born March 10, 1929, in Brooklyn, the daughter of the late Walter and Ethel Chandler. She was the beloved wife of Lewis A. Miller for almost 66 years, the mother of David Chandler Miller of Darien (wife Nina) and of Kathryn Ann Miller of Riverdale, the Bronx, and grandmother of Coleman Chandler Miller Esq. of Brooklyn and Caleb Miller Zalaznick, a junior at McGill University, Montreal. She was the loving aunt of Jean Ferguson of Seattle, Bruce Fergusson of Edmonds, WA, Faith Miller and Jonathan Miller of New York City, and Timothy Miller of Ridgewood NJ. Jean was a graduate of Sarah Lawrence College in 1988, through its Continuing Education program, and provided a community room for students at the Continuing Education Center after her graduation. She became a successful investor in the stock market for her own account, was skillful at needlepoint and gardening, and loved and raised boxers. As a member of the Darien Congregational Church, she taught Sunday School, chaired the Women's Association and the Board of Deacons, and headed the church Christmas Corner. As a volunteer, she worked in the eviction mediation program of Person-to-Person, a Darien nonprofit; and for the Community Council of Darien. Her philanthropy included these organizations as well as the Workplace, Bridgeport, CT, helping people gain workplace skills as well as jobs; the New York Common Pantry, the Coalition for the Homeless in New York, and more. She was a member of Christ Church Methodist, New York City. Memorial services will be held at Christ Church Methodist, Park Avenue at 60th St., on Monday, December 21, at 11am, and at the Darien Congregational Church, Post Rd. at Brookside Rd., on Thursday, December 17, at 10am. Gifts in her memory may be made to Sarah Lawrence College, 1 Mead Way, Bronxville, NY 10708, or Person-to-Person, 1864 Post Rd, Darien, CT 06820. 1/3

MODLIN--Margot Spett, passed away December 8, 2015 in her Manhattan home. She entered the world of business and started her first company, MSM Consultants, at a time when many women did not have careers. Most recently, she served as president of Southwest Gloves & Safety Equipment, Inc. and Century Glove, Inc. She also managed Weisman, Celler, Spett & Modlin, PC. Her passion for the New York Giants and skiing was exceeded only by her love of family. She is survived by Howard S. Modlin, her loving husband of 59 years; her children: James M. Modlin, Laura R. Modlin, Peter S. Modlin; her daughters-in-law Alice Shulman and Terri Wilsie, her grandchildren Deborah Modlin, Emma Modlin, Sarah Modlin, Emily Modlin, Benjamin Modlin, Samuel Modlin, her brother Mickey Spett, sister-in-law Lynn Mollick and nephew David Spett. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to New York Center for Autism Charter School, 433 East 100th Street, NY, NY 10029. nycautismcharterschool.com 1/3

BREWER--Frank of Mineola on December 11, 2015, at 91. Retired NY Times after 50 years as printer. Distinguished WWII Army Vet who saw combat in France. Beloved husband of the late Bernadette Kearns. Survived by sisters, Patricia & Joan. Loving owner of Candy, Scrappy & Blackie. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. 1/3

MAHLER--Herbert W.,died peacefully on December 10, 2015 at age 80 after a courageous battle against pancreatic cancer. He was the founder and CEO of Mahler & Emerson Inc. and is survived by his beloved wife of 51 years, Nancy, sons Peter and Alexander, and adored granddaughter Alexandra Lydia. Service private. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Lustgarten Foundation would be appreciated. 1/3

STERN--Louise. She enriched her friends' lives with her humor, gregariousness, warmth and kindness. In her later years she faced her challenges with determined courage, dignity and pride. She was very dear to us. May she rest in eternal peace. Susan and Robert Katz 1/3

COHN--Jules. (June 18, 1930 - December 9, 2015). Survived by his wife, Nancy Goldner, his nephew Eric Cohn, and many cousins. He loved Judaism, Kafka and all kinds of music. He had great intellect, curiosity and compassion for others. He was my soul-mate. Nancy Goldner 1/3

WINARSKY--Suzanne Bauer, died peacefully at home December 11, she was 96. After fleeing her birthplace Mannheim, Germany in 1937, she spent 70 years in New Jersey before relocating to Rockville, Maryland. Her parents, Ludwig and Irma, and her younger brother, Werner, died in the Holocaust. Suzanne was predeceased by her husband, Samuel, and her brother Henry Bauer. Survived by children Lewis Winarsky (Susan), Frances Miller, and Amy Winarsky (Michael Takiff), grandsons Andrew Miller, Simon Miller, and Aaron Takiff, and two great-grandchildren. Opera- lover, people-person, creator of Oma's pearls of wisdom. 1/3

ARTHUR--William. William ("Bill") Robert Arthur passed away peacefully at his home on Tuesday, December 1, 2015 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. He was 82 years old. Bill was born on July 27, 1933 in Ironton, OH and was raised in Ft. Thomas, KY. He was the only child of Daisy and Robert D. Arthur. He graduated from Highlands High School in 1951 where he lettered in football, basketball and baseball. He graduated from Duke University in 1955 with a degree in economics. While at Duke he was on a ROTC scholarship and was an active member of the Sigma Alpha Epsilon ("SAE") Fraternity. Upon graduating from Duke, he served in the military in the Army Counter Intelligence Corps. After his military service, Bill had a long and distinguished career with Merrill Lynch, Inc. lasting over 30 years. Starting as a stockbroker in Washington DC, he earned promotions into management (Columbus, OH and NYC) and ultimately achieved the position of Chairman of Merrill Lynch International. As Chairman of Merrill Lynch International, Bill traveled extensively and played a strong leadership role in Merrill's worldwide growth and expansion, especially in Southeast Asia and China. During this time Bill and his family resided in Summit, NJ and subsequently relocated to Hong Kong for five years. In 1989, Bill retired to the Country Club of North Carolina in Pinehurst, NC and in 2006, he relocated to Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Bill was a passionate golfer and was an active member of the Baltusrol Golf Club in New Jersey. He loved to travel with his family and go on golfing trips with good friends. He especially loved playing Pebble Beach in California. He was a big fan of Duke University's Football and Basketball teams as well as the Washington Redskins team. He loved art and a variety of great music-- especially Emmy Lou Harris and Jazz. He was a history buff and an avid reader. He was incredibly well read and current on international and domestic affairs and business. His mind was sharp and curious, and his heart was generous. He will be greatly missed by his many friends and family. He is predeceased by his former wife, Marilyn Mayberry Arthur, who passed away on November 11, 2014. He is survived by his daughter, Alice Lorraine-Lori (Tom Stroud), his son, David (Jennifer Mee Arthur) and his only grandchild, Edward William Arthur-Ted. Contributions in Bill Arthur's memory may be made to the Nasher Museum of Art at Duke University, 2001 Campus Drive, Durham, NC 27705, 919-668-4063. https://www.gifts.duke.edu/ nasher--gift. 1/3

SCHLEGEL--Mary "Marie" P. Beloved wife of Niles M. Schlegel for 62 years, passed away December 12, 2015 due to a rapid illness. Daughter of Peter and Ann (Halloran) McIntyre; mother of Deborah A. DeBenedictis (Tony) of West Roxbury, MA, and Peter N. Schlegel of New York, NY; sister of Barbara Sullivan (John), predeceased by brother James P. McIntyre (Monica) and sister Anne Leahy; grandmother to Pauline M. Maietta, Dominique A. (Maietta) Trappey (Francois), Vincent J. Maietta, Anne H. Maietta, Luke N. Maietta, Andrew P. Schlegel, Lucy F. Schlegel and Nicholas H. Schlegel. Marie was deeply involved with the welfare of children and served in childcare at St. Mary's Episcopal Church of Newton. Marie was dedicated to her family, an interactive and beloved member of the community at Brooksby Village, and was often escorted by her poodle, Cooky. For additional information or online guest book please call 978 744 0497 or visit MurphyFuneralHome.com. 1/3

For guestbook, please visit www.gormleyfuneral.com. 1/3

Adored grandfather of Chloe and Sasha Harrison; Joshua, Noah, and Rachel Stern. Contributions in Arnold's memory may be made to the Marlboro School of Music. 1/3
MOFFETT--Charles S.,Scholar. Mentor. Dear Friend. Your soul will live forever in the hearts of those who have loved you. David & Constance Yates 1/3

VERNON--Lillian, on December 14, 2015. Founder and Chairwoman of Lillian Vernon Corporation. Beloved wife of Paolo Martino. Devoted mother of Fred and David Hochberg. Services Wednesday, 10am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

STERN--Louise A. The Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board mourns the passing of our greatly esteemed member of over 20 years, Louise A. Stern. Louise was a co-founder of the Mount Sinai Breast Health Resource Program where the patients, staff and volunteers were blessed by her patient advocacy, philanthropy and dedication. Her generosity and commitment to our Board and the Mount Sinai community will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. Jennifer Price, President 1/3

VERNON--Lillian, trailblazer, leader, visionary, a transformational woman who achieved greatness in business, but should be remembered also for her wonderful spirit, gusto, generosity, decency and for never forgetting her roots. Lillian's shinning spirit ended just as Chanukah, the Jewish Festival of Lights concluded, but her radiance cannot be extinguished and will forever be with us. May Paolo, Fred, David, Tom and all those who loved Lillian be comforted at this time. Suri Kasirer & Bruce Teitelbaum 1/3

VERNON--Lillian, Mt. Vernon homemaker turned trailblazing entrepreneur and passionate advocate for women. For 21 years we at Citymeals on Wheels knew her as a compassionate supporter of our mission, a lively co-conspirator and no- nonsense voice at board meetings, an elegant hostess always ready to open her home to advance our cause. She enjoyed the life she created for herself with great style and obvious pleasure, never losing her deep sense of obligation to those not so fortunate. She had a great sense of humor too. Her steadfast generosity delivered thousands of meals to New York's homebound shut-ins and the refrigerated truck she bought us transports fresh produce to neighborhoods that lack it. She lived every moment of her life up to her last breath. Our hearts go out to her husband Paolo Martino and her sons, Fred and David Hochberg and to all her family. We will be reminded of her instinctive caring and lively spirit whenever we see that truck with the signature on it: Lillian Vernon. 1/3

COHEN--Jeffrey, 62, husband of Kathi Myerson Cohen, son to Miriam Dolman and Frank Cohen, Brother of Helisse Asbury and Wendy Friedman, and father to Tatum and Cody Cohen, born May 6, 1953 and who was president of Ralph Lauren Retail from 1982-1993, is remembered as a pioneer in the retail outlet industry. Working for companies ranging from Tommy Hilfiger to Ecko Unlimited, Jeff always made time for friends, family, and anybody who looked like they could use a smile. He was defined by his rigorous work ethic, drive to excel and push those around him to do the same. 1/3

DIAMOND--Madeline Loretta. May 14, 1943-December 14, 2015. Wife of Sheldon Diamond. Mother to Lee Diamond and his wife, Nichol, and Bradley Diamond and his wife, Jackie. Grandmother to Ashley, Madison, and Ethan. Sister to Artie Speiser. Loving Aunt to Sue, Eric, and Anne. Loving sisterin-law to Judi and Jack Diamond. Services will be held at 1pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY 11797. We will miss you Aunt Maddy. You were always the life of our family gatherings in Connecticut. Love forever and always, Sue, Eric, Karen, Lisa, Eric, and Anne Goldman & Family 1/3

MORIBER--Dr. Louis G. With his beloved family by his side, Dr. Louis G. Moriber, 98, died peacefully at home, on Tuesday, December 8, 2015, in Brooklyn, NY. Dr. Moriber--or Lou, as he was widely known, leaves an extraordinary personal and professional legacy: as a devoted husband to Frances Schneider Moriber, who died in 1997 after 56 years of joyful marriage; as proud father to son, Samuel Moriber of New York, and daughter, Lisa Miller of Virginia, grandfather to Jessica Miller of California and Seth Miller of Colorado; and great-grandfather to Kirya Miller, age 14, and Pip Miller, age 11, of Colorado. Born July 12, 1917 in Brooklyn, Lou had three brothers, Joseph, Maurice, and Edward, all deceased. Lou began his career as an aquatic physiologist at the Fish and Wildlife Service of the Department of the Interior, and then began a long and illustrious career at Brooklyn College, where he was well known as a remarkably caring and modest man of great intellect and heart. As professor of biology at Brooklyn College, he served for 35 years as teacher, mentor and as the Chair of the Biology Department, the Deputy Chair of the School of General Studies in Biology, and the Executive Officer for the Graduate Program in Biology at the City University of New York; and as a model of integrity and optimism to his colleagues, family and friends everywhere. In the course of his career Lou served as Pre- Med Advisor at Brooklyn College, where he was instrumental in advancing the careers of thousands of doctors. Passionate about education in the sciences even after his retirement, Lou joined his cousin, George Moriber, a chemistry professor at Brooklyn College, in creating a highly successful program to introduce science education to elementary and high school teachers. Lou was a thoughtful and heartwarming person to all who knew him. Forever curious and appreciative of the world around him, he was an avid nature photographer and a devotee of classical music and dance. He will be immeasurably missed. Donations to his memory may be made to Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders NYC, Inc. www.alznyc.org. 1/3

BREWER--Frank of Mineola on December 11, 2015, at 91. Retired NY Times after 50 years as printer. Distinguished WWII Army Vet who saw combat in France. Beloved husband of the late Bernadette Kearns. Survived by sisters, Patricia & Joan. Loving owner of Candy, Scrappy & Blackie. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. 1/3

FISH--Ira Richard, of Tenafly, NJ, on December 14 at age 79. Dear husband of Linda. Beloved father of Jane Kagan (Daniel), David (Dory Ellen), and Daniel. Outstanding grandfather of Samantha, Emily, Eliza, and Gabriel. Great-grandfather of Aviva, and dear brother of Fred. Remembered with love by his family and the many thousands of children who grew up spending unique summers with him at Jeff Lake Camp. Funeral services will be at 11:00am on Wednesday, December 16 at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ. Interment to follow at Pine Brook Jewish Cemetery, Montville, NJ. Contributions may be made to Birthright Israel, St. Barnabas Hospice, or Project Morry. 1/3

CAPLAN--David. The Board of Trustees and staff of New York Public Radio mourn the loss of David Caplan. Through a lifetime of public service, David enriched our community. For more than twenty-five years, he passionately served as a Trustee ensuring that the vital resource of public radio thrived and served our city. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Barbara, their children Nancy, Amy, David Jr., Patty and Tom, and the entire family. Cynthia King Vance, Chair Laura R. Walker, President and CEO 1/3
GOLD--Arthur A.,M.D. 11/3/29 to 12/15/06. Deeply loved. We miss your warmth and wit. Bobbie and The Family 1/3

LYTTON--Madeleine. August 28, 1921 - November 13, 2015. Madeleine was one of the great performers of Isadora Duncan's dances in France and taught them to many in the old world and new. She died at home in Castres at 94 and leaves her devoted daughter, Eleonore Lytton-Pistorio. Thanks to her parents, the English painter Neville Lytton and her French mother, Alexandra Fortel Lytton, Madeleine began studying at age six with Lisa Duncan, one of Isadora's adopted daughters. After her family was obliged to leave France during World War II (Neville's father had been Viceroy of India), she studied ballet and character dance in London, then entertained British troops. Madeleine Lytton played a key role internationally in the revival of the Duncan repertoire. Her master classes and dance performances in Europe and the United States were a revelation. Anna Kisselgoff 1/3

PROCTOR--Henry, of Tenafly, NJ, died at 84. Born in Brooklyn. Survived by wife Lenore; children Andrew, Laura, and Mark; and grandchildren Sara, Carolina, Alexander, and Juliette. FISH--Ira Richard, of Tenafly, NJ, on December 14 at age 79. Dear husband of Linda. Beloved father of Jane Kagan (Daniel), David (Dory Ellen), and Daniel. Outstanding grandfather of Samantha, Emily, Eliza, and Gabriel. Great-grandfather of Aviva, and dear brother of Fred. Remembered with love by his family and the many thousands of children who grew up spending unique summers with him at Jeff Lake Camp. Funeral services will be at 11:00am on Wednesday, December 16 at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ. Interment to follow at Pine Brook Jewish Cemetery, Montville, NJ. Contributions may be made to Birthright Israel, St. Barnabas Hospice, or Project Morry. 1/3

CAPLAN--David. Dear David, we love you and always will. Iris and Richard 1/3

VERNON--Lillian. The American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra Board of Directors and Staff mourn the passing of our esteemed Board Member Lillian Vernon. Lillian was a valued Founding Benefactor and her leadership and commitment to AFIPO's mission and generosity will contribute to the future of the Israel Philharmonic for generations to come. Our heartfelt sympathy to her husband Paolo, sons David and Fred and the entire family. We shall always remember Lillian as a true friend and philanthropist. Zubin Mehta and Itzhak Perlman, Co-Chairmen David A. Hirsch, President Lauren Veronis, Chairman Exec Committee and VP Sara Fabrikant, Claudio Pincus, Marilyn Ziering, Richard Ziman, Vice-President Raphael Sutton, Executive Director 1/3

SOLOMON--Dr. David Y.,age 92, passed away peacefully at his Manhattan home on Monday, December 14, 2015. Dr. Solomon was born in Kuwait and grew up in Iraq then fled religious persecution, escaping to Iran before emigrating to the United States in 1961 with the help of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee. He practiced medicine for 67 years because of a true devotion to people. He took a personal interest in every single patient regardless of their stature. He never turned anyone away and they came from all around the world to see him, some even calling him "Papa." He was the patriarch of his family; a loving husband, father and grandfather and a devoted son, brother and uncle. He touched everyone with his infectious celebration of life, his generosity and his unflagging determination to help others. He was also an amazingly creative cook. He is survived by his wife of 49 years Yris, his sister Rosemond, sons Darius and Teimour, daughters-in-law Enez and Grace and his grandson Ethan. He will be dearly missed. Family will receive Wednesday from 6pm-9pm with a funeral service held on Thursday at 11am, both to be held at Frank E Campbell, "The Funeral Chapel," 81st Street and Madison Ave. Interment to follow will take place at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ. 1/3

VERNON--Lillian. The Board and Staff of Film Society of Lincoln Center are saddened by the passing of Lillian Vernon, a supportive and active member of the board of directors for 20 years. Lillian contributed a great deal to the growth of the organization and was also instrumental in securing support for the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center. She will be deeply missed. Ann Tenenbaum, Chairman Daniel H. Stern, President Lesli Klainberg, Exe. Director 1/3

VERNON--Lillian, trailblazer, leader, visionary, a transformational woman who achieved greatness in business, but should be remembered also for her wonderful spirit, gusto, generosity, decency and for never forgetting her roots. Lillian's shinning spirit ended just as Chanukah, the Jewish Festival of Lights concluded, but her radiance cannot be extinguished and will forever be with us. May Paolo, Fred, David, Tom and all those who loved Lillian be comforted at this time. Suri Kasirer & Bruce Teitelbaum 1/3

BLUM--Susan, a woman of strong opinions and conviction, passed away on December 14th. Beloved wife of Michael. Beloved sister, sister- in-law, aunt, and cherished friend of many. Susan was a Professional Educator at The Professional Children's School, Little Red Schoolhouse, and the Town School. She was a Board Member of Breakthrough New York. Services will be on Thursday, December 17th at 11am at Central Synagogue, New York. Did you know her father was a Veterinarian? 1/3

COHEN--Jeffrey, 62, husband of Kathi Myerson Cohen, son to Miriam Dolman and Frank Cohen, Brother of Helisse Asbury and Wendy Friedman, and father to Tatum and Cody Cohen, born May 6, 1953 and who was president of Ralph Lauren Retail from 1982-1993, is remembered as a pioneer in the retail outlet industry. Working for companies ranging from Tommy Hilfiger to Ecko Unlimited, Jeff always made time for friends, family, and anybody who looked like they could use a smile. He was defined by his rigorous work ethic, drive to excel and push those around him to do the same. 1/3

VERNON--Lillian. The NYU Community deeply mourns the loss of our devoted friend, Life Trustee, and generous benefactor, Lillian Vernon. Lillian, who attended NYU's College of Arts and Science, was a pioneering businesswoman and entrepreneur whose inspiring life story and generous philanthropy touched countless lives. Born in Germany, she and her family fled the Nazis and rebuilt their lives in America. As a young wife and mother seeking to supplement her family's income, she placed an ad in Seventeen magazine offering purses with matching belts, and from the overwhelming response to that modest ad she built one of the most successful and admired mail-order companies in the history of American business, particularly notable for having a woman at its helm in a male- dominated business world. Possessed of boundless energy and determination, Lillian never forgot her humble beginnings and devoted much of her life to "giving back" through philanthropic support for charities and cultural and educational institutions. Prominent among these was NYU, where she energetically served on the Faculty of Arts and Science Board of Overseers, the School of Professional Studies Dean's Council, and, since 1997, the NYU Board of Trustees. She supported NYU's esteemed creative writing program through the establishment of the Lillian Vernon Professorship in Creative Writing and the Lillian Vernon Creative Writers House, helping to develop new generations of literary talent. We are saddened by her death, and our thoughts and prayers go out to her husband, Paolo Martino, her children -- David Hochberg, and Fred Hochberg, WSC '74, Fred's husband, Tom Healy, and all of her loved ones and friends. 1/3

RABINOWITZ--Jacob, born June 13, 1927, died December 15, 2015. Son of immigrants, graduated City College of New York, 1948. Electronics Engineer, husband of 66 years to Ruth Lapidus, father of David, Naomi and Jesse, grandfather of Emily, Jonah and Aaron, great- grandfather of Charlotte and Louisa. Grew up in the age of radio and helped pioneer color television, satellite and cellular communication. 1/3
BEILMAN--Ralph. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Ralph Beilman, associated with The New York Times from October 8, 1977 until retiring on January 1, 2001. 1/3

MILLER--Jean Chandler, of New York City, formerly of Darien, CT, died peacefully at home Saturday, December 12, 2015. She was 86. Jean was born March 10, 1929, in Brooklyn, the daughter of the late Walter and Ethel Chandler. She was the beloved wife of Lewis A. Miller for almost 66 years, the mother of David Chandler Miller of Darien (wife Nina) and of Kathryn Ann Miller of Riverdale, the Bronx, and grandmother of Coleman Chandler Miller Esq. of Brooklyn and Caleb Miller Zalaznick, a junior at McGill University, Montreal. She was the loving aunt of Jean Ferguson of Seattle, Bruce Fergusson of Edmonds, WA, Faith Miller and Jonathan Miller of New York City, and Timothy Miller of Ridgewood NJ. Jean was a graduate of Sarah Lawrence College in 1988, through its Continuing Education program, and provided a community room for students at the Continuing Education Center after her graduation. She became a successful investor in the stock market for her own account, was skillful at needlepoint and gardening, and loved and raised boxers. As a member of the Darien Congregational Church, she taught Sunday School, chaired the Women's Association and the Board of Deacons, and headed the church Christmas Corner. As a volunteer, she worked in the eviction mediation program of Person-to-Person, a Darien nonprofit; and for the Community Council of Darien. Her philanthropy included these organizations as well as the Workplace, Bridgeport, CT, helping people gain workplace skills as well as jobs; the New York Common Pantry, the Coalition for the Homeless in New York, and more. She was a member of Christ Church Methodist, New York City. Memorial services will be held at Christ Church Methodist, Park Avenue at 60th St., on Monday, December 21, at 11am, and at the Darien Congregational Church, Post Rd. at Brookside Rd., on Thursday, December 17, at 10am. Gifts in her memory may be made to Sarah Lawrence College, 1 Mead Way, Bronxville, NY 10708, or Person-to-Person, 1864 Post Rd, Darien, CT 06820. 1/3

FEINBERG--Mortimer R. It is with regret that I and my Ph.D. sponsor & psychology historian Edgar E. Coons just learned of the recent death of Dr. Mortimer Feinberg. He along with Drs. Alfred J. Morrow, Milton L. Blum, Raymond Katzell, and Milton Richlin all received their doctorate training in industrial/ organization psychology under the guidance of my father, Douglas H. Fryer, at New York University in the years 1937-1955. As such, they along with Dr. Fryer were pioneering trail-blazers in establishing this field. Mort, in leaving this world, serves as the luminary close to that passing parade. To us, at least as poignantly, he was a very dear friend. Our sympathies go to his family... Dr. Sarah Fryer Leibowitz, Rockefeller University 1/3
LIEBERMAN--Evelyn. Sister, aunt, cousin, friend, mentor. Rose's daughter. Generous to a fault. Funny. Always Evie. You have no idea how much you will be missed. xxoo. The Simonowitz Family 1/3

VERNON--Lillian, on December 14, 2015. Founder and Chairwoman of Lillian Vernon Corporation. Beloved wife of Paolo Martino. Devoted mother of Fred and David Hochberg. Services Wednesday, 10am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3
SCHECHNER--Kenneth S. 12/16/56-12/23/97. Sadly missed, lovingly remem- bered. Your Loving Family 1/3

Katherine Farley, Chairman Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. 1/3

Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 17, 2015.

BLUM--Susan, a woman of strong opinions and conviction, passed away on December 14th. Beloved wife of Michael. Beloved sister, sister- in-law, aunt, and cherished friend of many. Susan was a Professional Educator at The Professional Children's School, Little Red Schoolhouse, and the Town School. She was a Board Member of Breakthrough New York. Services will be on Thursday, December 17th at 11am at Central Synagogue, New York. Did you know her father was a Veterinarian? 1/3

MILLER--Barbara Brady, of Old Brookville, NY on December 13, 2015 age 92. Wife of the late Edward M. Daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Gage Brady Jr. Mother of Edward M. Jr. (Louise), Christopher C. (Elizabeth), Karen M. Marchini (Richard), Michael B. and the late Gage W. (Jodi). Dear sister of the late Beverly Roche. Grandmother of Jennifer, Richard Jr., Copeland, Brian, Michael, Edward M. III, Brady, Kaitlin, Megan, Danielle and Madison. "Mom" to David Kaliff. Mass at St. Patrick RC Church, Glen Cove on Saturday, December 19th at 10:15am. Interment St. Patrick Cemetery, Brookville. Donations to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. www.DodgeThomas.com 1/3

FEINBERG--Mortimer R. It is with regret that I and my Ph.D. sponsor & psychology historian Edgar E. Coons just learned of the recent death of Dr. Mortimer Feinberg. He along with Drs. Alfred J. Morrow, Milton L. Blum, Raymond Katzell, and Milton Richlin all received their doctorate training in industrial/ organization psychology under the guidance of my father, Douglas H. Fryer, at New York University in the years 1937-1955. As such, they along with Dr. Fryer were pioneering trail-blazers in establishing this field. Mort, in leaving this world, serves as the luminary close to that passing parade. To us, at least as poignantly, he was a very dear friend. Our sympathies go to his family... Dr. Sarah Fryer Leibowitz, Rockefeller University 1/3
SCHULSKY--Alexander. Dad, thanks for sharing wonderful memories with me. Steve 1/3

STEINBERG--Arnold. The entire Marlboro Music family mourns the loss of its dear friend, long-standing Treasurer and Trustee. He helped to guide Marlboro with wisdom and skill over his many years of service. He was a devoted music lover and a generous supporter. He will be dearly missed. We send deepest sympathy to Blema Steinberg and their family. 1/3
VERNON--Lillian, was a most beloved friend of the Creative Time family. A true innovator and supporter of artists, her presence, vision and inspiration will be missed immensely. 1/3

CANTOR--Julie. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the loss of our long-time, dedicated member, Julie Cantor, beloved wife of Charlie Cantor. We will miss her caring and devotion to her family, friends and our synagogue. Our deepest condolences to Charlie, their daughters, Deborah and Margo, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Martin Flumenbaum, President 1/3

O'MALLEY--Pamela, on December 15th, 2015 of Forest Hills, NY. Wife of the late George O'Malley. Devoted mother of George (Tracy) and Christopher (Susan). Loving grandmother of Mary and Meghan as well as Robert, John and James. Pamela is survived by her mother Jeanne Prine, eight brothers and sisters; as well as many cousins, nieces and nephews. Visiting hours at Fox Funeral Home, Inc. Forest Hills, Thursday, 7-9pm and Friday, 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Mercy Church on Saturday at 9:30am. Interment Saint John Cemetery. 1/3

BRUML--Lois, born on June 13, 1928. Died peacefully at home on Saturday, December 12, 2015. Lois filled her life with music, poetry and the arts, while seeing the beauty in everything and everyone. She is survived by her family, with whom she shared her incredible passion for life. Our hearts will be with you forever. May you rest in peace. 1/3

VERNON--Lillian, trailblazer, leader, visionary, a transformational woman who achieved greatness in business, but should be remembered also for her wonderful spirit, gusto, generosity, decency and for never forgetting her roots. Lillian's shinning spirit ended just as Chanukah, the Jewish Festival of Lights concluded, but her radiance cannot be extinguished and will forever be with us. May Paolo, Fred, David, Tom and all those who loved Lillian be comforted at this time. Suri Kasirer & Bruce Teitelbaum 1/3

TABACKMAN--Dr. Albert M.,a renowned osteopath, died of pancreatic cancer on December 16, 2015 at home in Charlottesville, VA at the age of 72. He was born on June 9, 1943 to Max and Ethelda Tabackman and grew up on 79th Street, working at their Womrath's Bookstore. He attended Camp Moosilauke every summer, his home away from home. He graduated from the Bronx High School of Science in 1960 before attending Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Cooper Union School of Architecture, and Concord College of Athens, WV. He received his medical degree from the West Virginia School of Osteopathic Medicine in 1982, where he taught for five years. He had a green thumb, a warm heart, healing hands, and a profound love of nature and learning. A renaissance man, he was an accomplished physician, medical researcher, artist, builder, and business owner. He was partner and co-founder, with his wife, of Quilts Unlimited for 35 years. Dr. Tabackman is survived by his wife, Joan Fenton, his three children Ephraim Tabackman, Noa Summerfield, and Max Tabackman Fenton, and by his seven grandchildren, the youngest of whom was born earlier this month. A funeral is scheduled for 10am at Monticello Memory Gardens in Charlottesville, VA on Friday, December 18, 2015. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the American Museum of Natural History or the Bronx High School of Science Endowment Fund. 1/3
