TESSEL--Stanley, 86, of Boca Raton, FL, passed away on Monday, December 7th, 2015 at his beloved home in the Catskill Mountains of Sullivan County, NY. He is survived by his two children, Carol and Michael Tessel, their mother, Bonnie Tessel, and his life partner of 23 years, Sharon Kewley. He also has a newborn grandson, Charles. He was entombed in City of Boca Raton Mausoleum on Friday, December 11, 2015 with full military honors by the Air Force Honor Guard. Glick Family Funeral Home of Boca Raton oversaw the arrangements. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a donation be made in his memory to The Callicoon Center Volunteer Fire Dept, General Delivery, Callicoon Center, NY 12724. Stanley was born in Brooklyn, NY on November 9, 1929 to Ann Selikoff and Abraham Tessel. Stanley graduated from Brooklyn Law School and was admitted to the New York State Bar in 1952, retiring from the New York State Bar in 2014, 62 years later. He was admitted to argue in front of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court in October 1952 and the United States Supreme Court in April 1957. Stanley joined the U.S. Air Force as a Judge Advocate and served through the remainder of the Korean War in Pusan. He earned the rank of Major, once state side he was stationed out of Stewart Air Base in Newberg, NY and continued to serve in the reserves until 1972. Throughout his life, he maintained a fierce pride in his military service and his country. Following his service, Stanley entered private law practice in New York City. He established his own firm with Bernard Turkewitz (Turkewitz & Tessel). Stanley later became a named partner at Kramer, Dilloff, Tessel, Duffy & Moore (now Kramer, Dilloff, Livingston & Moore). He specialized in personal injury law, with a focus on obstetrical medical malpractice. Stanley pioneered the successful litigation of medical malpractice suits involving babies born with brain damage due to medical negligence. In partnership with the Law Journal Seminars, a division of American Lawyer Media, Inc. he co-authored several versions of the book Diagnosis and Treatment of Fetal Distress with Stephen H. Mackauf, J.D., of Gair, Gair and Conason, they toured the country giving lectures in the 1990's on the subject. Bernard Nathenson, M.D., also spoke during these popular seminars. Stanley retired from full-time work and moved to South Florida in 1989. He continued to consult for his former firm, flying regularly from Florida to New York to depose witnesses before trial, along with giving the Law Journal Seminars. Notable cases Stanley did the depositions on were: Libby Zion http://www.washingtonpost. com/wp-dyn/content/article/ 2006/11/24/AR2006112400985. html. Stanley was a consummate gentleman, treating everyone with respect and dignity. Attorneys were amazed when their doctor clients would get up at the end of a deposition and shake Stanley's hand. It was said around the office that a Stanley Tessel deposition was like money in the bank. He also pursued his passion for travel, exploring all seven continents. He read the New York Times every morning and his Sundays were devoted to the crossword puzzles, the New York Giants and Chinese food. Throughout his life, he fondly collected carved wood art, rare coins and precious ceramics. Stanley will be remembered for his walking at a New York clip, endless generosity and winning smile. He provided all those he loved, particularly his children, with the resources to pursue meaningful educational and personal enrichment. Stanley's mottos on living a fulfilling life: Always have something to look forward to, keep planning and dreaming. And: Don't just live on this earth, go out and make a difference that you were here. Stanley made a difference. He will be sincerely missed. 1/3

BONOFF--Amy. We note with sorrow the passing of our member, Amy Bonoff and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

VARLEY--H. Paul, Jr.,84, of Woodland Park, NJ, on December 15, 2015. Paul received a B.S Degree from Lehigh University in 1952, a M.A. Degree from Columbia University in 1961, and a Ph.D, from Columbia University in 1964. Paul was Professor Emeritus of Japanese History, Department of East Asian Languages and Culture at Columbia University, New York, from 1965 to 1993. Later he was the Sen Soshitsu XV Professor of Japanese Cultural History, Department of History, University of Hawaii, Honolulu, retiring in 2008. In 1996 he received The Order of the Rising Star, Gold Rays with Rosette, from the Government of Japan. Husband of Betty Jane (Geiskopf). Father of Sharyn Hennen, and the late Donna Lee Varley. Memorial Gathering Saturday 2-4pm at the Shook Funeral Home, 639 Van Houten Ave., Clifton, NJ. www.ShookFH.com 1/3

PUGH--Richard C.,86, passed away at his home in Thousand Oaks, CA on December 5, 2015. Dick is survived by his wife of 61 years, Nan, children, Richard Jr., Andrew and Catherine, sister, Charlotte, and seven grandchildren. He served in the US Navy and had a distinguished career as a lawyer and law professor in New York and San Diego. His family, friends and former students and colleagues will miss his intelligence, warmth and sense of humor. 1/3

DENZER--Mary Jane, died on December 16, 2015, after a long illness. She was born on April 11, 1932 in New York City and grew up in Woodmere, Long Island. She was the devoted, loving wife of her late husband, Alan R. Denzer, sister of the late Willard F. Greenwald Jr., daughter of Nellie and Willard F. Greenwald, mother of Cathryn, Peter, Thomas, Holly, and stepmother of Alan Jr., Diane and Richard. She attended Abbott Academy and Wheaton College. She began her career as a fashion model at Saks Fifth Ave, worked for Diners Club, and later for Bergdorf Goodman. In 1979, she was invited to partner in business with a customer and launched Denzer Moran, a women's clothing store in Mamaroneck, NY, and one year later opened the eponymous Mary Jane Denzer Ltd., an internationally acclaimed destination for luxury, couture and designer apparel and special occasion shopping in White Plains, NY. In 2014, after twenty years at the corner of Mamaroneck and Maple Avenues, she fulfilled her dream of opening a world-class shop in the newly developed Renaissance Square, adjacent to the Ritz-Carlton, Westchester. As a mother, she leaves behind a legacy of strong, independent children, as well as her loving grandchildren, Avery, Haley, Oliver, Noah, Linus, Nina, Tyler and Logan. She was a businesswoman and a fashion icon, one who strove for perfection, made friends around the world, and gave many important new designers their start. Blazing a trail for women of her generation, she raised a large family and reached the pinnacle of her profession, beloved by her many friends and relatives and her dog Bodhi. Her philanthropic interests included Channel 13, National Hemophilia Foundation, Pediatric Cancer Foundation, Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, the American Heart Association and White Plains Hospital. The interment will be private. A reception will be scheduled at a later date. Donations in her honor may be sent to White Plains Hospital. 1/3

SCOTTO-- Madeline T.,(nee Porpora), preeminent educator, age 101, on December 16, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Francis A. for 56 years. The proud and loving mother of Josephine Cummings, Marie Rizzi, Raphael, Louis and Michele. Cherished grandmother of nine, great- grandmother of 16. A gracious, loving, compassionate, elegant woman of faith, devoted to her family, parish and students. Her warmth and wisdom were a precious gift to all who knew her. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Mother Seton Academy, 2215 Greenmount Ave., Baltimore, MD 21218 or St. Ephrem School. Visiting at McLaughlin & Sons, 9620 3rd Ave., Brooklyn, NY on Saturday and Sunday, 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, 10:30am, St. Ephrem Church, Brooklyn. 1/3

CRAWFORD--Louise D. July 13, 1927 -- December 11, 2015. Beloved wife of Peter H. Crawford. Cherished by son Jamie Gilroy, daughter Catherine (Richard) Eby, and grandson Cole. ESL teacher, talented watercolorist who painted NYC street scenes as well as sights on her travels including many throughout France. Enthusiastic origamist and pianist. She was always bright and cheerful, had a warm spirit and grand sense of humor. She was much-loved by those who knew her. Donations to National Arts Club would be appreciated. 1/3

KAPLEN--Alexander, on December 16, 2015. Cherished son of Jean, (nee Arbus), and the late Bill Kaplen (Maggie). Dear brother of Lawrence (Veronica) and the late Michael. Loving uncle of Benjamin. Alexander held a Harvard B.A. and a Yale LLB. He was also a writer and editor at New Yorker Magazine and a founder of Wigwag magazine, as well as a speech writer for Walter Mondale, Al Gore and Bill Clinton. He was active in many philanthropic and charitable organizations; as well as a Board member of WYNC Radio and the Film Forum. Also, he was very active with New York Presbyterian Hospital, PEN and the New York Philharmonic. Services will be held on Sunday, December 20, 2015 at the Workmen's Circle #

POLLACK--Lester. Bank Leumi USA deeply mourns the loss of former esteemed director, Lester Pollack. Lester joined the board of directors in December 2000 and served until April 2009. Over the years, Lester held a number of leadership roles with an array of prestigious organizations. Lester brought exceptional wisdom to his role as a director. We are forever grateful for his service as an integral member of our board during both difficult times and successes. He will be dearly missed. 1/3

PACHMAN--Arnold M. Died December 15, 2015, one day shy of his 78th birthday. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Susan Pachman, son Marc Pachman, daughter Lisa Goldberg, daughter-in-law Dr. Tara Stoinski, and grandchildren Samantha, Brenna, Rylee and Payton. He was predeceased by son, Andrew Pachman. Donations in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, for which he was a devoted volunteer. 1/3

BACKER--Terry. The board and staff of Waterkeeper Alliance and 274 Waterkeeper organizations worldwide mourn the loss of Long Island Soundkeeper and Connecticut State Legislator, Terry Backer. A fearless advocate, Terry was a Waterkeeper Alliance founder and board member as well as a fisherman, friend, father, son, hero and mentor. We honor Terry's larger- than-life spirit and are grateful for his tireless dedication to the fight for clean water and making a difference for future generations. Terry's memory and work will live on through the movement he inspired, and we send our heartfelt sympathy and support to his family at this sad time. 1/3

FEINBERG--Mortimer R. It is with regret that I and my Ph.D. sponsor & psychology historian Edgar E. Coons just learned of the recent death of Dr. Mortimer Feinberg. He along with Drs. Alfred J. Morrow, Milton L. Blum, Raymond Katzell, and Milton Richlin all received their doctorate training in industrial/ organization psychology under the guidance of my father, Douglas H. Fryer, at New York University in the years 1937-1955. As such, they along with Dr. Fryer were pioneering trail-blazers in establishing this field. Mort, in leaving this world, serves as the luminary close to that passing parade. To us, at least as poignantly, he was a very dear friend. Our sympathies go to his family... Dr. Sarah Fryer Leibowitz, Rockefeller University 1/3

GOLDMAN--Michael I.,died December 6 at his home in Highland Beach, FL, surrounded by his loving family. Born in Brooklyn, NY on February 28, 1944. Son of Rose and Phil M. Goldman. His lifelong passion and vocation began as an office boy for NASA, teaching himself how to program. Working in many aspects of the computer industry, he became a leader in the field of client server technology. He was founder and CEO of PC Strategy and Solutions of Parsippany, NJ, a national computer consulting and training company. He is survived by his wife, Esther, of 49 years, daughter, Debra, son, David and brother, Marc. Beloved by his brother-in-law, sisters-in-law, nieces, nephews and all those who treasured his generous nature and friendship. 1/3
DENZER--Mary Jane. To the most divine sister, aunt and friend. Your star will shine in our hearts forever. With love, Janie, Toni, Stan & Laurie 1/3

WILK-HARRIS--Ellen. Our wonderful life together ended one year ago today but your words and deeds remain strong within me. What a love of life you had. To find someone like you is the reason we draw breath. Love, Rogie 1/3

GATES--Frances Thomas. Died December 15, 2015 at Jefferson's Ferry retirement community where she had lived since 2002. The last surviving child of Violet and Norman Thomas, she was born in New York City June 28, 1915. She left Smith College after her sophomore year to marry her beloved Jack (John W. Gates), who predeceased her in 2006 after 71 happy years. They had three children and spent most of their lives on Long Island, but for a twelve year hiatus in St. Thomas, USVI where they were wildly popular with the locals and anyone who wanted to visit. She was predeceased by her son John in 2012. She is survived by her daughter, Nancy Gerber, and her son Norman; grandchildren Anne, Thomas and Jenny Gerber; great-grandchildren Kaitlyn, Lauren and Julia Gerber. She advocated for gun control, reproductive rights, civil rights, universal health care and environmental efforts to save the planet. She believed that all children have an inalienable right to food, shelter and good public education, to which end she served as an elected member of the school board that conceived, realized and built the Cold Spring Harbor High School. She and Susan Lassen co-founded the Hunger & Outreach Committee of St. John's Church, whose members she loved to the end. While in St. Thomas she taught dyslexic children how to read. She had fun. She was a lot of fun. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to any of the causes she espoused or to the Hunger & Outreach Committee, St. John's Church, P.O. Box 266, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY on January 9, 2016 at 11am. 1/3

KAPLEN--Alexander. The Board of Trustees and staff of New York Public Radio mourn the loss of Alexander (Lex) Kaplen. Lex became a NYPR Trustee in 1997 and served in many influential leadership positions, including as Vice Chair of the Board (from 2009 to 2013). He was deeply committed to NYPR's mission to provide outstanding journalism and music. With extraordinary passion, he ensured that NYPR would always stand for excellence and he will have a lasting legacy. We extend our deepest condolences to the Kaplen family. Cynthia King Vance, Chair Laura R. Walker, President and CEO 1/3

BAUMAN--Martin H.,died peacefully on December 16 at the age of 85. As President and Founder of Martin H. Bauman Associates, a prominent Executive Recruiting firm that was in business for 42 years, Martin had the reputation for bringing careful study and detailed analysis to every project he undertook. Research at NYU under Dr. Peter Drucker, the founder of modern management, showed that there was a poor correlation between the interview process and how candidates actually performed on the job. Martin became an executive recruiter and was the first person to develop an assessment process of potential candidates that not only included testing, but his own innovative self-concept method. After more than 40 years, the results were clear - over 96% of candidates placed by Martin H. Bauman Associates were still on the job after one year, while the industry average for recruiting firms was 67%. In 1992, Martin was inducted into the Executive Search Hall of Fame as one of the top recruiters in the U. S. Martin's competence and integrity brought him to the top of the industry, working with Presidents, Chairmen, and Managing Directors of companies that included Merrill Lynch, Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, AT&T, FedEx, Colgate-Palmolive, Revlon, and every major transportation company, including airlines, shipping and trucking firms. The son of Rose and Jack Bauman, Martin grew up in the Bronx, and attended New York University for all his studies. His graduate research, under Dr. Peter Drucker, focused on the Behavioral Sciences. Over the course of his career, Martin lectured at The New York University Management Institute and was an Associate Professor at Pace University. Courses taught included Advanced Management, Behavioral Sciences, Human Resources Management, and Interviewing. His speaking engagements included Fortune 500 companies and he published over 20 articles about executive search, management, and the interview process. Martin contracted polio in the Army in the 1950s at the age of 23, and attended college through the G.I. Bill. In 2000, he established the Martin H. Bauman Scholarship Fund for Handicapped Students at New York University. As a survivor of polio, he was intimately aware of the challenges that handicapped people face every day, and felt that an education was one of the most important goals that should be available to all. Martin impacted the lives of many, many people in his business life and in his personal life. Placing people in jobs was an art form that demanded an expertise in social and psychological behaviors. He always said that in addition to having the technical aspects for a job, you had to "have the right fit on all levels." He taught young employees by example. For the one year in the company's history that was not profitable, his employees voluntarily took a 10% cut in salary (so no one would have to be let go); Martin did not take a salary that year. Some ex-employees went on to form their own companies, and some are now Principals and Partners in firms. He was a good teacher and a man of integrity. Martin was preceded in death by his first wife, Carol. He is survived by his two children, John and Elizabeth, his sister, Thelma Greenstein, his wife, Sherry and her children, Christopher Connor and Laura Connor O'Sullivan, and his step-grandchildren, Thomas, Claire, and Maeve O'Sullivan. Donations can be made in Martin's name to his scholarship fund. Checks should be made out to New York University, noting the scholarship name in the memo area (Martin H. Bauman Scholarship Fund for Handicapped Students), and sent to NYU, Development & Alumni Relations, 44 West 4th Street, Suite 10-160, New York, NY 10012. Funeral Services will be held on December 18 at 9:30am at Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021. Burial will be at Beth Moses Cemetery, Wellwood Avenue, Farmingdale, NY 11735. The family will sit Shiva from 1pm until 4pm on Friday, December 18 at the Bauman home in Sands Point. 1/3

WASSNER--Diane. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of Mrs. Diane Wassner, Z"l, the beloved wife of the late I. Robert Wassner, Z"l, who together were deeply devoted to the cause of Jewish education. A Holocaust survivor, she understood the importance of Jewish education and provided generous support for deserving and needy students at the university. In recognition of her largesse Yeshiva University conferred upon her an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters degree in 2012. She was a Yeshiva University Benefactor. Diane Wassner served as National Vice President and a member of the Executive Council of YUWO and a founding member of the President's Society for Torah Chesed, and the Torah Chesed Fund of YUWO and the Future Builders that provides monthly stipends to needy students. Her dedication to Jewish education and her leadership and commitment to Jewish causes was evidenced by her generous support of many worthy causes and institutions in North America and Israel. Diane Wassner will be sorely missed. May all who were privileged to know her be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President of Yeshiva University Norman Lamm, President Emeritus National Presidium of YUWO Michele Hering Yosefa Knoll Michele Salig Debbie Schwartz Dinah Pinczower, National President Emeritus of YUWO 1/3

LEIFER--Anna, on September 19, 2015. Beloved wife of Seymour. Devoted, loving and dear mother of Marvin, Jane and Carol. Fond grandmother of Jennifer and Michael Leifer, Rachel Lampert and Bruno Wolf. Services were held at Old Montefiore Cemetery. Donations in her memory may be made to Orange County Hospice, Tustin, CA. 1/3

INGAL--Susan, was raised in Long Island and came of age in Brooklyn where she was married and began raising her family. After graduating from Hofstra University she earned her Master's Degree in Special Education from The City College of New York and participated in the early renaissance of the New York City Public Schools at PS 261. Susan loved teaching and found fulfillment in her children and pursuing her educational career. In 1995 after moving to Chatham, New Jersey she taught at the Harding Township School where she remained for 19 years. She loved her husband, her children, her Harding Kids and Colleagues, and her dogs. Not necessarily in that order. She was a devoted Ranger, opera, theater and crossword puzzle fan. She didn't mind shopping either. She is survived by her loving husband David, her children Alex, Samuel, Robert, Claire and Eve. As well as her mother Anne, brother Robert and nieces, Madison, Veronica, Caroline and Hannah. In Susan's memory, the family asks that donations be made to the Susan M. Ingal Memorial Scholarship Fund c/o Harding Township School 34 Lees Hill Rd. New Vernon, NJ 07976. 1/3

VORIDIS--Doda. The board of Venetian Heritage Inc. mourns the loss of its founding board member Doda Goulandris Voridis. Doda was a great supporter of numerous New York City and international cultural organizations. Her loyalty to us and her love of Venice was exemplary. She will be dearly missed. Lawrence Lovett, Founding Chairman Pierre Durand, Chairman and President Mrs. Donald K. Miller, Vice Chairman 1/3

SANDS--Donna Lynn. April 9, 1964-- December 11, 2008. Light of our lives, always in our thoughts, you are greatly missed. Mom, Richard Sands, Michael & Svetlana, Isabelle Donna, age 5 & Daniel Henry Sands 20 months. 1/3

COVILLE--Mark P.,of New Hope, Pennsylvania, passed away on December 10. Mark is survived by his wife, Lynda (nee Coombs), his children, Candace and David, and his sister, Brenda Coville. Mark was a direct descendant of William Bradford from the Mayflower. Mark was born in Enid, Oklahoma. He graduated from O'Fallon High School in Illinois and the University of Connecticut, where he served on the board of the Business school. He was inducted into the Hall of Fame in 2013. Mark began a successful career in the financial services field with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. In his 25 years with Merrill Lynch, Mark held a variety of senior positions in Capital Markets and was instrumental in developing the international stock loan business. He oversaw the expansion of the business, both domestically and internationally in London. Upon his return, Mark was responsible for the development of the global securities lending business. He returned to London and oversaw the international sales team for Blackrock, merging the Blackrock and Merrill Lynch teams. He served on the board of The Sharing Network of New Jersey, the Red Cross, and The Wounded Warrior Project. Mark was a friend, mentor, colleague, and inspirational leader. A spring memorial is planned. Memorial donations may be made to the Wounded Warrior Project, Inc. www.woundedwarrior project.org 1/3

GOLDMAN--Michael I.,died December 6 at his home in Highland Beach, FL, surrounded by his loving family. Born in Brooklyn, NY on February 28, 1944. Son of Rose and Phil M. Goldman. His lifelong passion and vocation began as an office boy for NASA, teaching himself how to program. Working in many aspects of the computer industry, he became a leader in the field of client server technology. He was founder and CEO of PC Strategy and Solutions of Parsippany, NJ, a national computer consulting and training company. He is survived by his wife, Esther, of 49 years, daughter, Debra, son, David and brother, Marc. Beloved by his brother-in-law, sisters-in-law, nieces, nephews and all those who treasured his generous nature and friendship. 1/3

SINGER--Paul, DDS. April 15, 1919 - November 29, 2015. Captain United States Army 1943-1945; Master dentist, gardener, potter, joke teller, world traveler. Committed anti-war activist. Beloved husband of 71 years to Geraldine (Behrman) Singer. Proud father to Meryl (Michael), Stephen (Marcy), Eric (Julie) and grandfather to Julie, Eliza, Megan, Ellis. Delighted great-grandfather to Nathaniel, Louisa, Jonas. An Extraordinary Man. 1/3

POLLACK--Lester. Bank Leumi USA deeply mourns the loss of former esteemed director, Lester Pollack. Lester joined the board of directors in December 2000 and served until April 2009. Over the years, Lester held a number of leadership roles with an array of prestigious organizations. Lester brought exceptional wisdom to his role as a director. We are forever grateful for his service as an integral member of our board during both difficult times and successes. He will be dearly missed. 1/3

MUNKELT--Albert G.,died earlier this year in Wilton, CT. Beloved husband Of the late Marjorie Starry and beloved father of Brooks (Zita) and Suzanne. He was born April 21, 1918 in New Britain, CT. Son of Albert Ernst Munkelt and Helen Gleason, he grew up in Brooklyn, NY. Albert attended Harvard, Rutgers and received a B.S. in business administration from NYU. He worked at Pillsbury and Wheatena before serving in the Army Air Force in WWII. After being honorably discharged as captain, Albert worked for the Veteran's Administration then joined the new company Minute Maid which was later bought by Coca-Cola. He became senior Vice President and head of marketing for the Coca-Cola Foods Division. He worked for the company for 35 years. Albert loved sports, traveling and reading. He was smart, funny and a true gentleman. He is missed. 1/3

CAPLAN--David R. David R. Caplan, 90, died at home December 10, 2015. David was born on March 11, 1925 in St. Louis, Missouri, son of Ralph Caplan and Helene Lowenstein Caplan. He was the beloved husband of Barbara Rudolph Caplan for 63 years and the father of Nancy, Amy, David Jr., Patty and Tom Caplan. He is also survived by his sons-in-law Geoffrey Lewis and Jonathan Simonoff, and grandchildren Samantha and Jessica Lewis, Danny and Sarah Caplan, and Emma and Jason Simonoff. He leaves behind his dear sister Shirley and her children Richard Nathan, Jill Hyman and Beth Russ and nieces Diane Caplan, Kathy Peck, and nephew John Caplan. David grew up in Peoria, Illinois. He became an avid tennis player, which remained one of his lifetime passions. He was a permanent fixture at the U.S. Open tennis championship in New York City. He served proudly in the US Navy during World War II, becoming a Lieutenant on the aircraft carrier USS Kadashan Bay. He attended Notre Dame University and Washington University in St. Louis. David worked for over 50 years in the textile and apparel industries. He began his career as a textile converter and went on to run Concord Fabrics, Evan Picone Sportwear, and HeadSport. David was honored three times as the Textile Man of the Year. He founded Metro Fabrics in 1985 and remained at the helm until selling the company in 2002. At this point, he launched full time into a career in public service. David loved children and believed passionately in public education and service. That passion brought him first to PENCIL (Public Education Needs Civic Involvement in Learning) where he served as a volunteer advisor to leadership. He then devoted his passion full time to City Year New York. David served on the Board and assumed the position of Dean. His work at CYNY spanned over 16 years. He was fundraiser extraordinaire, strategic advisor, ambassador, planner, mentor, and recruiter. He also had boots on the ground, visiting schools all over New York City, providing inspiration to members of the Corps, students, teachers and principals. David's other driving passion was his beloved WNYC, New York Public Radio where he served on the Board for over 25 years. Over the years, David played many other philanthropic roles including board member of the Fashion Institute of Technology, the March of Dimes, and the American Friends of Tel Aviv University. Donations in his honor can be made to City Year New York and WNYC/New York Public Radio. 1/3

SINGH--Aditya (A. K.), of Meridian Township. Born October 17, 1946, passed away Friday, December 11, 2015 due to rapid illness. He was predeceased by his parents and is survived by his brother, Anant, and other close relatives. He started his business career with IBM as a Systems Engineer in Detroit, MI and later as a Planner in Dallas, TX. After completing his PhD. at Michigan State University, he started his teaching career at Heidelberg University in Ohio and later at Penn State. He had a great intellect, curiosity and compassion for others and a wonderful spirit, gusto, generosity, decency and never forgetting his roots. He will be dearly missed. May he rest in eternal peace. 1/3

LEE--Yauling. November 21, 1937 - December 13, 2015. Beloved mother of Chien "Danny" Kwok and Agnes Lai; grandma of Ethan and Nicole; sister of surviving sisters Li Chi Ling, Lie Mon Ling, Lie Tong Ling and brothers Lie Thay Djong, Lie Ken Hong. Funeral: December 23, 9:30am-11:30am, Chinese Wai Lah Funeral Home, 22 Mulberry St., NY, NY 10013. 1/3

GORDON--Kenny. KG, 17 years have passed and while we miss you more than words can describe, the wonderful memories we shared together cannot fade. The love, laughter and joy you brought to our lives and all who knew you still brightens our days. All our love, Mom, Dad, Jonny, Catherine, Kenya, Chloe & Baby Gemma 1/3

TENEN--Jack J.,92, on December 17, 2015. Survived by his beloved spouse Lisa Miller, devoted daughters Jaye and Paula (Donald) Squires, and step-grandchildren Sydney, Nathan, and Noah. For service info www.jewish- funeral-home.com. 1/3

HARRIS--Faith Evelyn, died December 18, 2015 after a brief illness. She is mourned by sons Ben, Matt and Tim, as well as by Bonnie, Katie, Spencer, Carol and Lindsay. We love you, Mom. Funeral services are private. The family will receive visitors at the home of Matt and Bonnie Harris, Tuesday, 5-7:30pm. 1/3
VERNON-- Lillian. Town Hall Foundation Trustees and Staff mourns the passing of our 2007 Friend of The Arts Awardee Lillian Vernon. 1/3

HOFFMAN--Dr. Burton Paul, a retired orthopedic surgeon who practiced in White Plains, NY, died peacefully on December 14, 2015, two days before his 96th birthday. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he did his medical training at NYU and Joint Diseases Hospital. Throughout his professional life, he resided in Scarsdale, NY. He was married for 50 years to Betty Kornfeld of Philadelphia, PA. They had three sons: Jeffrey, residing in Boston, MA; Robert, residing in Berkeley, CA; and David, residing in Wellesley, MA. After Betty's death in 1992, he married Carolyn Laev Kagan, of Milwaukee, WI. During most of the 20 years prior to Carolyn's death, they resided in Milwaukee. He spent his last years in Boston. Burt Hoffman was an active runner, skier, sailor, mountaineer and golfer who loved to travel all over the world. Physically fit throughout his life, he completed the New York Marathon at age 70. Besides his three sons, he is survived by six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at Sharon Gardens in the Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY on January 3, 2016. Remembrance notes are requested in lieu of flowers. 1/3

EISINGER--Samuel. Born December 20, 1915 Happy 100th Birthday Beloved Father, Grandfather and Great-Grandfather. You are forever in our hearts. We love you and miss you and think of you every day. Give Emme kisses from all of us and send all of our love to our Angel in Heaven. 1/3

BRUML--Lois, born on June 13, 1928. Died peacefully at home on Saturday, December 12, 2015. Lois filled her life with music, poetry and the arts, while seeing the beauty in everything and everyone. She is survived by her family, with whom she shared her incredible passion for life. Our hearts will be with you forever. May you rest in peace. 1/3
LUBITZ--Lew. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed Member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. 1/3

BRAZIER--Alan, on December 7, a British sculptor and resident of Manhattan. Born to the late Derek Frank Brazier and Beryl Mavis Brazier (nee Coles) of Hitchin, Hertfordshire (UK); Alan studied at Arts University College, Bournemouth and Weymouth College under master stonemason, John Selman. Moving to London, and inspired by ancient carving, Rodin and Gaudier-Brzeska, he began creating uniquely expressive sculptural works. He debuted in the 1985 exhibition, Humanism In British Art at the Royal Festival Hall, Southbank, London. In 1988, Alan moved to New York, where he continued reinventing the sculptural form. His work can be found in notable private and public collections worldwide. For more information please see his website: alanbrazier.com Survived by his wife, Tonia Hsu, his sisters, Sandie Smith, Kate Asquith, Zoe Grant, and their children. Funeral services conducted by Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), NYC (www.frankecampbell.com). 1/3
CASHEL--Robert F. Nov. 3, 1924 - Dec. 16, 2014 We remember you and miss you every day. You are in our hearts forever. All our love. Lemina, Maya, Cameron & Barry 1/3

KAPLEN--Alexander. The staff and board of Film Forum are deeply saddened by the loss of Lex. He was a passionate lover of all things cinematic. He would show up at old movies and new ones, give us the benefit of his always smart and thoughtful advice, and warm our hearts with his charm, generosity, and appreciation. Rarely does someone arrive so unexpectedly into one's life, make huge changes for the better, and then leave so abruptly. We will miss him terribly. Karen Cooper and Bruce Goldstein 1/3

TESSEL--Stanley, 86, of Boca Raton, FL, passed away on Monday, December 7th, 2015 at his beloved home in the Catskill Mountains of Sullivan County, NY. He is survived by his two children, Carol and Michael Tessel, their mother, Bonnie Tessel, and his life partner of 23 years, Sharon Kewley. He also has a newborn grandson, Charles. He was entombed in City of Boca Raton Mausoleum on Friday, December 11, 2015 with full military honors by the Air Force Honor Guard. Glick Family Funeral Home of Boca Raton oversaw the arrangements. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a donation be made in his memory to The Callicoon Center Volunteer Fire Dept, General Delivery, Callicoon Center, NY 12724. Stanley was born in Brooklyn, NY on November 9, 1929 to Ann Selikoff and Abraham Tessel. Stanley graduated from Brooklyn Law School and was admitted to the New York State Bar in 1952, retiring from the New York State Bar in 2014, 62 years later. He was admitted to argue in front of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court in October 1952 and the United States Supreme Court in April 1957. Stanley joined the U.S. Air Force as a Judge Advocate and served through the remainder of the Korean War in Pusan. He earned the rank of Major, once state side he was stationed out of Stewart Air Base in Newberg, NY and continued to serve in the reserves until 1972. Throughout his life, he maintained a fierce pride in his military service and his country. Following his service, Stanley entered private law practice in New York City. He established his own firm with Bernard Turkewitz (Turkewitz & Tessel). Stanley later became a named partner at Kramer, Dilloff, Tessel, Duffy & Moore (now Kramer, Dilloff, Livingston & Moore). He specialized in personal injury law, with a focus on obstetrical medical malpractice. Stanley pioneered the successful litigation of medical malpractice suits involving babies born with brain damage due to medical negligence. In partnership with the Law Journal Seminars, a division of American Lawyer Media, Inc. he co-authored several versions of the book Diagnosis and Treatment of Fetal Distress with Stephen H. Mackauf, J.D., of Gair, Gair and Conason, they toured the country giving lectures in the 1990's on the subject. Bernard Nathenson, M.D., also spoke during these popular seminars. Stanley retired from full-time work and moved to South Florida in 1989. He continued to consult for his former firm, flying regularly from Florida to New York to depose witnesses before trial, along with giving the Law Journal Seminars. Notable cases Stanley did the depositions on were: Libby Zion http://www.washingtonpost. com/wp-dyn/content/article/ 2006/11/24/AR2006112400985. html. Stanley was a consummate gentleman, treating everyone with respect and dignity. Attorneys were amazed when their doctor clients would get up at the end of a deposition and shake Stanley's hand. It was said around the office that a Stanley Tessel deposition was like money in the bank. He also pursued his passion for travel, exploring all seven continents. He read the New York Times every morning and his Sundays were devoted to the crossword puzzles, the New York Giants and Chinese food. Throughout his life, he fondly collected carved wood art, rare coins and precious ceramics. Stanley will be remembered for his walking at a New York clip, endless generosity and winning smile. He provided all those he loved, particularly his children, with the resources to pursue meaningful educational and personal enrichment. Stanley's mottos on living a fulfilling life: Always have something to look forward to, keep planning and dreaming. And: Don't just live on this earth, go out and make a difference that you were here. Stanley made a difference. He will be sincerely missed. 1/3

LAMBERT-MARARIAN-- Elizabeth December 16, 2015, age 52. Elizabeth enjoyed her life and was blessed to have wonderful experiences. While she unabashedly wanted more she reflected and was very content. Born in Buffalo, she inherited her father's wanderlust and moved to Hollywood in her early twenties. From there she went to Boston, San Francisco, New Orleans and finally to New York City where she and her husband, Michael, met on August 16, 2002 and where she had the best career experiences of her life as the visual director of the men's department at Macy's Herald Square. Michael was her soulmate, sticking with her after a cancer diagnoses only one week after asking her to marry him. Together and despite cancer, they shared adventures, vacations, and wonderful life experiences. She wishes everyone could be as lucky and blessed. She was preceded in death by her parents, William and Colleen (Canney) Lambert, her in- laws, Michael and Carmella Mararian and is survived by three brothers, William, Brian and Lawrence, her aunt Maureen and a niece, Addison, and a houseful of cats. 1/3

GATES--Frances Thomas. Died December 15, 2015 at Jefferson's Ferry retirement community where she had lived since 2002. The last surviving child of Violet and Norman Thomas, she was born in New York City June 28, 1915. She left Smith College after her sophomore year to marry her beloved Jack (John W. Gates), who predeceased her in 2006 after 71 happy years. They had three children and spent most of their lives on Long Island, but for a twelve year hiatus in St. Thomas, USVI where they were wildly popular with the locals and anyone who wanted to visit. She was predeceased by her son John in 2012. She is survived by her daughter, Nancy Gerber, and her son Norman; grandchildren Anne, Thomas and Jenny Gerber; great-grandchildren Kaitlyn, Lauren and Julia Gerber. She advocated for gun control, reproductive rights, civil rights, universal health care and environmental efforts to save the planet. She believed that all children have an inalienable right to food, shelter and good public education, to which end she served as an elected member of the school board that conceived, realized and built the Cold Spring Harbor High School. She and Susan Lassen co-founded the Hunger & Outreach Committee of St. John's Church, whose members she loved to the end. While in St. Thomas she taught dyslexic children how to read. She had fun. She was a lot of fun. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to any of the causes she espoused or to the Hunger & Outreach Committee, St. John's Church, P.O. Box 266, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY on January 9, 2016 at 11am. 1/3

FEIGELMAN--Victor, of NYC deceased December 17, 2015, age 89. Husband to the late Miriam Richman Feigelman; father to Theodor, Elizabeth, Susan, Paul; companion to Shirley Matza. WWII 76th Division. Former Deputy Chief Engineer, NYC Board of Water Supply, later DEP. Donations may be made to Jewish War Veterans. 1/3

LUBITZ--Lewis. He almost made it. Lewis Lubitz passed peacefully early Friday morning in Palm Beach at the age of 99 and five-sixths. He was the definition of the self-made person, rising from poverty to wealth and comfort early in life. He "retired" at 50 but continued to put together real estate deals until his last years. With his wife Sylvia he was a world-traveler, he counted celebrities such as Ed Sullivan and Bob Newhart as close friends, he once had to ask Meyer Lansky to suspend a contract on his life, he was the king of the gin game both upstairs at the Friars Club and by the cabanas of the Palm Beach Towers (back when that meant something), he wore far too much cologne even in his youth, lived for the act of palming maitre d's twenty dollar bills, and held on to a full head of striking silver hair until the end. He was a loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. If it is true, and it is, that we become our parents, who became their parents, who became theirs, then he is truly immortal. He will live every time we are obscenely generous to strangers, every time we turn an adversary into a friend, every time we are cunning and quick in business, and every time we are able to flash a contagiously charming smile that warms the room. He is survived by his sister Annie Klein, his daughter Sara Richter (Mort), his grandchildren Matthew (Holly), Daniel (Ann Marie), David (Anna), and great-grandchildren Izzy, Elliot, Bodhi, Teo, who loved him. Funeral services will be Sunday, December 20, 2015 at 11:00am at Quattlebaum Funeral, Cremation and Event Center with a graveside committal at 1:30pm at Star of David Cemetery. 1/3

JANOWITZ--Dr. Melvin F.,of Haworth, NJ, died December 8, 2015. Survived by Ms. Trudy Pirnie his companion and partner for 18 years, son Gerald Janowitz, daughter-in-law Juliet Janowitz, grandchildren Haven and Sonia, and other grandchildren. Among the specialties of his research in mathematics was Lattice Theory and Discrete Mathematics. He published two books and many papers in mathematics and travelled worldwide delivering lectures and his papers with his companion Ms. Trudy Pirnie alongside him. 1/3

WASSNER--Diane. We mourn the passing of Diane Wassner, z"l. Beloved wife of I. Robert, z"l, sister-in-law to Florence Wassner, loving aunt and great-aunt to her many nieces and nephews. Funeral was held on December 16, 2015. A Holocaust Survivor - Diane was a quintessential lady of nobility and spirit, who displayed fortitude, bravery and strong religious commitment throughout her life. She leaves a legacy of faith and generosity to many spiritual descendants whose lives she enriched. Aunt Diane, we will always cherish your memory and your sterling example will be forever etched in our hearts. The Wassner, Hager, Schwebel, Eisikowitz, Katlowitz & Shippel families 1/3
SAVIN--Robert S. 3/17/25 -12/18/14. Miss you and wish you were here. Always in our hearts. Your Loving Family 1/3

DRAPER--Robert E.,died on December 17, 2015 at the age of 93. He grew up in Brooklyn and graduated from Boys High in 1938. He enrolled in the Army in 1942, serving in the Signal Corps, and was honorably discharged in 1944. After a short stint as a wire salesman in Chicago, he returned to New York to start National Cable Company and upon its merger, became President of Nassau National Cable Co., at which he was active until his death. He was married in 1945 to Clarice Schwartz and leaves behind two sons, Alan and Douglas, three grandchildren, Morgan, Rachel and Samuel, and one great-grandchild, Marigny. He was an avid golfer and horseplayer, while also being engaged intensely in the political world around him. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to J Street at jstreet.org. 1/3

SPECTOR, Leonard Exter, age 88, passed away peacefully in Southampton, NY on December 12, 2015. Born December 8, 1927, Len is survived by his wife Martha, his children Jonathan, Amy, Nancy, and Matthew, and six grandchildren. Len was loved by so many, and he will remain in our hearts always. Contributions in Len's memory may be made to the Deer Isle Memorial Ambulance Corps, PO Box 387, Deer Isle, Maine 04627. 1/3
WILLNER--Alvin. We miss you. You are remembered with love. Jane (Harold), Jay (Jeanne), Stella. 1/3

BONOFF--Amy, 68. Full of exuberance, happiness and compassion, Amy passed away peacefully on December 17th after a long battle with cancer. Daughter of Maurice Linker, wife of Harris Jaffe, mother of Jennifer Koppel and Daniel Bonoff, stepmother of Morgan Jaffe, grandmother of Reese and Caroline Koppel and treasured by many more. Service on December 20 at Central Synagogue at 12pm. 1/3

KARP--Joyce Weisman, 90, passed away peacefully on December 18, 2015 surrounded by family. Hug your loved ones tight. Hey Cassy, she's on her way. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, December 20th at 2:30pm at Louis Memorial Chapel in Kansas City. Donations in her memory can be made to The American Technion Society (55 East 59th Street, NY, NY, 10022 or Guide Dogs of America (13445 Glenoaks Blvd, Sylmar, CA 91342). 1/3

HIRSCH--Marvin, 73, on December 17, 2015. Son of Knish King of Brooklyn (Hirsch's Knishes), Mano and Helen Hirsch. Beloved husband of Bonnie. Devoted father of David and Pamela, adored grandfather of Jacob, Emma and Levon. Cherished brother of Larry and Fran. Avid boater and Softball Hall of Famer. Partner, Flamhaft, Levy, Kamins, Hirsch and Rendiero. Service Sunday, December 20th, 11:15am, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

BOOTH--John T.,died December 13, 2015 at his home in Litchfield, CT after living a full and purposeful life. He was predeceased by his wife of 52 years, Anne Mott, and daughter Alison. He is survived by daughters Miven Booth Trageser (Eric) of Los Angeles; and Roxanna Booth Miller (Richard) of West Hartford; grandchildren Dominick John and Noelle Katherine Trageser and Scarlett Anne Cistulli and his sister Gracemary Greenleaf of Denver. John was born in New York, graduated from Deerfield Academy and Amherst College, served as an officer in the Korean War and later received his LLB from Harvard University. John then enjoyed 40 years in a successful career in law, finance and community service. Memorial service will be held at 11am on January 2nd at Saint Michael's Episcopal Church in Litchfield. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial gifts be made to the Hartford Youth Scholars, 133 Allen Place, Hartford, CT 06106, hartfordyouthscholars.org. This request is in affirmation of John's view that education is the most powerful opportunity in life and should be accessible to all. 1/3

RABINOWITZ--Jacob, born June 13, 1927, died December 15, 2015. Son of immigrants, graduated City College of New York, 1948. Electronics Engineer, husband of 66 years to Ruth Lapidus, father of David, Naomi and Jesse, grandfather of Emily, Jonah and Aaron, great- grandfather of Charlotte and Louisa. Grew up in the age of radio and helped pioneer color television, satellite and cellular communication. 1/3

KAPLEN--Alexander. The Board of Trustees and staff of PEN American Center are deeply saddened by the untimely loss of Alexander (Lex) Kaplen. Lex has been a loyal and passionate supporter of PEN's literary programs and free expression advocacy for more than a decade. His sensibilities, intellect and belief in the importance of literature as a medium for cross-cultural understanding have informed and enlivened PEN's work. His contributions will have an enduring impact in strengthening PEN's community of writers and enabling the fulfilment of our mission. We will miss him enormously and offer our sincere condolences to the Kaplen Family and to all of Lex's friends. Andrew Solomon, President Suzanne Nossel, Executive Director Linda Morgan, Director of Development 1/3
KAHN--Nargas Rezvani, of Cliffside Park, NJ, died at age 77. Beloved wife to Herbert Kahn, mother to Fred Rezvani, loved by extended family. 1/3
LEVINE--Ira, Chemistry Professor at Brooklyn College, died December 17, 2015. He is survived by his loving family, sister Vicki Steinhardt and nieces Anna and Laura Steinhardt. 1/3

MASUR--Kurt. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Kurt Masur, and send condolences to his family. 1/3

MOINESTER--Roslyn. March 10, 1917 - December 20, 2015. A longtime resident of Coconut Creek, FL. Daughter of Gussie and Louis Weisinger. Preceded in death by husband Louis. She leaves behind loving daughter, June and numerous nieces and a nephew. Roslyn was a philanthropist and was honored numerous times by major Jewish organizations nationally and internationally. She enjoyed traveling especially to Israel and New York. She was a friend to many and will be remembered for the wonderful deeds of kindness and love. guttermanandmusicant.com 1/3
GARITY--Natalie Lyons. 12/22/89. Your love, support and optimism has guided me through life. Miss you and love you Mom. Susie 1/3

WEISS--Rabbi Joseph (Yosef). The Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS), an affiliate of Yeshiva University, and the Yeshiva University family mourn the passing of the revered Senior member of RIETS faculty who has taught for some 75 years and was actively teaching two weeks ago at the age of 95, instructing rabbinate students the Talmud and Codes while seeking Orthodox Rabbinic Ordination. He also served as Rabbi Emeritus of Congregation Moriah on Manhattan's West Side. Rabbi Weiss graduated from Yeshiva University's affiliated Marsha Stern Talmudical Academy-Yeshiva University High School for Boys in 1939, from Yeshiva College in 1943, and was ordained by Rabbi Moses Soloveitchik, Zt"l in 1940. He was a distinguished scholar who contributed to many scholarly publications, among them, Hapardes, Be'er Yitzchak and others. He is married to Merla Moller, the daughter of Dr. Raphael Moller, M.D., Z"l, a grandson of Rabbi Samson Raphael Hirsch, Zt"l who was for several generations the President of the Frankfurt Breuer community, Khal Adath Jeshurun, which was reconstituted in Washington Heights, NY under the leadership of Rabbi Joseph Breuer, Zt"l after escaping from the Nazi genocide in Germany. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Rebbetzin Merla Weiss, their children: Rabbi Hershel Weiss, Rabbi Chaim Yeshaya Weiss, Rabbi Shamshon Weiss, Rebbetzin Rifky Taub and Rebbetzin Rochel Gottesman, their daughter Rebbetzin Esther Alster, Z"l, passed away in January 2011. May they and all their children, grandchildren and great grandchildren, and the rabbinic students and academic colleagues, as well as the congregants of Rabbi Yosef Weiss, Zt"l be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

GREENDLINGER--Steven, 73, of Lynbrook, NY, passed away on Sunday, December 20, 2015. The funeral, with a brief graveside service, will be held at 10:30am on Wednesday, December 23, 2015 at New Montefiore Cemetery, West Babylon, NY. Star of David Memorial Chapel is handling funeral services. Steve was born in Brooklyn, NY on March 29, 1942, the son of Frances and Samuel Greendlinger and grew up in Hewlett, NY. Steve attended Curry College in Milton, MA. He served in the Army National Guard. On March 13, 2015, Steve's twin brother, Arthur Greendlinger (Max Greendale) preceded him in death. Steve is survived by his brother Michael Greendlinger and his wife Di Lewis and four nieces: Risa Greendlinger and her husband Don Reed, Stacy Greendlinger and her husband John Tambascio, Sara Buehler, Allison Gomes, and eight grand-nieces and nephews, cousin Steven Scharaga and his wife Joyce, as well as devoted friends of many decades. 1/3

MENIN--Edward B. "Bud." Died suddenly on December 19 at the age of 84. Fiercely devoted husband of Debbie for 60 years. Tremendous father to Lisa (Jade), Craig (Shelley) and Pam (Amir). Proud Poppy to Sydni, Raina and Blake. Beloved brother of Rhea and Morton Mandell and the late Marcia and Berton Karol. Son of the late Samuel and Bertha Menin. Expertly cared for by Yvonne Livingstone. Automobile dealer, passionate art collector, wonderful friend. A truly remarkable force of nature. In our hearts always. We will love you and miss you forever. Funeral services at B'nai Torah Congregation, 6261 S.W. 18th Street, Boca Raton, Florida on Tuesday, December 22 at 11am. Donations in Bud's name can be made to Holy Cross Hospital CVICU, 4725 N. Federal Highway, Fort Lauderdale, Florida 33308, Attention: Development Office. 1/3

ZANK--Morton I. (Mac), of Boca Raton, FL formerly of Yonkers, NY, passed away peacefully on December 19, 2015 at the age of 95. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Edith. Loving father of Carole (Phil) Gruber and Richard (Lisa) Zank. Grandfather of Adam (Jodi) Gruber, Kimberly (David) Gruber Greenburg, Benjamin Zank and Rebecca Zank. Great- grandfather of Eli and Noah Gruber and Hailey and Austin Greenburg. Funeral services will be held at The Gardens of Boca Raton. 1/3

BAHNY--Barbara Sharon, 56, on December 19th. Former Director of Public Relations at the Willard Hotel in Washington, D.C., recently relocated to New York City as Area Director of Public Relations at the Barclay Hotel. She was a world traveler, occasional opera singer, lover of languages, music, people, and life; gone way too soon after a heroic fight with a progressive lung disease. Devoted sister of Nathan and Jay. Services Wednesday 10am at "The Riverside" West, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Burial will take place in West Hartford, CT following the service. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. 1/3

MUNKELT--Albert G.,died earlier this year in Wilton, CT. Beloved husband Of the late Marjorie Starry and beloved father of Brooks (Zita) and Suzanne. He was born April 21, 1918 in New Britain, CT. Son of Albert Ernst Munkelt and Helen Gleason, he grew up in Brooklyn, NY. Albert attended Harvard, Rutgers and received a B.S. in business administration from NYU. He worked at Pillsbury and Wheatena before serving in the Army Air Force in WWII. After being honorably discharged as captain, Albert worked for the Veteran's Administration then joined the new company Minute Maid which was later bought by Coca-Cola. He became senior Vice President and head of marketing for the Coca-Cola Foods Division. He worked for the company for 35 years. Albert loved sports, traveling and reading. He was smart, funny and a true gentleman. He is missed. 1/3
RENICK--Theodore M. Dad and Poppy, 10 years gone, missing and loving you always. Jamie, Howard, Jordana and Caroline 1/3

EZRATTY--Joseph, beloved father of Monte, Brian, and Raif, father-in-law of Jackie, Debbie, and Elena and grandfather of Jake, Joanna, Robbie, Sydney, Bradley, Samantha, Danielle and beloved husband of the late Pearl Ezratty and wonderful and loving partner of Paula Franklin for the last five years, passed away peacefully on December 19th after a tough battle with prostate cancer. Joe came from a large and loving family and was cherished by his brothers Albie and his late wife, Essie, Bernie, and Marty and his wife Rona. He was a great human being who was loved, adored and respected by all who knew him. His life lessons will be carried on through his loving family, and he will be missed by all. Funeral services will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY on Monday, December 21 at 11am. 1/3

GOOT--Ebbie. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the recent passing of Ebbie Goot, beloved wife for 70 years of Irwin Goot, both active and highly respected members of the Houston, Texas Jewish community. She was the cherished, loving and nurturing mother of Barbara (and Michael) Gamson, Betty (and Michael) Tapick and Steve Goot. Ebbie Goot was the revered, doting grandmother of six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Barbara and Michael Gamson, Yeshiva University Benefactors, are admired leaders in Houston and New York, where Barbara serves on the board of the Whitney Museum and Michael is a trustee of Yeshiva University's Board of Trustees and the Yeshiva College Board of Overseers. GOLDBERG--Lillian Berger, 103, of Jamaica Estates, NY, died on December 20, 2015. Devoted wife of the late Judge M. Marvin Berger and then of the late Maurice Goldberg. Beloved mother of Howard and Joel Berger. Adored grandmother of Danny, Jeffrey and Max, and great-grandmother of Henry, Naomi and Zoe. Lillian was a past President of the Sisterhood of the Hillcrest Jewish Center, and served for many years as Administrator of the International Synagogue at John F. Kennedy Airport. Services will be conducted on Wednesday, December 23, at 9:30am, at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, and interment will be at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Hillcrest Jewish Center, 183-02 Union Turnpike, Flushing, NY 11366, info@hillcrestjc.org. 1/3

MASUR--Kurt. The New York Philharmonic deeply mourns the loss of our inspiring and dedicated Music Director Emeritus Kurt Masur (Music Director, 1991-2002). Maestro Masur's dedication to expressing humanism through music was most vivid in the wake of 9/11, when he led the Philharmonic in a moving performance of Brahms's Ein deutsches Requiem, and musicians from the Orchestra gave free chamber concerts around Ground Zero. Masur's Philharmonic tenure began earlier than expected, when he stepped in to conduct Mendelssohn's Elijah following the sudden death of Leonard Bernstein. Over the next 11 seasons, Masur hired 42 Philharmonic musicians; led the Orchestra on 17 tours around the world, traveling to 75 cities in 30 countries, including the first-ever Philharmonic concerts in mainland China; and expanded the Philharmonic's education programs. Highlights of his tenure included profound performances of oratorios by Bach and Mendelssohn, his predecessors as Kappelmeister of the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra, and Beethoven's Ninth Symphony on the U.N.'s 50th anniversary and the turn of the millennium; overseeing the four-season American Classics initiative; introducing a longstanding collaboration with Wynton Marsalis and Jazz at Lincoln Center; symphonic cycles of Brahms and Beethoven; and the commissions and premieres of 43 works, including the Messages for the Millennium. Masur presided over the Orchestra's return to the radio and the creation of its own recording label, principally to release performances preserved in the Archives, and he conducted 32 live concert recordings released on Teldec Classics. New Yorkers still experience Masur's humanist mark through the popular Annual Free Memorial Day Concert, which he introduced. From his 1981 debut until his last appearance in 2012, Maestro Masur led the Philharmonic in 909 performances. New York Philharmonic Music Director Alan Gilbert said: "Kurt Masur's years at the New York Philharmonic represent one of its golden eras, in which music-making was infused with commitment and devotion -- with the belief in the power of music to bring humanity closer together. The ethical and moral dimensions that he brought to his conducting are still palpable in the musicians' playing, and I, along with the Philharmonic's audiences, have much to thank him for. I will always be grateful for the support he gave me starting long ago when I was a student. I will miss him deeply." The funeral will be private and a public memorial will be planned for a later time. The New York Philharmonic family sends our sympathy and love to his wife, Tomoko, and their son, Ken-David and his wife, Melinda Lee; his daughters, Angelika and Carolin; his sons, Michael and Matthias; and his nine grandchildren. 1/3

BARKET--Keith Farris. Nov. 12, 1961 - Dec. 22, 2010 In Loving Memory Five years ago today, the greatest light in our lives was extinguished. With each day that passes, we miss you more. We send our eternal love, and gratitude that you were ours, out into the void where you left us. You are irreplaceable. You live on in our hearts. Until we meet again, we remain your devoted family. We love you forever, Laura, Jack and Maddy 1/3

HARDT--John Pearce, 93, of Virginia Beach, VA, passed away on December 11, 2015 at his home at Westminster Canterbury Retirement Community. He was born in Seattle, Washington to Sydney and Muriel Hardt. He received a B.A. and an M.A. from the University of Washington and a PhD from the Russian Institute of Columbia University in 1954. For the next 50 years, John was engaged in the study of the Soviet and post-Soviet economy and related issues. He joined the Congressional Research Service as the Senior Specialist in Soviet Economics in 1971. He worked at CRS until his retirement in 2003, publishing extensively and advising Members of Congress throughout this period. In 1953, he married Mary (formerly Scapellati) Hardt, with whom he raised five sons. John and Mary lived for over 40 years in Bethesda, Maryland before moving to Virginia Beach in 2009. John was preceded in death by his wife Mary and his brother Sydney. In addition to his sister Mary, he is survived by his sons, John (Jeanne), Anthony (Nancy), Daniel (Birgitte), Michael (Kathi), and Richard (Paola), as well as his grandchildren, Emily, Lisa, Andy, Madeleine, Sofia, Will, Isabella, Griffin, Eliot, and Joseph. John asked not to have a funeral service. We are grateful to the hospice and health care workers who helped him in his final months. We all cherish his memory. 1/3

BRUMMEL--Marilyn. To a woman of great intelligence, love of the arts and dedication to her family. We will miss her. Robert & Arlene Fischer 1/3

Service Wednesday, December 23, 11am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Burial private. Donations in his memory to American Cancer Society research would be appreciated. 1/3

MASUR--Kurt. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of our dear friend, the internationally acclaimed conductor Kurt Masur. Maestro Masur made his Carnegie Hall debut in 1974, leading the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra. He returned for forty more appearances at the Hall throughout his illustrious career, conducting the Gewandhaus, New York Philharmonic, London Philharmonic Orchestra, and other world-renowned ensembles. We cherish the memories of these extraordinary performances and will always remember his incredible artistry, his belief in the power of music to bring people together, and his strong musical leadership at the helm of the New York Philharmonic. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Tomoko, and to all of his family, friends, and loved ones. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes T. Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3

MUELLER--Ruth Annemarie, age 98, born in Mannheim, Germany, on January 21, 1917, passed away peacefully in her home in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on December 22, 2015. Celebrated author of her memoirs entitled "One Minute Before Midnight" wherein she describes her harrowing escape from Nazi Germany in 1939, she moved on to become a highly successful business owner in New York City. Ruth graduated with honors from Fordham University in Manhattan in 1979. Services will be held Wednesday, December 23, 2015, 4:00-8:00pm at Kraeer Funeral Home, 4061 North Federal Highway, Fort Lauderdale, Florida, 33308, and again Sunday, December 27, 2015, from 2:00-4:00pm at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, New York 10028. Burial will take place on Monday, 11:00am at the Woodlawn Cemetery, Webster Avenue and East 233rd Street, Bronx, New York. Ruth is survived by her husband, Raymond C. Griffis Jr., and many other much- loved friends and family members, too numerous to list. Our dear Ruth will be sincerely missed by all. She has been a relentless source of love and joy, and an inspiration to everyone who has had the extreme pleasure of knowing her. 1/3

MENIN--Edward B. "Bud." Died suddenly on December 19 at the age of 84. Fiercely devoted husband of Debbie for 60 years. Tremendous father to Lisa (Jade), Craig (Shelley) and Pam (Amir). Proud Poppy to Sydni, Raina and Blake. Beloved brother of Rhea and Morton Mandell and the late Marcia and Berton Karol. Son of the late Samuel and Bertha Menin. Expertly cared for by Yvonne Livingstone. Automobile dealer, passionate art collector, wonderful friend. A truly remarkable force of nature. In our hearts always. We will love you and miss you forever. Funeral services at B'nai Torah Congregation, 6261 S.W. 18th Street, Boca Raton, Florida on Tuesday, December 22 at 11am. Donations in Bud's name can be made to Holy Cross Hospital CVICU, 4725 N. Federal Highway, Fort Lauderdale, Florida 33308, Attention: Development Office. 1/3

WELD--Wilfrid Joseph, JP DL FRICS, of Lulworth Castle, Dorset, United Kingdom. Beloved husband of Sally and loving father and grandfather. He died unexpectedly, but peacefully, on December 3, 2015 in Tahiti. Funeral Mass to be held on Tuesday, January 5, 2016, Lulworth Castle Chapel at noon. No flowers please. No memorial service. Donations in aid of SOS Children's Villages in Tahiti and French Polynesia may be placed at: www.funeraldirector.co.uk/ wilfrid-weld 1/3

WEINER--Patricia Ann, 83, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL passed away peacefully on December 21, 2015. Pat was born in New York, NY to Herman and Fae Baker. She attended the Calhoun School and graduated from Syracuse University cum laude. A longtime resident of Great Neck, NY before relocating to Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Pat was an assistant editor at the Great Neck Record, editor of the weekly newspapers, The Westbury (Long Island) Times as well as the Roslyn (Long Island) News, editor and founder of the Long Island monthly newspaper, Teen To Teen, and owner and editor of the newspaper, Spotlight, for the Palm Beaches (Florida). Pat was active in many political and social causes. She also loved to travel, spend time with friends and family and to play bridge. She married Dr. Lazarus C. Weiner in 1956. Her husband predeceased her in 2012. Pat is survived by her two sons and daughters-in-law and four grandchildren: Glenn Weiner and Marian Passannante, Neil Weiner and Laura Pollack Weiner: Daniela, Jessica, Benjamin, and Nicholas. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, December 24 at 11am at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, NY. The family will receive visitors on Sunday, December 27 from 2-5pm in Westfield, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations are requested to Planned Parenthood online at https://www.planned parenthood.org. 1/3

MAYO--Elizabeth, died peacefully in her home in Forest Hills on December 21. She was born on September 27, 1929 to Frank and Eva Berkowski (later Berk) in Brussels, Belgium. Her family fled the Nazis when she was 11, after her father escaped from Breendonk Prison Camp, and they made their way to the United States. When their ship was refused entry into the U.S., they were taken to Cuba where they spent the rest of the war. Elizabeth married Louis Mayo in 1949. A talented artist and singer, Elizabeth graduated from Hunter College with a major in anthropology. As well as being devoted to her family, her keen intellect, mathematical excellence and love of people, enabled Elizabeth to spend decades working with Louis Mayo in building Mayo Studios, a NYC based photography and design studio. In her role as Treasurer, Elizabeth served as the company's office manager and bookkeeper. Louis passed away in 1993. She is survived by her two children, Mark Mayo and Deborah Mayo, four grandchildren, Isaac Chatfield, Mickey Mayo, Erika Mayo, Toni Mayo, daughter-in-law Sandy Mayo, son-in-law George W Chatfield, great-grandson Alden Mayo and her loving, live-in aide for many years, Betty Ramdat. Funeral services will be held at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam Ave. and W. 76th St. on Thursday, December 24, 2015 at 9:30am. 1/3

MILBERG--Stanley H.,died peacefully on December 13, 2015 at age 91. He is survived by his beloved wife Marcia Osofsky of Brooklyn, NY; his sister Rita Bricken of Manhattan; four sons, Daniel of Chicopee, MA, David of Buffalo, NY, William of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, and John of Rockville, MD; and seven grandchildren: Emma, Simon, Alanna, Claudia, Sylvie, Eva and Natalie. He is also survived by his daughters-in-law Hedy Kalikoff and Sara Sade. Stanley was predeceased by his wife Sylvia Lowits Milberg, who died in 1994. Born in Jersey City, NJ, Stanley was a decorated Veteran of WWII, an Army Air Corps navigator who flew more than 20 bombing missions over Germany. Stanley graduated from Columbia College with a B.S. in 1947 and an M.S. in 1949. He lived for almost 40 years in Westport, CT where he and Sylvia shared their active commitment to community well-being and the town's Democratic Party. Co-founder of the management consultant company Marcom, Inc., he went on to a successful career as a stock analyst and broker. Stanley was intellectually curious, a lover of music, the arts and the Mets, an avid reader and enthusiastic chef. Stanley was brilliant, cantankerous, charming, generous, caring and funny. He will forever remain in our hearts. 1/3

KAPLEN--Alexander. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation mourn the loss of Alexander Kaplen. Lex was a steadfast supporter of the Society and a passionate advocate for the architectural and cultural heritage of Greenwich Village. A gifted graphic designer, he gave generously of his time and talent. Lex's commitment allowed the Society to vastly expand the scope and quality of its work over the years. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Kaplen family. Andrew Berman, Executive Director Arthur Levin, Chair 1/3

LEVY--Burton. The Officers and Clergy of Temple Israel of the City of New York mourn the passing of longtime member Burton Levy. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved wife and family. Andrew Hoffman, President David J. Gelfand, Rabbi 1/3

EHRLICH--Burtt R.,76, died at home on December 21, 2015. He was a proud graduate of Columbia College and Columbia Business School; the founder and co-chairman of Ehrlich-Bober & Co.; and a current or past board member of organizations including the Carnegie Council on Ethics and International Affairs, the Arbitrage Fund, Buckingham Browne and Nichols, and Puppies Behind Bars. An inveterate collector (most notably of antique toy soldiers), he was once aptly described as "a die-hard Red Sox fan in Yankee country and an unrepentant left-wing Democrat." He loved the Times crossword, good cigars, and bad food. Burtt is survived by his wife Fran; children Steven, Julie, and David; their partners Kathleen, Noam, and Elisa; and granddaughter Mira--all of whom will miss him terribly. Services today, December 23, at 1:00pm, Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains. 1/3

DUCOFF--Rita. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale family mourns the passing of Rita Ducoff, beloved wife of Morris for over sixty years, devoted mother and grandmother. Rita loved life to the fullest, with a sharp wit and passion. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her children, Jill, Debbie, Ian and Susan, and her son-in-law Joel, a member of our Board of Trustees. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President and CEO David V. Pomeranz, Chief Operating Officer The Hebrew Home at Riverdale by RiverSpring Health 1/3

BARNETT--Albert, 93, died on December 21, 2015. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 66 years, Marilyn (Axelrod) Barnett. Albert was the oldest and last surviving of Alice's three boys, with Charles and Edgar. He had been a B-24 pilot in WWII, State Insurance Examiner and Manager of Mount Pleasant Cemetery. He will be missed by his three children, Larry (Marcia), Holly Sharcoff (Joe) and Jon (Lisa) and his five grandchildren, Jared, Alison, Jessie, Benjamin and Emma. 1/3

EHRLICH--Burtt. We mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend, Burtt Ehrlich. Burtt had a generous heart, a wonderfully wry sense of humor and a zest for traveling the world. He lived life to the fullest and was widely known as an avid and expert collector of unusual and arcane items. He dearly loved his family who will treasure his extraordinary legacy; his beloved wife Fran, his children Steven and Kathleen, Julie and Noam and David, and his precious granddaughter Mira. Burtt, our friend, we will miss you always. Judy and Bruce Berg, Karen and David Freedberg, Bonnie and Tom Strauss 1/3
