KING--Stephen Dennis, of Middletown, NJ, died and went home to the Lord on Wednesday, December 23, 2015. Steve is survived by his beloved wife, Cathy O'Flynn of 21 years and their sons, Matthew and Andrew King. Steve is predeceased by his mother and father, Dorothy and Patrick King. He is survived by eight siblings and their families, Patrick King, Dorothy D'Amato, Mary Salatino, John King, Theresa Scibelli, Thomas King, Margaret Garone, and Catherine King. Steve is also survived by his many cherished extended family and friends. Steve, a native of Brooklyn, NY, attended Mary Queen of Heaven Grade School, Brooklyn Technical High School, Cathedral Seminary and Brooklyn College. Steve had a distinguished career at a number of financial institutions including E.F. Hutton and Barclays Bank. He recently retired as Executive Vice President and Chief Operations Officer for the American Bible Society, where he served doing the Lord's work spreading the Word and Ministry for 19 years. Steve served his faith by participating in several church ministries, including as Board President of a non-profit, "Services for the Underserved." A Memorial Gathering will be held on Sunday, December 27, 2015 from 2-4 and 7-9 pm at John F. Pfleger Funeral Home, 115 Tindall Rd., Middletown, NJ. A Service to Celebrate Steve's Life will be held on Monday, December 28, 2015 at 10am at Christ Church, 90 Kings Hwy., Middletown, NJ and his ashes will be entombed following the service at Holmdel Mausoleum, 900 Holmdel Rd., Holmdel, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations in Steve's memory may be sent to "Every Tribe, Every Nation" to support global Bible translation at www.everytribeevery nation.org/your-role. For more information, to send condolences or for directions, please visit www.pflegerfh.com. 1/3
GMINSKI--W. Gerald (Gerry). Husband, father, historian, sailor, investment banker. Love for always and forever, Pamela, Emmy and Chris 1
McGUIRE--Muriel Margaret. Merry Christmas Mom, my memories of you are my greatest gift! Love always, Sissy 1/3

KAHN--Olivia, 95, on December 19. Daughter of Modernist architect Ely Jacques Kahn and Elsie Plaut, sister of E.J. Kahn Jr. of The New Yorker and mystery editor Joan Kahn, and aunt to Ely Jacques Kahn III, Joseph Plaut Kahn and Hamilton Rice Kahn. Artist, sculptor, world traveler, theatre lover and friend to many writers, editors and artists. A true New Yorker-- couldn't drive, lived on 36th Street for 77 years, read and evaluated every manuscript her sister published. Graduate of Bryn Mawr, studied at the Art Students League, walked two miles to and from her downtown studio for more than seven decades. A service will be held Sunday, December 27 at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue, beginning at 11am. 1/3

MASUR--Kurt. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of our dear friend, the internationally acclaimed conductor Kurt Masur. Maestro Masur made his Carnegie Hall debut in 1974, leading the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra. He returned for forty more appearances at the Hall throughout his illustrious career, conducting the Gewandhaus, New York Philharmonic, London Philharmonic Orchestra, and other world-renowned ensembles. We cherish the memories of these extraordinary performances and will always remember his incredible artistry, his belief in the power of music to bring people together, and his strong musical leadership at the helm of the New York Philharmonic. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Tomoko, and to all of his family, friends, and loved ones. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes T. Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3

MARCUS--David, 90, died peacefully on December 21, 2015. Devoted husband of Frances for 70 years. Beloved father of Jeffrey, grandfather of Michael, Lindsay and Robyn, and great-grandfather of Annie and Abby. A generous and wonderful man who lived the American Dream. We love you and will miss you forever. 1/3

GORDON--Jacob, D.D.S.,94 years old, died on December 23, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Alice. Devoted father of Jane (David), Robert (Gail) and Richard (Mari). Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Services Sunday, 10am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (Opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. 1/3

DUFFELL--Anne M.,on Tuesday, December 22, 2015. Our beautiful mom died at the age of 98. She was predeceased by her husband, John P. Duffell Jr. She was a wonderful mother to her nine children, Eileen Duffell Lugano, Father John P. Duffell III, Carolanne Travell, Richard Duffell and wife, Denise, Stephen Duffell, Rita Duffell and husband, Ron Safko, Denise Duffell and husband, John Basile, Anne Duffell and husband, Jim Hayes, and Suzette Duffell and husband, Joseph Duffy. She is survived by her 17 grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren. We are so blessed to have had a mother who was such a wonderful role model. She lived her life greeting each day with joy and instilled in her children the values important to her: faith, love, and family. Visiting hours will be from 2-5pm and 7-9pm on Sunday, December, 27th at Redden's Funeral Home located at 325 West 14th Street in Manhattan. Funeral services are to be held at 10:30am on Monday, December 28th at The Church of the Blessed Sacrament located at 152 West 71st Street in Manhattan. 1/3

DUBOW--Barry Michael, 67, died on December 22. Beloved father of Philip. Survived by parents Pearl and Irving, siblings Lew Dubow and Ellen Glatt, and former wife Marcia G. Yerman. Barry worked tirelessly to promote the sport of Pocket Billiards, championing the classic game of 14.1, managing Jean Balukas, and as Executive Director of the WPBA. Service at Schwartz Bros Jefferson Memorial Chapel at 11:30am on December 24. Donations to the Multiple System Atrophy Coalition (http://tinyurl.com/jcc6t12), the rare disease that destroyed his final years. He will be missed. 1/3

KAPLEN--Alexander. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation mourn the loss of Alexander Kaplen. Lex was a steadfast supporter of the Society and a passionate advocate for the architectural and cultural heritage of Greenwich Village. A gifted graphic designer, he gave generously of his time and talent. Lex's commitment allowed the Society to vastly expand the scope and quality of its work over the years. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Kaplen family. Andrew Berman, Executive Director Arthur Levin, Chair 1/3

ST. JOHN-PARSONS-- Donald, Ed. D, on December 18, 2015. Retired from Bank Street College of Education. Beloved husband of Susan, devoted father of Fiona, adored grandpa of Miranda and Alice. Service Tuesday, December 29, 3pm at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, St. James Chapel. Donations in his memory to Smile Train would be appreciated. 1

EHRLICH--Burtt. The members and friends of the New York City Columbia College Class of 1961 lunch group deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend and classmate. Burtt was a loyal Columbian and deeply committed to the College. He will be greatly missed. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife and children. 1/3

MUELLER--Ruth Annemarie, age 98, born in Mannheim, Germany, on January 21, 1917, passed away peacefully in her home in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on December 22, 2015. Celebrated author of her memoirs entitled "One Minute Before Midnight" wherein she describes her harrowing escape from Nazi Germany in 1939, she moved on to become a highly successful business owner in New York City. Ruth graduated with honors from Fordham University in Manhattan in 1979. Services will be held Wednesday, December 23, 2015, 4:00-8:00pm at Kraeer Funeral Home, 4061 North Federal Highway, Fort Lauderdale, Florida, 33308, and again Sunday, December 27, 2015, from 2:00-4:00pm at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, New York 10028. Burial will take place on Monday, 11:00am at the Woodlawn Cemetery, Webster Avenue and East 233rd Street, Bronx, New York. Ruth is survived by her husband, Raymond C. Griffis Jr., and many other much- loved friends and family members, too numerous to list. Our dear Ruth will be sincerely missed by all. She has been a relentless source of love and joy, and an inspiration to everyone who has had the extreme pleasure of knowing her. 1/3

EHRLICH--Burtt. Our hearts are broken. Burtt was one of a kind and we will miss, remember and love him always. We know he is smoking a cigar and doing the New York Times crossword puzzle with lightning speed. We send all our love to Fran, Steven and Kathleen, Julie and Noam, David and the entire family. Tom, Margo, Sarah, Dan and Stacy 1/3

MENIN--Edward B. "Bud." Died suddenly on December 19 at the age of 84. Fiercely devoted husband of Debbie for 60 years. Tremendous father to Lisa (Jade), Craig (Shelley) and Pam (Amir). Proud Poppy to Sydni, Raina and Blake. Beloved brother of Rhea and Morton Mandell and the late Marcia and Berton Karol. Son of the late Samuel and Bertha Menin. Expertly cared for by Yvonne Livingstone. Automobile dealer, passionate art collector, wonderful friend. A truly remarkable force of nature. In our hearts always. We will love you and miss you forever. Funeral services at B'nai Torah Congregation, 6261 S.W. 18th Street, Boca Raton, Florida on Tuesday, December 22 at 11am. Donations in Bud's name can be made to Holy Cross Hospital CVICU, 4725 N. Federal Highway, Fort Lauderdale, Florida 33308, Attention: Development Office. 1/3

(predeceased), Bridget (Richard Sandler), Patricia (Sergio Terrazas), David (Julie), Christopher (Marcia) and Mary (John Davis), grandmother of nine and great-grandmother of four, died peacefully at home on December 20, 2015 at the age of 86. Visitation will be at O'Brien's Funeral Home in Wall, NJ on Sunday, December 27 and a Mass of Christian Burial at St. Rose Church, 603 7th Ave., Belmar, NJ at 11:30am on Monday, December 28. She will be deeply missed. 1/3

KRAUS--George. On December 22, 2015. Loving father of Eric and Bob; dear father-in-law of Marjory Fisher and Kathy Morris; cherished grandfather of Sam, Max, Emily, Nick and Nate; beloved brother of Lili. Predeceased by his wife and soulmate of 63 years, Hedi; sister Gerda; and parents Otto and Frieda. Dad transcended the tragedies of the Holocaust and inculcated a deep, spiritual appreciation of nature and learning in all he touched. He was an old-world gentleman in the truest sense of the word. Funeral service was held on December 24, 2015 at the Community Synagogue, Port Washington, NY. Memorial contributions to the Michael J. Fox Foundation (www.michaeljfox.org) gratefully accepted. 1/3

CAREY--Roberts. Roberts "Robin" Browning Fray Carey. 1954-2015. The daughter of Jackson Lee Fray, Jr., and Mary Fauntleroy Cocke Fray, Robin was born and raised in Culpeper, VA. She died in a car accident December 17. Her given first name, Roberts, was in honor of her paternal great-grandmother, Ellen Roberts Browning, but she was known as Robin. After attending St. Anne's-Belfield School in Charlottesville, VA, Robin entered the University of Virginia as an Echols Scholar, graduating with distinction in 1976. Her publishing jobs after college included work at Esquire, The Washington Post, Fortune, Time, and Newsweek. In 2006 Robin founded Social Media Today LLC, a business-to-business media company. She ran a successful company, but Robin was also passionate about her nonprofit activities. She joined the board of the Women's Refugee Commission in 2005, and was co-chair from 2010 to 2013. The WRC is an international nonprofit working to protect women and children displaced by conflict and crisis. Robin, who spent time in Uganda for the WRC, was particularly interested in women's reproductive health. At the time of her death the commission was beginning the process of naming her as one of its overseers. With then-husband, Robert James McDonald Carey, Robin raised two sons, Preston Fray Carey and James Duncan Carey, in Maplewood, NJ. In 2012, she married John Dudley Casey, novelist and University of Virginia professor of creative writing. Four stepdaughters Maud, Nell, Clare, and Julia Casey are among her survivors. Robin is also survived by her sister Mary (Molly) Fray Sanford of Syria, VA, and her brothers Jackson Lee Fray III of Culpeper, VA, and Preston Cocke Fray of Burbank, CA. Intelligent, lovely, and spirited, Robin will be greatly missed not only by her family, but also by her Social Media Today team, fellow humanitarians, and many friends. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Memorial Church in Charlottesville, VA, Sunday, December 27, 2015, 2pm. A memorial service will also be held Saturday, January 2, 4pm, at St. George's Church, Maplewood, NJ. Donations in Robin's memory can be sent to: Women's Refugee Commission, Attention: Catherine Sykes, 122 East 42nd Street, 11th flr, New York, NY 10168. www.wrcommission.org. 1/3

FELDMAN--Iris Kellner, 1930-2015 died on December 20, 2015 at her home in Manhattan. A graduate of Packer Collegiate Institute and Goucher College, Iris had a career as a fundraiser for United Jewish Appeal, Israel Bonds and Brandeis University. Iris was predeceased by her husband, Benjamin Feldman. She is survived by daughters Carol Cataldo (Jim) and Ruth Pomerance, grandchildren Simon Cataldo (Francesca), Eva Berlin (Gdaly), Anna Cataldo, Aaron Prieto and Emilio Prieto. She is also survived by stepdaughter Renee Grandin (Steve), stepson Steve Feldman (Donna), and step-grandchildren Phillip Grandin (Megan), Alex and Will Grandin and step-grandaughter Maria Flippen (Todd). She leaves cherished lifetime friends as well as those met more recently at Brookdale Battery Park. A memorial service will be held in January 2016 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Iris' memory to Harlem Lacrosse and Leadership, P.O. Box 708 NY, New York 10030 or www.harlemlacrosse.org. 1/3

MARANS--Judah Aaron. The Officers and members of the Board of Directors of the Jewish Home Family note with profound sorrow the untimely passing of Judah Aaron Marans, son of Nina Kampler and our Jewish Home Foundation board member, Dr. Zvi Marans. We extend our deepest sympathy to his parents Nina and Zvi, his brothers Gabriel (Missy) and Benjamin, his sister Dara (Eric), his grandparents and his entire family. May his family know no other sorrow and may his memory be for a blessing. Eli Ungar, Chairman Carol Silver Elliott, President & CEO 1/3

MENIN--Edward B. "Bud." Died suddenly on December 19 at the age of 84. Fiercely devoted husband of Debbie for 60 years. Tremendous father to Lisa (Jade), Craig (Shelley) and Pam (Amir). Proud Poppy to Sydni, Raina and Blake. Beloved brother of Rhea and Morton Mandell and the late Marcia and Berton Karol. Son of the late Samuel and Bertha Menin. Expertly cared for by Yvonne Livingstone. Automobile dealer, passionate art collector, wonderful friend. A truly remarkable force of nature. In our hearts always. We will love you and miss you forever. Funeral services at B'nai Torah Congregation, 6261 S.W. 18th Street, Boca Raton, Florida on Tuesday, December 22 at 11am. Donations in Bud's name can be made to Holy Cross Hospital CVICU, 4725 N. Federal Highway, Fort Lauderdale, Florida 33308, Attention: Development Office. 1/3

MONCHER--Ruth. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member, Ruth Moncher, and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

DUNN--Mildred King. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Mildred King Dunn, who was a distinguished member of the Board for over 37 years. Mrs. Dunn served as a Member of the Association and was also an active member of the Met's National Council, providing assistance with and chairing the Seattle regional auditions for many years. On behalf of everyone at the Met, we extend our sincere condolences to her daughter, Kathleen Dunn Edwards; her son, Dennis Dunn; and to their family and friends. Ann Ziff, Chairman of the Board Judith-Ann Corrente, President & CEO Peter Gelb, General Manager 1/3
UNTERBERG--Charles. UNTERBERG--Clara Kletter Beloved parents and grandparents. Forever Loved. 1/3

GREEN--Dorothy "Bibs," (nee Shepherd), 84, on December 23, 2015. Dorothy was born in Greenport, Long Island, NY, and raised in Greenwich Village. She attended PS 41 and Commerce High School. She graduate Summa Cum Laude and Valedictorian of her class at City College of New York. Respected teacher at PS 19 New York City. She was a longtime member of the First Presbyterian Church in NYC. Daughter of the late Rev. Francis K. Shepherd and Dorothy (nee Caulkins) Shepherd. Beloved wife of Eli Green. Cherished mother of the late Cynthia and Deborah. Grandmother of Joseph, Erica, Matthew, Manny and Patricia. Also survived by 12 great-grand- children. Sister of the late Margaret, Patricia, Kenneth and David. Visitation Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14th St., NYC on Saturday, December 26, 2015 2pm to 5pm. Funeral Service Monday, 10am First Presbyterian Church, 12 West 12th Street, NYC. Interment East Marion Cemetery, East Marion, Long Island, NY. 1/3

MONCHER--Ruth 91, died December 23, 2015 from Alzheimer's Disease. Beloved wife of the late George Moncher, mother of the late Michael Moncher and of Amy Moncher Katz (Howard), grandmother of Lauren and Elizabeth. 1/3

BLAUNER--Max. 96, Holocaust Survivor and Real Estate Developer, died peacefully, in the presence of his family on December 20th, 2015 in Hollywood, Florida. He was born on November 3rd, 1919 in Grybov, Poland to Simcha and Doba Blauner. He survived the holocaust by escaping Poland to Russia, where he spent years in a Siberian Labor Camp. He was later put into a Polish division of the Red Army where he fought and helped defeat the Nazis. After the war, he met Rose Solewicz, whom he married on December 26, 1945. They had two children in Germany, Samuel and Doris, later immigrated to New York where they had two more, Gail and Sidney. Max was a natural born businessman. He started with a small import/export business in occupied Germany. After arriving in the United States in 1952, he ventured into several businesses before forming a successful real estate company in New York. Although he had notable projects in Manhattan, he felt the most pride in his development of the former American Banknote building, which ultimately led to the creation of 2,000 jobs in the South Bronx. He was an active member of the Lincoln Park Jewish Center in Yonkers, NY, as well as the Aventura Turnberry Jewish Center in Aventura, Florida and supported many philanthropic causes. He received numerous awards and proclamations, including the Citizens Advice Bureau's Living Legend Award in 2006. He is survived by his loving wife of 70 years, Rose, his sons, Samuel and Sidney, his daughters, Doris-Dalia Cohen and Gail, his daughters-in-law, Cyndee and Nina, his grandchildren, Kimberly Goldner, Jonathan, Ethan and Zeke, his grandson-in-law, Jeff and his great- granddaughters, Arielle and Talia. 1/3

BALSHONE--Marianne Lowy Reiss, age 90. An extraordinary woman born in Budapest in 1925. Survived the Holocaust thanks to Raoul Wallenberg and her own courage. Walking the streets with bombs falling around her, she brought food to her family. She devoted her life to promoting Freedom. Her art was the Art of Living; her motto "Carpe Diem." With training in dance before the war ended her childhood, she raised her family in a career of her own creating as one of New York City's first personal trainers. With immaculate fashion sense, elegance and charm she was frequently asked if she was Hungarian monarchy. In 1973 she moved to Columbus OH and opened Globetrotter Wine and Cheese, inspiring broadening of cultural landscape there. Moving to Palm Beach and her beloved turquoise ocean, made her third career speaking to schools about her survival in the Holocaust and the man who saved her family. An inspiring lecturer, she taught that One Person Can Make a Difference. Her history was chronicled in "Determined" (on Amazon) and the "The Envoy" by Alex Kershaw. She left a creative legacy of children joyful artist/ architectural designer Vivian Reiss, Obstetrician-Gyne- cologist Ronald Reiss and wife Carla. Grandchildren composer/entrepreneur Joel Garten, scientist/entrepreneur Ariel Garten, photojournalist Stephen Reiss, events @ Bon Appetite Nikki Reiss, psychologist Dr. Joy Jacobs. The world has lost another Holocaust survivor and incredible friend, mother, woman, strength and inspiration. Funeral this Sunday, 11am, Riverside Chapel, 180W 76th NYC. Gifts to Raoul Wallenberg committee. MarianneBalshone.com 1/3

PASIK--Tauba, 88, beloved wife of Pedro Pasik, died peacefully at her home on December 24. As a Professor of Neurology at Mount Sinai, she gained national and international recognition as a physician/scientist and was a role model for several generations of students, residents and fellows. She was a lover of opera, chamber music and poetry, an avid world traveler, a fierce women's rights advocate, a champion of just social causes and most of all a devoted wife, mother and grandmother, whose family was always her utmost priority. She had three children, Deborah, Lilia and Alexander (predeceased), all with doctorates, married to three physicians: Marc, Seth and Agata, and six grandchildren, Laura, Jacob, Joseph, Sara, Samantha and Clement. The family will be receiving at 1200 Fifth Avenue on December 26th, 3-5pm and 27th, 3-5pm. 1/3

BLOCH--Herta. It is with sadness that we announce the passing of Herta Bloch, nee Wertheimer, at the age of 94. Herta is survived by her daughter Marion, and her husband David; her son Andrew, and his wife Kathy; her three grandchildren Shoshana, Kiera and Evan. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and West 76th Street, on Sunday, December 27th. Chapel service will begin promptly at 11:30am. There will be a Shiva sitting at Herta's home on Monday, December 28th, from 2-7pm, with a short prayer service to begin at 5pm. 1/3
GOLDSTEIN--Gilda L. Goo, it's 10 years and we miss you very much. Bro and Martha 1/3

ROSEN--Ruth Metzger. 1920 - 2015. Died at home December 25. Beloved wife of the late Jesse Rosen and loving mother of Phyllis and Frank Bocian, Janet Kleinman, and Bob Rosen and Marcia Golub; devoted grandmother of David and Dawn Bocian, Michael and Debbie Bocian, Rachel Kleinman, Charlie and Danielle Kleinman, and Zack Rosen, and proud and cherished "GG" to Tommy, Mia, Hannah, Sarah and Jesse. There will be a private family burial on Sunday. Shiva will be at Ruth's apartment Sunday from 4-9pm and Monday and Tuesday from 1-5pm and 7-9pm. Contributions in Ruth's memory may be made to the Coalition for the Homeless. 1/3

SEGALL--Sarah. 85, of Brookline, MA, died peacefully on December 21, 2015 in Boston, MA. She was born to the late Ben and Nina Ostrovsky in Montreal, Canada and is survived by her husband, Maurice Segall, of Brookline, MA, to whom she was married for 64 years and by her three children: Elizabeth and her husband, James Sagui; Eric and his wife, Lynne; and Peter and his wife, Jackie, and Sarah's six grandchildren: Jessica, Sara, Katie and Andrew, David and Madeline. Sarah was passionate about many things: literature, art, music, and science. From 1951-1955 she was the dedicated Administrative Assistant to the Director of Canada's National Research Council, Gerhardt Hertzberg. An extraordinary reader and researcher, she held a B.S. from McGill University in Montreal, and a Masters Degree of Library Science from Columbia University, New York. In 1982 she became a student at the Boston Graduate School of Psychoanalysis and graduated with a Certificate of Psychoanalytic Psychotherapy in 1997. She served as a Trustee at the BGSP from 2008-2014 when she was honored for her service to that Institution. Throughout her life, Sarah excelled at understanding others and tried to make a positive difference in the lives of her family, friends, colleagues, and patients. She will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her honor to Boston Graduate School of Psychoanalysis, 1581 Beacon Street, Brookline, MA 02446. A service and celebration of her life will be held at Mount Auburn Cemetery, 580 Mount Auburn Street, Cambridge, Bigelow Chapel, on Sunday, December 27th at 11am. Luncheon immediately following, at her late residence, until 4pm. Services are being handled by Levine Chapels, Brookline, MA. 1/3

DUFFELL--Anne M.,on Tuesday, December 22, 2015. Our beautiful mom died at the age of 98. She was predeceased by her husband, John P. Duffell Jr. She was a wonderful mother to her nine children, Eileen Duffell Lugano, Father John P. Duffell III, Carolanne Travell, Richard Duffell and wife, Denise, Stephen Duffell, Rita Duffell and husband, Ron Safko, Denise Duffell and husband, John Basile, Anne Duffell and husband, Jim Hayes, and Suzette Duffell and husband, Joseph Duffy. She is survived by her 17 grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren. We are so blessed to have had a mother who was such a wonderful role model. She lived her life greeting each day with joy and instilled in her children the values important to her: faith, love, and family. Visiting hours will be from 2-5pm and 7-9pm on Sunday, December, 27th at Redden's Funeral Home located at 325 West 14th Street in Manhattan. Funeral services are to be held at 10:30am on Monday, December 28th at The Church of the Blessed Sacrament located at 152 West 71st Street in Manhattan. 1/3

FELDMAN--Iris Kellner, 1930-2015 died on December 20, 2015 at her home in Manhattan. A graduate of Packer Collegiate Institute and Goucher College, Iris had a career as a fundraiser for United Jewish Appeal, Israel Bonds and Brandeis University. Iris was predeceased by her husband, Benjamin Feldman. She is survived by daughters Carol Cataldo (Jim) and Ruth Pomerance, grandchildren Simon Cataldo (Francesca), Eva Berlin (Gdaly), Anna Cataldo, Aaron Prieto and Emilio Prieto. She is also survived by stepdaughter Renee Grandin (Steve), stepson Steve Feldman (Donna), and step-grandchildren Phillip Grandin (Megan), Alex and Will Grandin and step-grandaughter Maria Flippen (Todd). She leaves cherished lifetime friends as well as those met more recently at Brookdale Battery Park. A memorial service will be held in January 2016 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Iris' memory to Harlem Lacrosse and Leadership, P.O. Box 708 NY, New York 10030 or www.harlemlacrosse.org. 1/3

FERBER--Marlene Goldberg, age 70, of Greenport, New York passed away on December 19, 2015. A memorial service will be held at 1:00pm, January 17 at Temple Tifereth Israel, 4th St., Greenport, NY. Marlene was born in Brooklyn, NY on May 1, 1945. She received a bachelor's degree from Brooklyn College and a Masters Degree from the University at New Paltz. Marlene was married to Michael Ferber on December 30, 1969 they were married for 46 years. Marlene's professional career included teaching, marketing and culminated in her becoming the President of a division of a major international marketing corporation. After retirement, Marlene devoted herself to giving back to the community. She was a volunteer for the National Executive Search Corporation. She also became a Master Gardener and established a Fragrance Garden for the North Fork Animal Welfare League, as well as serving on their board. She was in line to become the next Commodore of the Gull Pond Yacht Club when she became ill. Marlene also volunteered for the Cornell Gardeners Volunteer Organization at Long Island Horticulture Society in Riverhead. Marlene was an accomplished sailor, hiker and helped grow oysters in her spare time. Marlene is survived by Michael Ferber, her children Dane and (Erin) and Jesse and (Brenda), her grandchildren, Aubrey and Evan, her sister Bunny, and other family and friends. Her sister Susie Pollack predeceased her. Memorial donations may be given to the North Fork Animal Welfare League (NFAWL) Box 297 Southold, NY 11971. 1/3

WILSON--Felix Zollicoffer, 76, of Juno Beach, FL, died peacefully, in the presence of his family, on December 21, 2015 at the Hospice of Palm Beach County. Felix was born and raised in White Plains, NY, attending St. Bernard's School and Iona Prep and serving in the US Army from 1959-1961. He married Francine Malaney with whom he raised three children in Larchmont, NY. Please visit http://www.JJFFH.com/ for a full obituary. 1/3

THORNHILL--Arthur H.,Jr. 91, died on December 17, 2015 in Charlottesville, Virginia. For 25 years he served as president and CEO of Little, Brown and Company, the prestigious publishing house founded in Boston in 1837. Thornhill's college education at Princeton University was interrupted by World War II while he served nearly four years in the U.S. ground and air forces in the Pacific Theater before returning to Princeton and completing a degree in American history in 1946. Two years later he joined Little, Brown and Company as a trainee and worked in various sales and editorial departments. He was named general manager of the trade division in 1954, elected a vice president in 1955, and became president of Little, Brown, Ltd. (Canada) in 1956. He rose to the position of executive vice president in 1959, and finally, to president and CEO in 1962, succeeding his father Arthur H. Thornhill, Sr. (1895-1970). One of Thornhill's major achievements was negotiating the 1968 merger in which Little, Brown became a subsidiary of Time, Inc., while retaining an independent board of directors, a Massachusetts charter, and full editorial control in all publishing decisions. Major authors published by Little, Brown during his tenure include Norman Mailer, Herman Wouk, Ansel Adams, Lillian Hellman, John Fowles, and Henry Kissinger. Thornhill expanded and developed the law, medical, and college text divisions of the company, and ventured into trade paperback publishing. He was also involved in a variety of activities and organizations both inside and outside the publishing industry, chairing, for example, the American Book Publishers Council's Committee on Reading Development and serving on the Board of Trustees of the Princeton University Press, Bennington College, and the Martha's Vineyard Preservation Trust, and as a fellow at the Center for Creative Photography at the University of Arizona. In 1987, Thornhill retired from Little, Brown. Thereafter, he and his wife Dorothy (deceased 2013) divided their time among residences in Virginia, Florida, and Martha's Vineyard. He was a member of the Union Club, the Century Club, the St. Botolph Club, the Edgartown Yacht Club, the Edgartown Reading Room, the John's Island Club, and the Farmington Country Club. He is survived by a daughter Sandra Brushart, a son Arthur III, and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held later in Duxbury, Massachusetts. Condolences may be sent to the family at www.hillandwood.com. 1/3

RADOW--Seymour, on December 25, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Corynne G. Loving father of Margie (Barry); Forrest, Joan Osleeb, Debra (Chris) Soussanin and Steve Radow. Dear brother. Devoted poppa. Proud WWII Veteran. Services Monday, 11am at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Pine-lawn, L.I. 1/3

BALSHONE--Marianne Lowy Reiss, age 90. An extraordinary woman born in Budapest in 1925. Survived the Holocaust thanks to Raoul Wallenberg and her own courage. Walking the streets with bombs falling around her, she brought food to her family. She devoted her life to promoting Freedom. Her art was the Art of Living; her motto "Carpe Diem." With training in dance before the war ended her childhood, she raised her family in a career of her own creating as one of New York City's first personal trainers. With immaculate fashion sense, elegance and charm she was frequently asked if she was Hungarian monarchy. In 1973 she moved to Columbus OH and opened Globetrotter Wine and Cheese, inspiring broadening of cultural landscape there. Moving to Palm Beach and her beloved turquoise ocean, made her third career speaking to schools about her survival in the Holocaust and the man who saved her family. An inspiring lecturer, she taught that One Person Can Make a Difference. Her history was chronicled in "Determined" (on Amazon) and the "The Envoy" by Alex Kershaw. She left a creative legacy of children joyful artist/ architectural designer Vivian Reiss, Obstetrician-Gyne- cologist Ronald Reiss and wife Carla. Grandchildren composer/entrepreneur Joel Garten, scientist/entrepreneur Ariel Garten, photojournalist Stephen Reiss, events @ Bon Appetite Nikki Reiss, psychologist Dr. Joy Jacobs. The world has lost another Holocaust survivor and incredible friend, mother, woman, strength and inspiration. Funeral this Sunday, 11am, Riverside Chapel, 180W 76th NYC. Gifts to Raoul Wallenberg committee. MarianneBalshone.com 1/3

GERSTEN--Libbie (Izen). Beloved wife of Bobby Gersten for 71 years, passed away peacefully on December 23, 2015 at age 93. Libbie was most proud of and devoted to her family: children Sharon Luckman and Paul Shapiro, Richard and Annemiek Gersten, Jackie and Monte Ezratty, and Ron Gersten; grandchildren Melissa and David Keller, Greg and Beth Luckman, Max Gersten, Thea Gersten, Jake Ezratty, Joanna Ezratty, Ali Gersten, Robbie Gersten; and great- grandchildren Jordana and Aiden Keller, Charley and Casey Luckman, all of whom will miss her dearly. Libbie was a rock in the foundation of Brant Lake Camp documenting the history of camp through her creation of the memorabilia room, yearbooks, photography and more. In her younger years at BLC she taught archery and in 1980 co-founded the Dance Camp. She was strong, energetic, creative; a lover of travel and the arts; a dancer and dance teacher for over 20 years in Long Beach, NY. Libbie grew up in Asheville, NC, and graduated UNC Chapel Hill in 1944. She was the most wonderful, loving wife, mother, grandmother, great- grandmother and friend. 1/3

EHRLICH--Burtt. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our long term YPO Forum member. Burtt was a dear friend, wonderful family man, irreverent, astute observer and advisor. Our thoughts are with his wife, Fran and the entire family. He will be sorely and deeply missed. Jan Endresen, Rudi Flik, Joel Friedman, Arthur Goldstein, Andy Kahn, Tod Johnson, Richard Richman, Neil Ryan, Dan Silver, Alan Stuart 1/3

GOTTLIEB--Stephen Philip, 73, died peacefully and surrounded by family in his home in New York City on December 23, 2015. Born on October 18, 1942 to Lucille and Albert Isaac Gottlieb, Steve was a native of Revere, MA. He graduated from Boston College and Harvard Law School and went on to become a project finance partner at the prestigious Wall Street law firm Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft before founding Argent Group Ltd. and later the Argent Marine Companies. Serving as Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of Argent Marine until his death, Steve was a world-leading expert on the waterborne transportation of liquefied natural gas (LNG) working to revolutionize the LNG transportation market. In addition to a great passion for his work, Steve loved his family, travel, Boston athletic teams, sports cars and his state-of-the-art tropical aquariums. He resided in Incline Village, NV and maintained homes in New York City, San Francisco and Costa Rica. Brilliant, dignified and exceptionally hard working, Steve was an extraordinary man who touched the lives of all those lucky enough to know him. We will remember his warm smile, his unique sense of humor, his passion for life and most of all his steadfast dedication to those he loved. He leaves behind his devoted wife, Denise Miller; brothers, Jay (Gale) and Martin (Jacqui) Gottlieb; three adoring children, David (Betsy) Gottlieb, Kim (Kevin) Klipstein and Vanessa Gottlieb; two step-children, Letia (Matt) Clouston and Zach (Emily) Miller; and four grandchildren, Tanner, Lily, Teagan and Rose. Steve fought tirelessly and with an often super-human fortitude all his life. His departure leaves an emptiness in the hearts of many, but Steve loved and was loved with all heart and soul, and this love will live on. A memorial reception will be held for Steve in February, 2016. Donations in Steve's honor may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. 1/3

DEE--Thomas J.,passed away peacefully on December 23, 2015. Beloved husband of Linda, (deceased). Father of Katherine Dee and Andie (Dee) Butler. Grandfather of Zoe, Sierra, and Jason. Devoted friend. Services private. 1/3

LASKER--Joe. Joe Lasker was the last living member of the 48 prominent realists - including Edward Hopper, John Sloan and Raphael Soyer--who wrote for Reality, the mid-Fifties polemical journal that argued against non-representational art. He died December 3 at age 96 of congestive heart failure in Norwalk, CT. "I feel that much of American art of the last 60 years has something missing, namely narrative," Lasker said in an interview. "Without narrative there would be little left of the art of the Old Masters, of 20th-century expressionism and surrealism. There would be no Guernica by Picasso." The New York Times art critic Howard DeVree wrote of Lasker, "There is a psychological warmth and penetration in the work...especially stimulating canvasses...marvelo- usly effective...a tour de force." His oil paintings and other depictions of cityscapes, landscapes, portraits, fantasies, interiors and still lifes hang in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Smithsonian, Hirshhorn, Philadelphia, Tel Aviv and other museums. He illustrated and/or wrote children's books, including American Library Association Notable Books Merry Ever After (1976) and The Boy Who Loved Music (1979) for Viking Press. His prizes include Prix de Rome and Guggenheim Fellowships and awards from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, and the National Academy of Design, where he was National Academician and secretary. He is represented by Toronto's Liss Gallery (and formerly, for 60 years, New York's Kraushaar Galleries). Joseph Leon Lasker was born in New York in 1919 to Romanian immigrants. In high school, he entered the painting competition of the Treasury Department's Fine Art Section and won commissions for still-extant murals in the Calumet, MI, and Millbury, MA, post offices. At night, he studied at, and graduated from, Cooper Union art school. In WWII he served in the 1147th Engineer Combat Group. He is survived by Mildred (Jaspen), his wife of 67 years; children David, Laura and Evan, grandchildren Ryan Looney and Rebecca Looney-Tulin, and great-grandchildren Ty and Jake Looney. A celebration of his life will be held in Norwalk on Saturday, January 2; email: davidrlasker@gmail.com. 1/3

SEGALL--Sarah. 85, of Brookline, MA, died peacefully on December 21, 2015 in Boston, MA. She was born to the late Ben and Nina Ostrovsky in Montreal, Canada and is survived by her husband, Maurice Segall, of Brookline, MA, to whom she was married for 64 years and by her three children: Elizabeth and her husband, James Sagui; Eric and his wife, Lynne; and Peter and his wife, Jackie, and Sarah's six grandchildren: Jessica, Sara, Katie and Andrew, David and Madeline. Sarah was passionate about many things: literature, art, music, and science. From 1951-1955 she was the dedicated Administrative Assistant to the Director of Canada's National Research Council, Gerhardt Hertzberg. An extraordinary reader and researcher, she held a B.S. from McGill University in Montreal, and a Masters Degree of Library Science from Columbia University, New York. In 1982 she became a student at the Boston Graduate School of Psychoanalysis and graduated with a Certificate of Psychoanalytic Psychotherapy in 1997. She served as a Trustee at the BGSP from 2008-2014 when she was honored for her service to that Institution. Throughout her life, Sarah excelled at understanding others and tried to make a positive difference in the lives of her family, friends, colleagues, and patients. She will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her honor to Boston Graduate School of Psychoanalysis, 1581 Beacon Street, Brookline, MA 02446. A service and celebration of her life will be held at Mount Auburn Cemetery, 580 Mount Auburn Street, Cambridge, Bigelow Chapel, on Sunday, December 27th at 11am. Luncheon immediately following, at her late residence, until 4pm. Services are being handled by Levine Chapels, Brookline, MA. 1/3
LICHTENSTEIN--Harriet Shafran. Harriet we love and miss you so much. Your wisdom, strength and courage leaves us with wonderful memories. Roni & Wally 1/3

RAISLER--Aline "Ali" Stevens, born April 17, 1923 died peacefully on December 25, 2015 in Palm Beach. Beloved wife of the late Ira Stevens and Harold Raisler, survived by her loving children Randall Stevens (Alice), Peggy Winkelman (Martin), adoring granddaughters Taryn, Jaime and Tiffany, and great-grandchildren Charlie and Bo. A graduate of Cornell University in 1943, she earned a Master's in Social Work from Columbia University. She devoted 23 years of her life to help those in need at the National Multiple Sclerosis Society and the Westchester Lighthouse for the Blind. She was active in the Westchester Mental Health and Cornell Alumni Associations. Her intellect, passion for people and love of family, wit and charm will continue to inspire. All are treasured memories and she will be missed. Shiva at 930 5th Avenue, Tuesday, December 29 and Wednesday, December 30, 4-8pm. 1/3

PASIK--Tauba, 88, beloved wife of Pedro Pasik, died peacefully at her home on December 24. As a Professor of Neurology at Mount Sinai, she gained national and international recognition as a physician/scientist and was a role model for several generations of students, residents and fellows. She was a lover of opera, chamber music and poetry, an avid world traveler, a fierce women's rights advocate, a champion of just social causes and most of all a devoted wife, mother and grandmother, whose family was always her utmost priority. She had three children, Deborah, Lilia and Alexander (predeceased), all with doctorates, married to three physicians: Marc, Seth and Agata, and six grandchildren, Laura, Jacob, Joseph, Sara, Samantha and Clement. The family will be receiving at 1200 Fifth Avenue on December 26th, 3-5pm and 27th, 3-5pm. 1/3

WEITZNER--Florence Golding, born September 5, 1922 in Tannersville, New York, died December 23rd, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Walter Weitzner. She is survived by her daughters Lori Weitzner Parr and Ame Weitzner Enwright and grandchildren Emma and Sophie Parr and Michael and Catherine Enwright. 1/3

DONOVAN--William J. "Bill," passed away peacefully at home on November 6, 2015 at the age of 75. He grew up and lived most of his life in Scarsdale, NY. After graduating from Scarsdale High School in 1959, he attended Dayton College in Ohio, graduating with honors and a degree in history. He worked as an actor in the 1970s with parts in Taxi Driver, Serpico and Phantom of the Paradise as well as in TV and theater. Thereafter, he produced a bicentennial series for PBS. For many years, Bill had a successful career as an event and commercial photographer while also directing, writing and producing two award winning documentaries. The first of these, "Inheritance" was released in 1987 and featured at the Sundance (then US) Film Festival. His second film, titled "Michael Harrington and Today's Other America - Corporate Power and Inequality" was about the life and legacy of the democratic socialist who inspired Presidents Kennedy and Johnson to wage the War on Poverty. It was released in 1999 by the Filmmaker's Library and is still shown in college classrooms throughout the country. Bill is survived by his wife of forty-two years, Ruth and his adult children Ben and Lisa. At the request of his family, donations in his memory may be made to Calvary Hospice. 1/3

EISENSTEIN--Rebe, age 95, of Hackensack, NJ, on December 25, 2015. Aunt, cousin, friend and singer extraordinaire. Predeceased by beloved husband, Alvin, and cherished daughter, Enid. Graveside service 11:30am Monday, December 28, 2015 at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla. Her friends and family will miss her voice and loving spirit. 1/3

SUSS--Asher. 64, a well-known voiceover artist and actor in New York City, gifted mimic of numerous foreign accents, linguist, polyglot and warm hearted Renaissance man, died suddenly of a heart attack in his apartment on December 16, 2015. Asher grew up in Baltimore, the son of Molly and Abraham Suss, the latter a Holocaust survivor. He excelled in school and went on to earn a B.A. and M.A. in International Relations at Johns Hopkins University and a JD from George Washington University. After studying Italian at the University of Bologna, Asher came to New York in the late 1970s and practiced product liability and trademark law. Asher loved music. At age 14, he graduated from the Peabody Conservatory in saxophone and began taking lessons at Juilliard with Joe Allard. Later at Juilliard, he studied music theory and took lessons in voice as a bass-baritone with the renowned tenor Charles Bressler. He left legal practice and went into arts administration, serving as executive director of the Long Island Philharmonic, the Washington Bach Consort, the Hoboken Chamber Orchestra, and the Steinway Foundation, where he produced a concert at the Kennedy Center for which he commissioned piano concerti from three prominent composers (Rodion Shchedrin, Lalo Schifrin and Lowell Liebermann), conducted by Mstislav Rostropovich. As Executive Director of the National Association of Performing Arts Managers and Agents, he organized the first-ever international conference of artists' managers, held at the United Nations. Asher got into voiceover work after making talking books for the Jewish Braille Institute. In 2003, he received the Candle of Understanding Award for his work with JBI for giving more hours that year than any other volunteer in recent memory. Asher's numerous credits for voiceover and acting on stage and across TV, film, print, online/multimedia, and modeling can best be seen on such internet sites as backstage.com/AsherSuss/, AsherSuss.com, IMdb, Youtube and Facebook. For many years Asher also acted as Santa Claus for Macy's, delighting children and their parents by speaking in their native languages. Asher proudly appeared on stage in the Yiddish adaptation of the Pirates of Penzance. In November 2007 Asher appeared on the cover of TimeOut New York Magazine reflecting an advertising campaign for "Ugly Can Be Beautiful Too;" however, Asher was anything but ugly. A beautiful man, Asher is survived by his brother Norman, niece Jessica, and nephew Jonathan. Asher leaves to mourn a circle of friends and relatives who were vastly enriched by his intelligence, knowledge, humor, and heart. As he had an abiding interest in Jewish history and affairs, please send any donations to the Center for Jewish History in New York, the Jewish Braille Institute or the American Heart Association. A graveside ceremony will be held at the Chizuk Amuno Arlington Cemetery, Baltimore, Maryland at 9am on Sunday, December 27, 2015. 1/3

GOSS--Richard Wayne II, of San Francisco, CA, and Fishers Island, NY, on December 17, 2015, aged 82. He is survived by his wife Michele du Pont Goss, his son Richard Wayne Goss III and daughter-in-law Karen Barfod Goss, his son Jared du Pont Goss, his daughter Holland Goss Lynch and son-in-law K.C. Lynch, and five grandchildren. He is also survived by his brother Porter J. Goss, his sisters Wayne G. Douglas, and Garril G. Page, and numerous nieces and nephews. Born on November 3, 1933, in Waterbury, CT, to Richard Wayne Goss and Virginia Johnston Goss, he graduated from The Fessenden School (1947), The Hotchkiss School (1951), and Yale University (1955). He served in the United States Army as a 1st Lieutenant in the Artillery at Fort Sill, OK. As a member of the All-Army track team he set numerous athletic records. An investment banker at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith from 1957 to 1981, he moved to San Francisco in 1965 to open the firm's first office outside of New York City. From 1981 to 1985 he was an executive recruiter at Korn/Ferry International before returning to investment banking at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette from 1985 until his retirement in 1990. Elected to the board of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco in 1986, he served as its president from 1991 to 1998; he subsequently joined the Fine Arts Museums Foundation, and was its president from 2001 to 2007. He was a former trustee of Town School, The Hotchkiss School, Enterprise for High School Students, and Children's Hospital. He was a member of the Pacific-Union Club, the Fishers Island Club, Hay Harbor Club, the Fishers Island Yacht Club, amongst others. He was long active in La Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin. Memorials will be held at a later date in San Francisco and Fishers Island. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco or The Hotchkiss School. 1/3

RUSSELL--Donald G.,84, an oil industry executive who served in several Vice President positions with Shell Oil and as President and Chief Executive Officer of Sonat Exploration, passed away December 19, 2015, after a lengthy illness. Russell authored or coauthored several industry standard publications and was a past President of the Society of Petroleum Engineers. He was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 1982. 1/3

HALLIDAY--James Denbigh, died December 12, 2015 at the age of 89. Born in Brooklyn, NY. Served in Army Air Force, 1943-45. A graduate of Brooklyn College and NYU School of Business. Worked for E.F. Hutton, F.C.I.A. and as a financial consultant in Jamaica, the Philippines, and Guyana. Jim is predeceased by his son, Richard, his granddaughter, Elissa, and his stepgrandson, Tommy. He is survived by his wife, Joyce Davison, his children Emmett (Rose Reyes), James (Karen Eisner), Christine (Bruce Hermansdorfer), David, and their mother Maryjane Halliday, his grandchildren Nick, Marta, John, and Richard, his deceased brother Robert K. Halliday's children Deborah, Robert, Diane, and Maryclaire, his step-children Steven, Michael (Shionnie), Edward (Katie), and Wendy (Marc), his step-grandchildren Chuck, Christina, Amanda, and Jessica. Jim donated his body to the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School Anatomical Association. A celebration of his life will be held on January 29, 2016. For more information please email: jhalliday2015@gmail.com 1/3
SUSSMAN--Robert. Artist, on December 24, age 72. Father of Leilani, Adeline, Joshua, Leda. Brother of Philip. 1/3

FLURER--Ursula, daughter of Friedrich Flurer and Anna Heber died on November 25, 2015 in New York, NY. Born on June 12, 1937, a Gemini, in Bad Mergentheim, Germany, she graduated with a degree in graphic design from one of the world's leading design schools, Hochschule fur Gestaltung (HfG), University of Art and Design, Offenbach. In Frankfurt she began her professional career working at McCann Advertising. In 1967, Ursula moved to New York and quickly became a sought after designer for leading international brands. In 1972, Ursula launched her own company. A true innovator for more than forty years, Ursula has nearly two hundred US patents associated with her product design work. Known for restrained designs that appealed to consumers worldwide and successfully drove sales, Ursula referred to her design work as "playing with shapes." Her mission was to "create things that make everyday more beautiful." The pursuit of perfection resulted in Ursula's award-winning and iconic 1970s design for Bristol-Myers Tickle deodorants. Flurer's impressive body of work includes beauty and healthcare package designs for Ponds, Colgate-Palmolive, Coty Inc., Del Laboratories, Johnson & Johnson, Novartis, Unilever, Lego, Playtex, and Weight Watchers International, to only name a few. Ursula had a lifelong curiosity of the world: self development, energies, dynamics, spirituality, cultures and communities. Together with her companion of the last 27 years, Dr. Howard Eggers, she traveled the globe making friends everywhere she went. For more than forty years, summer weekends found Ursula with the beaches and dunes of Davis Park, Fire Island. Truly her happy place. Next June a celebration of Ursula's life will take place on Fire Island. Ursula is survived by dozens of friends all around the world, who knew her unconditional kindness and who considered her to be "family." 1/3

HORTON--Carl, Sr.,died November 5 at age 71 in Windermere, FL after a yearlong battle with cancer. Born and raised in Philadelphia, he was the oldest child of the late Willie and Dorothy Horton. He graduated from Morgan State University ('67) and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania ('72). His lifetime career in marketing and the spirits industry culminated with his 2001 appointment to CEO and president of Absolut Spirits Co. Inc. - the third-largest distilled spirits brand in the U.S. at the time. Carl was a proud member of Kappa Alpha Psi fraternity, loved golf and photography. He is survived by his wife, Regina Marrow; his children Meredith and Carl Jr. and their mother Phyllis Clark (nee Sims); sisters Brenda Harris, Inez (Doug) Ward, Sheila Horton; and brothers William (Cindy) and Leon (Edwina McIntosh) Horton. Carl was cremated and a celebration of his life will be held in the spring. Donations may be made to Morgan State University at: www.givetomorgan.com. Please mark "In memory of Carl Horton." 1/3

DULDNER--Kurt P. Kurt P. Duldner died peacefully surrounded by his family on December 3, 2015, one month shy of his 93rd birthday. Born on January 9, 1923 in Vienna, Austria, Kurt's carefree boyhood abruptly came to an end in 1938 with the Nazi invasion of Austria. Like thousands of other refugees, Kurt's journey to freedom and survival took him through the European underground to Brussels and France. Traveling with his older cousin, sewing and selling leather bags for pocket change, they traveled to Marseille, where they boarded a boat to Shanghai, one of the few places that accepted refugees without a visa. There they were reunited with Kurt's family and joined the community of 25,000 Jewish European refugees who had fled Nazi persecution. While in China he worked for a chemical trading company, which laid the groundwork for what would later be a successful career in the United States. When the Communist government came to power in 1949, Kurt, unable to find work, moved to New York CIty. There he met and married his first wife Ida. Together they had two children, Marianne and Laura. Kurt's love of life knew no bounds. Beyond being a devoted and generous family man, he had the incredible gift to be able to connect with all sorts of people in various walks of life: befriending countless colleagues, taxi drivers, workmen, elevator men, and hat check ladies. An inimitable force, he brought life to any party and a smile to those he met. He had a long and successful career and was widely known and respected by his many friends for his business acumen, considerable intelligence, lively wit, and infectious sense of humor including his hilariously botched sayings such as "we will come to that bridge when we get there," "grab the horn by the bull" and "get me off the hooker." Kurt never forgot his love and gratitude to the Chinese people. He was instrumental in erecting a commemorative plaque in Shanghai thanking the Chinese people for creating a safe haven for the Jewish refugees. Whether traveling the world, skiing the slopes of Aspen, playing an intense tennis match, or enjoying the symphony and opera, Kurt's love of life knew no bounds. And in keeping true to his Viennese roots, no meal, whether served in a four star restaurant, or a salami sandwich, was complete without a glass of fine wine and a good piece of chocolate. He shared his love of life with the family he cherished, his beloved wife, Anne Foster Duldner, devoted daughters Marianne and Laura, dear son-in-law Steven Sherman and treasured granddaughters Lilli and Nicole. With a twinkle in his eye and that knowing grin, he enriched the lives of everyone who had the privilege of knowing him. Dear, sweet Kurti, a life well lived. 1/3

BASSETT--Margaret. For- mer Upper West Side real estate broker and gifted pianist Margaret Bassett, 78, passed away December 6. Beloved mother, grandmother and friend. A celebration of her life, with music, is scheduled February 6, 2016 at NYSEC. dimicelifuneralhome.com. 1/3

GOLDMAN--William "Bill" Allen. 1940-2015. Bill Goldman's deep, wide chest held a heart that always had room for one more. All who met Bill recognized and responded to his quick wit, compassionate nature and propensity for corny jokes. In 1966, Bill joined the law firm, Dreisbach, Crabbe, Newlon, Bilger, Brown & James. He left to serve as general counsel for the Homewood Corporation, and guided their expansion. In 1999, Bill returned to the legal profession, setting up a fortuitous partnership with Michael Braunstein, Professor Emeritus at The Ohio State University. Together, Goldman & Braunstein cut a brilliant swath through the field of eminent domain, defending Ohio property owners faced with the threat of losing their land to powerful pipeline companies. The two became business partners and best friends. Bill was as comfortable in a room full of flannel- shirted farmers as he was in a courtroom. "Leveling the playing field" for landowners became Bill's mission and passion. With the steadfast support of his beloved paralegal, Sherry Evanichko, Goldman & Braunstein became the Midwest's leading eminent domain firm. Personally, Bill mixed long-term, treasured relationships with newer, equally meaningful, friendships. He found happiness with his "third and final" wife, Joanna, an enduring union for the last 25 years. Both enjoyed spending time with family and their multi- generational friends, traveling, reading and debating. There wasn't a more ardent Ohio State University Buckeye fan or scathing couch- coach than Bill. Bill and Joanna enjoyed time in California with the family they treasured: Kimberly (Goldman) and Javier Garcia, Shelby and Beth Goldman, grandkids Tyler, Madeleine Rose, Vincent, Julia and Will, beloved sister-in-law Betty Larson, and faithful dogs, Teddy and Winston. Bill embraced his community, serving on the Boards of the Jewish Community Center of Greater Columbus, Franklin County Veterans Memorial and The Columbus Zoo. Bill filled his six-foot-three frame with optimism, boundless energy and a voice that commanded attention. He spoke his mind, eloquently and passionately. He was a friend everyone could count on. He touched the lives of thousands, loved and admired by countless clients, colleagues and friends. He will never be forgotten. 1/3

DOUGAN--Susan Stauffer, died peacefully of natural causes on December 10, in Camarillo, CA, at the age of 78. Suzie grew up in New York City and Tenafly, NJ, graduated from Tenafly High School and Boston University, and later lived in Brooklyn Heights, Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, and for many years in Palm Desert, CA. A blithe spirit has left us. Transparently honest, humble to a fault, overlooking the shortcomings of others, and forever young, Suzie made permanent friends easily, touching so many with her boundless care. An avid reader, animal lover, gifted painter and deeply spiritual person, Suzie was an early survivor of breast cancer -- miraculously living another 34 years. Suzie is survived by her loving son Cameron, his step-sisters Elizabeth and Amanda, his new family Ann, Eli and Makayla, her former husband (of many years) Hugh, and his wife Jane, and by her dear step- and half-brothers and sisters, including John Allen, Paddy, Eugene, and Linda, and their families, and many long-term friends including Mary and John, and others too numerous to list. We treasured her presence and love, and will all deeply miss her. 1/3

AUERBACH--Elliot H. December 23, 2015. Elliot was a physicist at Brookhaven National Laboratory for more than three decades and a proud member of the Board of Directors of the New York Civil Liberties Union and of its Suffolk County Chapter. In addition to his accomplishments as a scientist, he lived an active life as a skier and world traveler. Elliot will be missed by all who enjoyed him, his wonderful sense of humor and his extraordinary mind. He is survived by his loving wife, Rita Auerbach; his sister, Brenda Seitelman, and her family; and his brother-in-law, Todd Breitbart. Contributions in his memory can be made to the New York Civil Liberties Union--Suffolk County Chapter, Touro Law Public Advocacy Center, 225 Eastview Drive, PA 221, Central Islip, NY 11722. 1/3

ROSEN--Ruth Metzger. 1920 - 2015. Died at home December 25. Beloved wife of the late Jesse Rosen and loving mother of Phyllis and Frank Bocian, Janet Kleinman, and Bob Rosen and Marcia Golub; devoted grandmother of David and Dawn Bocian, Michael and Debbie Bocian, Rachel Kleinman, Charlie and Danielle Kleinman, and Zack Rosen, and proud and cherished "GG" to Tommy, Mia, Hannah, Sarah and Jesse. There will be a private family burial on Sunday. Shiva will be at Ruth's apartment Sunday from 4-9pm and Monday and Tuesday from 1-5pm and 7-9pm. Contributions in Ruth's memory may be made to the Coalition for the Homeless. 1/3

BERLIND--Robert Elliot, 77, painter extraordinaire, died on December 17th. Son of Peter Berlind and Mae Miller Berlind. Survived by his wife Mary Lucier, sons Alexey and Gabriel, brothers Roger and Alan and predeceased by Bruce. A graduate of Andover, Columbia University and the Yale School of Art. Service, Monday, December 21st at 2pm, Plaza Jewish Community Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

FELDMAN--Iris Kellner, 1930-2015 died on December 20, 2015 at her home in Manhattan. A graduate of Packer Collegiate Institute and Goucher College, Iris had a career as a fundraiser for United Jewish Appeal, Israel Bonds and Brandeis University. Iris was predeceased by her husband, Benjamin Feldman. She is survived by daughters Carol Cataldo (Jim) and Ruth Pomerance, grandchildren Simon Cataldo (Francesca), Eva Berlin (Gdaly), Anna Cataldo, Aaron Prieto and Emilio Prieto. She is also survived by stepdaughter Renee Grandin (Steve), stepson Steve Feldman (Donna), and step-grandchildren Phillip Grandin (Megan), Alex and Will Grandin and step-grandaughter Maria Flippen (Todd). She leaves cherished lifetime friends as well as those met more recently at Brookdale Battery Park. A memorial service will be held in January 2016 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Iris' memory to Harlem Lacrosse and Leadership, P.O. Box 708 NY, New York 10030 or www.harlemlacrosse.org. 1/3

EHRLICH--Burtt. Our hearts are broken. Burtt was one of a kind and we will miss, remember and love him always. We know he is smoking a cigar and doing the New York Times crossword puzzle with lightning speed. We send all our love to Fran, Steven and Kathleen, Julie and Noam, David and the entire family. Tom, Margo, Sarah, Dan and Stacy 1/3

DWEK--Joe, MD, MRCP, FACP, died peacefully at home on Friday, December 25, 2015 at the age of 87 after a long illness. He is survived by Sally, his beloved wife of 57 years, his four children, David (Jamie), Steven (Holly), Robert (Alissa), and Adele Dubin (Daniel), and eleven grandchildren. Born in Paris, Dr. Dwek grew up in Manchester England and graduated from medical school in Manchester and Edinburgh. After immigrating to the US in 1959, Dr. Dwek joined the staff of Booth Memorial Medical Center (now New York-Presbyterian-Queens) in 1966 and was Chairman of the department of Medicine and program director from 1973-1989 and chairman of Academic Affairs from 1989-93. He served for many years as Clinical Associate Professor of Medicine at New York University School of Medicine and was the William Harris visiting professor in Taiwan from 1995-1999. In 2000, he launched HealthReach NY, a not-for-profit organization providing free medical care to the uninsured in Queens. Funeral services will be held Sunday morning at 9:15am at Riverside Chapel at 180 West 76th Street. Shiva will be observed at home through Friday morning. 1/3

RUBIN--Robert Jay, MD, age 87, died on Monday December 21, 2015 at JFK Medical Center in Edison, NJ. Born in Brooklyn, he had resided in Watchung, NJ for 40 years. Dr. Rubin was Chief of Surgery at JFK Medical Center for many years. He also was a clinical professor of surgery at RWJ Medical School and was co-director of the residency training program in Colon and Rectal Surgery. Dr. Rubin was on staff for many years at Muhlenberg Hospital, RWJ University Hospital and JFK Hospital. Husband of Lillian (Garshofsky) Rubin; father of Mark Rubin and his wife Jennifer, Mitch Kunzman and his wife Jen and Douglas Kunzman and his wife Lexy; his daughter Lisa Cherepon and her husband Bill and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on January 3, 2016 at 11am at Higgins Home for Funerals, 752 Mountain Blvd., Watchung, NJ 07069. 1/3

WESLER--Phyllis Albert, a noted fashion designer in New York, beloved wife of Allan Wesler, and mother of Robert Wesler and Elizabeth Jill Wesler and sister to Richard Albert, died December 22, 2015 in Miami FL. Services will be held at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, 7800 Myrtle Ave Glendale, NY on Monday December 28 at 1:30pm. 1/3

WICKENHEISER--Robert J.,Ph.D. Born in Strasburg, ND, 1943, son of Margaret and Joseph F. Wickenheiser, died November 25 at home surrounded by his wife Patricia and five children: Kari, Kristen (Scott), Kathryn, Kort (Cathy) and Kyle (Harneet). He attended St. John's Prep in Minnesota, BA in Philosophy at St. Benedict's College in Atkinson, KS 1965, Noviate at Assumption Abbey in Richardson, ND, MA and PhD in English Literature from University of Minnesota (1970). He taught English Literature at Princeton University, New Jersey for seven years. In 1978 he became the youngest college President in the US at Mount St. Mary's in Emmetsburg, MD, where he served for 16 years. In 1995, he became the President of St. Bonaventure University, a Franciscan site. He served for nine years, raising money for the Regina Quick Center for the Arts and the Robert Kenney Museum, and the William Richter Recreation Center plus many other University causes, including the Friedsdam Library. He was a specialist in the works of John Milton, and his huge Milton collection now resides at the University of South Carolina, who published an illustrated catalogue. He was writing a book about the poet/writer Willam Herbert before his death. He was a great scholar, teacher, administrator, and person who was admired by colleagues, students and many friends. He was witty, kind and courageous during his bouts of ill health. He leaves his wife Patricia, five children, grandchildren and two brothers Alvin and James and a sister Alice Muckenhien, nieces, nephews, cousins and many devoted friends and SBU Alumni. A service was held at St. John's Catholic Church on December 1 in Olean, NY. Donations may be made in his memory to Assumption Abbey, Richardton, NB. Dr. Anthony Bannon and Priscilla Cunningham, Former Chairs of the Quick Art Center Council. 1/3

MARCUS--Lottie Blumlein. The board and staff of American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev are deeply saddened by the loss of Lottie Blumlein Marcus, an energetic, kind-hearted woman of valor. Together with her beloved husband of 72 years, the late Dr. Howard Marcus, Lottie made a significant impact on Israel's Negev region through her magnanimous support of Ben- Gurion University of the Negev (BGU). In 2004, Lottie and Howard were awarded honorary doctoral degrees by BGU in recognition of their pioneering spirit, exceptional philanthropy and dedication to Israel and higher education. The Marcus Family Campus in Beer-Sheva reflects their commitment to the University and to the fulfillment of David Ben-Gurion's vision to build a world-class institution of education and research in the Negev desert. Lottie will be deeply missed. We extend our profound condolences to her daughter, Ellen Marcus, a BGU board vice chair, and Ellen's husband, Harvey Malyn; to Lottie's granddaughter, Jennifer Hill and her husband, Ryan; to Ellen's stepson, Michael Malyn; and to all those who have been touched by Lottie's gentle benevolence. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lloyd Goldman, President Ruth Flinkman-Marandy, SW Campaign Chair Doron Krakow, EVP Philip Gomperts, SW Reg. Dir. 1/3

SCHAPIRO--Dr. Morris "Shep", of Boca Raton, FL, age 97, died peacefully at home on December 21. He was a physician in Bayonne, NJ, for 40+ years and a decorated veteran of World War II. Predeceased by his beloved wives Evelyn Gershonowitz and Florence Simko, he was a devoted husband to Barbara Grossman for the past 18 years. Besides Barbara, he leaves daughter Judy Yogman (Robert Sartini), son Steven Schapiro (partner Placida Gallegos), grandsons Joshua (fiancee Mirissa) and Eli Jelly Schapiro (Zsofia), former daughter-in-law, Katherine Jelly, nephew Ned Shandloff (Pattie), grandnieces Brooke and Heather Appell (Evan), great-granddaughter Amalia, great-grandniece Sophie, nephews Martin (Alice) and Robert (Tina) Cooper, Barbara's children, Stephen Grossman (Sue), Sharon Meyer (Keith), and Beth Shuster (Mark), and their families, and brother-in-law Morton Spar. Graveside service Sunday at 2pm at Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island. 1/3

KELLY--Kenneth. Of Winchester, December 23, 2015. Beloved husband of Kim (Roop) Kelly. Loving son of Thomas and Catherine (Kearney) Kelly of Ireland. Devoted father of Michael and Samantha Kelly. Son-in-law of William and Karen Roop of Concord. Dear brother of Naill Kelly of Bermuda and Alan Kelly of Medford. Uncle of Fiona, Aidan, and Scarlett. Brother-in-law of Matthew Roop of Maine. Also survived by many loving friends. Funeral procession from the George L. Doherty Funeral Home, 855 Broadway (Powder House Square) Somerville, Wednesday morning at 10am followed by a Funeral Mass in St. Joseph Church, Somerville at 11am. Relatives and friends invited. Calling hours Monday 3-8pm and Tuesday 5-8pm. Interment Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Concord. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Kenneth's memory to the Respond Inc, 66-70 Union Square, Somerville, MA 02143 www.respondinc.org. Kenneth was a Business Entrepreneur, Board of Director and member of the Somerville Chamber of Commerce, Union Square, Business Group Chairperson, Owner of the Vital Site Services, Inc, Independent and Brass Union, Union Square, Foundry and Saloon, Davis Square, and River Bar, Assembly Row. Recipient of John W. Fitzgerald Lifetime Achievement Award. For more information please visit: dohertyfuneralservice.com 1/3

KIPPUR--Robert. Age 71 years, Artist, of West 22nd Street, New York City. Had shows of his artwork in New York City. Graveside service Tuesday, 2:30pm at Northport Rural Cemetery, Sandy Hollow Road, Northport. Services are being handled by Nolan & Taylor- Howe Funeral Home: (800)261-8338, nthfh.com 1/3

AUERBACH--Elliot H. December 23, 2015. Elliot was a physicist at Brookhaven National Laboratory for more than three decades and a proud member of the Board of Directors of the New York Civil Liberties Union and of its Suffolk County Chapter. In addition to his accomplishments as a scientist, he lived an active life as a skier and world traveler. Elliot will be missed by all who enjoyed him, his wonderful sense of humor and his extraordinary mind. He is survived by his loving wife, Rita Auerbach; his sister, Brenda Seitelman, and her family; and his brother-in-law, Todd Breitbart. Contributions in his memory can be made to the New York Civil Liberties Union--Suffolk County Chapter, Touro Law Public Advocacy Center, 225 Eastview Drive, PA 221, Central Islip, NY 11722. 1/3
RAYBON--Warren G. December 28, 1925-August 2, 1997. Happy 90th birthday. We love and miss you every day. Hilde, Monica and Christopher 1/3

GOLDBERG--Avery Ira. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member, Avery Ira Goldberg. Beloved husband of Leila, son of past Chairman of the Board, Bernard and Carole Goldberg, benefactors of the Bernard and Carole Goldberg Ballroom, brother of Stewart. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President 1/3

DWEK--Joe, MD, MRCP, FACP, died peacefully at home on Friday, December 25, 2015 at the age of 87 after a long illness. He is survived by Sally, his beloved wife of 57 years, his four children, David (Jamie), Steven (Holly), Robert (Alissa), and Adele Dubin (Daniel), and eleven grandchildren. Born in Paris, Dr. Dwek grew up in Manchester England and graduated from medical school in Manchester and Edinburgh. After immigrating to the US in 1959, Dr. Dwek joined the staff of Booth Memorial Medical Center (now New York-Presbyterian-Queens) in 1966 and was Chairman of the department of Medicine and program director from 1973-1989 and chairman of Academic Affairs from 1989-93. He served for many years as Clinical Associate Professor of Medicine at New York University School of Medicine and was the William Harris visiting professor in Taiwan from 1995-1999. In 2000, he launched HealthReach NY, a not-for-profit organization providing free medical care to the uninsured in Queens. Funeral services will be held Sunday morning at 9:15am at Riverside Chapel at 180 West 76th Street. Shiva will be observed at home through Friday morning. 1/3

MALINA--Evelyn Dorfman. Died peacefully on December 24th, at the age of 97, in Santa Monica, CA. Evy had a big family, with Fred of 54 years, and lots of friends. Interested and interesting, generous and kind. Send thanks to: Comfort Choice Hospice, 6222 Wilshire Blvd. Suite 225, Los Angeles, CA 90048. 1/3

GOSS--Richard Wayne II, of San Francisco, CA, and Fishers Island, NY, on December 17, 2015, aged 82. He is survived by his wife Michele du Pont Goss, his son Richard Wayne Goss III and daughter-in-law Karen Barfod Goss, his son Jared du Pont Goss, his daughter Holland Goss Lynch and son-in-law K.C. Lynch, and five grandchildren. He is also survived by his brother Porter J. Goss, his sisters Wayne G. Douglas, and Garril G. Page, and numerous nieces and nephews. Born on November 3, 1933, in Waterbury, CT, to Richard Wayne Goss and Virginia Johnston Goss, he graduated from The Fessenden School (1947), The Hotchkiss School (1951), and Yale University (1955). He served in the United States Army as a 1st Lieutenant in the Artillery at Fort Sill, OK. As a member of the All-Army track team he set numerous athletic records. An investment banker at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith from 1957 to 1981, he moved to San Francisco in 1965 to open the firm's first office outside of New York City. From 1981 to 1985 he was an executive recruiter at Korn/Ferry International before returning to investment banking at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette from 1985 until his retirement in 1990. Elected to the board of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco in 1986, he served as its president from 1991 to 1998; he subsequently joined the Fine Arts Museums Foundation, and was its president from 2001 to 2007. He was a former trustee of Town School, The Hotchkiss School, Enterprise for High School Students, and Children's Hospital. He was a member of the Pacific-Union Club, the Fishers Island Club, Hay Harbor Club, the Fishers Island Yacht Club, amongst others. He was long active in La Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin. Memorials will be held at a later date in San Francisco and Fishers Island. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco or The Hotchkiss School. 1/3

RAISLER--Aline "Ali" Stevens, born April 17, 1923 died peacefully on December 25, 2015 in Palm Beach. Beloved wife of the late Ira Stevens and Harold Raisler, survived by her loving children Randall Stevens (Alice), Peggy Winkelman (Martin), adoring granddaughters Taryn, Jaime and Tiffany, and great-grandchildren Charlie and Bo. A graduate of Cornell University in 1943, she earned a Master's in Social Work from Columbia University. She devoted 23 years of her life to help those in need at the National Multiple Sclerosis Society and the Westchester Lighthouse for the Blind. She was active in the Westchester Mental Health and Cornell Alumni Associations. Her intellect, passion for people and love of family, wit and charm will continue to inspire. All are treasured memories and she will be missed. Shiva at 930 5th Avenue, Tuesday, December 29 and Wednesday, December 30, 4-8pm. 1/3

GERSTEN--Libbie (Izen). Beloved wife of Bobby Gersten for 71 years, passed away peacefully on December 23, 2015 at age 93. Libbie was most proud of and devoted to her family: children Sharon Luckman and Paul Shapiro, Richard and Annemiek Gersten, Jackie and Monte Ezratty, and Ron Gersten; grandchildren Melissa and David Keller, Greg and Beth Luckman, Max Gersten, Thea Gersten, Jake Ezratty, Joanna Ezratty, Ali Gersten, Robbie Gersten; and great- grandchildren Jordana and Aiden Keller, Charley and Casey Luckman, all of whom will miss her dearly. Libbie was a rock in the foundation of Brant Lake Camp documenting the history of camp through her creation of the memorabilia room, yearbooks, photography and more. In her younger years at BLC she taught archery and in 1980 co-founded the Dance Camp. She was strong, energetic, creative; a lover of travel and the arts; a dancer and dance teacher for over 20 years in Long Beach, NY. Libbie grew up in Asheville, NC, and graduated UNC Chapel Hill in 1944. She was the most wonderful, loving wife, mother, grandmother, great- grandmother and friend. 1/3

RUSSELL--Donald G.,84, an oil industry executive who served in several Vice President positions with Shell Oil and as President and Chief Executive Officer of Sonat Exploration, passed away December 19, 2015, after a lengthy illness. Russell authored or coauthored several industry standard publications and was a past President of the Society of Petroleum Engineers. He was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 1982. 1/3

WEISHAR--Joseph, 83, on December 25, 2015. Founder and president of New Vision Studios in New York City. Beloved husband of Sandra Driesen, devoted father of Margo and Peter (Donna), cherished stepfather of Jane (Vincent) and Daniel (Robin), adored grandfather of Marshall, Madeline, Natalie and Nathan, Isabella and Alexandra. Also survived by many cousins and friends. Service Monday, December 28, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory to The Players, 16 Gramercy Park S., NY, NY 10003 would be appreciated. 1/3
