HARTE--Judith Shereff, of Livingston, NJ, passed away in New York City on Wednesday, December 30, 2015 after a long and courageous fight with lung cancer. She was 77. Judi was an amazing mother, grandmother, sister, and woman. She enjoyed gardening, reading, painting, sculpting, music and building and fixing things. For a small person, Judi had a huge heart and always opened up her home and her heart to help others. After Hurricane Sandy, she had many displaced people stay with her for extended periods of time and never felt like it was too much; instead, she always said that she wished they would stay longer since she really enjoyed being with them and helping them. Judi was born to Abraham and Rose Shereff on June 18, 1938 in New York City and raised in Forest Hills, NY. She was preceded in death by her parents. Judi is survived by her brother and sister-in-law Richard and Susan Shereff; daughter Helaine Harte and son-in-law David Rhode, her sons and daughters-in-law Douglas and Ronni Harte and Jonathan and Belynda Harte; and the pride of her life, her grandchildren, Alex and Haleigh Harte and Tyler, Casey and Rebecca Rhode. Judi loved all animals. After being a teacher and raising her children, she worked at Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange, NJ, and spent many years rescuing and rehabilitating injured and orphaned wild animals and birds. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Turtle Back Zoo in Judi's honor. Funeral service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue in New York City at 11:30am on Sunday, January 3rd. 1/3

DICKLER--Ruth Crohn, 102, died Thursday, December 31, at home of natural causes. A native New Yorker who loved the City-its parks, museums, concert halls and people, she lived with her father, Dr. Burrill B. Crohn, after her parents divorced when she was 12. Her brother, the late Dr. Eduard B. Crohn, lived with their mother, Lucile Pels Crohn, in Europe. Mrs. Dickler met her husband-to-be, the late Gerald Dickler, when they were in their mid-teens. He was already attending Columbia College; she went to Barnard College for two years before dropping out to help support them while he began practicing law. She was librarian and book review editor, as well as a board member, at Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York. She also served as president of The Burrill B. Crohn Research Foundation at Mount Sinai Hospital. But her greatest passion was philanthropy. She and her husband made large donations to institutions they both loved: the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the New York Public Library, the 92nd Street Y, UJA and Planned Parenthood. They also planned gifts to other city institutions. She leaves three daughters, Abby Pratt of West Stockbridge, Massachusetts and Squirrel Island, Maine, and her husband, Larry Pratt; Jane Dickler Lebow of New York City and Susan Dickler of New York City and West Tisbury, Massachusetts, and her husband, Sig Van Raan. She had four grandchildren, Sam Pratt, Kate Lebow, Dr. Robert Pratt and Emily Hoppe; three stepgrandchildren, Jackson, Sofie and Zoe Van Raan, and four great-grandchildren, Lucy and Owen Pratt and Naomi and Jacob Lawrence. There will be no funeral. A gathering of family and friends is planned in the future. Donations in her memory may be made to The Burrill B. Crohn Research Foundation at Mount Sinai Medical Center or Citizens Housing and Planning Council. 1/3

GEIGER--Melissa Brown Wiley, died of natural causes in New York City on Saturday, December 19, 2015 surrounded by her loving family. Born in Bay Shore, NY in 1937, she was the oldest child of Melissa Adams and Robert Hoffman Wiley. Melissa graduated from Spring Valley High School, Spring Valley, NY in 1955. She attended Skidmore College and married in 1957. Howard and Melissa began their marriage at Dartmouth College. Howard's career brought them to many places: Munich, Germany; New Jersey; Minneapolis; San Francisco and finally settling down in Manhattan in 1987. Their lifelong home was on Lake George in Putnam, NY. Melissa brought music and friendship wherever she went; these passions defined her life. An extremely talented pianist, she played the organ for her church beginning at age 12. Melissa played an active role in her children's education, always volunteering, often as the accompanist for school musical productions. She sang in the Plymouth Church Choir and with the Plymouth Music Series. She supported the Minnesota Opera. Melissa was the Minister of Music, Organist and Choir Director at Suffern Presbyterian Church in Suffern, NY. While living in San Francisco, she sang in the Unitarian Church Choir and was a board member of The San Francisco Chamber Singers, now called Volti. In Manhattan, she joined the music department of the Rudolf Steiner School as a faculty member and retired in 2002. Melissa joined The Riverside Church in 1988 committed to making our world a better place through music. She was a member of The Riverside Choir, the Riverside Choral Society, served as Music Committee chair, raised funds for the Men's Shelter and was actively involved in the founding of the Catherine Van Buren Endowment Fund and the Friends of Music. She most recently enjoyed spending time with her children, grandchildren, friends, and her dog. Melissa is survived by her children, Melissa Ann Geiger (Paul Marvin) of New York, NY, Kirsten Geiger Rider (Harold) of Winnetka, IL, Howard (Skip) Wilton Geiger III of New York, NY, Christopher Wiley Geiger of Larkspur, CA and her brother, William Adams Wiley (Lynn) of Grantham, NH; nine grandchildren, Paul and Oliver Marvin of New York, NY, Harold, Sarah and Christopher Rider of Winnetka, IL, Lillian Geiger of New York, NY, Wiley, Bourke and Finley Geiger of Larkspur, CA as well as many adored nieces, nephews and her beloved dog Libee. Her husband of 56 years, Howard Wilton and her brother, George Martin Wiley III, predeceased Melissa. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Friends of Music, The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY, 10027. Services will be held at The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY at 12:00pm on Monday, January 4. A memorial reception will immediately follow. There will be additional opportunities to meet with family and friends. 1/3
FRIEDMAN--Reginia, M.D. You were the most precious gift of all little sister. What joyful birthday fun and frolic we would have had today. With Much Love, Esther, Your Schvester 1/3

DICKLER--Ruth Crohn. The Division of Gastroenterology at The Mount Sinai Medical Center is saddened at the loss of our dear friend and benefactor, Ruth Crohn Dickler, daughter of a founding giant of our profession, Dr. Burrill B. Crohn. The miracle of Ruth's life is not simply that she remained active and healthy for 102 years, but that she used those years to raise such a distinguished and devoted family, to support such a wide range of worthy causes, and to promulgate the timeless legacy of her father at Mount Sinai by underwriting many of the ground-breaking research and educational initiatives of our Division. Bruce E. Sands, MD, The Dr. Burrill B. Crohn Professor of Medicine; Division Chief Steven H. Itzkowitz, MD, Professor of Medicine and Oncological Sciences, Program Director David B. Sachar, MD, Clinical Professor of Medicine; Division Chief Emeritus 1/3

John Usdan, President Howard Martin, CEO 1/3

GRAHAM--Dr. Harold Nathaniel, (July 27, 1921 to December 31, 2015) brilliant and playful, scientist and creator of games, stories, and puns. He delighted in his family: his five children, Peter (Lew), Margy, Vicki (Nat), Rocky (Marjie), and Emily; his five grandchildren, Andrew (Erin), Rae (Billy), Spencer, Jordan (Megan), and Marisa; and his four great grandchildren, Betty, Josie, James, and Charlie. VINSON--Myron "Mike", on December 30, 2015. Adored husband of Carol. Beloved father of Daniel and Laura. Cherished grandfather of Adam and Hannah. Service January 3, 2016, 10am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. 1/3

COOPERSMITH--Dr. Sy, psychoanalyst, died peacefully at home of respiratory arrest on November 6, 2015. He was 84. Sy was born on June 19, 1931 and grew up in Boston. He graduated from Boston Latin High School, Bates College and earned his doctorate at Columbia University Teachers College. Sy did his psychoanalytic training at the National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysis where he also served on the faculty and was a senior clinical supervisor. He is survived by his wife Dr. Valerie Pinhas, and daughter Andie Coopersmith. A Memorial Service will be held at NPAP on January 10, 2016 from 1-3pm, 40 West 13th St., NY, NY 10011. 1/3

KELLY--Ellsworth. The Checkerboard Film Foundation is very saddened at the passing of Ellsworth Kelly, seminal artist and true gentleman. In 2007, we were privileged to produce, with Jo Carole Lauder, the documentary film, "Ellsworth Kelly: Fragments." Most memorably, we filmed Ellsworth in Paris as he recounted his formative experiences while living there from 1948 to 1954, and his exploration of French culture and monuments that so informed his work. He said: "In my paintings, I am not inventing; my ideas come from constantly investigating how things look." They included the shadows of an arch of a bridge on the Seine ("White Plaque: Bridge Arch and Reflection," 1951-55); the external chimneys on the wall of a building ("Ormesson," 1950); and the long angular windows at The Museum of Modern Art, Paris ("Window," his first panel painting, 1949). We send our very sincere condolences to Jack Shear, whose inspiration and guidance were invaluable. The Board of Trustees and Edgar B. Howard, President 1/3

HSU--Ta Chun. Weill Cornell Medicine is saddened by the passing of our friend Ta Chun Hsu, former president of The Starr Foundation and a graceful, longtime generous champion of our institution. His legacy endures through the C.V. Starr Biomedical Information Center, which the foundation established in 1987 to provide physicians, scientists, staff and students with the latest information resources. The foundation's commitment to education is also exemplified in the C.V. Starr Scholarship, which has supported the training of generations of medical students since its creation nearly 30 years ago. We will greatly miss his friendship and sage advice. Our condolences to The Starr Foundation leadership, his family and his many friends. Dr. Laurie H. Glimcher, Dean, Weill Cornell Medicine Jessica M. Bibliowicz, Chairman, Board of Overseers 1/3

FREILICH--Dr. Gerald. Emeritus professor of mathematics at Queens College of CUNY who specialized in geometric measure theory, passed away on December 27th, 2015 at age 88. Professor Freilich was the author of several books and many research articles and reviews in academic journals. He was a former governor of the Mathematical Association of America as well as Chairman of the New York Metropolitan Section and served on the national panel of the Committee on the Undergraduate Program of Mathematics. Born in Brooklyn, he received a bachelor's degree, Summa Cum Laude, from City College in 1946 and a Doctorate in Mathematics from Brown University in 1949. He taught at Brown University and then at City College of New York, advancing to full professor and Chairman of the Mathematics Department in 1966. During those years, he was an original member of the organizing Committee of the SUNY Doctoral Program and single- handedly established the SUNY graduate Mathematics Library. He also taught at Wesleyan University as a visiting professor. He joined the faculty of Queens College in 1971 and taught there until his retirement in 1995. Professor Freilich served in the US Navy in World War II. After the war he was a Lieutenant J.G. in the Navy Reserves. He also did research for the National Ordinance Lab on helicopters and submarines. He is survived by Marion (nee Freudenberger) after 62 years of marriage. He is also survived by his brother Dr. Herbert Freilich and children Sandra Novetsky (Dr. Gary) and Dr. David Freilich (Erica) as well as eight grandchildren and six great-grandchildren and many nephews and nieces. 1/3

BAKER--Elizabeth, "Betsy." Elizabeth "Betsy" Lentz Baker died unexpectedly in Savannah, GA on December 4, 2015 after a brief illness. A resident of Manhattan's Upper West Side for 50 years, and more recently of Tuxedo Park, NY, Betsy was born in Kittanning, PA, on August 13, 1936 to Elizabeth Fleming Wagner and William Roy Baker and was raised in State College, PA and Wilmington, DE where she graduated from Alexis I. DuPont High School. She earned a B.S. degree from Drexel University specializing in textile chemistry and was a member of Delta Zeta Sorority. She worked for Celanese, Hercules, Inc., and as a commercial print model. Betsy volunteered with The Leukemia Society, Community Board 7, various cancer support groups, and Manhattan's Bull Moose Dog Run. A longtime survivor of tonsilar area cancer, which she faced with courage and conviction, Betsy was an inspiration to all those who knew her. Despite the physical challenges with which the disease left her, Betsy was able to flourish thanks to the devoted care of her physician, Dr. Margaret Lewin. Survived by stepfather Romeo Barrick Wagner, cousins Robert Hayman, Sr. (Sally), Robert Hayman, Jr. (Sherry), and Victoria Sutton (James) and her poodle, Queen Victoria "Tori." Donations in Betsy's memory may be made to "Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine/The Albert L. Lewin, M.D. Award Fund for Clinical Excellence in Pediatrics," Office of Advancement Services, Case Western Reserve University, 10900 Euclid Avenue, Cleveland, Ohio 44106-7035. Telephone 216-368-2000. 1/3

SHORT--Stephen. June 11, 1945-December 12, 2015. Stephen Short, a former Procter of the Admiralty, who also served in the Merchant Marine, passed away on December 12th. A longtime member of the New York State bar, his legal career encompassed maritime, criminal and personal injury law. In his youth, Mr. Short was also a gifted athlete, excelling as a swimmer, skier, sailor and avid tennis player. He was also deemed an Olympic caliber fencer by Maestro Odon Niederkirchner, of the NYAC. A colorful figure and lifelong champion of the underdog, he will be missed by all who loved him, including his sisters, Leslie Blake and Cheryl Bulbach and his brother, Dr. Wayne Blackmon. As per his wishes, Mr. Short's corneas were donated to the Eye Bank for Sight Restoration. A Memorial will be held in mid-January at the Village Funeral Home. 1/3

ERIKSEN--Stein, December 11, 1927-December 27, 2015. Stein Eriksen Lodge mourns the passing of our namesake Stein Eriksen. It was Stein's vision that created the lodge. He set the high standard for hospitality and service that still exists today. His celebrity charisma created a special ambiance within the Lodge, restaurant and out on the mountain that was warm and inviting and contributed to Deer Valley Resort being named number one and the Lodge being named "World's Best Ski Hotel." As one of the most recognized names in the ski world, Stein Eriksen has been synonymous with skiing style and elegance for more than 60 years. Our thoughts are with his wife Francois and his son Bjorn, three daughters, Julianna, Ava and Anja, as well as his five grandchildren. Stein will be sorely missed. Ski well our friend! Dennis A Suskind, President Russ Olsen, CEO 1/3

BENDAHAN--Maurice, died peacefully January 1. Loving husband of Yvette and father of Miriam and great uncle. Funeral Sunday, January 3, 9:30am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91st St, New York. Interment at Beth Olam Cemetery in Ridgewood, Queens. 1/3

ROSEN--Baran S.,passed away after a brief illness. DICKLER--Ruth. It is with deep sadness that we note the passing of Mrs. Ruth Dickler who first joined The Citizens Housing & Planning Council as a volunteer in 1962, where she began to build and shape our archival library. She was an important resource for New York City's researchers, academics, and students. Upon her retirement she became a member of CHPC's Board of Directors. A talented writer and editor, her research and organizational skills helped to shape CHPC's work for nearly five decades. A mentor and friend to all of us at CHPC, her legacy continues in the historic library that bares her name. Our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends and to our city which has lost a great lady. 1/3

HANNING--Geraldine, of NYC, formerly of Delaware, OH, on December 15th, 2015 age 92. Former Broadway and TV Actress. Beloved daughter of the late Maurice and Mary nee Miller. Mass at the Church of St. Mary's, Delaware, OH, Thursday, January 7th at 10am. Interment St. Mary's Catholic Cemetery. 1/3

MOSKOVITZ--Adele. Died December 31, 2015, two days after her 100th birthday. Generous, gracious and beautiful, she lost her beloved husband, Irving, in 1996, just short of their 59th Wedding Anniversary. She is survived by her children, Anne Davis and Peter (both widowed), grandchildren Ariel Morvan, David and Zoe, and three great-grandchildren, Eleanor, Angelica and Benjamin. Adele studied dramatic arts at NYU, acted briefly, and was passionate about music, art and travel. She loved her home in New York and a second home in Cannes, France, in which places she brought family and friends together. While her children were growing up in Scarsdale, NY, she was an officer of the PTA, served as co-leader of a Girl Scout troop and hosted a foreign exchange student, Delcia Bence Rusk, to whom she remained close all her life. In a brief reprise of her acting career, she played Mrs. Frank in a 1961 Scarsdale High School production of The Diary of Anne Frank in which her daughter, Anne, was played by Liza Minnelli in her acting debut. A lover of music and constant concertgoer, she was an active Board Member of Young Audiences, the Bowden International Music Festival, and the Marlboro Music Festival, which she attended for over forty years. She took great pleasure in encouraging young musicians at the beginning of their careers. The funeral is private. There will be a memorial service, the date to be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to Marlboro Music, 1528 Walnut Street, Suite 301, Philadelphia, PA 19102. 1/3
BROOK--Jonathan Edward. 6 months have passed without you. We miss you more than words can say. Our love for you will always live on in our hearts. Nicole, Juliette, Cassie, Mom, Dad, Adam 1/3

PERALTA-RAMOS--Arturo Jr. Born in Southampton, L.I. to Arturo H. Peralta-Ramos Sr. and Millicent Rogers, Arturo Henry Peralta-Ramos, Jr. passed away December 21, 2015, at his home in Taos, NM at the age of 87. He is survived by his wife of fifty years, Jacqueline Blanchard Peralta-Ramos, his son Arturo H. Peralta-Ramos III, (Eunjae Peralta-Ramos) of Jackson Hole, Wyoming, his daughter Lorian Peralta- Ramos Buckley, (Peter Buckley) of Aiken, South Carolina, his grandchildren, Sascha and Syler Peralta-Ramos, Jamie and Ian Buckley, Ashley and Lindsey Gamble, and his step-mother Mercedes Peralta-Ramos. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his older half brother Peter Salm, and younger brother, Paul Peralta-Ramos. Arturo Peralta-Ramos Jr. grew up in the United States and Europe. He attended school on both continents, most notable being Institut Le Rosey in Switzerland and Staunton Military Academy in Virginia. He briefly attended the University of Virginia before striking off to pursue his life-long career as an Entrepreneur. Based out of New York City, his business interests spanned a diverse array of industries including mining, flour milling, defense, electronic marketing, recreation and entertainment. His most recognized achievement was as a co-founder of Comp-U- Card International, one of the leading edge precursors to online marketing. A staunch patriot, over many years Arturo acted as an advisor to the Lyndon Johnson administration, along with numerous senators and congressmen, and participated in a number of classified assignments. One of his greatest passions throughout his life was bird hunting. In that pursuit he travelled the world and won numerous domestic and international championships. Arturo also maintained strong affection for the Millicent Rogers Museum in Taos, NM, dedicated to the life and artistic creations, collections and endeavors of his mother, Millicent Rogers. Over the years he served on the board and participated both as an avid advisor and benefactor. Funeral services will be performed on January 9, 2016, at 11am at the San Francisco de Asis Church in Ranchos de Taos by Father Dino Candelaria, followed by a final graveside blessing at the Taos Sierra Vista Cemetery. A reception for family and friends will be held at the Trading Post Restaurant following the interment. In lieu of flowers, gifts or donations in his memory should go to the Millicent Roger Museum. www.millicentrogers.org 1/3

BERMAN--Hannah, passed away peacefully at the age of 98 on January 1, 2016; beloved wife of the late Dr. Martin H. DOSHI--Shrenik Ramaniklal. After a struggle with leukemia, Shrenik Ramaniklal Doshi passed away in New York, NY on Friday, January 1, 2016. He was 71 years old. As president of Jewelex New York, he was a pioneer in the diamond industry. His charisma, generosity, and compassion drew many friends who will miss him dearly. HSU--Ta Chun (T.C.), our esteemed president emeritus and director, died peacefully in his sleep on Sunday, December 27, 2015 at the age of 97. T.C. lived a full life. He was a gentleman in every sense of the word, dedicated, deeply loyal, a good friend, and counselor to generations of colleagues at the Starr Companies and The Starr Foundation. T.C. was born in Beijing in 1918, son of Yu Hsuen Yang (mother) and Tsing Lo (Singloh) Hsu (father), brother of the late Ta Ching (Irene) Hsu and the late Vivian Hsu Jee, and beloved "Uncle T.C." to many. T.C.'s father was one of the earliest backers of Cornelius Vander Starr's businesses in Shanghai and, when Tsing Lo Hsu was killed in the early days of World War II, Mr. Starr brought T.C. to America to complete his college education. T.C. never forgot Mr. Starr's generosity and friendship and made significant contributions to Starr's organizations over the years. T.C. attended the University of Shanghai from 1936-1938 and graduated from Haverford College in 1942 with a B.S. in economics. He earned a masters degree at Columbia University in the School of Journalism in 1944 and began his career with the news department of the Chinese Information Service in New York. He returned to Shanghai to work on the Chinese edition of The Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury, newspapers owned by Mr. Starr. In 1947, T.C. joined the staff of the Shanghai Commercial & Savings Bank until 1949, and then joined Starr's American International companies in Hong Kong and later San Francisco. In 1964, T.C. moved to New York to work directly with Mr. Starr on a variety of projects, including the management of The Starr Foundation, Mr. Starr's private philanthropic foundation. After Mr. Starr's death in late 1968, T.C. became President of The Starr Foundation and served in that role until 1999. T.C. remained an active director of the Foundation until his death. T.C. will be laid to rest in China. A memorial service in New York City is planned for a future date. M.R. Greenberg, Chairman The Starr Foundation 1/3

HALPER DICKSON--Sari. January 30, 2009. Seven years. Extraordinary mother, wife, sister and daughter. Sorely missed and adored by Zachary, Aleks and Diana, Barbara, Shauna, John, Joe. She is our song. 1/3

BENDICH--Albert M. June 18, 1929 - January 5, 2015 Dearest Al, It seems like yesterday when you left us. We've lost our brightest light. You've so inspired us in life, by your actions, deeds, words, love and philosophy and will continue to do so - always. Endless love and respect, Pam and your loving family and friends 1/3

RIFKIN-COMRAS--Blanche. Passed away December 31, 2015 at the age of 99. Loving wife to the late Oscar Comras and Louis Rifkin; Dear sister to Gertrude Goldstein; Beloved mother to Madelyn Katz (Albert) and Donald Comras (Albert Husted); Adored grandmother of Jay Katz and David Katz (Lauren Hurvitz); Ecstatic great- grandmother of Sam Katz, Amanda Katz, Natalie Katz, CC Katz, and Lila Katz; Cherished aunt to all her nieces and nephews. A bundle of energy and pillar of the community, she worked tirelessly for: The Advisory Board of Jacobi Hospital; The Advisory Board of Einstein/Montefiore; Member of the Community Board 11 for 30 years; The Board of Directors of Bronx House; and National Council of Jewish Women. Services will be held at the Shalom Jewish Funeral Home, 1528 Castle Hill Avenue, Bronx on Sunday, January 3, 2016 at 11:30am. Interment: Mt. Hebron Cemetery. Donations in her name may be made to: www.bronxhouse.org or to: www.ujafedny.org. 1/3

KLUGER--Arthur, 81, on December 30, 2015. Beloved husband of Susan, devoted father of David, Dan and Hannah. Adored grandfather of Sarah, Jackson, Ella and Georgia. Funeral service private; celebration of his life to be announced. 1/3

COSGROVE--Margaret L. Margaret L. Cosgrove, known to her Manhattan neighbors for her extraordinary acts of kindness, generous philanthropy, tree planting and animal rescues, passed away peacefully in her New York home on December 15, 2015. She was 91. Full obituary at: www.jasinfuneralhome.com 1/3

HSU--Ta Chun. The faculty and staff of the Edward Harkness Eye Institute are greatly saddened by the loss of T. C. Hsu, a wonderful friend and member of the Board of Advisors. As past president of The Starr Foundation for more than three decades, T. C. helped to advance the mission of many organizations in the arts and sciences throughout the world. His support of the Starr Retina Research Unit and the Starr Research Scholars enabled pioneering discoveries in eye diseases at Columbia. His warmth, gentlemanly character, and optimism throughout his life will be greatly missed. G. A. Cioffi, M.D., Chairman Stanley Chang, M.D., Chairman Emeritus Sir Howard Stringer, Chairman, Board of Advisors Department of Ophthalmology Columbia University Medical Center 1/3

KELLY--Ellsworth. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our beloved colleague, an artist who did indeed achieve his goal to "get at the rapture of seeing" and whose works will indeed fulfill his wish that they exist "forever in the present." 1/3

DIAMANT--Joan Champion, died December 18 in Lenox, MA. Born in New York; studied at The Walden School and The Art Students League; worked at Pierre Matisse Gallery. Moved with second husband Lincoln Diamant to Ossining, NY, where she mastered bookbinding, then returned to painting. Ageless at 91, she was, like one of her Hudson Valley or Berkshire landscapes, the cynosure of any room. Survived by her son, Anthony Bruck, of Chicago; stepson, Rolf Diamant, and daughter-in-law Nora Mitchell, of Woodstock, VT. 1/3

MALINA--Ruth, 97, died peacefully on December 25 in New York City. The beloved wife of Arthur for 59 years, she is survived by her brother Murray Levitan; her daughter Jane Levinson and her husband Vic; her son Richard Malina and his wife Wendy; her grandchildren Nick, Lynn, Maggie, Tom (and their spouses Julie, Roderick, David, Liz), Cathy, and Emily; her great-grandchildren Nate, Zack, Owen, Emma, Ben, Asher, and Estelle. She was cared for with great devotion by Mary, Marcel, and Bega in her later years. She was one of a kind, and we will all miss her dearly. 1/3

GOLDBERG--Marianne L.,died peacefully at her home in Chilmark, MA on December 21 after a sudden and brief illness. She was surrounded by friends. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, December 29 at 2pm at the Martha's Vineyard Hebrew Center in Vineyard Haven. Burial will follow at the Abel's Hill Cemetery in Chilmark. A celebration of her life will be held at a later date. Donations may be made in her memory to the Pathways Projects Institutes Limited, P.O. Box 437, Chilmark, MA 02535. Services are under the care of the Chapman, Cole and Gleason Funeral Home in Oak Bluffs. For online guest book and information visit: www.ccgfuneralhome.com 1/3

SCHRADE--Robert. Sevenars Concerts honors the life of Robert Schrade, beloved co-founder with wife Rolande. Incomparable pianist, teacher, father and grandfather, he inspired all. Donations in his honor may be made to: Sevenars Concerts, c/o R. C. Schrade, 80 E. End Ave, 3G, New York, NY 10028. Service: St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave., NYC, January 11, 11am. 1/3

RATNER--Laura. Our hearts are saddened by the death of Laura, mother of our very dear friends Felice (Jay) and Dennis (Andrea). She lived a long life and is now at peace. We will miss her. Cheryl and Bill 1/3

HARRISON--Maria T. (nee Preite) of Short Hills died on Thursday, December 31st, surrounded by her family. She was 56. Maria was born in Brooklyn, NY, and has lived in Short Hills for the past 25 years. She graduated from St. John's with a B.A., which led her to pursue a masters in education at Caldwell College. Maria was a firm believer in the potential of others and dedicated her life to helping them achieve it. Former New York City Mayor Ed Koch appointed her to serve on the New York City Commission on the Status of Women, where she advocated for gender equality through dialogue and policy proposals. She later spent a decade as an elementary school teacher for Ecole Toussaint Louverture, a public elementary school in East Orange, New Jersey. Maria was the beloved wife of Edmond Harrison, devoted mother of Meghan and E.J. Harrison, loving daughter of Joseph Preite and the late Gloria Mercorella Preite, and dear sister of Ralph Preite. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral Mass at St. Rose Of Lima Church, 50 Short Hills Avenue, Short Hills, NJ, on Tuesday, January 5th, at 10:00am. Visitation will take place at St. Rose of Lima Church on Sunday and Monday from 4:00-8:00pm, with Interment also at St. Rose of Lima. Services provided by The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, Maplewood. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Look Good Feel Better (http://lookgood feelbetter.org/donate). 1/3

KAPLAN--Gilbert. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague Gilbert Kaplan, passionate music lover and devoted and beloved husband of Lena. Gil joined the Carnegie Hall Board of Trustees in 1980, and served the Hall with devotion for more than thirty-five years. Gil brought his financial acumen and keen insight to Carnegie Hall's management as a longstanding member of the Finance and Operations Committee, where he helped govern major institutional advances from the restoration of Carnegie Hall to the creation of an education center. Following his successful career in business and journalism, Gil became a celebrated scholar of Gustav Mahler, establishing the Kaplan Foundation and conducting Mahler's Second Symphony with leading orchestras around the world. Gil was invited by the Vienna Philharmonic to conduct the original version of Mahler's Second Symphony and his recordings of the Symphony with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic were very successful. Gil demonstrated his deep love and knowledge of music every season as a frequent concertgoer, and many members of the Carnegie Hall's family were honored to be guests on Gil's acclaimed radio program "Mad About Music." We will always remember Gil for his warmth, musical scholarship, and his love of Carnegie Hall. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Lena; his devoted children Kristina, Claude, John, and Emily; and their families and loved ones. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director 1/3

HIRSCHBERG--Irving, resident of Amagansett, NY, died suddenly on December 30th at age 88. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Phyllis. He is survived by his two daughters, Lise and Wendy, sister Shirlee (Geri Grossman), and his grandson Miles Emanuel. He retired as an accomplished electrical engineer at Fairchild Camera. He had a major impact on the East End community. Irving was a tutor of ESL students at East Hampton High School, a friend to senior citizens through R.S.V.P. and an active Democrat. He was devoted to his tennis and golf games. Irving was a loyal and generous friend to many. Contributions may be made in his memory: Cinema Arts Centre, Huntington, Long Island or the Southern Poverty Law Center. 1/3

OSTREICH--Ellen S.,88, of Lake Mary, Florida (former resident of New York and Boca Raton, Florida), passed away on January 2, 2016. Born January 14, 1927 to Rose Lehman Stein, Esq. and Simon Stein, M.D. Graduated from Cornell University in 1946 and received M.A. in 1947 from New York University. Beloved wife of the late Leonard L. Ostreich, M.D. Beloved mother to Marjorie (Dustan) Smith, Richard, M.D. (Helene) Ostreich, Steven (Andrea) Ostreich and Peter Ostreich (deceased) and Glenda. Adored grandmother to nine, Carey, Jordan, Tamara, Amy, Debbie, Rachel, Danielle, Stacey and Emily and adored great-grandmother to five, Chloe, Myles, Jeremy, Mason and Lily. The funeral service will be on January 5, 2016 at 12:00pm at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York. Family requests donations be made to Vitas Healthcare (Hospice) or Boys Town Jerusalem. 1/3

SOLOWAY--Michael, "Mickey," on January 2, 2016. Loving husband to Loretta and father to Spencer (Alex). His smile and sense of humor will be missed by all who had the joy of knowing him. Services today, Monday, 12:45pm, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Juilliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3

RUDOFSKY--Jesse Frank, of Belmont, MA. Music producer with group Ace, Dollface and Franky Lightning, passed on December 26. Beloved husband of Carolee Beberian Rudofsky. Son of Toby (Gross) Rudofsky and Harry Rudofsky. Father of Cherie, Jessica and Danna Heidi Rudofsky. Funeral, Holy Trinity Armenian Church, 145 Brattle St., Cambridge, MA, January 7, 11am. 1/3

MOSKOVITZ--Adele. Died December 31, 2015, two days after her 100th birthday. Generous, gracious and beautiful, she lost her beloved husband, Irving, in 1996, just short of their 59th Wedding Anniversary. She is survived by her children, Anne Davis and Peter (both widowed), grandchildren Ariel Morvan, David and Zoe, and three great-grandchildren, Eleanor, Angelica and Benjamin. Adele studied dramatic arts at NYU, acted briefly, and was passionate about music, art and travel. She loved her home in New York and a second home in Cannes, France, in which places she brought family and friends together. While her children were growing up in Scarsdale, NY, she was an officer of the PTA, served as co-leader of a Girl Scout troop and hosted a foreign exchange student, Delcia Bence Rusk, to whom she remained close all her life. In a brief reprise of her acting career, she played Mrs. Frank in a 1961 Scarsdale High School production of The Diary of Anne Frank in which her daughter, Anne, was played by Liza Minnelli in her acting debut. A lover of music and constant concertgoer, she was an active Board Member of Young Audiences, the Bowden International Music Festival, and the Marlboro Music Festival, which she attended for over forty years. She took great pleasure in encouraging young musicians at the beginning of their careers. The funeral is private. There will be a memorial service, the date to be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to Marlboro Music, 1528 Walnut Street, Suite 301, Philadelphia, PA 19102. 1/3

SHARGEL--Leo, died on January 2, 2016 at 99. Caring and sincere, Leo was a devoted husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and friend, as well as a WWII Veteran. A true gentleman and energetic storyteller who loved to play cards, Leo will be missed by his wife of 73 years, Lillian, his children, Gerald and Judith, his daughter and son-in-law Terry and Robert, his grandchildren Johanna, David, Jake, Jill and Jamie and their spouses, as well as his 9 (soon to be 10) great-grandchildren. Shiva Monday-Wednesday at home of Gerald Shargel. 1/3

YOSPIN--Tobias, of Roslyn, NY, Brooklyn born and bred, on December 31, 2015, at age 96. Beloved husband of the late Audrey (Kreinik) Yospin. Loving father of Richard Yospin, and the late Marjorie Yospin Newman. Adoring grandfather of Matthew, Gabriel and Sarina Yospin, and Eric and David Newman. Dear brother of Elaine Melnikoff and Thelma Kanig. Graduate of City College, and NYU Dental School; emeritus professor, City University of New York; painter and sculptor; lifetime tennis player, golfer and swimmer; passionate classical music listener; together with Audrey, world traveler. Graveside services at Beth Moses Cemetery, 1500 Wellwood Ave., West Babylon, NY 11704, on Monday, January 4 at 1pm. Memorial Observance at the home of Joan and Richard Yospin, Wednesday, January 6, 2016. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to: the Yiddish Book Center, 1021 West Street, Amherst, MA 01002. Levine Chapels, Brookline, 617-277-8300. www.levine chapel.com 1/3

TRYFOROS--Nicholas James, July 27, 1923-December 31, 2015. Nicholas James Tryforos, son of James and Garufa, was the youngest and last survivor of thirteen children. In explaining why "Mama and Papa had thirteen children, not twelve or fourteen" Nick said, "When I was born, papa picked me up, checked me out, and said 'Mama! FINALLY a perfect baby.'" A lifelong New Yorker, he was a proud graduate of The Greek American Institute, Theodore Roosevelt High School and New York University. He served in the Army in WWII. After basic training, the Army sent him to language school to become a Hindustani interpreter. He received horse cavalry and military intelligence training, and then served in the Philippines and in General MacArthur's headquarters in Tokyo during the occupation of Japan. Nick used his Hindustani skills for the rest of his life to surprise and delight both friends and complete strangers from India. After returning from Japan Nick worked for 15 years in the family flower and novelty business, then had a 25-year career with the IRS, retiring in 1986 as a Group Manager, supervising large corporation tax audits. Amateur gymnast, superb photographer, family documenter and archivist, Nick was the favorite uncle of many and worked hard to make and cultivate relationships with family and friends. He collected any piece of junk that could potentially serve a future purpose, taught his children the value of a dollar and the importance of grunt labor, and was the original tiger mom and DIY guy. He was the resident teaser (while being wheeled to major surgery with four children at home, Nick whispered to his wife "don't worry dear, as long as we have our health!") and an inveterate joke teller ("Have you heard the one about the skeleton that walked into a bar..."). Nick delighted in meeting his children's friends, showing them photos related (and unrelated!) to their discussion, and always enjoyed giving them another tour of the garage! Nick was quietly proud of everyone in his family, and his family was very fortunate to have him. He leaves behind his dear wife of 63 years and best friend Mary, and his children, Margaret and her husband Paul, Jim and his wife Sue, Tom, and Tina and her husband David. He also leaves his grandchildren, Peter, Evan, Kate and her husband Pat, John, Lucas, Eva, and Eli, and great-grandson Theo. Within minutes of Nick's passing, his second great-grandson, Grant, was born. Visitation will be held from 6 to 9pm Monday, January 4th at Frederick Funeral Home in Flushing, and funeral services at 11:30am Tuesday at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Flushing. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to SmileTrain.com, DoctorsWithoutBorders.com or World Vision In Support of Syrian Refugees. 1/3

RUBINSTEIN--Sabena. Bnai Zion mourns the loss of Sabena Rubinstein, former president of the New York Region, and second generation supporter of Bnai Zion. Sabena was the daughter of former National Vice President, Anna Gelman and her husband Nat, who were all longtime supporters of the Bnai Zion Medical Center in Haifa. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her husband Sergio, and may the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. George W. Schaeffer, Chairman of the Board David H. Eisenberg, National President Cheryl Bier, Executive Vice President 1/3

DOSHI--Shrenik Ramaniklal. After a struggle with leukemia, Shrenik Ramaniklal Doshi passed away in New York, NY on Friday, January 1, 2016. He was 71 years old. As president of Jewelex New York, he was a pioneer in the diamond industry. His charisma, generosity, and compassion drew many friends who will miss him dearly. He leaves behind a loving family that will carry on his tradition of exceptional philanthropy. He is survived by his wife, Rupa Doshi and his son and daughter-in-law, Nirav and Alma Doshi. 1/3

BOESCHENSTEIN--Josephine Moll, "Molly." October 29, 1930-December 30, 2015. Josephine Moll "Molly" Boeschenstein passed away peacefully Wednesday, December 30, 2015, in Hobe Sound, FL. Molly was born Josephine Hamlin Moll on October 29, 1930, in Detroit, MI, to Josephine Hamlin and The Honorable Lester Moll, a prominent Detroit prosecutor and judge. She grew up in Grosse Pointe, MI. In 1953, she married William W. Boeschenstein, who was working for Owens Corning in Detroit. The couple later moved to Perrysburg, Ohio, where they raised four sons. Mr. Boeschenstein ultimately became Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of Owens Corning in Toledo, Ohio. Although her husband became the public face of the company, Molly was a genuine partner to him throughout his career. Molly was known for her intelligence, style, love of competition, and her outstanding, irreverent sense of humor. Conversations with her were punctuated by astute observations, humorous ripostes, and often times belly shaking laughter. She had a wide and deep circle of friends from every corner of her life. Molly was deeply involved in a number of civic and charitable organizations. Notably, she was the first President of the St. Vincent Medical Center Foundation in Toledo, OH, a committed volunteer at the Toledo Museum of Art, and a member of the Board of Directors of The National Council on Alcoholism and Addiction and The Freedom Institute in New York. Molly and her husband have made their principal residence in Hobe Sound, FL. She is survived by her husband of 62 years, William W. Boeschenstein, sons William Jr., Michael, Peter and Stephen, their spouses, and 10 grandchildren and one great- grandchild. Funeral services are pending. Memorial contributions may be made to the Toledo Museum of Art, the Jupiter Medical Center Foundation in Jupiter, FL or the Martin Health Foundation in Stuart, FL. 1/3

DIAMANT--Joan Champion, died December 18 in Lenox, MA. Born in New York; studied at The Walden School and The Art Students League; worked at Pierre Matisse Gallery. Moved with second husband Lincoln Diamant to Ossining, NY, where she mastered bookbinding, then returned to painting. Ageless at 91, she was, like one of her Hudson Valley or Berkshire landscapes, the cynosure of any room. Survived by her son, Anthony Bruck, of Chicago; stepson, Rolf Diamant, and daughter-in-law Nora Mitchell, of Woodstock, VT. 1/3

TARSHIS--Steve, 1949-2016. Cherished husband, father, brother, son. Acclaimed musician and teacher who touched so many lives. 1/3

CHELOUCHE--Roslyn R. (Ros), May 24, 1937-December 31, 2015. Loving mother of Adina Chelouche (George Tellides); cherished grandmother of Alexander, Theodore and Julia Tellides. Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, NYC on January 7 at 12:45pm. 1/3

ROGERS--Wayne M. The staff at Kleinfeld Bridal is deeply saddened by the death of its Chairman, Wayne Rogers. From the 1990's to the present, Wayne in partnership with Ronald Rothstein and Mara Urshel, built Kleinfeld into the most successful designer bridal retailer in the world. He helped expand the Kleinfeld name into 150 countries through the hit "Say Yes to the Dress" TV show and he licensed the brand to HBC for Canada. Wayne followed no rules, no industry practices and believed one always had to enjoy the freedom of free thought with no boundaries. Wayne loved Kleinfeld and its success, its dedicated staff and its brides. His personal charm and caring nature was a blessing to everyone who worked at Kleinfeld. We extend our sincere and heartfelt condolences to Amy, Laura, Bill and their families. He will be truly missed. Ronald R. Rothstein and Mara Urshel 1/3

COTTY--Edmond, 92, died December 28 at his home in Scarsdale, NY. Son of Gustave Cotty and Marie Parisod, he earned his MBA from the University of Lausanne, Switzerland. There he met his wife, Yvette Mina Chuard. He emigrated to New York City in 1948 to join the investment firm of Istel, Lepercq & Co. He went on to be president of John Bristol & Co. (1964) and founder of Cotty, Feldman & Co. (1971) which merged with New Court Securities/Rothschild, Inc. (1974) where he directed their Investment Management Division until his retirement (1993). He was very active in the Scarsdale Congregational Church. He is predeceased by his beloved wife of 57 years, Yvette, and by his treasured daughter, Isabelle Cotty. He is survived by his daughter Anne-Claude Cotty and son Phil Cotty. A celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, January 9 at 11am at the Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Road, Scarsdale, NY. Donations may be made in his honor to White Plains Hospital or Scarsdale Volunteer Ambulance. 1/3

KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Juilliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3

GILBERT--Edward M.,dubbed the "Boy Wonder of Wall Street" in the 1950's, died peacefully at his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico on Wednesday, December 23, 2015. He was five days short of his 93rd birthday. Eddie lived a unique and exceptional life. As a young man, Eddie fought bravely in World War II and received a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star. He had many achievements. He was a competitive springboard diver and in 1942 made the U.S. Open at Forest Hills; he had a world-renowned stamp collection and gave generously to many causes in Santa Fe. In 1992, Eddie co-founded BGK Group, a highly successful commercial real estate company headquartered in Santa Fe. Under Eddie's leadership the company acquired a large national portfolio as well as premier buildings in New Mexico, Texas and elsewhere. By 2010, when New York-based Rosemont Real Estate acquired part ownership of BGK, Gilbert's company was the largest holder of commercial real estate in New Mexico, owning properties in 28 states. He was "larger than life" say his children. He will be greatly missed. He is survived by his wife Peaches, seven children, Robin, Alexandra (Ronald), Dominique, Nina, Sasha, Beatrice and Zoe and three grandchildren, Brooke, Ross and Yeabsira. 1/3

ANGELO--John. Central Park Conservancy mourns the passing of John Angelo, devoted husband of our friend and Board member, Judy Hart Angelo. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, management, and staff of Central Park Conservancy, we send our heartfelt condolences to the entire Angelo family. 1/3

BIALER--Stewart Sidney, died on November 27 following a battle with melanoma. He was 72. Stewart was born in Brooklyn, NY, to Lena and Solomon Bialer. He impacted countless lives as a passionate teacher in New York City's public schools. He gave generously, sharing his wisdom, compassion, time, home, heart, harvest and money-always seeking lives to enrich and the ways in which he could help. He is survived by his wife Susan BeGasse; children Emily and Lisa; sons-in-law Jordan and Jerry; and grandchildren Ori, Alyssa, Aaron, Julia, Jacob and Laila. Stewart's son, Adam, died suddenly two weeks following his death. 1/3

HOCHSWENDER--Woody, June 20, 1951, to December 31, 2015. His name was Wiliam Joseph Hochswender III, but everyone knew him as Woody. For many, he was the lanky, redheaded and perennially boyish fashion and style reporter for The New York Times, Harper's Bazaar, Esquire and Golf. For others, he was an inspirational practitioner of Nichiren Buddhism: he brought comfort, joy and wisdom to many through his example, his guidance and his two books, "The Buddha in Your Mirror" and "The Buddha in Your Rearview Mirror." In Sharon, CT, where he had lived since 1993, he was known as a quirky character with memorable pickup trucks (his beautiful golden retriever, Lola, nearly always along for the ride) and a passion for swimming, biking and otherwise enjoying the beauty around him. For his daughter, Kate, he was her biggest cheerleader as well as the person who always encouraged her to set a high standard and then meet it. He adored her, and she adored him. A true journalist, Woody was interested in everything; for the past few years, he was able to travel widely and meet interesting people in the company of his girlfriend, Kirsten Jensen. His daughter and former wife, Cynthia, were glad that he was able to enrich his life and expand his horizons with Kirsten before his death, from a glioblastoma tumor, on December 31. For a full obituary and details of his January 17 memorial service in Lakeville, CT, go to his memorial website at www.forevermissed.com. 1/3

DICKLER--Ruth. The officers and staff of The Pollock-Krasner Foundation mourn the passing of Ruth Dickler, beloved wife and widow of Gerald Dickler, the Founder Chairman of The Pollock-Krasner Foundation. For over thirty years, Ruth gave advice and counsel to the Foundation's program. We will miss her wisdom, grace and generosity. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Charles Bergman, Chairman Samuel Sachs II, President Kerrie Buitrago, Executive Vice President 1/3

ANGELO--John. The LeFrak family mourns the loss of our dear friend John Angelo. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife Judy, his sons Jack and Jessie, and his daughter Kate. John was a renaissance man, a one-of-a-kind individual who left a lasting impression on everyone he met, and was always fun to be with. We will miss him tremendously. 1/3

ROAMAN--Joyce, of Hollywood, FL, 89, passed away January 1, 2016. Joyce is predeceased by her husband Alan Norman Roaman and her son Michael Warren Roaman. She is survived by her daughter Judi Roaman and a daughter-in-law Carla Chammas and a son Peter Michael Roaman, two grandchildren, Benjamin Michael Roaman and Katherine Mixer and her husband Scott Mixer, and three great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held today, Tuesday, January 5 at 10:30am at Temple Solel in Hollywood, FL. Interment will take place on Wednesday, January 6 at 11am at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery in Glendale, NY. 1/3

RIZZUTO--Patricia Anne, 71, of New York, NY passed away on January 1, 2016 in Portland, ME. Patricia was born in Newark, NJ on March 8, 1944 the daughter of Hall of Fame Yankees shortstop Phil Rizzuto and Cora Ann Esselborn Rizzuto. She was an incredibly loving and dedicated mother and grandmother. She enjoyed spending time at her house on Fire Island and playing with her granddaughter Lucia Rizzuto-Michelsen. She is survived by her daughter Jennifer Rizzuto and her daughter-in-law Heidi Michelsen Golden; sister Penny Yetto; brother Philip Rizzuto Jr; and her beloved granddaughter Lucia Rizzuto- Michelsen. 1/3

BENDICH--Albert M. June 18, 1929 - January 5, 2015 Dearest Al, It seems like yesterday when you left us. We've lost our brightest light. You've so inspired us in life, by your actions, deeds, words, love and philosophy and will continue to do so - always. Endless love and respect, Pam and your loving family and friends 1/3
WEINSTEIN--Ruth. Beloved wife of Aaron and mother of Robert and Michael. Died January 4, 2006. Gone 10 years and still missed. 1/3

ROGERS--Wayne M. The staff at Kleinfeld Bridal is deeply saddened by the death of its Chairman, Wayne Rogers. From the 1990's to the present, Wayne in partnership with Ronald Rothstein and Mara Urshel, built Kleinfeld into the most successful designer bridal retailer in the world. He helped expand the Kleinfeld name into 150 countries through the hit "Say Yes to the Dress" TV show and he licensed the brand to HBC for Canada. Wayne followed no rules, no industry practices and believed one always had to enjoy the freedom of free thought with no boundaries. Wayne loved Kleinfeld and its success, its dedicated staff and its brides. His personal charm and caring nature was a blessing to everyone who worked at Kleinfeld. We extend our sincere and heartfelt condolences to Amy, Laura, Bill and their families. He will be truly missed. Ronald R. Rothstein and Mara Urshel 1/3
SCHUBERT--David Paul, passed away on Saint John's Day 2015. Beloved of family Chris, Danielle and Joann. 1/3

KELLOGG--James C.,IV. Born in Elizabeth, NJ, on July 2, 1939. Departed on December 31, 2015 and resided in Short Hills, NJ. Memorial Service Friday, January 8th, 12:00pm, Short Hills Community Congregational Church. Luncheon Friday, January 8th, after the service, Short Hills Club, 144 Highland Avenue. James C. Kellogg, philanthropist and loving husband, father of three children, and grandfather of nine grandchildren, died on Thursday of congestive heart failure, surrounded by his family. He was 76 years old. Jim was a graduate of The Pingry School, Princeton University, and Harvard Law School. During his career, he was a partner at the Manhattan law firm Townley & Updike, the President of the Community Foundation of New Jersey, the President of the J.C. Kellogg Foundation, and a valued trustee of many non-profit boards. He was most proud of his philanthropic work in Elizabeth, New Jersey. He cherished the idea of creating opportunities for people from disadvantaged backgrounds to be healthy, learn, and grow. Jim grew up in Elizabeth, NJ and spent his summers in Bay Head, NJ, where he made many friends whom he kept throughout his life. Those friends would gather on a regular basis for couples' dinners and bridge marathons. He looked forward to Romeo lunches, Scorpions bridge, and the Literatti book club, where he always touted the latest political book. In the past few years, Jim became a Life Master at bridge by participating in ACBL bridge tournaments across the country. He spent his winters at Yeamans Hall in South Carolina. Jim had a deep commitment to public service; he advised and served on the boards of Frost Valley YMCA, Bay Head Chapel, Short Hills Community Congregational Church, Point Pleasant Hospital, the Children's Specialized Hospital, Trinitas Regional Medical Center, Meridian Health Systems, Council of Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton University, Union County College, Bloomfield College, the Prudential Insurance Company, New Jersey State in the Trust for Public Lands, and the Scholarship Fund for Inner City Children. He was appointed by the Governor to the boards of New Jersey Transit and the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency. His lifelong passion for philanthropy paled in comparison to his love for his family- his wife, three children, and nine grandchildren. Jim was happiest at family gatherings and loved playing backgammon and gin rummy with his children and grandchildren. Pop Pop's signature backgammon move was to wait for his opponent to admit defeat only to turn the board around and play the losing side, teaching his mentee how to stage a comeback and win! He was active in every aspect of his children's and grandchildren's lives, including attending their school events, and offering advice on and help with work issues. He is survived by his wife, Gail Chambers Kellogg, his children, Jimmy Kellogg, Kate Kellogg, and Elizabeth Kellogg Winterbottom; adoring grandchildren, Emily, Jimmy and Grace Kellogg; Chris and Andrew Kellogg Peeler; Hailey, Francesca, Maile, and Penelope Winterbottom; and his three younger brothers, Peter, Kelly, and Rusty. A service to celebrate his life will be held Friday, January 8th at 12:00pm at the Short Hills Community Congregational Church. Immediately following the service, the family invites all attendees to join them for lunch at the Short Hills Club. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Frost Valley YMCA in Claryville, NY. For more info, or to send condolences to the family, please visit www.bradleyfuneral homes.com. 1/3

KAPLAN--Gilbert. The Juilliard School community mourns the passing of Gilbert Kaplan, a member of the school's Evening Division faculty since 2000 and devoted supporter of the arts around the world. Through his popular courses on Mahler for music lovers, Gil brought his extraordinary expertise and passion to a composer whose work is better understood through his scholarship and performances. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Lena, and his beautiful family. He will be deeply missed by all. Joseph W. Polisi, President; Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean; Danielle La Senna, Director of Juilliard's Evening Division 1/3

ANGELO--John. We mourn the death of our pal John Angelo, whose energy, confidence and love of life inspired everyone he knew. Our family's sympathies go to his devoted wife Judy and their children Kate, Jack and Jesse. Susan and Peter Solomon and Family 1/3

GILBERT--Edward M.,dubbed the "Boy Wonder of Wall Street" in the 1950's, died peacefully at his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico on Wednesday, December 23, 2015. He was five days short of his 93rd birthday. Eddie lived a unique and exceptional life. As a young man, Eddie fought bravely in World War II and received a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star. He had many achievements. He was a competitive springboard diver and in 1942 made the U.S. Open at Forest Hills; he had a world-renowned stamp collection and gave generously to many causes in Santa Fe. In 1992, Eddie co-founded BGK Group, a highly successful commercial real estate company headquartered in Santa Fe. Under Eddie's leadership the company acquired a large national portfolio as well as premier buildings in New Mexico, Texas and elsewhere. By 2010, when New York-based Rosemont Real Estate acquired part ownership of BGK, Gilbert's company was the largest holder of commercial real estate in New Mexico, owning properties in 28 states. He was "larger than life" say his children. He will be greatly missed. He is survived by his wife Peaches, seven children, Robin, Alexandra (Ronald), Dominique, Nina, Sasha, Beatrice and Zoe and three grandchildren, Brooke, Ross and Yeabsira. 1/3

ANGELO--John M. The Board of Directors, Volunteers, and Staff of the Ronald McDonald House of New York wish to express our sincere sympathy of the passing of our dear friend and benefactor, John M. Angelo. John dutifully served as a member of the Board of Directors of our charity from 2005 to 2014 when he became a Member at Large. He was both generous and kind to the special kids and families battling cancer at the Ronald McDonald House. Our sincere sympathy and deepest condolences go out to his dear wife, Judy, his children, and the entire Angelo family. Respectfully, Tina Lundgren, Chairman of the Board; Harris Diamond, Vice Chair, Chairman Elect; Stanley B. Shopkorn, Chairman, Emeritus; Joel Newman Interim President & Chief Executive Officer, Ronald McDonald House New York 1/3

KASHNER-- Howard, of Scarsdale, NY, died January 4, 2015 at age 75. This caring, ethical, smart, generous, funny, gallant man was admired by his colleagues, teased by his many old friends, lovingly connected with his brothers Len and Frank and his widespread family, adored by his grandchildren Zane, Tessa, Robert Ezra, Mila, and Eva and deeply loved by his wife, Rita, and his daughters, Elisabeth (Jonathan) and Megan (Trina). Rest in peace, you sweet man. Services at Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains, NY, 12:30pm, Wednesday, January 6. 1/3

MOSLER--Sheila Hawley Sanders. The loving family of Sheila Hawley Sanders Mosler, 80, is profoundly saddened by her passing on January 4, 2016. Sheila was an incredibly loving and giving person and will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. Born and raised in New York City, Sheila was formerly married to John Mosler Sr., Chairman of Mosler Safe Company, mother to her sons John and Bruce, and daughter Michele. Her father was Chairman of the Hudson River Day Line and an original partner of the Circle Line. Sheila's career, which spanned more than 30 years, was focused on bridging her skills and expertise in acting between political, corporate, humanitarian and educational areas in New York City and internationally. She served as the Deputy Commissioner and Executive Lobbyist for the New York State Department of Commerce, where she was appointed by Governor Nelson Rockefeller as a corporate liaison with the top management of Fortune 500, medium sized and small businesses to maintain and bring new business to New York State. She also served as a Special Assistant and Lobbyist for the Governor's Consultant on Labor & Commissioner of Human Rights, where she acted as a bridge to the labor unions and minority grounds in New York State, as well as a Member of the Governor's Special Committee, where she was appointed as the youngest member of a special committee to review state laws and procedures in the areas of human rights and labor relations. While Sheila excelled in her professional career, she also had a place in her heart for giving back to the community. She was also a successful cabaret singer and recorded an album, "Rare! Hot!". Sheila was a graduate of Finch College and received an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from St. John's University. Sheila is survived by her sons, Bruce (Wendy) Mosler and John (Jean) Mosler, her daughter Michele Mosler, and her grandchildren David and Charlotte Mosler. The wake honoring her life will take place on Thursday, January 7th from 5 to 8pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel and a private Mass will follow on Friday, January 8th at 9:30am at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer. 1/3

SCHNEIDER--Claire, 92, died on January 5, 2016. She was predeceased by her husband of 54 years, David. She is survived by her daughters Stephanie Singer of Florida, Amy Schneider of New Hampshire and Tina Schneider of Maine. She is also survived by her seven grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, and an extended family who loved her dearly. Funeral services to be held at noon on January 7th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America or the Multiple Sclerosis Foundation. 1/3
SCHUBERT--David Paul, passed away on Saint John's Day 2015. Beloved of family Chris, Danielle and Joann. 1/3

GLOBUS--Sarah, died at home on December 13, 2015. She is survived by her husband, Herschel Goldfield, her children, Ori and Vivian, and by sisters Martha Globus-Rodriguez and Laura Day. Sarah is remembered with great love and affection by her family and friends and by the community in Manhattan Valley, where she devoted many years of her life helping children and others in need as the founder of Neighborhood Kids of Harlem. Sarah graduated from Hunter College and Columbia Law School. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Children's Aid Society. 1/3

MORRISON--Richard. We mourn the loss of our partner, colleague and friend Richard Morrison, who suffered a heart attack and passed away on January 4. He was an important member of Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP for nearly 30 years, and was deeply devoted to his work, colleagues and clients. As Managing Partner of Weil's Miami office and a longstanding partner in our Real Estate practice, Richard was instrumental in the development of Weil's presence in Miami and was also integral in helping to shape our global Real Estate practice. Richard split his time between our Miami and New York offices, and was known and loved by partners, associates and staff across all of Weil's offices. He graduated with a B.A. from Vanderbilt University in 1981 and earned a J.D. from the University of Florida's Levin College of Law in 1984. We will remember Richard with the utmost respect and admiration, and we offer our deepest sympathy to his family; he will be greatly missed by his many friends and colleagues at Weil. 1/3

BUSH--George, 87, died on Monday, January 4, 2016. Loving husband of the late Flora Wilhelm Bush. Devoted father of Dr. Rachel W. Bush and the late Dr. Jared Bush. Beloved grandfather to Maxwell, Zachary and Jacob. Adored youngest son of the late Benjamin and Rachel, and brother to the late Daniel and Paul. Also survived by his nephew and niece, Avigail and Jennifer. Services today, Wednesday, 10:30am, at Riverside Cemetery, Saddlebrook, NJ. May God comfort and sustain the family among the mourners of Zion. 1/3

KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Juilliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3

ANGELO--John. The Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation community is deeply saddened to lose a brilliant, generous and kind friend. He will be greatly missed. Our hearts go out to John's family, countless friends and colleagues. Alan Leventhal, Chairman Lorraine Egan, President 1/3

SIMON--Sylvia F.,age 89, died January 3 at her home in Rye, NY. Beloved wife of the late Franklin Simon II. Devoted mother of Cici Holbrook and Leslie Simon. WEISSMAN--Julia Zlabovsky, 98, died on October 15, 2015 after a brief illness. Born in El Paso, Texas, she graduated from the College of Mines and Metallurgy of the University of Texas and later settled in New York City to pursue a career as a writer and editor. As author or co-author, she published books and articles in many areas of the arts and crafts, including folk art, needlework and cooking. She was predeceased by her sisters, Vera Zlabovsky and Esther Boxer and by her brothers Isador (Saul) Stuart and David Stuart. She is survived by her daughter Erica Weissman, brother Frank Stuart, nephew David Stuart, nieces Elizabeth Stuart and Rebecca Orlowski (Steven), and grandnephews Jesse, Derek, and Paul Orlowski. 1/3

ROSS--Donald K. Sr.,of Franklin Lakes, NJ, Water Mill, NY and Vero Beach, FL passed away at his home in New Jersey on January 5, 2016 after an extended illness. He was born in 1925, the son of Alexander and Althea Grainger Ross of Ridgewood, NJ. Mr. Ross was the valedictorian of his Ridgewood High School class in 1942 and matriculated as an undergraduate at Yale University in the V 12 United States Navy training program. While at Yale he was a member of the varsity swim team and majored in electrical engineering. Upon graduation he was commissioned as an ensign in the U.S. Navy. After three years of active duty in the Navy he resigned his commission and entered Harvard Business School. Upon graduation he spent a summer as a counselor at Camp Pemigewassett in Wentworth, NH where he and his brother Sandy had spent their boyhood summers. He soon joined New York Life Insurance Company as a trainee. Mr. Ross spent his entire professional career at New York Life, culminating with his serving for a decade as its CEO, President and Chairman of its board of directors. Don met the love of his life, Mary Fyffe, in the second grade. They were married in 1949 and she survives him; along with their four children Catherine Lesher (Charles), Susan Morris (William), D. Keith Ross, Jr. (Suzanne) and Deborah Cipriano (Gaetano), along with nine grandchildren, three step-grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his younger brother Alexander "Sandy" Ross and many nieces and nephews and their families. He was a beloved family man and a true gentleman of the old school with a calm demeanor, impeccable judgment, and an illuminating smile. Mr. Ross was a life- long, enthusiastic golfer. He was an active member of the Arcola Country Club in Paramus, NJ, National Golf Links of America in Southampton, NY, and the Moorings Country Club, Vero Beach, FL. He also was a longtime member of the Indian Trail Club in Franklin Lakes, NJ where he played competitive platform tennis for many years. In addition to his career with New York Life Insurance Co., Mr. Ross was Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the YMCA of Greater New York; Trustee of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. and the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation; and a member of the Boards of Directors of the Committee for Economic Development and the New York Chamber of Commerce. In addition he was an elder and building committee member of the Presbyterian Church of Franklin Lakes, NJ and he was instrumental in the construction of its Church on Franklin Lake Road. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, January 8, 2016 at 4pm at the High Mountain Presbyterian Church, 730 Franklin Lake Road, Franklin Lakes, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Hackensack UMC Foundation Heart Failure Fund, 360 Essex Street, Suite 301. Hackensack, NJ 07601 or by calling 551-996-3720. Services by Vander Plaat-Vermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Road, Franklin Lakes, NJ 07417. For further info. please visit www.vpmemorial.com or call us at (201)891-4770. 1/3

BOULEZ--Pierre. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall celebrate the life of our dear friend and colleague Pierre Boulez, one of the most important and influential artists of the 20th century. A legendary composer, conductor, musical philosopher and activist, Pierre Boulez was a visionary and trailblazing global force for modern music. Carnegie Hall was privileged to elect him an Honorary Trustee in 1995, and to appoint him as the Richard and Barbara Debs Composer's Chair from 1999 to 2003. Boulez made approximately 75 appearances at Carnegie Hall, conducting close to 60 performances on our stages, and his works have been performed on more than 80 programs. As an arts educator, he was inspirational-challenging audiences to explore a new aesthetic of music through his musical research center IRCAM, and, in the course of the Professional Training Workshops he led through Carnegie Hall's Weill Music Institute, offering profound insights to young musicians. Boulez's work in Paris served as an inspiration in the conception of Zankel Hall, the opening season of which included performances by Boulez with the Ensemble Intercontemporain. Pierre Boulez will be deeply missed by all of us at Carnegie Hall and by the entire artistic community, though his brilliant musical legacy and pioneering spirit will stay with us all. We express heartfelt condolences to his sister, Jeanne Chevalier Boulez, and brother, Roger Boulez, as well as their many children and grandchildren. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes T. Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3
COOPER--Wyatt E. Sept. 1, 1927-Jan. 5, 1978. Daddy and Carter within us always. Gloria and Anderson. 1/3

Polisi, President; Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean; Danielle La Senna, Director of Juilliard's Evening Division 1/3

KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Juilliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3

BOULEZ--Pierre. The New York Philharmonic deeply mourns the passing of Pierre Boulez, our bold and innovative Music Director from 1971 to 1977 as well as a trailblazing composer and thinker. Under Boulez, the Philharmonic introduced concert formats that brought the audience in direct contact with composers and performers, including the informal Rug Concerts and downtown Prospective Encounters. He returned in 1986 for a 14- event series highlighting his work as conductor, composer, and leader of the Ensemble Intercontemporain. In 1992 he celebrated the Philharmonic's 150th anniversary in a concert also led by former Music Directors Zubin Mehta and Kurt Masur. In the same year Boulez was made an Honorary Member of the Society, an honor shared by such figures as Wagner, Stravinsky, and Bernstein. New York Philharmonic Music Director Alan Gilbert said: "Pierre Boulez was a towering and influential musical figure whose Philharmonic leadership implicitly laid down a challenge of innovation and invention that continues to inspire us to this day. To me, personally, he also was an unfailingly gracious mentor and friend, from the years when I worked with him in Cleveland and when I was appointed to the Philharmonic to the last time I saw him in Baden- Baden on a Philharmonic tour. I will miss his musicianship, kindness, and wisdom." The New York Philharmonic family sends our love and compassion to his family. 1/3

SHANNON--George E.,83, Broadcast Pioneer dies. George Shannon was President of CBS in the 70s and 80s, during the golden years of the "Tiffany Network." He oversaw all broadcast production facilities nationwide, all remote production including sports events and major news coverages, network distribution system, engineering and development. Countless Emmy Awards for engineering excellence were earned under his leadership and vision. Mr. Shannon, of West Islip, Long Island, passed on January 4, 2016. He was the beloved husband of the late Rita J. Shannon. He was the devoted father of Sharon Ann Fuentes, Barbara Ann Kelly and Michael T. Shannon and the cherished grandfather of six. Mr. Shannon will be reposing at The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy., (Quarter mile west of the Robert Moses Cswy). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial, Saturday 10:00am at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Babylon, Long Island. Interment to follow at St. Patrick's Cemetery, Huntington, Long Island. Visiting Friday, 2:00pm until 4:30pm and 7:00pm until 9:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 5028, Hagerstown, MD 21741-5028 or to St. Johnland Nursing Center, 395 Sunken Meadow Road, Kings Park, NY 11754. 1/3
