MORRISON--Richard. We mourn the loss of our partner, colleague and friend Richard Morrison, who suffered a heart attack and passed away on January 4. He was an important member of Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP for nearly 30 years, and was deeply devoted to his work, colleagues and clients. As Managing Partner of Weil's Miami office and a longstanding partner in our Real Estate practice, Richard was instrumental in the development of Weil's presence in Miami and was also integral in helping to shape our global Real Estate practice. Richard split his time between our Miami and New York offices, and was known and loved by partners, associates and staff across all of Weil's offices. He graduated with a B.A. from Vanderbilt University in 1981 and earned a J.D. from the University of Florida's Levin College of Law in 1984. We will remember Richard with the utmost respect and admiration, and we offer our deepest sympathy to his family; he will be greatly missed by his many friends and colleagues at Weil. 1/3

STANLEY--Ted. The Brain & Behavior Research Foundation, formerly the National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression (NARSAD), mourns the passing of Ted Stanley, a prominent philanthropist for mental health research and our organization. Mr. Stanley in partnership with his wife, Vada, who passed away in 2013, were early supporters and kind friends to the Brain & Behavior Research Foundation. Their generosity in supporting research on mental illness is a great model for all of us. We recognize that they have enhanced the lives of many through their work and have the deepest gratitude to them both. Our deepest sympathies to their son Jonathan and to all of their loved ones. Jeffrey Borenstein, M.D., President Constance E. Lieber, President Emerita Stephen A. Lieber, Chairman of the Board Herbert A. Pardes, M.D., President of the Scientific Council 1/3

BALDWIN--Robert H.B. NewYork-Presbyterian is deeply saddened by the loss of Robert H.B. Baldwin, a beloved friend of our institution. Mr. Baldwin served as Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees at The Presbyterian Hospital (now NewYork- Presbyterian), and was elected a Life Trustee in 1997 in recognition of his outstanding contributions to the Hospital. A man of extraordinary talent and vision, he emphasized the importance of philanthropy as chairman of Morgan Stanley, and fostered an enduring bond between the firm and NewYork-Presbyterian that continues to advance patient care for New Yorkers and patients around the world. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Dorothy, his children and stepchildren and all of his family and loved ones. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman of the Board John J. Mack, Vice Chair of the Board Jerry I. Speyer, Vice Chair of the Board Steven J. Corwin, MD, CEO NewYork-Presbyterian 1/3

MARK--Erika Reider, of New York City and East Hampton died on January 5, 2016 after a brief illness. She was predeceased by her husband Richard, to whom she was lovingly married for 57 years. She is survived by her daughters, Jennifer and Audrey, and grandchildren Emily, Johnny, Henry, Tommy and Charlie, as well as her brothers, Alan and Jeffrey Reider. She graduated from Wellesley College and had a stellar career as a magazine editor. She received the National Magazine Award for her work at Good Housekeeping and was honored at a reception with President Clinton at the White House. She was fluent in five languages and was an avid world traveler with an adventurous spirit. She enjoyed playing tennis at the East Hampton Tennis Club and golf at the Noyac Golf Club as well as participating in two book clubs. Most of all she loved spending time with her family who greatly adored her and will miss her terribly. Funeral services to be held Friday January 8, 2016 at 2:00pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. 1/3

KAISER--Walter, May 31, 1931 to January 5, 2016. Born in Bellevue, Ohio during the Depression, the son of a grocer, he became a page in the U.S. Senate in 1944 and then won scholarships to Philips Academy, Andover and Harvard, an institution he didn't leave until retirement. He graduated magna cum laude with highest honors in 1954, received his Ph.D. in 1960, and was made Professor of English and Comparative Literature in 1969. From 1988 to 2002 he served as Director of Villa I Tatti, the Harvard University Center for Italian Renaissance Studies in Florence. His leadership profoundly shaped I Tatti, and those were among his happiest years; he always felt that he truly belonged to the northern Mediterranean, especially to Greece and Italy. His love of learning and the arts gave color and depth to every aspect of his life. Few people have been more learned or more cultivated, wittier or more awake to beauty. Fewer still have had his genius for friendship. He was extraordinarily generous with his attention, and always finding opportunities for generosity where others wouldn't have seen them. He was the best of fathers. He is survived by his children, Miranda and David, and three granddaughters; by his brother, Bob; by his many godchildren; and by hundreds of others whose lives he enriched immeasurably, as the astonishing outpouring of grief and love from around the world since his death attests. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Walter Kaiser Fund for the Biblioteca Berenson at Villa I Tatti, Harvard University. 1/3

KAYE--Honorable Judith. The NYU School of Law mourns the passing of our distinguished alumna, the Honorable Judith Kaye '62. Judge Kaye, who served for 25 years on the New York Court of Appeals and was its Chief Judge from 1993 to 2008, was a trailblazer for women, a brilliant jurist, and a vocal advocate for legal reform. She was also a deeply committed member of the NYU Law community. In addition to serving as a trustee in the 1980s and '90s, she was an advisory board member of our Center on Civil Justice; a director of our Institute for Judicial Administration; and recipient of nearly all of our most distinguished awards for alumni achievement and service. We are grateful for her life and deeply saddened by her loss. NYU School of Law Trevor Morrison, Dean 1/3

KAYE--Judith S. With heartfelt sadness, the Trustees and Administration of Barnard College mourn the passing of the Honorable Judith S. Kaye '58, who was a devoted alumna, a Barnard Trustee from 1995 to 2002, and again from 2008 to 2009, an active trustee emerita, and a member of the Athena Center Board of Advisors. In 1987, she received the College's highest honor, the Barnard Medal of Distinction, and in 2010, the Frederick A.P. Barnard Award for all she has done for women, for the rights of the individual, and for her alma mater. Barnard honors the memory of this extraordinary woman and extends its deepest sympathies to her family. Jolyne Caruso-FitzGerald Chair, Board of Trustees Debora Spar, President 1/3

MARK--Erika Reider, of New York City and East Hampton died on January 5, 2016 after a brief illness. She was predeceased by her husband Richard, to whom she was lovingly married for 57 years. She is survived by her daughters, Jennifer and Audrey, and grandchildren Emily, Johnny, Henry, Tommy and Charlie, as well as her brothers, Alan and Jeffrey Reider. She graduated from Wellesley College and had a stellar career as a magazine editor. She received the National Magazine Award for her work at Good Housekeeping and was honored at a reception with President Clinton at the White House. She was fluent in five languages and was an avid world traveler with an adventurous spirit. She enjoyed playing tennis at the East Hampton Tennis Club and golf at the Noyac Golf Club as well as participating in two book clubs. Most of all she loved spending time with her family who greatly adored her and will miss her terribly. Funeral services to be held Friday January 8, 2016 at 2:00pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. 1/3

KAYE--Judith S. The members of the Boards of the Fund and Committee for Modern Courts mourn the passing of the former Chief Judge of the State of New York, our fellow Board member, colleague, and outstanding advocate for judicial reform. May she rest in peace. 1/3

KAYE--Judith. January 7. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our colleague and friend Judith Kaye. Before joining our New York appellate litigation and arbitration practice in 2009, Judith spent 25 years on the bench of the New York Court of Appeals, including the last 15 as its Chief Judge. The first woman to serve on New York's highest court, Judith earned a national reputation for her pioneering opinions and court reforms. She wrote seminal opinions on such issues as the death penalty, same-sex marriage, education and state constitutional rights while leading innovative changes to the New York court system, including the establishment of specialized courts to focus on issues of drug addiction, domestic violence and mental health. As Chief Judge, Judith created the Adoption Now program, helped establish the Center for Court Innovation and co-chaired the ABA Commission on the American Jury. She retired from the bench in 2008, having served longer than any Chief Judge in state history. At Skadden, Judith helped numerous clients navigate complex issues of New York law. She also served as a trustee of the Skadden Fellowship Foundation and continued her advocacy for families and children, including through her service as the chairwoman of the Permanent Judicial Commission on Justice for Children. Judith graduated from Barnard College ('58) and NYU School of Law ('62), where she was one of 10 women in a class of nearly 300. Judith is survived by her children, Luisa, Jonathan and Gordon, and seven grandchildren. She will be greatly missed. 1/3

KAYE--Hon. Judith S. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts deeply mourn the passing of the Hon. Judith S. Kaye, former Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals and the first woman to lead the state's judiciary. A passionate supporter of the performing arts, she was a Lincoln Center board member, where she made a lasting contribution as Chairman of the Legal Committee. Judge Kaye also served on the board of Lincoln Center Education and she was honored at our David Rubenstein Atrium Gala in 2013. Her wisdom, leadership and friendship inspired us daily. We offer our sincerest condolences to her children Luisa, Jonathan, and Gordon, their spouses and children, and to her many friends and former colleagues. Katherine Farley, Chairman Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. 1/3

CARLSON--Claudia, died at the Dawn Greene Hospice in her 59th year on January 6, 2016. Claudia was born in Bloomington, Indiana to Elof and Helen (nee Zuckerman) Carlson and raised in six college towns. She was an illustrator, graphic designer, book designer, cartographer, photographer, and poet. She wrote three books of poetry, co-edited one volume of poetry, and wrote and illustrated a children's book. She worked for Farrar, Straus and Giroux, Oxford University Press, and American Friends of Magen David Adom. She also was a founding member of River Writers of Manhattan. She received her BA at Stony Brook University. After her mother's death she was raised by her father and Nedra (nee Miller) Carlson with her younger siblings, Christina, Erica, John and Anders. With David Allen she had two children Natalie (nee Allen) Hardaker, and Caitlin Allen. She is also survived by her husband, playwright James Racheff. A memorial service is planned for early spring. Condolences can be sent to: claudiacarlson@gmail.com 1/3

KAYE--Honorable Judith S. at home on January 7, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Stephen. She is survived by her children, Luisa Kaye Hagemeier, Jonathan Kaye, and Gordon Kaye; seven grandchildren; and brother, Allen Smith and beloved sister-in-law Penelope Smith; as well as many cherished nieces, nephews, cousins and other relatives. Funeral service will be held on Monday, 10am, January 11, 2016 at a venue to be announced, followed by private burial. The family requests that any donations be made to JALBCA (www.jalbca.org) or The PJCJC Fund, Inc. for the Judith S. Kaye Scholarship to support a youth in foster care who is attending college (pjcjc@nycourts.gov). 1/3

SQUIRE--Annette C. of Boynton Beach, FL, devoted and beloved wife for almost 60 years of the (late) Albert Squire, daughter of the late Irving and Bella (nee Lehman) Cohen, sister of the late Molly Gershen, mother of Jeffrey and Judi Squire, loving grandmother of Evan and Emma Squire, and aunt to Robert and Joe Gershen, Susan Stoll, Susan Albright and Laura Stamm, passed away peacefully surrounded by family on December 8, 2015 at Delray Medical Center following a stroke on December 7. Annette, who turned 90 December 2, graduated with a B.S. from Columbia University School of Nursing and an M.S. from the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing. Starting her career in New York City for the Visiting Nurse Service, Annette then spent many years in Pennsylvania as a school nurse for the Pennsbury School System. All who knew Annette recognized that she was a caring and skillful nurse and loving mother, aunt, grandmother, sister, daughter, niece, cousin and friend. Annette cared deeply for the people in her life and we all will miss her warm smile, concern, and love. Her family expresses their heartfelt appreciation to her skillful, kind, loving and warm caregivers, Kimberly Barrett and Jacques Clervil. A memorial service is being planned for early 2016. The family knows that Annette would appreciate contributions in her memory to the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing 215-898-484 nursing.upenn.edu/friends giving, Columbia University School of Nursing, 866-GIFTSYS, or nursing.columbia.edu/giving, a charity benefiting Israel or any charity of your choice. 1/3

SWADOS--Elizabeth. February 5, 1951-January 5, 2016. Artist, mentor, composer. Cherished wife of Roz Lichter. Culture has lost a great one but heaven will now rock with the music of her soul. Thank you to the doctors and nurses and staff at Cornell Weill and NYU Langone. A memorial service is being planned. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Liz's memory may be made to the Educational Advocacy Project at the Legal Aid Society ("Legal Aid Society- EAP") or the Jewish Women's Archive. "She shall be like a tree planted by the rivers of water that brings forth the fruit in season, whose leaves shall not wither." 1/3

KRAVET--Stanley, 81, passed peacefully at home in Manhasset, NY, with his family and devoted wife Rhoda Kravet by his side. Born in 1934 in Brooklyn, NY to Rose and Morris Kravet, he graduated from Boys High and NYU School of Business, where he met his wife. He attended Brooklyn Law School on a full scholarship and after graduating he began working at Royal Abstract, a New York City title insurance agency. He spent over 45 years building Royal Abstract into a well known and successful company and welcomed his son Martin into the business in 1985. He was very well respected by all who knew him. Outside of his work he was involved in the rebuilding of the Jewish Center of Bayside Oaks, in Queens. He enjoyed golf and was an esteemed member of Engineers Country Club and Cold Spring Country Club. He and his wife spent winters at Boca West in Boca Raton, Florida where they were members of Boca West Country Club. He was a kind and proud man who was devoted to his family. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Rhoda, loving father to son Martin (wife Susan) and daughter Susan Pecker (husband Elliot) and his adored grandchildren, Justin, Rachel, Dylan and Caroline. He was a loving husband, father, grandfather and brother and he will be greatly missed. Funeral service will be held at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, in New York City on Friday, January 8 at 12pm. 1/3
LEWIS--Ruth. January 8, 2014 Always in our hearts. Neville, Matt, Andy and Jon 1/3

GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Gene; devoted children Paul, Judith Kingman, and Robert; grandchildren Alexander and Garrett Kingman and Michelle and David Glantz, and nephew Bruce Kauderer. A consummate gentleman, he was a World War II veteran, lawyer, founder of real estate development, investment and management firm, Windsor Properties, and esteemed patriarch of his extended family. His patience, wisdom, optimism, generosity and strong family values will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. Laid to rest in Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York on December 28, 2015. 1/3

BOULEZ--Pierre. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall celebrate the life of our dear friend and colleague Pierre Boulez, one of the most important and influential artists of the 20th century. A legendary composer, conductor, musical philosopher and activist, Pierre Boulez was a visionary and trailblazing global force for modern music. Carnegie Hall was privileged to elect him an Honorary Trustee in 1995, and to appoint him as the Richard and Barbara Debs Composer's Chair from 1999 to 2003. Boulez made approximately 75 appearances at Carnegie Hall, conducting close to 60 performances on our stages, and his works have been performed on more than 80 programs. As an arts educator, he was inspirational-challenging audiences to explore a new aesthetic of music through his musical research center IRCAM, and, in the course of the Professional Training Workshops he led through Carnegie Hall's Weill Music Institute, offering profound insights to young musicians. Boulez's work in Paris served as an inspiration in the conception of Zankel Hall, the opening season of which included performances by Boulez with the Ensemble Intercontemporain. Pierre Boulez will be deeply missed by all of us at Carnegie Hall and by the entire artistic community, though his brilliant musical legacy and pioneering spirit will stay with us all. We express heartfelt condolences to his sister, Jeanne Chevalier Boulez, and brother, Roger Boulez, as well as their many children and grandchildren. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes T. Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3
SWADOS--Elizabeth. The Peter S. Reed Foundation extends deepest sympathies to fellow board member Roz Lichter on the passing of her brilliant wife, Liz Swados. 1/3

KASHNER--Howard. We at Royce & Associates, LLC mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Howard Kashner. Over the course of a long and distinguished association with the firm, first as Outside Counsel for Pennsylvania Mutual Fund (1968-1995) then as General Counsel for The Royce Fund (1995-2002), Howard not only embodied the virtues of intelligence, relentless integrity and fine judgement, he exemplified trust, loyalty, and true friendship to all of those with whom he worked. He was an invaluable part of our company and we will miss him greatly. 1/3

KAYE--Judith. January 7. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our colleague and friend Judith Kaye. Before joining our New York appellate litigation and arbitration practice in 2009, Judith spent 25 years on the bench of the New York Court of Appeals, including the last 15 as its Chief Judge. The first woman to serve on New York's highest court, Judith earned a national reputation for her pioneering opinions and court reforms. She wrote seminal opinions on such issues as the death penalty, same-sex marriage, education and state constitutional rights while leading innovative changes to the New York court system, including the establishment of specialized courts to focus on issues of drug addiction, domestic violence and mental health. As Chief Judge, Judith created the Adoption Now program, helped establish the Center for Court Innovation and co-chaired the ABA Commission on the American Jury. She retired from the bench in 2008, having served longer than any Chief Judge in state history. At Skadden, Judith helped numerous clients navigate complex issues of New York law. She also served as a trustee of the Skadden Fellowship Foundation and continued her advocacy for families and children, including through her service as the chairwoman of the Permanent Judicial Commission on Justice for Children. Judith graduated from Barnard College ('58) and NYU School of Law ('62), where she was one of 10 women in a class of nearly 300. Judith is survived by her children, Luisa, Jonathan and Gordon, and seven grandchildren. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at 10:00am (doors open at 9:15), Monday, January 11, at the David H. Koch Theater, Lincoln Center. 1/3

ELLENBERG--James Louis, formerly of Rye Brook NY, age 75, passed away January 9th, 2016. He is predeceased by his loving wife Joan Ellenberg, and his parents Louis and Claire Ellenberg. Jim is survived by his devoted sons, Larry (Robin) and Gregg (Tatum) and his adored grandchildren, Jordan, Max and Hatty as well as his loving sister Judi Falk (Maurice) Private funeral will be Monday followed by Shiva held Monday and Tuesday 4-8:30pm. Contact family for address. 1/3

SWADOS--Elizabeth "Liz." The Mercer-Houston Dog Run community mourns the loss of our beloved member. This incandescent spirit enhanced us through her deep humanity, integrity, and singular talent. We cherish her memory. Our heartfelt sympathies to her devoted wife, Roz, and gentle pats to Clementine and Leo. 1/3

GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Gene; devoted children Paul, Judith Kingman, and Robert; grandchildren Alexander and Garrett Kingman and Michelle and David Glantz, and nephew Bruce Kauderer. A consummate gentleman, he was a World War II veteran, lawyer, founder of real estate development, investment and management firm, Windsor Properties, and esteemed patriarch of his extended family. His patience, wisdom, optimism, generosity and strong family values will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. Laid to rest in Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York on December 28, 2015. 1/3

KAYE--Hon. Judith S. The Fordham Law community is deeply saddened by the death of Hon. Judith S. Kaye, former Chief Judge of the New State Court of Appeals. She was a great friend of Fordham Law School and its alumni, particularly those serving in the state and federal judiciary. Over the years, she wrote for the Fordham Law Review and other journals, and she inspired students, graduates, and alumni with her remarks at the school's diploma ceremony, conferences, and lecture series. The school honored her in 2002 with the Fordham- Stein Prize, which is presented annually to a member of the legal profession whose work embodies the highest standards of the legal profession. In 2012, she participated in a special conversation alongside retired Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor that canvassed their concerns about the election of judges, the importance of civic education and involvement for lawyers, and their pathbreaking appointments as the first women to hold their respective judicial roles. In addition to her jurisprudence, her administrative impact will leave an indelible mark on the office of Chief Judge of the State of New York. We extend our deepest sympathy to her colleagues at Skadden Arps and her family. Matthew Diller, Dean Fordham Law School 1/3
SINGER--David. 1927-2010 I love you more & I miss you more with each passing day. Jeannie and your dear family 1/3

GOLD--Debra (Fridovich), on January 6, 2016, age 103. Beloved wife of the late Theodore. Loving and devoted mother of William (Nili) and the late Jeffrey. Cherished grandmother of Avitai (Jocelyn) and Doria. Special great-grandmother of Elijah and Tali. Dear sister of the late Asenath (Ben) Rosenberg, Renee (Jack) Leeb, Louis (Sylvia) Fridovich, Joseph (Rhoda) Fridovich and Zelig (Rae) Fridovich. Adored aunt and great-aunt to many. Donations may be made to the Yeshivah of Flatbush Scholarship Fund. Services were held January 8. 1/3

FREIWALD--Benjamin, passed away December 22nd, 2015 in Hollywood, California. Benjamin is predeceased by his mother Kathleen Preston Knight. He is survived by his father Joshua Freiwald, sister Jessica Watt, partner and mother of his child Laura Strayer, and daughter Imogen Freiwald. His family and friends laid him to rest in The Garden of Legends at Hollywood Forever on Friday, January 8th, 2016. Benjamin was born on May 12th, 1963 at Kaiser Hospital San Francisco. Benjamin is a long standing member of the ACLU. Donations in his memory can made at www.aclu.org/freiwald. 1/3

BOESCHENSTEIN--Josephine "Molly." Freedom Institute extends its sympathy to the family of Josephine "Molly" Boeschenstein, a former Board Member and wonderful friend. Her support of our work in the prevention and treatment of alcohol and substance abuse and addiction was unwavering. Molly's generosity and commitment to our cause leaves a lasting legacy. With gratitude, Freedom Institute. 1/3

SIEGEL--Peter L. It is with heavy hearts, we announce that Peter L. Siegel died January 6, 2016 due to complications from a bone marrow transplant for the treatment of Leukemia. Peter was born in New York City on March 24, 1950 and grew up in Great Neck, NY. He has a BA from the University of Mass. Amherst, and holds two masters degrees from the University of Chicago. He was a passionate sailor and resided in Brooklyn, NY. He is survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Deborah and William Cosentino, seven cousins, as well as his very dear friends Dave Turner and Christine Benner. He is and will be greatly missed. We will be holding a memorial service for Peter this spring in New York City, time and location to be announced. 1/3

HOWAT--Anne Hadley. 27 September 1937 - 5 January 2016. Executive volunteer in family planning through EngenderHealth. She was married to her best friend Jock, who died in June, for 57 years. She was a loving mother to her daughters, Karen and Laura, both surviving, and a kind and engaging friend to many. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to EngenderHealth, New York City. Memorial plans are to be determined. 1/3

LIBERTINI--Richard Joseph, actor, died January 7, after a two year battle against cancer. He was born nearly 83 years ago in Cambridge, MA to Esther and Rocco Libertini. He graduated from Emerson College and was partner with MacIntyre Dixon and Linda Segal in the uproarious act they named, "Stewed Prunes" which played in coffee houses in New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago. His first Broadway play was in Woody Allen's "Don't Drink the Water." His last was in Allen's "Relatively Speaking" in 2011-12. Richard worked in a number of television series, and movies, most notably as the Guru in the film, "All of Me," and the crazy General in "The In-laws." He is survived by his son Richard, a musician, sister Alice Langone, brother Albert, brother-in-law Mike Langone, sister-in-law Catherine Dillon, cousin Mario Libertini of Abruzzi, Italy, beloved nieces and nephews, former wife, and friend Melinda Dillon, and many true and great friends. A memorial service will be held in the future. 1/3

WIGDER--Harriet (Fein). We regret to announce the untimely passing of Harriet (Fein) Wigder. Harriet was born in Brooklyn, NY on June 23, 1930 to Betty and Victor Fein. She was a graduate of Hunter College and obtained a Master of Arts degrees from Teachers College, Columbia University. Harriet was an elementary school teacher in the New York City public school system. She had a special fondness for children, their education and integration into the mainstream of New York cultural life. Harriet was an early devotee of the fledgling State of Israel and visited Israel in her teenage years and many times thereafter. She was married to Dr. Bernard Wigder and they lived in Riverdale, New York for many years. They were actively involved in community charitable activities and were supportive of the Jewish Theological Seminary and the Riverdale Jewish Center. In retirement the Wigders lived in Pembroke Pines, Florida and continued their participation there in communal affairs. Bernard died in 2005. Harriet remained the beloved matriarch of her family and the extended Feinzeig clan. She passed away last Shabbat afternoon, January 2, 2016 with her immediate family in attendance. Harriet leaves her brother Jack, her sister-in- law Karin and her niece Shifra, who treasure her memory. Contributions in her name should be directed to the Hadassah Women's Organization. 1/3

BOULEZ--Pierre. The Directors of the Amphion Foundation, Inc. acknowledge with deep regret and sorrow the passing of Pierre Boulez, longtime friend and colleague of our founder, Elliott Carter. Their close relationship began in 1955 when Carter attended the premiere of "Le Marteau Sans Maitre" and continued without interruption until Carter's passing in 2012. Although he will be greatly missed by many, his stature as a preeminent composer and conductor, and his devotion to contemporary music, has created a permanent legacy which will continue to influence the development of music for many years to come. The Amphion Foundation, Inc. Virgil Blackwell, President James M. Kendrick, Secretary 1/3

CHUBB--Hendon. Hendon Chubb, an eccentric polymath, died suddenly January 3rd. He was a husband, father, grandfather, brother, artist, writer, psychologist, dog-lover, Yale graduate, rug designer, director and CFO of a Fortune 500 Company, honorary Girl Scout, gardener, officer of the American Cycad Society, vintner, army veteran, civil rights election monitor, early programmer, lover of France, Justice of the Peace, and poet. He was much loved by many and is sorely missed. A service will be held in the spring. 1/3

HOCHSWENDER--Woody, June 20, 1951, to December 31, 2015. His name was Wiliam Joseph Hochswender III, but everyone knew him as Woody. For many, he was the lanky, redheaded and perennially boyish fashion and style reporter for The New York Times, Harper's Bazaar, Esquire and Golf. For others, he was an inspirational practitioner of Nichiren Buddhism: he brought comfort, joy and wisdom to many through his example, his guidance and his two books, "The Buddha in Your Mirror" and "The Buddha in Your Rearview Mirror." In Sharon, CT, where he had lived since 1993, he was known as a quirky character with memorable pickup trucks (his beautiful golden retriever, Lola, nearly always along for the ride) and a passion for swimming, biking and otherwise enjoying the beauty around him. For his daughter, Kate, he was her biggest cheerleader as well as the person who always encouraged her to set a high standard and then meet it. He adored her, and she adored him. A true journalist, Woody was interested in everything; for the past few years, he was able to travel widely and meet interesting people in the company of his girlfriend, Kirsten Jensen. His daughter and former wife, Cynthia, were glad that he was able to enrich his life and expand his horizons with Kirsten before his death, from a glioblastoma tumor, on December 31. For a full obituary and details of his January 17 memorial service in Lakeville, CT, go to his memorial website at www.forevermissed.com. 1/3

WEISSMAN--Julia Zlabovsky, 98, died on October 15, 2015 after a brief illness. Born in El Paso, Texas, she graduated from the College of Mines and Metallurgy of the University of Texas and later settled in New York City to pursue a career as a writer and editor. As author or co-author, she published books and articles in many areas of the arts and crafts, including folk art, needlework and cooking. She was predeceased by her sisters, Vera Zlabovsky and Esther Boxer and by her brothers Isador (Saul) Stuart and David Stuart. She is survived by her daughter Erica Weissman, brother Frank Stuart, nephew David Stuart, nieces Elizabeth Stuart and Rebecca Orlowski (Steven), and grandnephews Jesse, Derek, and Paul Orlowski. 1/3

ROSENBLATT--Helen, on January 8, 2016. Beloved wife of Bob. Loving mother of Neil (Stacey) and Melissa (Mike) Katz. Adored Grandma of Ella, Jenna, and Alex. Cherished sister of Lenny (Ellen) Chess, the late Normie Chess and sister-in-law Kim Chess. Also, survived by many nieces and nephews. Services under the direction of Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels. 1/3
MEISTER--Bertram, M.D. Happy birthday! If to be remembered is to live on, you will always be with us. Arlene, Lynn and Barbara 1/3

MEYERHOFF--Erich, born 1919 in Braunschweig Germany, died of heart failure on December 26, 2015 in New York City. He was admired, respected, and loved by colleagues, family, and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Socialist Party USA www.tinyurl.com/p5334n6 or The Medical Library Association Scholarship Fund www.tinyurl.com/z5vzk36 will be appreciated. 1/3

BROSS--Arthur, of Poughkeepsie, NY, died Wednesday, December 30, 2015 due to complications from Alzheimer's disease. He was surrounded by his loving family, caregivers and grand dog. Art was born October 17, 1928 in Bronx, NY to the late Joseph and Bessie Bross and preceded in death by five siblings. He was 87 years young. Art served in the Army and Army Reserves, attaining the rank of 1st Lieutenant and he received a National Defense Service Medal. Never one to back down from a challenge, he worked full time while attending City College of New York for his B.S.M.E and M.S.M.E. degrees. Art was a Senior Engineer at IBM Microelectronics in Hopewell Junction, NY, author or editor of three books, and holder of 10 U.S. patents. He loved the country, gardening, birding, antiquing, and barbecuing, with a penchant for overcooked meats. Art was a beloved husband of the late Isabel Beth Bross for 47 years, a devoted father to his two daughters, Judy (Jeff) Bramson of Highland Park, IL and Jill Bross of Westhampton, NY. His two grandchildren, Alex and Nina Bramson were the loves of his life. Memorial donations can be made in Art's memory to the Alzheimer's Association. www.alz.org 1/3

KAYE--Hon. Judith S. The lawyers and staff of Proskauer mourn the loss of our friend the Hon. Judith S. Kaye, the former Chief Judge of the State of New York, and wife of our esteemed and beloved late colleague Stephen Rackow Kaye, who served as senior partner and former Chair of our Litigation and Dispute Resolution Department. Judith was one of the nation's most esteemed jurists and public servants of her time. She was a true role model and helped to pave the way for future generations of women to succeed in the law. Judith exemplified the fundamental values of the profession, and we were profoundly privileged to have had Judith as a friend for the last 50 years. 1/3
KASPER--Anne, 1917-2015. Beloved wife and mother. Widow of Irving Kasper, mother of Marvin, Orlando, FL and Carol R. Hannan of Pasadena CA. Interment, Cedar Park. 1/3

KATZ--Peggy Roselle, born May 29, 1945 on Long Island, NY to Ellen Rowsell and George A. Goldstein, died December 1, 2015 in Atlanta, GA. She is survived by her brother Andy Goldstein, her children Andrew and Jon Katz, and her grandchildren Sebastian, Nicholas, and Audrey. Her husband, Robert "Bob" Katz, passed in 2013. A true friend, beloved colleague, and adored mom, she will forever remain in our hearts. 1/3

KAYE--Judith S. The fellows of the College of Commercial Arbitrators express profound sadness on the passing of our esteemed colleague, the Hon. Judith S. Kaye. We were honored to have her join the community of arbitrators. She will long be remembered with fondness. Edna Sussman, President, College of Commercial Arbitrators 1/3

BERKOWITZ--Leonard, 89, Professor Emeritus of Psychology and Vilas Research Professor at the University of Wisconsin, died on January 3, 2016 in Madison, WI. Dr. Berkowitz was born in New York City on August 11, 1926. He received his bachelor's degree from NYU and his Ph.D. from the University of Michigan. He served in the United States Army during WWII. Dr. Berkowitz was on the faculty of the University of Wisconsin at Madison from 1955 to 1989. He also held visiting appointments at Stanford, Oxford, Cambridge, and Cornell Universities. He was one of the pioneers in the experimental study of altruism but is, perhaps, best known for studying influences on aggressive behavior, including the effects of television and film violence. Dr. Berkowitz was the author of over 170 articles and books, and is one of the most frequently cited psychologists of the twentieth century. After his retirement, he continued to write in his field, submitting his last article for publication on November 1, 2015. He was an avid world traveler, collector of modern art, follower of world events and opera-goer. Dr. Berkowitz was predeceased by his first wife, Nettie, in 1975. He is survived by his wife of forty years, Norma, and two daughters, two stepsons, five grandchildren, two step-grandsons and a brother. A memorial fund has been established in his honor for the benefit of Psychology graduate students at the UW- Madison. Contributions to the Berkowitz Memorial Fund may be mailed to the University of Wisconsin Foundation, Attn: A. Kitslaar, 1848 University Ave, Madison, WI 53726. 1/3

BAUER--Fred L.,Esq., 64, died January 5, 2016. Survived by his sisters Elaine B. Zamore and Beverly Feller, four nieces and two nephews. Attended NYU and John Marshall Law School. Member of Law Review. Received LLM from New York University. Sole practitioner in Tax Law. 1/3

FULLER--Lee M.,Jr. The Council, past Presidents and members of The University Club mourn the passing of our esteemed friend and beloved former House Committee Chair Lee M. Fuller Jr., A.B., Princeton, '60; J.D., Columbia '65. Lee was our friend and confidant, a patriot and a gentleman. A man of great generosity, he was devoted to his family. He now has a commanding view of the track from above. Our most heartfelt condolences to his wife Vicki, to his son Scott, also a well-respected member of our Club, and to his entire family. Ave atque vale. The University Club 1/3

DELFINER--Henry, of Lexington, MA passed away January 3, 2016. Born in Vienna, Henry and his sister fled Austria on the day of the Anschluss, coming to the United States via Paris. He graduated from Amherst College in 1943, joined the Army, serving with the 88th Infantry Division in northern Italy. On May 2, 1945, acting as the translator for his commanding officer, Henry took the surrender of a whole German corps, including the First German Parachute Division. Decorated with the Bronze Star, he left the Army as a major. After the War, he was instrumental in reclaiming the family business from the Nazis, thereafter running the Herzmansky Department Store himself. He was also involved with the family business Greene Tweed of Kulpsville, PA through most of his adult life. He received a Ph.D. from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy and taught at Tufts University as a professor of International Relations. His class on "Understanding International News," which he taught in the Experimental College at Tufts was very popular. After retiring from Tufts in 1987, he continued to write scholarly articles about the history of central Europe. In 1999, concerned with a lack of balance in political views in academia, he joined with Hadley Arkes, Edward N. Ney Professor in American Institutions at Amherst College in establishing the Colloquium on the American Founding, a twice-yearly weekend series of lectures and seminars where well-known national figures and influential conservative speakers were invited to present their views. He will be remembered for his kindness and his extraordinary generosity. Beloved husband of Barbara (Schudawa) Delfiner. Devoted father of Hannah Delfiner, Michael Delfiner and his wife Tracey, and Ruth Delfiner and her husband Paul Cooke. Loving brother of Charlotte Sperber. Cherished grandfather of Allon Bloch and his wife Annelise, Benjamin Delfiner, Rebecca Delfiner and her fiance Tom, and Emma Cooke. Proud great-grandfather of Alexander Bloch. 1/3

MCKEAND--Carol Evan, died peacefully on the morning of December 19th, 2015 after a 10 year battle with Alzheimer's. An extremely talented author, television writer and producer (two Emmy nominations and the winner of four of the prestigious Humanitas awards). A true New Yorker, she will be remembered for her engaging, irreverent wit and the loyalty and kindness of a true friend. Dearest Carol... you are deeply missed by your husband Nigel, your daughter Sarah (a.k.a Bishi), your son-in-law Ryan, and your two amazing grandchildren, Olivia, 11 and Griffin, 8. You touched everyone who knew you. A memorial will be held for Carol on January 23rd, 2016 in Beverly Hills. For information, please email carolevan1930@gmail.com. We have loved you through every "Glad and Sorry Season". 1/3

STANLEY--Ted. The Fountain House community and our members, who have been profoundly impacted by Ted and Vada's extraordinary generosity, extend our deep condolences to the Stanley family for its loss. Initially motivated by his son's bipolar disorder, Ted's unparalleled contributions to scientific research improved and extended the lives of countless people with mental illness everywhere. His altruism, advocacy and compassion represent a legacy to be forever respected and cherished. With gratitude and sympathy The Fountain House Board of Directors and President Kenneth J. Dudek 1/3

HALPERT--Carolyn McDaniel. The Methodist Home for Nursing and Rehabilitation notes with sorrow the passing of our esteemed, very active Board member, Carolyn Halpert. Her hard work on behalf of the residents will be sorely missed, as well as her gracious presence at our meetings. SQUIRE--Annette C. of Boynton Beach, FL, devoted and beloved wife for almost 60 years of the (late) Albert Squire, daughter of the late Irving and Bella (nee Lehman) Cohen, sister of the late Molly Gershen, mother of Jeffrey and Judi Squire, loving grandmother of Evan and Emma Squire, and aunt to Robert and Joe Gershen, Susan Stoll, Susan Albright and Laura Stamm, passed away peacefully surrounded by family on December 8, 2015 at Delray Medical Center following a stroke on December 7. Annette, who turned 90 December 2, graduated with a B.S. from Columbia University School of Nursing and an M.S. from the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing. Starting her career in New York City for the Visiting Nurse Service, Annette then spent many years in Pennsylvania as a school nurse for the Pennsbury School System. All who knew Annette recognized that she was a caring and skillful nurse and loving mother, aunt, grandmother, sister, daughter, niece, cousin and friend. Annette cared deeply for the people in her life and we all will miss her warm smile, concern, and love. Her family expresses their heartfelt appreciation to her skillful, kind, loving and warm caregivers, Kimberly Barrett and Jacques Clervil. A memorial service is being planned for early 2016. The family knows that Annette would appreciate contributions in her memory to the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing 215-898-484 nursing.upenn.edu/friends giving, Columbia University School of Nursing, 866-GIFTSYS, or nursing.columbia.edu/giving, a charity benefiting Israel or any charity of your choice. 1/3

SWEENEY--Anne J. 85, passed away in Los Angeles on Friday, December 11, 2015. She was preceded in death by her adoring husband, Donald E. Sweeney, Sr., and her brothers, James (in infancy), Thomas, James, William, and Edward, and her sisters Claire Rose Taber and Marie Becker. She was born on March 1, 1930, in Wilkes-Barre, PA to James J. and Marie O'Connell Tormay. She moved to Onondoga Hill in Syracuse, NY in 1939. She was a communicant of St. Michael's Church in Syracuse. She received her Bachelor of Science degree from the State University of New York Teacher's College at Oswego in 1951, where she was President of the Newman Club. Her great passion in life was teaching and her favorite people were children. She completed her student teaching in Baldwinsville, NY and began her formal career in Liverpool. She moved to the Hudson Valley in the mid fifties and taught in Hudson, NY, and later in the Kingston Consolidated School District for 18 years. She taught second grade at both the Elisha M. Brigham Elementary School and Chambers Elementary School. Her students will remember her ability to do all of the voices when reading "Charlotte's Web" aloud to the class, lessons in "SC" (self control) and her mantra, "Life is Choices." She also taught evening adult education with her husband at John F. Kennedy Elementary School and was CCD instructor at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Kingston, NY, where she also served as a Eucharistic Minister. She is survived by her three children, Anne M. Sweeney and her husband Philip H. Miller of Los Angeles, Donald E. Sweeney of Kingston, and Rosemary Sweeney Hanczor and her husband, Robert Hanczor of San Diego. She also leaves seven adoring grandchildren - Christopher and Rosemary Miller, Michaela and Shelagh Sweeney, and Catherine, Elizabeth and Brigid Hanczor, as well as a cousin, Rita Tormay of Yonkers, NY and many nieces and nephews. A Funeral Mass was held on December 16 at St. Monica's Catholic Church in Santa Monica, CA, followed by a burial service at Holy Cross Cemetery in Culver City, CA. Donations can be made to the Donald E. and Anne J. Sweeney Memorial Scholarship Fund, St Monica Catholic Schools, 1030 Lincoln Blvd., Santa Monica, CA 90043. 1/3
KAYE--Hon. Judith S. Judith was a dear, dear friend and colleague. We will miss her terribly. Gloria and Barry Garfinkel 1/3

RYAN--David Francis, beloved husband of Linda Thung-Ryan, died peacefully in his home, Croton on Hudson, NY on January 4th. He was 73. David was born in Yonkers, NY. He graduated from the College of the Holy Cross and the Columbia School of Law. For over 40 years, he practiced Antitrust and Intellectual Property Law, as a partner, at the renowned New York City firms: Kaye Scholar, Fierman, Hays & Handler and Fitzpatrick, Cella, Harper & Scinto. Throughout his life, David was a humanist with a love and encyclopedic knowledge of the arts. He was an avid sports enthusiast. David is survived by his wife Linda; his son David Ryan III (Mary Ryan) and his daughter Deirdre Ryan (Warren Costikyan); six grandchildren; and his siblings, Veronica Plavonich, Judith Ryan, Deborah Johnson, Paul Ryan, Mark Ryan, and Mary Ryan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the College of the Holy Cross or The Metropolitan Opera. 1/3

SULSER--Fridolin, M.D. December 2, 1926 - January 3, 2016. Dr. Fridolin Sulser, who devoted his life to understanding the physiological basis of mental disorders and their treatment, died on January 3, 2016 at age 89, surrounded by loving family. He is survived by his brother, Emil Sulser of Maienfeld, Switzerland, wife, Johanna Mooser Sulser, and children Anna (Sulser) Newton, Adrian Sulser, Daniel Sulser, and Bettina (Sulser) Bryant, along with eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Dr. Sulser was born in Grabs, Switzerland and grew up in the town of Maienfeld, amidst his beloved Swiss Alps. He graduated from the Humanistische Gymnasium in Chur in 1947, attended Medical School at the University of Basel (pre-clinical) and the University of Zurich (clinical), graduating with an M.D. in 1955. He served as a medical officer in the Swiss Army, married the love of his life, Johanna, and moved with his wife and infant daughter to begin a position as assistant professor at the University of Bern. The family's great American adventure began in the fall of 1958 when Fridolin accepted a post-doctoral fellowship in Neuropsychopharmacology at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, M.D. Four years later, he went to Burroughs Wellcome Research Labs in New York as Head of Pharmacology. In 1965 he joined the Vanderbilt University Medical School Faculty as professor and Director of the Pharmacology Research Center, becoming a Professor Emeritus of the University in 2000. Dr. Sulser received many honors during his research career, including the prestigious Anna-Monika Prize, and was a Fellow and President of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology as well as a Fellow of the Collegium International Neuro-Psychopharmacolo- gium. He was a very proud father and grandfather, who celebrated the childrens' successes as they pursued their chosen paths. He found inspiration in nature, literature, philosophy and the fine arts. Memorial Service: January 24 at 4pm at the Greater Nashville Unitarian Universalist Church, 374 Hicks Road, Nashville, TN 37221. In lieu of flowers, please consider donating to the scholarship fund at Vanderbilt School of Medicine "In Memory of Dr. Fridolin Sulser" (Vanderbilt Gift Processing, PMB 407727, 2301 Vanderbilt Place, Nashville, TN 37240-7727) or to the Friends of Radnor Lake "In Memory of Fridolin Sulser" (www.radnorlake.org). 1/3

KAYE--Judge Judith S. With great sadness the Yeshiva University community mourns the loss of Judge Judith S. Kaye, who was granted an honorary degree from the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law in 1993. Judge Kaye was the first woman to become Chief Judge of New York, serving with great distinction for 16 years, longer than any other chief judge in the state's history. The daughter of Jewish immigrants from Poland, Judge Kaye's distinguished legacy demonstrates her belief in equality before the law, and her commitment to break down barriers in the legal field, and in society at large. Judge Kaye is remembered for the exceptional warmth and generosity she displayed to the Cardozo community, especially in her interactions with students. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President, Yeshiva University Melanie Leslie, Dean, Cardozo School of Law 1/3

ROSENBERG--Irving, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Oceanside, NY died suddenly January 1, 2016. After distinguished WWII service in the Army Air Force, Irving began a lifelong career with CBS Television, retiring as Director of Film Services. Loving husband and best friend to Alice. Loving father to Amy and Neal, Jane and Walter. Adoring grandfather to Joshua, Jessica, Rachel, Evan, Hannah and Daniel. Doting great-grandfather to Jonah and Koby. 1/3

O'BRIEN--Mrs. Elva L. of Manhattan, NY died on January 7, 2016. She would have been 97 years of age in February. Mrs. O'Brien was born on February 13, 1919, in West Springfield, Massachusetts to Henry and Mary (Choquette) Brassard. On May 30, 1944, she married Lawrence F. O'Brien, Jr., at St. Joseph's Church in Springfield. Mr. O'Brien went on to twice serve as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, as a senior White House aide to Presidents John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson, and as Commissioner of the National Basketball Association. They were married for 46 years before Mr. O'Brien passed away in New York City in September of 1990. Mrs. O'Brien resided in Washington, D.C., from 1961-1973, before moving to New York City in 1973 where she lived at 860 U.N. Plaza for more than 40 years. She spent summers at her home in the town of Cotuit on Cape Cod in Massachusetts. A thoughtful and generous philanthropist, Mrs. O'Brien was involved in the Archbishop's Christmas Appeal/Catholic Charities of New York and also supported the New York Public Library, the Cotuit Library Association in Barnstable on Cape Cod, Massachusetts, and the Environmental Film Festival in Washington, D.C. Mrs. O'Brien was instrumental in creating the "Lawrence F. O'Brien Gallery" exhibit space within the National Archives in Washington, D.C. She was fiercely loyal to her family and friends, possessed a keen sense of humor and was a person inclined to speak her mind. Her passion for books and for reading was legendary. Mrs. O'Brien is survived by her beloved son Lawrence F. O'Brien III, and his wife Helen (Powell) O'Brien of Washington, D.C., and her two cherished grandsons Luke O'Brien and Peter O'Brien both also of Washington, D.C. Funeral services will be private. A reception in fond remembrance will be scheduled at a future date. The family requests that any donations in memory of Mrs. O'Brien be made to the New York Public Library/Audio Books Division or Catholic Charities of New York. 1/3

KAYE--Hon. Judith S. The trustees of the William Nelson Cromwell Foundation mourn the passing of their longtime colleague Hon. Judith S. Kaye, an extraordinary leader in public service and private practice. George A. Davidson, Chair John D. Gordan, III, Secretary Charles T. Dowling, Treasurer 1/3

WALTUCH--Randall E. You left us so suddenly a year ago and none of your family will ever be the same again. Your stoic business acumen has proven one of your legacies, along with your kind loving nature. We miss you and will forever. Your loving family 1/3

BERG--Ivar E. (1929-2016), an Emeritus Professor of Sociology at the University of Pennsylvania, who made important contributions to the study of higher education, labor markets and industrial sociology, died on January 1, 2016. Dr. Berg's classic book, Education and Jobs: The Great Training Robbery (1970) cast doubt on economists' assertions that people with more education earn more because they are more skilled and productive; instead, employers frequently hire people to work in jobs that do not make use of their education. His book played a major role in a landmark civil rights decision by the U. S. Supreme Court, Griggs vs. Duke Power Company (1971) and was credited with providing the bases of the theory of market signaling, for which Akerlof, Spence, and Stiglitz shared the 2001 Nobel Prize in Economics. Among his many honors, he was elected a Fellow of the International Academy of Management, which cited him as "one of the seminal figures in the sociological study of labor markets and the founder of economic sociology." Born January 3, 1929 in Brooklyn, NY, he earned his AB at Colgate and his doctorate at Harvard. He served in the U.S. Marine Corps, retiring as a major, and on the faculties of Columbia and Vanderbilt, in addition to Penn. Dr. Berg, author of more than 70 articles and chapters and dozen books, leaves a wife, Sharon (Calli) Berg, a son and daughter-in-law, Geoffrey and Amy Berg, and stepsons Tim Smallwood (and his wife, Staci Smallwood) and Jim Smallwood (and his fiance, Catta Keith). 1/3

HOWAT--Anne H. EngenderHealth mourns the passing of our friend, colleague, and Board member, Ms. Anne H. Howat. A champion for women's reproductive rights and health, Anne had served on the Board of Directors in various capacities for more than 45 years. Anne will be remembered for her passion for promoting women's rights and informed choice and increasing access to reproductive health services globally. We extend heartfelt condolences to Anne's daughters, Laura and Karen, and the entire family. We are indebted to Anne for her invaluable counsel and guidance, which made EngenderHealth an even stronger and more effective organization. We will miss her dearly. Pamela W. Barnes, President Rob Petty, Chair, Board of Directors EngenderHealth 1/3

KAYE--Judith S. The Historical Society of the New York Courts mourns the loss of our founder and guiding spirit, Judith S. Kaye. We recognize and celebrate that no one has had a more profound, positive impact on our court system. She was New York's first female, and longest serving, Chief Judge, and used her matchless energy and wisdom, heart and soul, to reshape the courts to improve the lives of countless people. She pioneered court innovations based on the premise that the legal system exists to serve the people with fairness and sensitivity. For this she was beloved, nationally and internationally. She neither sought nor basked in the accolades, acknowledging them with a shy smile and a handwritten note combining modesty and gratitude. She could be hilariously funny, but never at anyone else's expense. It is fitting that her memorial service will be held at Lincoln Center as the arts were important in her life, and she could be heard singing in the courthouse corridors. Judith once said she has a 5 to 9 job, arriving at 5am (often with grandmother photos to exchange with maintenance staff) leaving at 9pm, and yet she was always able to be there, undistracted, for her family and friends. Though as a historical society we focus on figures from the past, we were so fortunate to have had one of the nations' leading lights in our midst. She battled her illness with courage and dignity. It seemed to us that the day of her passing would somehow never come. But she was, after all, human. The Historical Society of the New York Courts 1/3

KAYE--Judith. The law clerks to Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye deeply mourn the loss of our beloved Chief. A brilliant jurist, scholar, writer, thinker, she served as mentor to us all, our teacher, confidante, cheerleader and friend. Her passion for justice, her commitment to equal rights, her insistence that everything could be made better, powered by boundless energy and a never-ending cascade of new ideas, will continue to inspire us always. Each of us is sustained by treasured memories of the times we spent together, by uproarious laughter born of her mischievous wit. We all feel so lucky to have worked with her, our lives are richer for having known her, and we will miss her terribly. 1/3

SHIELDS--William X.,author of "Bigger Than Life: The Last Great Amateur," the biography of his father, tennis legend Francis Xavier Shields, passed away after a heart attack on January 2nd at his home in Hollywood, FL. He was 66. "Willy" was especially proud of his many years coaching Special Olympic tennis athletes in Florida. The son of the late Francis X. Shields and the late Katharine M. Blaine, Willy is survived by his wife Janet Lynn Shields, his children Morgan Christina Shields and Holton Joseph Shields, and his siblings Marina Shields Contardi, Christine Mortimer Biddle, Katharine Shields and Walker Blaine. 1/3

von ZUBEN--Frederick G.,died peacefully on January 7, 2016 at 77 years old with his devoted wife of 47 years, their two loving sons and his sister by his side. KURZ--Rona Hoffman, passed away December 30, 2015. Beloved wife of Stanley (deceased), lovingly remembered by her children Susan Eleftherakis (Peter), Jane Klemmer (Tim), Peter Kurz (Jennifer), grandchildren Clifford, Elizabeth, Katherine, Alexander, Kerry, Devon, Michelle and Caroline, and her brother Leonard Hoffman. Her family and friends will gather for a celebration of her life on March 13. 1/3

KAYE--Judith. January 7. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our colleague and friend Judith Kaye. Before joining our New York appellate litigation and arbitration practice in 2009, Judith spent 25 years on the bench of the New York Court of Appeals, including the last 15 as its Chief Judge. The first woman to serve on New York's highest court, Judith earned a national reputation for her pioneering opinions and court reforms. She wrote seminal opinions on such issues as the death penalty, same-sex marriage, education and state constitutional rights while leading innovative changes to the New York court system, including the establishment of specialized courts to focus on issues of drug addiction, domestic violence and mental health. As Chief Judge, Judith created the Adoption Now program, helped establish the Center for Court Innovation and co-chaired the ABA Commission on the American Jury. She retired from the bench in 2008, having served longer than any Chief Judge in state history. At Skadden, Judith helped numerous clients navigate complex issues of New York law. She also served as a trustee of the Skadden Fellowship Foundation and continued her advocacy for families and children, including through her service as the chairwoman of the Permanent Judicial Commission on Justice for Children. Judith graduated from Barnard College ('58) and NYU School of Law ('62), where she was one of 10 women in a class of nearly 300. Judith is survived by her children, Luisa, Jonathan and Gordon, and seven grandchildren. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at 10:00am (doors open at 9:15), Monday, January 11, at the David H. Koch Theater, Lincoln Center. 1/3

KREMEN--Andrea, died on January 7, 2016 at the age of 68. Beloved wife of Arnold Kotlen. Loving mother of Jessica (Bill) and Gillian. Adoring grandmother of Alek and Jake. PAHLAVI--Her Imperial Highness Princess Ashraf, twin sister of His Late Imperial Majesty, Shah of Iran, died peacefully in her home in Europe January 7 at age 96. Survived by her son Prince Chahram Pahlavi, five grandsons and great-grandchildren. Her Imperial Highness was President of the Women's Organization of Iran, Honorary Vice Chair of Iran's National Committee for World Literacy Program, Vice President of the Imperial Organization for Social Welfare, Head of the Iranian Delegation to the United Nations, Chair of the First United Nations Conference on Human Rights in Tehran in 1968, Chair of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, Honorary President of the Foundation for Iranian Studies, Pioneer in women's rights and was the first woman to appear unveiled in public. As emissary for her brother, she developed tied to many nations of interest to Iran. A skilled diplomat who successfully established full diplomatic relations between Iran and the Peoples Republic of China. In exile she remained active supporting initiatives related to reviving Iran's cultural, literary and artistic heritage. 1/3

HOWAT--Anne Hadley. 27 September 1937 - 5 January 2016. Executive volunteer in family planning through EngenderHealth. She was married to her best friend Jock, who died in June, for 57 years. She was a loving mother to her daughters, Karen and Laura, both surviving, and a kind and engaging friend to many. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to EngenderHealth, New York City. Memorial plans are to be determined. 1/3

CHABON--Brenda, PhD, January 7, 2016. Clinical psychologist for 20 years at Montefiore Medical Center; esteemed teacher, beloved partner of Marco Persichetti and his daughter Katherine; loving sister of Arthur Chabon; cherished aunt of Isaac and Jacob Chabon. 1/3

KREMEN--Andrea, died on January 7, 2016 at the age of 68. Beloved wife of Arnold Kotlen. Loving mother of Jessica (Bill) and Gillian. Adoring grandmother of Alek and Jake. Dear daughter of Ruth Kremen. She had a life filled with a distinguished career in the legal field, countless trips all over the world, hours spent reading novel after novel, and an endless love of the arts. However, the true light of her life was the time spent with her two grandchildren. Services Monday, 12 noon at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

ROSENBLATT--Helen, on January 8, 2016. Beloved wife of Bob. Loving mother of Neil (Stacey) and Melissa (Mike) Katz. Adored Grandma of Ella, Jenna, and Alex. Cherished sister of Lenny (Ellen) Chess, the late Normie Chess and sister-in-law Kim Chess. Also, survived by many nieces and nephews. Services under the direction of Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels. 1/3

HELLER--Leon I.,93, January 9, 2016. Survived by sons Michael (Heli) and Stephen (Evelyn), five grandchildren, three great-grandchildren. Predeceased by his wife, Susan, of blessed memory. Former Director of Madison Medical Laboratories. Served as Ritual Director and Vice President of Park Avenue Synagogue. Loved as a man of great intellect, integrity and comedic genius. Funeral 11:00am Monday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

KAYE--Judith S. The directors and members of the New York International Arbitration Center deeply mourn the passing of our chairperson, the Hon. Judith S. Kaye, former Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals. We were privileged to have her take on the leadership of the Center. She brought it from a concept to a reality and led it with her inimitable warmth, grace, and humor. Her legacy will honor her memory. Board of Directors and Alexandra Dosman, Executive Director, New York International Arbitration Center 1/3

CARPENTER--David Chandler, 74, died January 9, 2016 surrounded by his loving family. He leaves his wife of 24 years, Elizabeth, son Stefan, daughter Leslie Kolczak (Franck), stepson Adam Gould (Natalie), and adored grandchildren, Luc and Sasha. David graduated from Middlebury College and Rutgers University, and was very happily retired after a successful career in international and private banking. He enjoyed life to the fullest until the very end. David's passions included family, friends, world travel, gourmet cooking and good wine. 1/3

SHAPIRO--Lorraine. 1927-2016. A master teacher who inspired generations of children to live their dreams. Beloved wife of 65 years to Herb in a marriage for the ages. Adored mother of Michael, James, and Jill. Cherished grandmother of Eliza, Jay and Luke. Loving mother-in-law to Susan and Mary. She taught first grade until she was 78 and continued to volunteer in retirement, teaching children in oncology wards. An artist of quiltmaking and baking. Her imprint is indelible, a tribute to optimism, irrepressibility and zest. 1/3

PAHLAVI--Her Imperial Highness Princess Ashraf, twin sister of His Late Imperial Majesty, Shah of Iran, died peacefully in her home in Europe January 7 at age 96. Survived by her son Prince Chahram Pahlavi, five grandsons and great-grandchildren. Her Imperial Highness was President of the Women's Organization of Iran, Honorary Vice Chair of Iran's National Committee for World Literacy Program, Vice President of the Imperial Organization for Social Welfare, Head of the Iranian Delegation to the United Nations, Chair of the First United Nations Conference on Human Rights in Tehran in 1968, Chair of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, Honorary President of the Foundation for Iranian Studies, Pioneer in women's rights and was the first woman to appear unveiled in public. As emissary for her brother, she developed tied to many nations of interest to Iran. A skilled diplomat who successfully established full diplomatic relations between Iran and the Peoples Republic of China. In exile she remained active supporting initiatives related to reviving Iran's cultural, literary and artistic heritage. 1/3

DOPPELT--Eleanor. On January 9, our beautiful, beloved mother passed. Ellie was predeceased by her adoring husband, Stanley. Cherished mother of Earl (Diane), Stuart (Roni) Jonathan (Carolyn) and Alison Kozek (Neil). Devoted grandmother of Brad, Kyle and Meredith Doppelt, Brian and Stephanie Doppelt, Jason, David and Jennifer Doppelt and Adam, Daniel and Brooke Kozek. Doting great-grandmother of Hunter, Miles and Leya. Loving sister of Alvin Lee. She will be missed by all. 1/3
MOORE--John McDonald. 1/11/19 -9/14/99. Cherished. 1/3

CARON--Anne T.,(Flanagan), 84, died at the Orchard Cove Retirement Community in Canton, MA on Saturday, January 9, 2016. She was the wife of the late Wilfred R. Caron. Born and raised in New York City, she was a graduate of Villa Maria Academy and St. John's University. Anne was a resident of Canton for four years after living in Little Compton, RI for 16 years. Prior to that, she resided in Scarborough, NY and Washington, DC. Mrs. Caron worked for IBM in New York, New Jersey and Washington, DC for 35 years, retiring as a manager in 1991. She enjoyed reading and was very active at Orchard Cove. Mrs. Caron was the sister of Catherine A. Sheehan of Brentwood, NY and the late John J. Flanagan. She is also survived by several nieces and nephews. Visitation will be held from the Farley Funeral Home, 358 Park St. (Rt.27), Stoughton, MA on Friday from 9-10am followed by a Funeral Mass at St. James Church, Stoughton at 10:30am. Interment will take place at the Massachusetts National Cemetery, Bourne. In lieu of flowers, donations in Anne's memory may be made to Massachusetts General Hospital Cancer Research, Development Office, 125 Nashua St., Suite 540, Boston, MA 02114. Directions and obituary at www.farley fh.com. 1/3

von ZUBEN--Frederick G.,died peacefully on January 7, 2016 at 77 years old with his devoted wife of 47 years, their two loving sons and his sister by his side. He is survived by his wife Antonia, his sons Christian and Max, his daughters-in-law Erin and Heather, his five grandchildren Michael, Aidan, Lucy, Phoebe and Grace, and his sister Jane Thompson. Fred was born in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada. He cherished his family and was a friend to many. He was an avid sportsman and was a Hall of Honor hockey player at Colgate University. Fred and Toni raised their sons in New Vernon, NJ and loved to spend time with family in Southold, NY and at Point Clark on Lake Huron in Ontario. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street in New York City on Monday, January 11 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, January 12 at 11am at St. Mary's Abbey at Delbarton School, 230 Mendham Road, Morristown, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation at: www.pdf.org. 1/3

GREASON--Mary Twomey. The entire Marymount Manhattan College community mourns the loss of Mary Twomey Greason. Mary Twomey Greason graduated magna cum laude from Marymount Manhattan College in 1986 with a Bachelor of Arts in art history and went on to a life of service for the College. Mary encouraged alumni to become involved and give back to the college, and demonstrated tremendous generosity and leadership in her work on the Board of Trustees from 1995 to 2004 and again from 2005 to 2014. She lit up every room she entered and was a friend to all. Mary's commitment to Marymount Manhattan and her dedication to the college's students, faculty, and staff will always be remembered. Services: visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY, Tuesday, January 12th from 3:00-5:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm. Funeral Mass at 11:00am on Wednesday, January 13th, at Our Lady of Peace Church, East 62nd St. between Second and Third Avenues. In lieu of flowers, the family has suggested contributions to the Mary Twomey Greason Endowed Scholarship at Marymount Manhattan College. Kerry Walk, Ph.D., President, Marymount Manhattan College Hope Knight, Chairperson of the Board of Trustees, Marymount Manhattan College 1/3

KIMMELMAN--Miriam E.,of Battery Park City, New York, widow of Richard Washburn, born September 16, 1948, died after a short illness on January 7, 2016. She is survived by her cousins: Ruth Golan, Yehuda Yuval, Meira Yablunka and Ora Zamir, all residing in Israel with their 11 children. Miriam was a founding member of the Dystonia Medical Research Foundation (DMRF) New York City Chapter, devoted to research, education and support for those affected by dystonia. Miriam met neurosurgical pioneer Irving S. Cooper MD, in November 1961 and underwent three brain surgeries between the ages 13 and 21 to alleviate her dystonic symptoms. She was a strong advocate for dystonia research, providing financial support for DMRF and donating her brain to advance understanding of this rare disorder. Mriam worked for over 40 years for New York State as a Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor, helping people with disabilities to reach their potential. Miriam and her husband were instrumental in the creation of the Liberty Community Gardens in 1987. After 9/11 she and others fought to have the gardens saved and replaced to their current location. Plans for a memorial service TBA. Donations in her memory should be made to the Dystonia Medical Research Foundation, 1 E Wacker Dr, Ste. 2810, Chicago, Illinois 60601. 1/3

SHAPIRO--Lorraine. 1927-2016. A master teacher who inspired generations of children to live their dreams. Beloved wife of 65 years to Herb in a marriage for the ages. Her imprint is indelible, a tribute to optimism, irrepressibility and zest. 1/3

HAGOPIAN--Louis Thomas. Of Vero Beach, FL and Darien, CT, died after a short illness in his Florida home on January 9, 2016 at age 90. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Joanne Kelly Hagopian; his daughter Susan Goddard and sons Thomas and Matthew; nine grandchildren; his sister Helen Geovjian; and more than 40 members of his extended family. Lou thought himself to be one of the luckiest men in the world, with a wife and family who loved him and whom he loved dearly, parents he respected and adored and a career he both enjoyed and succeeded in beyond his wildest hopes. As the son of parents who fled to the United States after their families were killed in the Armenian Genocide, he felt that he truly lived the American Dream and loved this country for it. Lou served in the US Navy during World War II and graduated from Michigan State University after the War. His career started in the auto business, but his skills in marketing and communications soon led him to a successful career in advertising with the oldest agency in the US, NW Ayer. He led NW Ayer for over 25 years, including the last ten as Chairman and CEO. During his tenure, Ayer was selected Agency of the Year and developed numerous iconic advertising campaigns with taglines such as "A Diamond is Forever" and "Be All That You Can Be." He also was Chairman of the Advertising Association of America and a founding member of the innovative Partnership for Drug-Free America. Lou was a man of style with an enormous heart, tremendous charm and a wicked wit. He loved to serenade his wife, Joanne, with "Misty" or "My Funny Valentine" whenever given the slightest excuse (and often without). An avid and excellent golfer for over 70 years, he started as a caddy at the Pine Lake Country Club outside of Detroit and ended as a member of the Royal & Ancient Golf Club in St. Andrews (where he won the Seniors Tournament at the age of 86). Services will be held at St. Thomas More Catholic Church in Darien, CT at 10:30am on Saturday, January 16. A memorial service will also be scheduled for friends and relatives in Vero Beach in the next several weeks. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a memorial donation be made to Indian River Habitat for Humanity, www.irchabitat.org. Services are under the direction of Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. An online guest book is available at www. strunkfuneralhome.com. 1/3

HERRON--Caroline Rand, age 74, died January 5. She lived in Truro, MA, and New York City, and graduated from Radcliffe College in 1962. Ms. Herron was staff editor of The New York Times Book Review (1993-2005), following editorial and writing positions with the newspaper, including at the Week In Review and the Washington bureau, beginning in 1973. She served in various editorial positions at The Partisan Review (1963-1978). As President of the Highland Affordable Housing in Truro, two duplex houses were built, and a donated house was moved and refurbished, providing housing for five families. Ms. Herron was preceded in death by her parents Davis Herron and Elsa Ruth (Cohen) Herron, and is survived by her brother, Rand Herron. 1/3

SCAGLIONE--Carolyn, M.D.,of Englewood, NJ died on January 10, 2016, age 88. Known professionally as Carolyn R. Denning, M.D., she was an internationally recognized pediatrician and one of the leading experts in the field of Cystic Fibrosis research and care. Carolyn Rebecca Denning was born on May 30, 1927 in Detroit, MI. She was raised in Franklin, KY and graduated from University of Kentucky in 1947. She graduated from Tulane University School of Medicine with an M.D. degree in 1952. After her internship and residency, she completed a pulmonary fellowship in 1957 at Babies Hospital, at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center where she worked with Dr. Dorothy Andersen and the group that originally described CF. She spent the remainder of her career in the Metropolitan New York City area. From 1963-1977, she served as Director of Cystic Fibrosis and Pediatric Pulmonary Disease Centers of Babies Hospital, at Columbia Presbyterian. In 1977, she founded the Cystic Fibrosis, Pediatric Pulmonary and GI Center at St. Vincent's Hospital, and served as its Director until retiring in 1995. For over 40 years she cared for hundreds of patients with CF and formed lasting bonds with their families. She trained many of the CF caregivers who are practicing throughout the world today, upholding her standards of care and compassion. She is survived by her husband of 59 years, Peter R. Scaglione, M.D., four sons and seven grandchildren. The family will receive friends at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ, on Friday, January 15 from 6-9pm and Saturday, January 16 from 12-4pm (3pm Remembrance). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Research Fund for Cystic Fibrosis, 455 Oradell Ave., Oradell, NJ 07649. A memorial service will be held at later date. 1/3
