O'BRIEN--William H. William H O'Brien, of Boynton Beach, FL and formerly of Franklin Lakes, NJ and Edwards, CO, passed away on Sunday, January 10, 2016. Mr. O'Brien was born in 1918 to the late George and Anna Marie O'Brien in White Plains, NY. He served in the US Air Corps in European Theatre during WWII, earning six Battle Stars and the Presidential Unit Citation with Oak Leaf Cluster. Mr. O'Brien is a graduate and benefactor of Notre Dame, and special programs at Oxford University and Birmingham University in England; a former President and Director of Shulton, Inc. in Clifton, NJ; former Vice Chairman of Glaxo, Inc., Research Triangle Park, NC; former Chairman of Barr Laboratories, Northvale, NJ; Board member of National Associations in the pharmaceutical and cosmetic industries; member of the Knights of Malta; former Chairman of the United Fund of Passaic County, former member of the National Advisory Board, National Hospice Organization, former member advisory committee for the St. Vincent de Paul Seminary in Florida. He served as president of several civic, religious and social organizations and was listed in Who's Who for many years. He is a member of the Delray Dunes Golf and Country Club. Mr. O'Brien was preceded in death by his wife, Delores Smith O'Brien. He is survived by daughter Maureen Joan O'Brien of Arvada, CO and son Richard William O'Brien of Arvada, CO. He was predeceased by his brothers, Gerald, George, and Robert B. O'Brien. Friends may call on Wednesday, January 13, 2016 from 6pm to 8pm at the Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, 745 NE 6th Avenue, Delray Beach. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Thursday, January 14, 2016, 10am at St. Vincent Ferrer Catholic Church, 840 George Bush Blvd., Delray Beach with celebrants, Monsignor David Toups and Monsignor Stephen Basso of St. Vincent de Paul Seminary, Rev. Gerald Grace, St. Lucy Catholic Church, Monsignor Thomas Skindeleski, St. Vincent Ferrer Catholic Church and possible celebrant Rev. William Beauchamp of Notre Dame. Burial will be in Fort Logan Military Cemetery, Denver, CO. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the O'Brien-Smith Leadership Program in the College of Business at the University of Notre Dame, Development Office, Notre Dame, IN 46556, c/o William Doyle. Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach, FL (www.Lorneandsons.com) in charge of services. 1/3

WITHAM--Col. Bertram H.,Jr. World War II Veteran, former IBM Treasurer, dies at 97. Bertram High Witham, Jr., born November 13, 1918 in Yolo County, California, died January 7, 2016 in Macon, Georgia after a short illness. Witham graduated from the business schools at UC Berkeley and the University of Pittsburg. During WWII, he served in England with the 94th Bomb Group, flying 30 missions, and received three Distinguished Flying Crosses. He was awarded the Legion of Merit prior to his retirement from the Air Force in 1961. That same year Witham joined IBM World Trade Corporation where he held the positions of Controller and Financial Vice President. He retired as IBM's Corporate Treasurer in 1978. He served on the boards of Fidelity Investments, Merrill Lynch, Schroder Bank, the Thunderbird school of Global Management and others. Witham was known for his integrity and strong Christian faith, supporting many causes. He had a generous heart and helped countless individuals throughout his life. GREASON--Mary Twomey, of Manhattan and Quogue, NY passed away peacefully on January 9th, surrounded by her loving family, after a brief and sudden illness. Mary was born January 15, 1932 in the Bronx to Timothy and Anna (nee King) Twomey. Mary was a wonderful and loving wife, mother, grandmother, and friend to all who met her. She is survived by Edward W. Greason, her husband of nearly 61 years, her sons Edward and his wife Marisa, William and his wife Margaret, and Michael, her granddaughter Elizabeth, and brother-in-law Robert, as well as many nieces, nephews and cousins. Among her many accomplishments, she was most proud of graduating from Marymount Manhattan College, where she later served as a Trustee for 19 years and received the College's President's Medal of Honor. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel" Madison Ave and 81st Street, on Tuesday, January 12, from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral mass will be held at 11am on January 13 at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62nd Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mary T. Greason Scholarship Fund at Marymount Manhattan College or to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. 1/3

GREASON--Mary Twomey. The entire Marymount Manhattan College community mourns the loss of Mary Twomey Greason. Mary Twomey Greason graduated magna cum laude from Marymount Manhattan College in 1986 with a Bachelor of Arts in art history and went on to a life of service for the College. Mary encouraged alumni to become involved and give back to the college, and demonstrated tremendous generosity and leadership in her work on the Board of Trustees from 1995 to 2004 and again from 2005 to 2014. She lit up every room she entered and was a friend to all. Mary's commitment to Marymount Manhattan and her dedication to the college's students, faculty, and staff will always be remembered. Services: visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY, Tuesday, January 12th from 3:00-5:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm. Funeral Mass at 11:00am on Wednesday, January 13th, at Our Lady of Peace Church, East 62nd St. between Second and Third Avenues. In lieu of flowers, the family has suggested contributions to the Mary Twomey Greason Endowed Scholarship at Marymount Manhattan College. Kerry Walk, Ph.D., President, Marymount Manhattan College Hope Knight, Chairperson of the Board of Trustees, Marymount Manhattan College 1/3

PRESENT-- Dr. Daniel H. A brilliant, creative, and abundantly loved giant has left us. Dr. Daniel H. Present, born April 3, 1934, passed away on January 12th from complication of Parkinson's Disease. He was 81 years old. His passing will be deeply mourned by Jane Werner Present, his wife, partner, lover and best friend of more than 59 years, his three children, their spouses, and four grandchildren, Tracy Present, Stephanie, Michael, Billy and Katherine Podalak, Douglas, Susan, Adam and Margot Present, and his sister Judy Present Liss; his friends, associates and the thousands of lives he touched during his 50 years of practice. Dan graduated from Syracuse University Magna Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa in 1955 and State University of New York Downstate College of Medicine, Magna Cum Laude, in 1959. He completed an internship, medical residency, Gastroenterology residency and GI Fellowship at Mt. Sinai Hospital, and entered private practice in 1964, where he quickly began to focus his attention on the management of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. He was the recipient of the first research award given by the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America. Dan brought clinical trials into clinical practice. His first paper was accepted for publication in 1966. He subsequently published 329 papers. At the time of his retirement, his publications had been cited more than 15,000 times. During his 54 years at Mt. Sinai, he served as President of both the Association of the Attending Staff and the Alumni Association for which he received the coveted Jacobi Medallion for Conspicuous Service to the Alumni. Dan received every award in his field including the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine Distinguished Service Award, The American Gastroenterology Association Distinguished Clinician Award, Master of the American College of Gastroenterology, The WiIIiam Dock, M.D. Master Teacher Award in Medicine State University of New York, the Janssen Award for Outstanding Achievement Award in Clinical Gastroenterology, the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America Lifetime Achievement Award and the George Arents Award for Excellence in Medicine, the highest achievement awarded by Syracuse University. He is generally recognized as having pioneered the way Crohn's disease is treated. More than any recognition, Dan loved taking care of his patients. He loved them and they returned that love many times over. His joy came from sparing his patients the pain, discomfort, and humiliation of inflammatory bowel disease by finding the right combination of medications and thoughtful creativity. He fought against surgery if there was a possible medical solution. He talked with his patients for many more hours than any HMO wouId have allowed. He sat at their bedside and visited them late at night, he celebrated when they felt better. Nothing made him happier than a college student being able to return to school, or a young adult feeling well enough to plan a wedding or bear a child. He loved teaching young Gastroenterologists and, along with a grateful patient, created the Present-Levison fourth year fellowship in Clinical GI, which allowed the brightest young men and women to spend a post-graduate year learning clinical GI at Mt. Sinai. These fellows now care for IBD patients all over the world. Funeral services will be held on Thursday at 12pm at "The Riverside," 180 West 76th St., New York. Contributions in Dan's memory may be made to the Present-Levison Fellowship at Mt. Sinai, and sent to the Division of Gastroenterology, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Box 1069, New York, New York 10029. 1/3

POSER--Joseph Edward. Born London, 30 July 1924, died New York, 24 December 2015. Former president of the American Fur Merchants Association and the International Fur Trade Federation. Survived by Mimi, his wife of 63 years, children Margaret, Nicholas (April Newbauer), Daphne (George Kalogerakis), grandchildren Rachel, Justin, Simon, brother Norman, sister Elizabeth Gribin, by relatives in the USA, England and Scandinavia, and will be missed by his many friends. 1/3

MASLOW--Marilyn Moore, 83, of Naples, FL died Saturday January 9, 2016. While living in Scarsdale, NY and completing a course of professional study at Tobe Coburn School of Fashion Design, Marilyn embarked on a successful career as a children's fashion editor for Harper's Bazaar. Survivors include her husband Richard; six children, Jennifer Holtzman Maslow of Ashland, OR, Hilary Maslow of Charlotte, VT, Melanie Maslow-Kern of Dallas, Douglas Maslow of Dallas, Allison Maslow of Shavertown and Leslie Maslow of New York. She is survived by eight grandchildren: Percy, Temple and Rivers Holtzman; Eric Naud; and Olivia, Louise, Malcolm and Duncan Lumia. Also surviving are her beloved sisters-in-law, Louise Moore and Gyana Pendleton, and nine nieces and nephews. For more information and to place online condolences please visit: www.fullernaples.com 1/3

HAGOPIAN--Louis Thomas. Of Vero Beach, FL and Darien, CT, died after a short illness in his Florida home on January 9, 2016 at age 90. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Joanne Kelly Hagopian; his daughter Susan Goddard and sons Thomas and Matthew; nine grandchildren; his sister Helen Geovjian; and more than 40 members of his extended family. Lou thought himself to be one of the luckiest men in the world, with a wife and family who loved him and whom he loved dearly, parents he respected and adored and a career he both enjoyed and succeeded in beyond his wildest hopes. As the son of parents who fled to the United States after their families were killed in the Armenian Genocide, he felt that he truly lived the American Dream and loved this country for it. Lou served in the US Navy during World War II and graduated from Michigan State University after the War. His career started in the auto business, but his skills in marketing and communications soon led him to a successful career in advertising with the oldest agency in the US, NW Ayer. He led NW Ayer for over 25 years, including the last ten as Chairman and CEO. During his tenure, Ayer was selected Agency of the Year and developed numerous iconic advertising campaigns with taglines such as "A Diamond is Forever" and "Be All That You Can Be." He also was Chairman of the Advertising Association of America and a founding member of the innovative Partnership for Drug-Free America. Lou was a man of style with an enormous heart, tremendous charm and a wicked wit. He loved to serenade his wife, Joanne, with "Misty" or "My Funny Valentine" whenever given the slightest excuse (and often without). An avid and excellent golfer for over 70 years, he started as a caddy at the Pine Lake Country Club outside of Detroit and ended as a member of the Royal & Ancient Golf Club in St. Andrews (where he won the Seniors Tournament at the age of 86). Services will be held at St. Thomas More Catholic Church in Darien, CT at 10:30am on Saturday, January 16. A memorial service will also be scheduled for friends and relatives in Vero Beach in the next several weeks. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a memorial donation be made to Indian River Habitat for Humanity, www.irchabitat.org. Services are under the direction of Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. An online guest book is available at www. strunkfuneralhome.com. 1/3

LITTELL--Rosalind "Ronnie." The family of Ronnie Littell deeply mourn her death on January 10, 2016 at age 91. Beloved wife of David; mother of Bruce (and Heather) and Scott (and Sherri); grandmother of Nicole (and Tom), Danielle, Brent, Griffin, Marissa and Erika; great-grand- mother to Emma and Jack. A prolific song writer and lover of music, Ronnie was a frequent guest on the Joe Franklin Show. PRESENT--Daniel H.,M.D. The faculty and staff of the Dr. Henry D. Janowitz Division of Gastroenterology and the Department of Medicine at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai mourn the passing of Daniel Present, M.D. Beloved by his patients and revered by his trainees and colleagues, Dr. Present leaves behind a fifty-year legacy of research and treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. His innovations in the care of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis immeasurably improved the lives of thousands of patients. Our deepest condolences go to his family: wife Jane, children Douglas, Stephanie and Tracy, and his grandchildren. 1/3

DIAMOND--Michael H. The partners of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy LLP mourn the passing of dear friend and former partner, Michael H. Diamond. A highly regarded lawyer who made a tremendous impact on the litigation field in Los Angeles and beyond, Mike joined Milbank in 2000 as partner and head of the Litigation Group in the Firm's Los Angeles office. Prior to joining Milbank, he spent 23 years at Skadden, Arps, where he opened and expanded the firm's Los Angeles office. After retiring from Milbank in 2007, Mike founded a successful consulting and expert witness firm, MHD Group. During his career, he advised numerous corporations and their officers, directors and shareholders, on complex and high-profile disputes. Mike was also dedicated to pro bono work, applying his legal skills to a wide range of matters. These included the merger of Brandeis-Bardin Institute with the University of Judaism, which formed the American Jewish University, and his successful defense of journalists in a case related to the 2000 Democratic National Convention, which earned him recognition from the ACLU Foundation of Southern California. He held degrees from Brown University and Columbia University Law School. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mike's wife, Marilyn, his four children Seth, Cory, Beth and Debra and ten grandchildren, and to his entire family. 1/3

SMYLIE--The Reverend Robert F.,87 and a resident of Seabrook Village in Tinton Falls, NJ, passed away on Saturday, December 19, 2015. He was born in Memphis, Tennessee; grew up in St. Louis, Missouri; and spent most of his adult life living in Englewood, NJ and working in New York City. A graduate of Washington University, Robert was an ordained Presbyterian minister with a Masters in Divinity and Theology from Princeton Theological Seminary and a Masters in Philosophy from Columbia. A lifelong student of international affairs, world traveler, and advocate for peace and human rights, he had spent 27 years with the Presbyterian Church USA's Peacemaking Program in several capacities before retiring as the Director of its United Nations Office in 2002. He had also served as a US Navy chaplain, taught at the University of Florida as an Assistant Professor in Social Sciences, and had been a Visiting Fellow at New College, University of Edinburgh in Scotland. Robert was a widower; his wife, Yuri Yamamoto, was a concert pianist and teacher. He is survived by his sons, Mark and John. A memorial service is scheduled for 11am, Saturday, January 16, at First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Memorial Scholarship established by the family of his grandniece, Rachel G. Smylie, at the charity Geography of Hope. 1/3

BARNET--Sylvan, born in Brooklyn, New York, on December 11, 1926, died at home in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on January 9, 2016. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II, then graduated from New York University (1948), Phi Beta Kappa, and entered the graduate program at Harvard (Ph.D. in English Language and Literature, 1954), where he wrote a prize-winning essay on Shakespeare. He spent his entire teaching career at Tufts University (1954-84), serving twice as chair of the Department of English. He published a number of essays in scholarly journals, a popular introduction to Shakespeare, and he served as General Editor of The Signet Classic Shakespeare, a paperback series (one play per volume) that is widely used in colleges and universities. He was also the author or co-author of several widely used textbooks-on argument (with Hugo Bedau, late of the Tufts Department of Philosophy), art, composition, drama, and literature, including "A Short Guide to Writing about Art" (now in its 11th edition), and "Introduction to Literature" (16th edition). In 1963, he and William Burto (his partner since 1952, deceased 2013) developed an interest in Japanese art, especially calligraphy, and they went on to build a collection that was exhibited in the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Freer Gallery, the Harvard Art Museum, and the Museum of Fine Art, Houston. The Metropolitan exhibition was accompanied by a catalog by Miyeko Murase, "The Written Image" (2002), to which Barnet and Burto contributed two essays, one on collecting, the other on looking at calligraphy from a Western point of view. (After Burto's death their collection was divided among the first four of these museums.) He and Burto also wrote "Zen Ink Paintings" (1982) as well as several essays on Japanese art. As a teacher of English literature, he was familiar with a good deal of writing about death. Among the favorite passages he carried in his head-he could not understand why some educators disparage "rote memory"-were Shakespeare's "Golden lads and girls all must/As chimney sweepers come to dust." and this epitaph by Sir Henry Wotton (1568-1639), "Upon the Death of Sir Albert Morton's Wife": "He first deceased; she for a little tried/To live without him, liked it not, and died." (Barnet said, shortly after the death of his partner, that Wotton's lines came to his mind every day, and that he regretted, every day, his inability to re-enact them.) He leaves his sister-in-law Saretta Barnet, a niece and three nephews and their spouses, nine grandnephews and nieces, a great-grandnephew and niece, and his longtime friend, Morton Berman. Most of his estate was bequeathed to a scholarship fund at Tufts, in honor of his parents, Philip and Esther Barnet. By his wish there will be no services. 1/3

DOPPELT--Ellie. The members of Brae Burn Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member Ellie Doppelt. Our sympathy is extended to her entire family. Paul Friedman, President Douglas Simon, Secretary 1/3

SCAGLIONE--Carolyn, M.D.,of Englewood, NJ died on January 10, 2016, age 88. Known professionally as Carolyn R. Denning, M.D., she was an internationally recognized pediatrician and one of the leading experts in the field of Cystic Fibrosis research and care. Carolyn Rebecca Denning was born on May 30, 1927 in Detroit, MI. She was raised in Franklin, KY and graduated from University of Kentucky in 1947. She graduated from Tulane University School of Medicine with an M.D. degree in 1952. After her internship and residency, she completed a pulmonary fellowship in 1957 at Babies Hospital, at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center where she worked with Dr. Dorothy Andersen and the group that originally described CF. She spent the remainder of her career in the Metropolitan New York City area. From 1963-1977, she served as Director of Cystic Fibrosis and Pediatric Pulmonary Disease Centers of Babies Hospital, at Columbia Presbyterian. In 1977, she founded the Cystic Fibrosis, Pediatric Pulmonary and GI Center at St. Vincent's Hospital, and served as its Director until retiring in 1995. For over 40 years she cared for hundreds of patients with CF and formed lasting bonds with their families. She trained many of the CF caregivers who are practicing throughout the world today, upholding her standards of care and compassion. She is survived by her husband of 59 years, Peter R. Scaglione, M.D., four sons and seven grandchildren. The family will receive friends at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ, on Friday, January 15 from 6-9pm and Saturday, January 16 from 12-4pm (3pm Remembrance). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Research Fund for Cystic Fibrosis, 455 Oradell Ave., Oradell, NJ 07649. A memorial service will be held at later date. 1/3

GREASON--Mary Twomey, of Manhattan and Quogue, NY passed away peacefully on January 9th, surrounded by her loving family, after a brief and sudden illness. Mary was born January 15, 1932 in the Bronx to Timothy and Anna (nee King) Twomey. Mary was a wonderful and loving wife, mother, grandmother, and friend to all who met her. She is survived by Edward W. Greason, her husband of nearly 61 years, her sons Edward and his wife Marisa, William and his wife Margaret, and Michael, her granddaughter Elizabeth, and brother-in-law Robert, as well as many nieces, nephews and cousins. Among her many accomplishments, she was most proud of graduating from Marymount Manhattan College, where she later served as a Trustee for 19 years and received the College's President's Medal of Honor. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel" Madison Ave and 81st Street, on Tuesday, January 12, from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral mass will be held at 11am on January 13 at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62nd Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mary T. Greason Scholarship Fund at Marymount Manhattan College or to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. 1/3

NEWMAN--Frances Rudolph. Beloved wife of the late George Newman passed away on January 10, 2016. She is survived by her sons Laurence and his wife Luisa Hunnewell and Jerrold and his late wife Nadine Fribourg; sister Joyce Weiskopf; grandchildren Mark, Rosemary, Daniel, Jason and Scott. He was our ally, comforter, advisor and also gave us his most superb and caring medical expertise. Susan and Bob Schwartz and Family 1/3

VOLKMAR--Isaac. The path we walked yearns your shadow. . . engulfed in your memory and wrapped in love a new day begins. And the pain becomes the truth and the truth becomes the light and the light becomes redeeming. Sweetie boy, I know your soul has always been blessed. . . for us and for many you are a blessing, an angel and pure love. We miss you and love you. Dad (pops) 1/3

STEINBERG--Ethel Bookhalter, 97, on January 12, 2016. Born in Winnipeg, Manitoba and died in New York City. An independent woman ahead of her time, she was a Captain in the Canadian Army, and then a pediatrician serving the children of the New York City area. She shared her love of reading with her family and then as a volunteer with the New York City Public Schools. Survived by Herman, her devoted husband of 65 years, daughters Susan, Judith (Howard), Leslie, and Joan, grandchildren Aaron (Jillanne), Anne, David, Paul (Naeha), Rachel (Christopher), and Nathan, and great-grandchildren Thomas and Leena. All who knew her will remember her for her vitality. Gifts may be made in her memory to the New York Public Library. Service on Thursday, January 14 at 1pm at Star of David Funeral Home, 1240 Wellwood Avenue, West Babylon, NY. For more information: jewish-funeral-home.com. 1/3

PRESENT--Daniel H.,M.D. We at the Mount Sinai Health System are saddened by the passing of Daniel H. Present, M.D., a beloved physician who, in a five-decade career at Mount Sinai, was at the forefront of research into the diagnosis and treatment of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD). Dr. Present was the first researcher to show the effectiveness of an immunosuppressant, 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP), in fighting Crohn's disease. When Dr. Present published his results in The New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM) in 1980, it changed the lives of thousands of Crohn's patients. Later, he studied the use of cyclosporine for severe steroid- refractory ulcerative colitis, and demonstrated that it could help avoid or delay colectomies in many of these seriously ill patients. In a third breakthrough in the late 1990s, Dr. Present studied cA2, also known as infliximab, an anti-tumor necrosis factor antibody, and showed, in another seminal paper in the NEJM, that it could help close fistulas in Crohn's patients. Early in his career at Mount Sinai, he was mentored by Henry D. Janowitz, M.D., for whom the Division of Gastroenterology is named. Dr. Present was also a talented clinician who cared for thousands of patients over his career. Over a decade ago, he and his wife, Jane, established an endowed fellowship at Mount Sinai to train graduates from outside institutions to become experts in the care of patients with Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Dr. and Mrs. Present also maintained a foundation for clinical research of IBD. Upon his retirement from Mount Sinai in 2014, the foundation donated its principal in support of The Susan and Leonard Feinstein Inflammatory Bowel Disease Clinical Center at Mount Sinai. We extend our deepest sympathies to Jane and their children, Douglas, Stephanie, and Tracy, at this difficult time. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and Chief Executive Officer, Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, M.D. Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System 1/3
SPOKOJNY--Dr. Artur. May 10, 1955-January 7,2014. Shabbat Bo, 1/15-16, is Artur's 2nd yartzeit. Time cannot erase our love, dear Artur. 1/3

PRESENT--Daniel H.,M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of a beloved colleague, mentor, and friend. Clinical Professor of Medicine, Dr. Present combined an active clinical practice with prolific ground-breaking research in Gastroenterology. In the tradition of Drs. Crohn, Ginsberg, and Oppenheimer, he continued Mount Sinai's pioneering work in the study of inflammatory bowel diseases. Through his investigations, an important class of medications was added in treating Colitis and Crohn's Disease. He was awarded the prestigious Jacobi Medallion in 1991 and was a great supporter of the institution. A long term AAS board member, he served as President of the physicians' organization from 1979-1980. Dr. Present will be remembered for his outstanding contributions to the School and Hospital, and his commitment to excellence. His legacy will continue in the generations of students he taught and the many lives he touched. We extend condolences to his wife Jane and his entire family. Eric Neibart, M.D., President Mark Reiner, M.D., Vice President Amy Weinstein, Administrator 1/3
BISHOP--Franklin G. (Jerry), January 14, 1996. Twenty years. Still sorely missed. Evelyn 1/3

BARNET--Sylvan, born in Brooklyn, New York, on December 11, 1926, died at home in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on January 9, 2016. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II, then graduated from New York University (1948), Phi Beta Kappa, and entered the graduate program at Harvard (Ph.D. in English Language and Literature, 1954), where he wrote a prize-winning essay on Shakespeare. He spent his entire teaching career at Tufts University (1954-84), serving twice as chair of the Department of English. He published a number of essays in scholarly journals, a popular introduction to Shakespeare, and he served as General Editor of The Signet Classic Shakespeare, a paperback series (one play per volume) that is widely used in colleges and universities. He was also the author or co-author of several widely used textbooks-on argument (with Hugo Bedau, late of the Tufts Department of Philosophy), art, composition, drama, and literature, including "A Short Guide to Writing about Art" (now in its 11th edition), and "Introduction to Literature" (16th edition). In 1963, he and William Burto (his partner since 1952, deceased 2013) developed an interest in Japanese art, especially calligraphy, and they went on to build a collection that was exhibited in the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Freer Gallery, the Harvard Art Museum, and the Museum of Fine Art, Houston. The Metropolitan exhibition was accompanied by a catalog by Miyeko Murase, "The Written Image" (2002), to which Barnet and Burto contributed two essays, one on collecting, the other on looking at calligraphy from a Western point of view. (After Burto's death their collection was divided among the first four of these museums.) He and Burto also wrote "Zen Ink Paintings" (1982) as well as several essays on Japanese art. As a teacher of English literature, he was familiar with a good deal of writing about death. Among the favorite passages he carried in his head-he could not understand why some educators disparage "rote memory"-were Shakespeare's "Golden lads and girls all must/As chimney sweepers come to dust." and this epitaph by Sir Henry Wotton (1568-1639), "Upon the Death of Sir Albert Morton's Wife": "He first deceased; she for a little tried/To live without him, liked it not, and died." (Barnet said, shortly after the death of his partner, that Wotton's lines came to his mind every day, and that he regretted, every day, his inability to re-enact them.) He leaves his sister-in-law Saretta Barnet, a niece and three nephews and their spouses, nine grandnephews and nieces, a great-grandnephew and niece, and his longtime friend, Morton Berman. Most of his estate was bequeathed to a scholarship fund at Tufts, in honor of his parents, Philip and Esther Barnet. By his wish there will be no services. 1/3

COOPERSMITH--Jack, of Boca Raton, died on January 10, 2016, at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife of 71 years, Anita Selikoff Coopersmith, his son Jeffrey (Marjie), daughters Leslie (Michael) Greenberg, Amy (Stan) Baratz, grandchildren, Lorie (John) FitzGibbon, Julie Myers, Jarred (Bernadine) Coopersmith, Aubrey (David) Lipscomb, Blake (Sara) Baratz, Justin (Rachel) Baratz, Courtney Baratz (fiancee Ryan Rosoff), great-grandchildren Bexley Baratz, Harlow Baratz, Hannah Lipscomb, Sophie Lipscomb, Lily FitzGibbon and Jane FitzGibbon. Jack thought of himself as one of the luckiest men in the world, with an adoring wife and family who loved him and whom he loved dearly; parents and in-laws who he respected and loved, and a career he enjoyed. He lived the American dream. Jack served in the US Army during World War II, landing in Normandy on D+3. After the war he was a founding partner of Tricap Realty, ultimately joining Leonard Litwin at Glenwood Management. He retired in 1992 as Senior Vice President responsible for all leasing operations. He was a founding member of Temple Avodah, Oceanside, NY. Jack was a man with style, a big heart, engaging charm and a wicked wit. He loved to dance with his wife to Frank Sinatra and big band tunes. He loved playing golf with his many friends at the Boca Woods Country Club. The family requests that memorial donations be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation at: JDRF, 3001 Metro Drive Suite 100, Bloomington, MN 55425, 952-851-0770. 1/3

SCAGLIONE--Carolyn, M.D.,of Englewood, NJ died on January 10, 2016, age 88. Known professionally as Carolyn R. Denning, M.D., she was an internationally recognized pediatrician and one of the leading experts in the field of Cystic Fibrosis research and care. Carolyn Rebecca Denning was born on May 30, 1927 in Detroit, MI. She was raised in Franklin, KY and graduated from University of Kentucky in 1947. She graduated from Tulane University School of Medicine with an M.D. degree in 1952. After her internship and residency, she completed a pulmonary fellowship in 1957 at Babies Hospital, at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center where she worked with Dr. Dorothy Andersen and the group that originally described CF. She spent the remainder of her career in the Metropolitan New York City area. From 1963-1977, she served as Director of Cystic Fibrosis and Pediatric Pulmonary Disease Centers of Babies Hospital, at Columbia Presbyterian. In 1977, she founded the Cystic Fibrosis, Pediatric Pulmonary and GI Center at St. Vincent's Hospital, and served as its Director until retiring in 1995. For over 40 years she cared for hundreds of patients with CF and formed lasting bonds with their families. She trained many of the CF caregivers who are practicing throughout the world today, upholding her standards of care and compassion. She is survived by her husband of 59 years, Peter R. Scaglione, M.D., four sons and seven grandchildren. The family will receive friends at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ, on Friday, January 15 from 6-9pm and Saturday, January 16 from 12-4pm (3pm Remembrance). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Research Fund for Cystic Fibrosis, 455 Oradell Ave., Oradell, NJ 07649. A memorial service will be held at later date. 1/3

PRESENT-- Dr. Daniel H. A brilliant, creative, and abundantly loved giant has left us. Dr. Daniel H. Present, born April 3, 1934, passed away on January 12th from complication of Parkinson's Disease. He was 81 years old. His passing will be deeply mourned by Jane Werner Present, his wife, partner, lover and best friend of more than 59 years, his three children, their spouses, and four grandchildren, Tracy Present, Stephanie, Michael, Billy and Katherine Podalak, Douglas, Susan, Adam and Margot Present, and his sister Judy Present Liss; his friends, associates and the thousands of lives he touched during his 50 years of practice. Dan graduated from Syracuse University Magna Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa in 1955 and State University of New York Downstate College of Medicine, Magna Cum Laude, in 1959. He completed an internship, medical residency, Gastroenterology residency and GI Fellowship at Mt. Sinai Hospital, and entered private practice in 1964, where he quickly began to focus his attention on the management of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. He was the recipient of the first research award given by the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America. Dan brought clinical trials into clinical practice. His first paper was accepted for publication in 1966. He subsequently published 329 papers. At the time of his retirement, his publications had been cited more than 15,000 times. During his 54 years at Mt. Sinai, he served as President of both the Association of the Attending Staff and the Alumni Association for which he received the coveted Jacobi Medallion for Conspicuous Service to the Alumni. Dan received every award in his field including the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine Distinguished Service Award, The American Gastroenterology Association Distinguished Clinician Award, Master of the American College of Gastroenterology, The WiIIiam Dock, M.D. Master Teacher Award in Medicine State University of New York, the Janssen Award for Outstanding Achievement Award in Clinical Gastroenterology, the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America Lifetime Achievement Award and the George Arents Award for Excellence in Medicine, the highest achievement awarded by Syracuse University. He is generally recognized as having pioneered the way Crohn's disease is treated. More than any recognition, Dan loved taking care of his patients. He loved them and they returned that love many times over. His joy came from sparing his patients the pain, discomfort, and humiliation of inflammatory bowel disease by finding the right combination of medications and thoughtful creativity. He fought against surgery if there was a possible medical solution. He talked with his patients for many more hours than any HMO wouId have allowed. He sat at their bedside and visited them late at night, he celebrated when they felt better. Nothing made him happier than a college student being able to return to school, or a young adult feeling well enough to plan a wedding or bear a child. He loved teaching young Gastroenterologists and, along with a grateful patient, created the Present-Levison fourth year fellowship in Clinical GI, which allowed the brightest young men and women to spend a post-graduate year learning clinical GI at Mt. Sinai. These fellows now care for IBD patients all over the world. Funeral services will be held on Thursday at 12pm at "The Riverside," 180 West 76th St., New York. Contributions in Dan's memory may be made to the Present-Levison Fellowship at Mt. Sinai, and sent to the Division of Gastroenterology, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Box 1069, New York, New York 10029. 1/3
PRESENT--Dr. Daniel H. Oh Danny Boy, you were a cherished friend to Gil, me, and the whole Cates family. 1/3

The Board of Directors and Management of Ares Commercial Real Estate Corporation 1/3

MESSMORE--Mary Anne, of Baltimore, Maryland, died peacefully with her family by her side on January 11, 2016. Mary's life was most remarkable for the effect she had on the people around her. She brought light and laughter to every room she entered. A rock of comfort and support for anyone grieving or feeling lonely, Mary loved to laugh and make others laugh, play games, cook, and spend time with friends. She loved her dogs, the mountains, music, boating, reading, and traveling. But most of all, she loved her husband, John, her son, Ike, and her daughter, Lindsey. For those fortunate enough to have met her, Mary will be remembered as one of the warmest and most thoughtful people the world has known. Generous and welcoming, she opened her home to everyone-friends and strangers alike-who needed a home-cooked meal or a safe haven. She was fiercely loyal to and supportive of those close to her and kind to everyone she met. Mary's family takes comfort in the knowledge that her legacy lives on through the immeasurable impact she had on others. While the joy and laughter that her memories evoke pale in comparison to her radiant physical presence, they ensure that she will never be forgotten. It is Mary's family's hope that all who knew her will honor her memory by striving to treat others with the grace and kindness that she did. It was the size of Mary's heart that made the world a better place. A celebration of Mary's life will be held at 5pm on Saturday, January 23, at Baltimore Country Club at Five Farms, 11500 Mays Chapel Road, Lutherville, MD 21093. All friends are welcome. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in Mary's name to Dyslexia Tutoring Program (dyslexiatutoringprogram.org). As John Irving, one of Mary's favorite authors, once wrote: "It is hard work and great art to make life not so serious." In that respect, Mary was a tireless and masterful artist. 1/3

SILVERMAN--Ruben D.,age 88, died on January 14, 2016, of complications of Parkinson's Disease. A lifelong resident of Lakewood, NJ, Mr. Silverman practiced law in Lakewood for over 55 years, representing a broad and diverse swath of the Lakewood community including Congregation Sons of Israel (the first Orthodox synagogue in Lakewood), and the operators of the Point Pleasant Beach. Mr. Silverman was a graduate from Lakewood High School in 1944, and then enlisted in the United States Navy at age 17, serving on the USS Nassau during the closing days of World War II. Upon the conclusion of his military service, he returned to New Jersey where he attended and was a graduate from Seton Hall College. He then entered the first class of Seton Hall Law School, and, after obtaining his J.D., began a law practice with his late brother, Orion Silverman. He practiced law for 55 years before retiring. He held positions on the local election, tax and zoning boards. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Phyllis, and three children: Sharon Lieberman (and her husband, Steven), Dr. Lawrence Silverman (and his wife, Jodi Moise) and Barbara Hirsch (and her husband, Dr. Mark Hirsch), as well as seven grandchildren: Rachel Lieberman, Jessica Lieberman, Benjamin Lieberman, Joshua Moise-Silverman, Samuel Moise-Silverman, Corey Hirsch and Sarah Hirsch. Funeral services will be at the Mt. Sinai Cemetery in Lakewood, NJ, on Friday, January 15, 2016, 9:00am. The family asks that donations in his memory be made to the Lakewood Historical Society or to the Overlook Foundation, Attention: Movement Disorder Fund, in memory of Ruben Silverman. Services entrusted to Torchinsky Hebrew Funeral Home, Washington, DC, 202-541-1001. 1/3
PRESENT--Daniel, M.D. A wonderful man, a loss to too many. Barbara and Bob Murray 1/3
SPOKOJNY--Dr. Artur. May 10, 1955-January 7,2014. Shabbat Bo, 1/15-16, is Artur's 2nd yartzeit. Time cannot erase our love, dear Artur. 1/3

COSTAS--Christophil Basil, of New York, NY, passed away on January 12 at the age of 75. Raised in Brooklyn, he was the adored husband of Elizabeth, a devoted father to Alex and his wife, Jaime, and doting grandfather to Jack and Josephine. Chris was the genuine article, a lover of history, literature, music, fine food and wine. His enthusiasm for life, love of family, sense of humor and kindness touched us all. His spirit will remain with us always. The family will be receiving friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Friday, January 15. The funeral will be at 9am on Saturday, January 16 at the Holy Trinity Cathedral. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Howard Stuart, on January 13, 2016 at the age of 75. Beloved husband of Leslie and the late Gail. Dear father of Jeff and Laura (Lisa). Loving stepfather of Aimee (Michael) and Charles (Kathleen). Adoring grandfather of Emma, Noah, Caitlyn, Mia, Aidan, Christopher and Elizabeth. Donations in his name may be made to The American Heart Association. Services today, 11:15, at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

BARNET--Sylvan. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Sylvan Barnet, an esteemed Benefactor and generous donor to the Museum. With his late partner William Burto, he donated the 17 important Chinese and Japanese hanging scrolls, dating from the 12th to the 17th century, featured in the Met's 2002 exhibition "The Written Image: Japanese Calligraphy and Painting from the Sylvan Barnet and William Burto Collection." These scrolls are treasured enhancements to the Museum's extensive holdings of Asian art, and will continue to provide a great benefit to scholars and the general public for generations to come. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Daniel H. Weiss, President 1/3

MEYERS--Donald. Riverdale Mental Health Association extends condolences to the family of Donald Meyers, M.D. Husband of former Director Helen Meyers, father of Board member, Andrew Meyers, Don was a devoted supporter of RMHA. 1/3

SONNENKLAR--Eric Gordon, 44 years old. Passed away suddenly on the morning of January 13, 2016. Devoted husband of Lisa. Adored father of Harris and Nicolas. Cherished son of Susan and the late Dr. Norman Sonnenklar. Beloved brother of Alan and Jill. Loving uncle of Jacob, Adam, Noah, Sam, Alessandro and Luke. He will be with us forever in our hearts. 1/3

KIGGEN--Edith Adams, a prominent music producer, died at Mt. Sinai Hospital on October 28, 2015. She died of advanced multiple sclerosis. Her career included working with such artists as Cab Calloway, Whitney Houston, Stevie Wonder and James Taylor. Mrs. Kiggen produced many events at Carnegie Hall, and the record "Swing Reunion," nominated for a Grammy in 1985. She was born in Pasadena, CA on January 19, 1936 to celebrated airline executive Alvin Adams and daughter of New York Governor Nathan Miller, Elizabeth Miller Adams. Edith Kiggen's brother, Ambassador Alvin Adams, Jr., died just two weeks earlier, on October 10, 2015. She is survived by her daughter Elizabeth Kiggen of New York City, brother Nathan Adams of Enis, MO, sister Helen Vollmer of Moraga, CA. 1/3

COCHRANE--Lydia Goodwin (Steinway). Youngest child of Ruth and Theodore Steinway, and the last of her generation. Survived by sons John and Nicholas, their wives Elizabeth Fama and Ginger Gregory, and six grandchildren. While she spent most of her adult life in Chicago and Italy, part of her remained a New Yorker. Her East Coast nephews, nieces, great-nephews and great-nieces are saddened by her death and send condolences to John, Nick and the rest of the Cochrane clan. 1/3

COCHRANE--Lydia Goodwin (Steinway). 87, died in Chicago on January 5 of cardiac arrest, surrounded by family. Lydia was born in New York to Theo-dore and Ruth Steinway (Davis), the youngest of six children. After attending Dalton, Putney, Smith, and the University of Chicago, she taught French for many years at the University of Chicago Laboratory Schools, introducing Montessori-style methods into the curriculum. Later, she translated scholarly books and articles from French and Italian with the remarkable precision and passion that she brought to every endeavor. She was married to Eric W. Cochrane, noted professor of Italian history at the University of Chicago (died 1985). They lived in Chicago and Florence, Italy. An active member of the Fortnightly of Chicago, Tuesday Ladies, and two book groups, she swam in the early morning with friends and attended season subscriptions to almost everything Chicago has to offer. She is survived by her sons John and Nicholas, their wives Elizabeth Fama and Ginger Gregory, grandchildren Sally, Eric, Caleb, Jean, Lydia, and Sam, all of whom knew her as a deep friend, and a large Steinway/Davis/Cochrane clan. She was intelligent, inquisitive, open-minded, decisive, self-reliant, elegant, and infinitely complex. A memorial service will take place in Chicago in the early spring. 1/3

SCHALLER--Ralph F.,died peacefully in his sleep on the morning of January 10, 2016, next to his adored and adoring wife, Roni Schaller, who remained by his side throughout his illness. His friends and family cannot imagine life without him. A memorial to celebrate his life will take place on Sunday, January 17, at 1:30pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. As Ralph told all who asked, "I had a great life, better than most." 1/3

SIEGEL--Peter L. It is with heavy hearts, we announce that Peter L. Siegel died January 6, 2016 due to complications from a bone marrow transplant for the treatment of Leukemia. Peter was born in New York City on March 24, 1950 and grew up in Great Neck, NY. He has a BA from the University of Mass. Amherst, and holds two masters degrees from the University of Chicago. He was a passionate sailor and resided in Brooklyn, NY. He is survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Deborah and William Cosentino, seven cousins, as well as his very dear friends Dave Turner and Christine Benner. He is and will be greatly missed. We will be holding a memorial service for Peter this spring in New York City, time and location to be announced. 1/3

O'HARA--Rebecca Browning. O'HARA--Katharine Barbara (Kate), died on December 31, 2015. Rebecca was 99, of NYC. She is survived by her daughters, The Reverend Ellen O'Hara, Terry E. O'Hara, Liza O'Hara Mercereau, Alice O'Hara, and Hedwig O'Hara; by her son, Henry P. O'Hara; by her granddaughters, Julie Rosado and Emily Bader; and her great-grandchildren, Laila Sanchez and Jelani Sanchez. Katharine O'Hara, her daughter, was 71, of Staten Island. A memorial service will be held at Redden's Funeral Home at 325 West 14th Street, NYC on Monday, January 18, 2016 from 4pm to 6pm. The family requests that in lieu of sending flowers, donations be made to Amsterdam House (www.amsterdamnursing home.org) or Community Access (communityaccess.org) or to the beneficiary of donor's choice. 1/3

KIND--Patricia. Fountain House members, Board and staff, who have been so deeply impacted by Patricia Kind's extraordinary compassion and lifelong commitment to people with mental illness, extend our sincere condolences to her family for its loss. Daughter of Hedwig and Arnold van Ameringen, Fountain House's early benefactors, Patricia carried on her family's legacy of unparalleled generosity and its tradition of making our world a better place for the most vulnerable. Though based in Philadelphia, Patricia's altruism and empathy made Fountain House a place of hope and transformation for countless people in New York City and an inspiration for model programs around the country and the world. She was instrumental in the founding of clubhouse model programs in the Philadelphia area, Hedwig House and Circle Lodge. The Fountain House community extends its condolences to Patricia's children: Laura McKenna, Christina Kind, Valerie Kind-Rubin, Ken Kind, and Andy Kindfuller; brother, Henry van Ameringen; and niece Alex Herzan. Patricia's friendship and unwavering faith in our efforts will be greatly missed. With sympathy and gratitude, Kenneth J. Dudek, President, Fountain House 1/3

PRESENT--Daniel, M.D. The volunteers and staff of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America joins the IBD community in mourning the passing of Daniel Present, M.D., founder of the Foundation for Clinical Research in Inflammatory Bowel Disease at Mount Sinai. Dr. Present was a brilliant clinician who touched and improved the lives of thousands of patients living with Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis during his 50 years of medical practice. Our sincere condolences to his family. 1/3
WURTH--Marjorie. Beloved wife to Herbert, mother to William and Laurel, sister to Carol, grandmother and aunt. Marge was a fashion writer who charmed the world with her dry, brilliant wit. Love. 1/3

BLAUFARB--Leon Solomon. Baruch atta Adonai melech haolam dayan emet. Our dad passed away January 13th with his family around him. Storyteller, attorney, bartender, reader, fisher, athlete, a master of The Times Crossword. The best parts of him continue on in the best parts of his sons. Memorial service Monday, January 18, 2016, 11am, Park Slope Jewish Center, 1320 8th Ave, Brooklyn. 1/3

RICKMAN--Alan. Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM) mourns the passing of Alan Rickman, an exceptional talent and great friend to the institution as an actor, director, advocate, and audience member. Alan was part of our artistic family, directing "Creditors" in 2010, directing and performing in "John Gabriel Borkman" in 2011, graciously serving as co-emcee at a gala for our departing president, and participating in numerous BAMcinematek and humanities programs. BAM was graced by Alan's creative passion, consummate professionalism and kindness, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Rima and family at this time. BAM President Katy Clark, BAM Executive Producer Joseph V. Melillo, BAM President Emerita Karen Brooks Hopkins, BAM board and staff 1/3

GENUNG--Diana Riggs, died peacefully on January 11, 2016, following a short and courageous battle with cancer. She was born in Elmira, NY in 1946, the daughter of Elizabeth Falck Riggs Hart and John S. Riggs. She graduated from Miss Hall's School in Pittsfield, MA and Beaver College in Glenside, PA. She is survived by her husband of 48 years, Frederick M. Genung of Naples, FL and Old Forge, NY; her son Alexander M. Genung and his wife Elizabeth (Lee) Carstensen Genung of Stowe, VT; her daughter Elizabeth (Kate) G. Taylor and her husband Prescott B. Taylor of Wellesley, MA; four grandchildren, Lucy and Chip Genung, and Ellie and Caroline Taylor; her sister Anne A. Good of Naples, FL and Old Forge, NY. A memorial service will be held at 10:30am on January 30th at the Naples Botanical Garden. In lieu of flowers, please consider a gift to the Naples Neighborhood Health Clinic or The Everglades Foundation, both in Naples, FL, or the Mission Boutique thrift store and food pantry in Old Forge, NY (Niccolls Memorial Presbyterian Church, PO Box 605, Old Forge, NY 13420). 1/3

PERRY--Susan M.,66, died on January 10, 2016 of brain cancer. Sue loved sailing, the Yankees, great music and New York City. Born in Fond du Lac, Wisconsin on July 19, 1949, Sue grew up in Wauwatosa and graduated from Wauwatosa West High School. She earned a B.S. in English and secondary education from the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee and an M.A. in English from the University of Maine. She completed coursework for a doctorate in rhetoric and composition from the University of Rhode Island. Sue worked in New York as a copy supervisor at Wishbone/ITP, as a senior copywriter at Saatchi and Saatchi Healthcare Advertising, and as a writer and medical editor for Cline Davis and Mann. She taught a variety of courses at Iona College and at The Portfolio Center in Atlanta. She began her career writing copy at WTMJ in Milwaukee. Sue treasured her nieces and nephews-Wallis and Arthur Perry; Lisa Manon and her daughter Sahsheem Davis; Jennifer Manon, Josh Bardfield and their daughters Sadie and Uma; Jesse Schmidt, Katie Barnes Schmidt and their son Grady; Darren Schmidt and Sunita Kurra; Mary Catharine, Rory and Hannah Gillick; Molly Horstman and Raphael Gang; Terry Horstman; and Patrick Perry and his daughter Ashlynn-and they adored her in return. Five of Sue's brothers and sisters survive her: John (Becky) Perry, Terry Perry (the late Terry Gillick), Katy Perry (Andy Horstman), Anne Perry (Ray Schmidt), and Joe Perry. They and Sue's many friends will deeply miss her quick, irreverent wit, her insistence on proper grammar and her uncanny ability to make everyone feel as if they were her favorite. Sue's mother Mary Sullivan Perry died in 1960, her father Wally in 1989, and her sister Barbara in 2001. Plans for a memorial celebration in Milwaukee are pending. Donations suggested to the Sojourner Family Peace Center or Midwest Athletes Against Childhood Cancer (MACC Fund), both of Milwaukee. 1/3

MANUS--Morton. President of Alfred Music, passed away at his Los Angeles home on January 9 after a battle with cancer. He was a devoted husband to his wife Iris, a loving father and grandfather, an innovative music publisher, a celebrated author, an inspiring mentor to his staff, and a dedicated friend. Morty was a great man. Born in 1926 in New York to Russian immigrants Samuel and Ann, Morty proudly enlisted in the Air Force during WWII, received a business degree from The City College of New York, and in the late 1940s, joined his father in the family business, Alfred Music. When Morty started working at Alfred Music, there were four employees: Morty's father Sam, a picker, a packer, and a bookkeeper. The important part of this story is Rose, the bookkeeper, who had a daughter named Iris. Morty and Iris fell in love, and as they say, the rest is history. They were married over 60 years. Alfred Music began in New York's Tin Pan Alley in 1922 and focused on mood music for silent films. Inspired by the need for quality music education products, Morty, a pianist, clarinetist, and guitarist, reinvented the company in the 1950s. He oversaw the development of an instructional series for accordion, followed by similar publications for guitar, piano, and recorder. Morty is the author and editor of hundreds of titles in Alfred Music's catalog, including the enormously popular series, Alfred's Basic Guitar Method and Alfred's Basic Piano Library. When Alfred Music outgrew its New York headquarters in the mid-1970s, Morty and Iris moved the company to Los Angeles. As time went by, they split their time between New York and Los Angeles, having many close friends on both coasts. The company continued to grow under Morty's leadership. Morty was joined in the business by his son Ron in 1988 and his son Steven in 1992. The family business expanded into the world's leading instructional music publisher with offices in Australia, Germany, Singapore, and the United Kingdom. In 2005, Alfred Music purchased Warner Bros. Print Publications. Morty received an honorary Doctorate of Music from VanderCook College of Music in July of 2008. Morty and Iris continued to be deeply committed to music education by supporting many music scholarships, competitions, and organizations. Morty had many hobbies including being an avid sports fan, rooting for the Lakers and Dodgers. He was also a keen investor, skilled at stock charting and analysis. Among Morty's other great accomplishments was climbing Mount Washington, New Hampshire on several occasions. He would often remark to his companions during the climb, "You will tell your grandchildren about this." Though terribly saddened by their loss, the Manus family members are now focusing on celebrating his life and the bright light of his legacy. Thanks to his amazing life's work, generations of music makers will continue to experience the joy of making music. Morty and Iris recently summed up their love for music education and Alfred Music with these words: "Working a lifetime with Music and Musicians was not always milk and honey, but it was as close to heaven on earth as we could get." Morty is survived by his wife Iris; his three sons Steven (wife Sylvie), Scott, and Ron (partner Renee); his three granddaughters Alexandra, Samantha, and Melissandra; and his brother-in-law Jay Kopelman (wife Sherry). In lieu of flowers, please donate to: vh1savethemusic.org/ donate or cancer.org. 1/3

HAGERMAN--Peter S.,76, of Mendham, New Jersey died Wednesday, January 6, after a valiant battle with cancer. Born in East Orange, New Jersey, he was the son of the late Helen and Stephen T. Hagerman. Peter was a graduate of Columbia High School in Maplewood, New Jersey. Later, as member of the Class of 1961 of The School of Business Administration at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, he received a Bachelor of Science degree in Business Administration. He later achieved a Master of Science in Business Administration from New York University. As a dedicated alumnus, Peter established an endowed scholarship fund, funded several student scholarships in the College of Business Administration and, with another classmate, created the highly successful and increasingly influential Endowment for Teaching of Ethical DecisionMaking at Lehigh. Peter was awarded the Eugene G. Grace Class of 1889 Award for distinguished service to the University's Planned Giving Program, as well as the prestigious Packard Award for outstanding service to the University. His name was recently inscribed on Lehigh's Leadership Plaza of the Alumni Memorial Building. Starting his career at E.F. Hutton & Company Inc., he later founded Hallmark Capital Management, a successful investment management firm, where he was the President for many years. Peter often remarked that his profession was also his hobby. After his retirement, Peter remained involved with Hallmark as Vice Chairman. Peter was named a Five Star Wealth Manager by New Jersey Monthly Magazine from 2012 through 2015. Peter is survived by his son, Stephen James Hagerman, of Denver, Colorado, his daughter Christine A. Hagerman, of Randolph, New Jersey and his beloved grandchildren, James and Sarah, also of Randolph, New Jersey. In addition, he is survived by his sister, Judith Gould, of Forest Hill, Maryland, his niece, Deborah Scott of Lititz, Pennsylvania and his nephew David Bergman, of Phoenix, Maryland. He will also be remembered by countless friends and business associates as a devoted professional, mentor and friend. The family held a private funeral service. In his memory, Peter requested that memorial donations be made to Lehigh University, Advancement Office, 27 Memorial Drive West, Bethlehem, Pennsylvania 18015. 1/3

de SIMONE--Lillian Imundo. Beloved mother, teacher and friend, passed away peacefully on January 6, 2016, after a long illness. She was at home, surrounded by her three daughters. Her charm, intelligence and wit enriched the lives of all who knew her. Born and raised in the Bronx, NY, she worked in the personnel department at the Revlon company's headquarters, and helped her brother Rico establish the New Dimension Theatre in Oradell, NJ. In the 1970's as a divorced mother of three, she entered Ramapo College, earned her bachelor's degree and then began her long, rewarding career in education. She taught drama, public speaking, English and literature at Emerson High School for 27 years, helping generations of students to find meaning in stories, to make sense of the world and to find their own voices. Beloved by her students, she was voted favorite teacher by more than a dozen senior classes. Over the years, she shared her love of travel and all things Italian with students she led on trips to Italy. She took joy in the rich process of education and was a lifelong learner herself. From the most recent archeological discovery to finding a new jazz standard; from cooking a favorite meal to alerting the family to a special moonrise, her curiosity and enthusiasm was a joy for all around her. She will be remembered for her laugh, her love of life and her fierce courage of the heart. Lillian was the youngest child of Filomena Volino Imundo and Rocco Imundo, and was predeceased by her siblings Ann, Louis, Rose and Rico. She is survived by her daughters Renata Simone of Marblehead, MA, Lauren de Simone and Stephanie Sanders of Ridgewood, NJ, and her granddaughters Lily and Roxanne Sanders. Private observances will be held. Condolences can be sent to lillydesimone@aol.com. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a donation in memory of Lillian to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation or the charity of your choice. 1/3
SCHOCH--Anton. April 11, 1920 - January 15, 2016. WWII Veteran. Ebullient grump. Beloved friend. karpfinger@aol.com 1/3

MESSMORE--Mary Anne, of Baltimore, Maryland, died peacefully with her family by her side on January 11, 2016. Mary's life was most remarkable for the effect she had on the people around her. She brought light and laughter to every room she entered. A rock of comfort and support for anyone grieving or feeling lonely, Mary loved to laugh and make others laugh, play games, cook, and spend time with friends. She loved her dogs, the mountains, music, boating, reading, and traveling. But most of all, she loved her husband, John, her son, Ike, and her daughter, Lindsey. For those fortunate enough to have met her, Mary will be remembered as one of the warmest and most thoughtful people the world has known. Generous and welcoming, she opened her home to everyone-friends and strangers alike-who needed a home-cooked meal or a safe haven. She was fiercely loyal to and supportive of those close to her and kind to everyone she met. Mary's family takes comfort in the knowledge that her legacy lives on through the immeasurable impact she had on others. While the joy and laughter that her memories evoke pale in comparison to her radiant physical presence, they ensure that she will never be forgotten. It is Mary's family's hope that all who knew her will honor her memory by striving to treat others with the grace and kindness that she did. It was the size of Mary's heart that made the world a better place. A celebration of Mary's life will be held at 5pm on Saturday, January 23, at Baltimore Country Club at Five Farms, 11500 Mays Chapel Road, Lutherville, MD 21093. All friends are welcome. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in Mary's name to Dyslexia Tutoring Program (dyslexiatutoringprogram.org). As John Irving, one of Mary's favorite authors, once wrote: "It is hard work and great art to make life not so serious." In that respect, Mary was a tireless and masterful artist. 1/3

LIEBER--Constance E. March 2, 1924 - January 15, 2016. Constance Lieber transformed her family's experience with significant mental illness into a life suffused with meaning, purpose, and extraordinary effectiveness. Few people could imagine the breadth and depth of her interests, ranging from the most creative modern art to inspiring architecture, exhilarating music, and insightful studies of neuroscience and human behavior. Guided by her compassion, dedication, and curiosity - as well as her personal relationships with scores of leading psychiatrists and neuroscientists - Constance informally advised thousands of parents who were desperately seeking better treatments and cures for their mentally ill children. During their sixty-five year marriage, Constance and her husband Stephen A. Lieber shared enduring love and intense intellectual insights to transform the field of basic and clinical research into the origins of schizophrenia and other mental illnesses. Since 1980, Constance and Steve have been among the leading public advocates and philanthropic supporters of schizophrenia and depression research in the US and around the globe. Their efforts included the creation of significant clinical and scientific institutions to support emerging discoveries in the fields of biological psychiatry and patient services. For over twenty-five years, they gave exemplary leadership to the Brain and Behavior Research Foundation (formerly NARSAD), the world's largest private funder of mental health research. Constance served as President from 1989 to 2007. In 2014, their activities were honored by the American Psychiatric Association with a Special Presidential Commendation, stating "Constance and Steve have provided unwavering moral and material support to unravel the mysteries of the brain, and to better understand and treat mental illness." In 1987, the Liebers established an annual award for outstanding achievements in schizophrenia research. To date, two Lieber Prize winners have gone on to win Nobel Prizes. At Columbia University, they founded two centers of excellence - the Lieber Recovery and Rehabilitation Clinic for Psychotic Disorders and the Lieber Schizophrenic Clinic. At Williams College, they were the founders of the undergraduate neuroscience program. In 2011, they created the Lieber Institute for Brain Development, affiliated with the Johns Hopkins University, to integrate new discoveries in developmental neurobiology and genetics in order to achieve clinical advances that can change lives. Constance was a graduate of Brooklyn College and attended Columbia University for her post-graduate studies. She received honorary doctorates from Williams College and Brooklyn College. She received over two dozen awards to recognize her outstanding leadership, including: the Brooke Astor Award for Outstanding Contribution to the Advancement of Science, the Women in Science Award from The Rockefeller University, the Distinguished Service Award from the Yale University's Department of Psychiatry, and the Humanitarian Award from the Society of Biological Psychiatry. Survivors include her beloved husband Stephen, her children Janice and Sam (Mary Rubin), her devoted grandson, her sister Beverly, and several nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her honor to the Brain and Behavior Research Foundation, 90 Park Avenue, 16th Floor, New York, New York 10016. A service will be held at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, on Tuesday, January 19th at 11:30am. Burial will be private. The family will receive visitors at the family home in Mamaroneck on Wednesday and Thursday from seven to nine o'clock in the evening. At a future time, a memorial service to celebrate Connie's extraordinary life will be held in Manhattan. Please contact the Brain and Behavior Research Foundation for details. 1/3

GLIZE-KANE--Avery, Of Cannes, France, died Friday, January 8, 2016. Avery was born on June 18, 1939 in Baltimore, Maryland. She moved to France after graduating from Trinity College to attend law school in Nice, and despite being a newcomer to the language, graduated at the top of her class. Avery (aka maitre Glize) served the Cote d'Azur for more than forty years as a bilingual French lawyer. She founded the Riviera Council of the U.S. Navy League and later served as Honorary Consulate of the United States in Nice. Avery counted hundreds of friends in the US Navy, from five star Admirals down to fledgling sailors, and too many friends on the Riviera to count. We will all miss her terribly. She is survived by her loving daughter, Dr. Ferney Santini and husband, Jean-Jacques Santini, two adored grandchildren, Jean-Yves and Lauren Santini and three brothers, James Gregory Kane, Michael Kane and Steven Renehan. GREENBAUM--Theodora Simon, of New York and East Hampton, died peacefully at home, December 22nd, age 88. Born in Manhattan on April 15, 1927, the daughter of Jacob M. and Mildred L. Simon, Teddy was the devoted wife for 62 years of her beloved late husband Robert. She is survived by their three children, Roger, William and Margot; five grandchildren, Olivia, Aliza, Ariela, Emma and Iris; and one great- grandchild, Lucie. She was a graduate of The Dalton School and, in 1947, of Vassar College, where she was editor-in-chief of the Vassar Miscellany News and a lifelong active alumna. Teddy's leadership in raising funds for a Class of 1947 entrance hallway to Vassar's Main Library is a testament to her dedication to Vassar and her ability to motivate classmates to make a significant gift to their alma mater. She was a member of the latter-1940s news staff of Time, Inc. Ardent in her appreciation of fine arts, Teddy pursued graduate studies in art history at NYU and photography at International Center of Photography during the 1970s. She became an art dealer and appraiser, working with individual and corporate clients in New York, New Jersey and Eastern Long Island. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club of Manhattan and an avid supporter of major arts institutions in the New York metropolitan area and the Hamptons. With her searching intelligence, wit and insight, she was an indispensable partner in the success her husband Robert enjoyed in his professional life, an inspiration to her children and grandchildren to aspire to excellence in all they do, and a beacon of grace and light in friendships that lasted decades. Her ashes will be buried at sea. Contributions in her memory may be made to Vassar College, or to Guild Hall of East Hampton, NY. 1/3

HORNER--Larry Dean. Passed away at his home in San Jose del Cabo, Mexico on December 29, 2015. He was 81. The cause was heart failure. Mr. Horner was born on April 8, 1934 in Marquette, KS to Harriet and Marion Horner. He attended the University of Kansas on baseball and football scholarships where he graduated in 1956 with a B.S. in business. He was a member of the Beta Theta Pi fraternity. He is also a graduate of the Stanford University Executive Program. During his 35 years with KPMG (Peat Marwick Mitchell & Co.), Mr. Horner rose from entry-level accountant to Chairman and CEO. He was among the first in the accounting profession to foresee the globalization of markets and the need for worldwide accounting standards, and he engineered the firm's merger with Klynveld Main Goerdeler in 1987, forming KPMG and serving as the combined company's Chairman and CEO as well as Chairman and CEO of KPMG International. Subsequent to his retirement from KPMG in 1991, Mr. Horner served as Chairman and CEO of several private and public companies involved in international finance, real estate and manufacturing. His extensive service on corporate boards included those of American General Corp., ConocoPhillips, Clinical Data, UTStarcom, Inc., Technical Olympic USA, New River Pharmaceuticals, Atlantis Plastics, Inc. and Intrexon. Mr. Horner was a great believer in civic responsibility. His charitable and civic boards included the New York Partnership, New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the Lincoln Center Institute, the Metropolitan Museum of Art Business Committee, United Way of America, United Way International, Business Higher Education Forum, The Conference Board, American Enterprise Institute, Stanford University Graduate School of Business Advisory Council and Claremont McKenna College. Mr. Horner was committed to providing international educational opportunities for college students. He and his wife Donna established scholarships for study abroad at the University of Kansas, Claremont McKenna College and Westmont College. Mr. Horner is survived by his wife Donna Dillon Manning Horner. He is also survived by his five children: Basil (Jennifer) Horner of Tucson, Arizona; Brian (Ann) Horner of Rancho Palos Verdes, California; Adeline (Olaf) Neubert of Sagaponack, New York; Hal Horner of Tucson, Arizona; and Adele (Jim) Jacques of Portland, Maine. He had eleven grandchildren who brought him great joy. A celebration of his life will be held at a future date in San Jose del Cabo, Mexico, where he and his wife have had a home since 1999 and in New York City. 1/3

KIMMELMAN--Miriam E.,of Battery Park City, New York, widow of Richard Washburn, born September 16, 1948, died after a short illness on January 7, 2016. She is survived by her cousins: Ruth Golan, Yehuda Yuval, Meira Yablunka and Ora Zamir, all residing in Israel with their 11 children. Miriam was a founding member of the Dystonia Medical Research Foundation (DMRF) New York City Chapter, devoted to research, education and support for those affected by dystonia. Miriam met neurosurgical pioneer Irving S. Cooper MD, in November 1961 and underwent three brain surgeries between the ages 13 and 21 to alleviate her dystonic symptoms. She was a strong advocate for dystonia research, providing financial support for DMRF and donating her brain to advance understanding of this rare disorder. Mriam worked for over 40 years for New York State as a Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor, helping people with disabilities to reach their potential. Miriam and her husband were instrumental in the creation of the Liberty Community Gardens in 1987. After 9/11 she and others fought to have the gardens saved and replaced to their current location. Plans for a memorial service TBA. Donations in her memory should be made to the Dystonia Medical Research Foundation, 1 E Wacker Dr, Ste. 2810, Chicago, Illinois 60601. 1/3

PRESENT--Daniel H.,M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of a beloved colleague, mentor, and friend. Clinical Professor of Medicine, Dr. Present combined an active clinical practice with prolific ground-breaking research in Gastroenterology. In the tradition of Drs. Crohn, Ginsberg, and Oppenheimer, he continued Mount Sinai's pioneering work in the study of inflammatory bowel diseases. Through his investigations, an important class of medications was added in treating Colitis and Crohn's Disease. He was awarded the prestigious Jacobi Medallion in 1991 and was a great supporter of the institution. A long term AAS board member, he served as President of the physicians' organization from 1979-1980. Dr. Present will be remembered for his outstanding contributions to the School and Hospital, and his commitment to excellence. His legacy will continue in the generations of students he taught and the many lives he touched. We extend condolences to his wife Jane and his entire family. Eric Neibart, M.D., President Mark Reiner, M.D., Vice President Amy Weinstein, Administrator 1/3

SINGH--Jyoti Shankar. Noted Internationalist and Author, Dies at 80. A former Deputy Executive Director of the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) Executive Coordinator of the 1984 International Conference on Population in Cairo, and Executive coordinator of the 2001 World Conference Against Racism in Durban, South Africa, as well as a Permanent Observer to the United Nations for Partners on Population and Development, Mr. Singh died Tuesday January 11th. A renowned expert on population issues whose career spanned more than five decades, Mr. Singh authored eight books. A consummate professional, he was a masterful planner of large scale international conferences, always distinguished by his attention to detail. Jyoti Shankar Singh was born on April 15, 1935 in Pathalgaon, India to Brijnath Kumar and Tirthmani Singh and obtained several degrees from Banaras University, India, an MA from New York University in 1979, and a Doctor (honoris causa) Degree from the International Institute Integration, Bolivia, 1980. In the early part of his career he was a Secretary General of the World Assembly of Youth, Brussels, 1966-1972 before his extensive career at the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA). He is survived by his wife and partner of 54 years, Mariluz Singh Molares; children Anil Singh- Molares of Seattle, WA; Rajeev Singh-Molares; and Ajit Singh-Molares of London, UK; and eight grandchildren whom he loved dearly. 1/3

COCHRANE--Lydia Goodwin (Steinway). 87, died in Chicago on January 5 of cardiac arrest, surrounded by family. Lydia was born in New York to Theo-dore and Ruth Steinway (Davis), the youngest of six children. After attending Dalton, Putney, Smith, and the University of Chicago, she taught French for many years at the University of Chicago Laboratory Schools, introducing Montessori-style methods into the curriculum. Later, she translated scholarly books and articles from French and Italian with the remarkable precision and passion that she brought to every endeavor. She was married to Eric W. Cochrane, noted professor of Italian history at the University of Chicago (died 1985). They lived in Chicago and Florence, Italy. An active member of the Fortnightly of Chicago, Tuesday Ladies, and two book groups, she swam in the early morning with friends and attended season subscriptions to almost everything Chicago has to offer. She is survived by her sons John and Nicholas, their wives Elizabeth Fama and Ginger Gregory, grandchildren Sally, Eric, Caleb, Jean, Lydia, and Sam, all of whom knew her as a deep friend, and a large Steinway/Davis/Cochrane clan. She was intelligent, inquisitive, open-minded, decisive, self-reliant, elegant, and infinitely complex. A memorial service will take place in Chicago in the early spring. 1/3
