PRESENT-- Dr. Daniel H. A brilliant, creative, and abundantly loved giant has left us. Dr. Daniel H. Present, born April 3, 1934, passed away on January 12th from complication of Parkinson's Disease. He was 81 years old. His passing will be deeply mourned by Jane Werner Present, his wife, partner, lover and best friend of more than 59 years, his three children, their spouses, and four grandchildren, Tracy Present, Stephanie, Michael, Billy and Katherine Podalak, Douglas, Susan, Adam and Margot Present, and his sister Judy Present Liss; his friends, associates and the thousands of lives he touched during his 50 years of practice. Dan graduated from Syracuse University Magna Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa in 1955 and State University of New York Downstate College of Medicine, Magna Cum Laude, in 1959. He completed an internship, medical residency, Gastroenterology residency and GI Fellowship at Mt. Sinai Hospital, and entered private practice in 1964, where he quickly began to focus his attention on the management of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. He was the recipient of the first research award given by the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America. Dan brought clinical trials into clinical practice. His first paper was accepted for publication in 1966. He subsequently published 329 papers. At the time of his retirement, his publications had been cited more than 15,000 times. During his 54 years at Mt. Sinai, he served as President of both the Association of the Attending Staff and the Alumni Association for which he received the coveted Jacobi Medallion for Conspicuous Service to the Alumni. Dan received every award in his field including the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine Distinguished Service Award, The American Gastroenterology Association Distinguished Clinician Award, Master of the American College of Gastroenterology, The WiIIiam Dock, M.D. Master Teacher Award in Medicine State University of New York, the Janssen Award for Outstanding Achievement Award in Clinical Gastroenterology, the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America Lifetime Achievement Award and the George Arents Award for Excellence in Medicine, the highest achievement awarded by Syracuse University. He is generally recognized as having pioneered the way Crohn's disease is treated. More than any recognition, Dan loved taking care of his patients. He loved them and they returned that love many times over. His joy came from sparing his patients the pain, discomfort, and humiliation of inflammatory bowel disease by finding the right combination of medications and thoughtful creativity. He fought against surgery if there was a possible medical solution. He talked with his patients for many more hours than any HMO wouId have allowed. He sat at their bedside and visited them late at night, he celebrated when they felt better. Nothing made him happier than a college student being able to return to school, or a young adult feeling well enough to plan a wedding or bear a child. He loved teaching young Gastroenterologists and, along with a grateful patient, created the Present-Levison fourth year fellowship in Clinical GI, which allowed the brightest young men and women to spend a post-graduate year learning clinical GI at Mt. Sinai. These fellows now care for IBD patients all over the world. Contributions in Dan's memory may be made to the Present-Levison Fellowship at Mt. Sinai, and sent to the Division of Gastroenterology, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Box 1069, New York, New York 10029. 1/3

SILVERMAN--Robert E.,professor and consummate fly fisherman, died at the age of 91 in his home in Naples, Florida on January 3, 2016. He was born in Providence, RI on March 1, 1924 to Natalie (nee Jess) and Samuel Silverman. After attending Brown University for one year (class of '46), he enlisted in the Army where he served abroad for three years during WWII. Upon returning he re-enrolled in Brown University and graduated in 1949. He received his PhD in psychology from Indiana University in 1952 and accepted a job at New York University, where he spent his entire professional career (moving from the University Heights Campus to the Washington Square Campus in 1973) until retiring in 1983. During his tenure there, he served as Assistant Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences (1959-1962) and department chair (1961-1970). He also wrote a successful introductory psychology textbook. He spent the next 35 years fishing, studying the Daily Racing Form, betting on race horses, and writing. During this period he moved from homes in Great Neck, Montauk, San Diego, CA and Marathon Key, eventually settling in Naples, Florida. He is predeceased by his wife of 63 years, Margaret Takacs Silverman. He is survived by his brother, Perry Silverman, two daughters, Pamela Silverman and Jill Silverman, and four grandchildren. At his request, his ashes are to be scattered on his favorite lake in Maine, where he fished for trout and salmon yearly for over 50 years. 1/3

HERZOG--Diana. Diana E. Herzog (nee Rigby) 76, of New York City and Southport, CT, passed away from complications after a stroke, on Wednesday, January 13, 2016 at her residence. Diana was born on June 23, 1939, in Stoke-on-Trent, England, to Elinor (Ada Allen) and Reginald Rigby. Diana attended the Courtauld Institute, in London, earning a bachelor's degree. She then studied Medieval art in Frieburg, Germany, and later at the Institute of Fine Arts at New York University where she achieved a Master's in Fine Art. Diana moved to New York City in 1963, and married John E. Herzog, whom she had met on a trip to Mexico two years before. Diana and John lived in Manhattan, where Diana taught English as a second language at the New School, telling her devoted students that the pilgrims celebrated the first Thanksgiving in Philadelphia! Diana and John moved to Brooklyn Heights in 1972, where they were active in the Heights Casino and Plymouth Church. They summered in Clinton Corners, NY, where visitors could admire large vegetable beds and beehives, and later in Madison, CT, in the beautifully restored "Red Top," with its view of the Long Island Sound. Diana started her career in collectible financial documents at R.M. Smythe & Co., first researching obsolete and inactive securities and then branching out into the field of autographs as the firm expanded into a leading auction house. Diana was a formidable business woman, securing important consignments and putting collectors together with the items they sought. Diana personally assembled autographs of British royalty, writers and poets, acquiring the nickname "Lady Di." Diana was active in the Junior League of Brooklyn, Resources for Children with Special Needs, and many industry organizations including as president of the Manuscript Society, and PADA. Diana enjoyed membership in the Cosmopolitan Club and the Grolier Club. Diana edited the magazine "Friends of Financial History" for many years, now published by the Museum of American Finance, which she and John nurtured for over 25 years. As world travelers, Diana and John explored together, spending time in Europe and Asia, bringing home artifacts and anecdotes as well as cherished contacts. Diana accompanied John on many securities industry trips, supporting John at Herzog, Heine, Geduld. Diana's love of art and opera, her linguistic talents, and her culinary skills were well known by her friends and family. Her tennis game was graceful, and she loved reading, especially British mysteries. Diana cherished her roots in England, visiting often to maintain close relationships with family and friends "across the pond." Diana will be missed by all who knew her, and especially by her family, who are deeply saddened by her passing. Diana is survived by her husband of over 50 years, John; her daughters, Mary (Andy Davidoff) and Sarah Shine (Kevin); her cousins, Michael J. Rigby, (Ann Sheridan) Pat Sharrock, and Anne Grabaskey (Peter); and her grandchildren, Keith and Sophie Shine. Diana's family is extremely grateful to Genevee Thomas, Veronica Vernon, and Joylynn Thomas for the wonderful care they took of Diana during her long illness. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church, 651 Pequot Avenue, Southport, CT 06890, on Wednesday, January 20, 2016, at 3:00pm. A reception at the church will follow. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Pequot Library, 720 Pequot Avenue, Southport, CT 06890, where Diana loved to go, and helped create two exhibits. The Shaughnessey Banks Funeral Home, 50 Reef Rd. in Fairfield Center has been entrusted with the services. To send an online condolence, visit: shaughnesseybanks.com. 1/3
NETZER--Corinne T. Celebrate her celestial birthday forever and always, Ides of January - 1/15. 1/3

MARCHAL--Jacques. Jacques Marchal, died suddenly at his home on January 3, 2016. He was the most beloved husband and best friend of his wife Marion, and the much loved father of Leslie and Philip, grandfather of Laura, Stephen, Isabella and Jacqueline, father-in-law of Larry and Sue, brother of Francoise, and uncle to many French nieces and nephews. Jacques escaped from France during World War II to join the Free French Forces, and came to the United States to complete his training as a pilot. He returned after the war to obtain his Bachelor of Science. Settling in the United States a few years later, he built a career at the Mobil Oil Company, as it was then called, where he worked for over 35 years in its international operations, ultimately specializing in the negotiation of exploration and production agreements with countries across the world. He was the kindest and most thoughtful of men, courtly, with an insatiable curiosity about world events, and a born storyteller who drew on his adventurous youth to bring to life another era for his children and grandchildren. He will be sorely missed. 1/3

MEADOW--Claire S.,77, died peacefully January 9, 2016 of pancreatic cancer. Graduate, Hunter College and Columbia Law School; practicing real estate attorney. Founding member, Westchester Women's Bar Association; passionate supporter of Israel. Survived by beloved husband Myron Meadow, children Andrea Danziger, Roxanne (David) Cohen, Aaron Meadow and four grandchildren. 1/3

SCHALLER--Ralph F. The best brother-in-law a guy could ask for. You opened your heart to me and to my entire family and you will never be forgotten. The Brodhersons were proud to have you as one of our own. 1/3

KLEIER-Jonathan. Happy 33rd Birthday Jonathan, our guardian angel. There is surely lots of champagne being opened up right now in heaven, and we can hear Jay Z and Billy Joel loud and clear, and the Palm is getting ready for your reservation. We miss and love you every second of every day, forever. You will always be the light of our lives. A huge bear hug from home. Love you, The Family 1/3

DONLEAVY--Thomas Joseph "T.J.," died peacefully in his sleep on January 6, 2016. Committed to his own inner vision he was a poet, sculptor and composer. T.J. approached life with vigor, compassion and dedication. His late niece Marita O'Hare, along with her son B. Patrick Brown, were dedicated to bringing his art to the public through exhibitions, a website and a soon to be published book: "Life as Art: The Works of T.J. Donleavy" by Nancy Malloy. Mr. Donleavy studied at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts and The Barnes Foundation. Mr. Donleavy is survived by his son David Zwanetz Jr.; grandsons Michael and David; brother, Author J.P. Donleavy, Ireland, ("Ginger Man"); nephew, Producer Phillip Donleavy; niece, Ceramic Artist Karen Donleavy; sister, Professor Emerita Mary Rita Donleavy, Lehman College, CUNY, grandnephew, B. Patrick Brown, Scarsdale, NY. 1/3

McTAGUE--Marilyn Ann. 1935-2016. The Caedmon School honors the life of former teacher and administrator, Marilyn Ann McTague. Over her 30-year career, she touched the lives of countless children of New York City. We are grateful for the many ways she helped to shape our school community. 1/3

DUNHAM--William B.,died on January 11 in New York. Although he had a long career in finance, human resources, and real estate, he is best remembered for his role in the traditional jazz scene. First drawn to jazz in boyhood, he played with the Crimson Stompers at Harvard as part of the then thriving college jazz band circuit. Eventually settling in New York, Mr. Dunham organized one of the early traditional jazz bands, the Grove Street Stompers, to play Monday nights in Greenwich Village. Mr. Dunham led the band for over fifty years. At times leading jazz musicians, such as Wild Bill Davison were featured with the group. Arthurs Tavern, where the band played, remains one of the most celebrated locations for traditional jazz world-wide, still following the format instituted by Mr. Dunham. He is survived by his beloved wife, Sonya, daughter Amy, son-in- law Richard and three grand children. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to The American Cancer Society https://donate.cancer. org/index. 1/3

BECKHARD--Madeleine (nee Klein) of O'Fallon, MO (formerly of Dover, NJ and Metz, France), beloved Wife of Ted for 53 years, devoted Mother of Alan (Laura) and Grandmother of Eric and Kathryn. Dear Sister of Chantal (Gerard), Fernand, and Michel. Information "Wien & Son" 1-800-719-7910. 1/3

PINES-- James M.,a lawyer, economist and international economic development consultant, died on January 10, 2016 in Chevy Chase, MD at the age of 89. He was the son of Samuel S. and Ruth Golden Pines. Pines grew up in Peekskill, NY, and earned a B.A. from Bard College, an M.A. from Harvard, and a law degree from Yale. Over more than three decades as a consultant on nutrition, food aid and program evaluation, Pines undertook assignments with the United States Agency for International Development, the World Bank, and non-governmental organizations in more than 60 countries. Pines' first marriage ended in divorce. Survivors include his companion of 30 years, Janet Lowenthal; his former wife, Caryl Pines Curry; two sisters, Joanne Pines Hersh and Doris Pines Markoff; a daughter, Eve Pines and a son, Roger Pines; son-in-law Richard Martinko; and grandchildren Reed and Irene Martinko. Memorial gifts may be made to JSSA Hospice, 6123 Montrose Rd., Rockville, MD 20852 and to the Robert White Human Rights Fund, Center for International Policy, 2000 M St., NW Washington, DC 20036. A Memorial Service will take place at 12pm on January 27, 2016, at the Wisconsin Place Community Center, 5311 Friendship Blvd., Chevy Chase, MD 20815. 1/3

COLEMAN--Zdzislawa Anna, 69, a resident of the Hyde Park neighborhood in Chicago and former employee of NORC, died January 1. She was born on September 24, 1946, in Pietrzykowice, Poland, the daughter of Alojzy and Otylia Walaszek. She received a Ph.D. in sociology from John Hopkins University and lectured at University of Chicago. A lover of art and poetry, she did sculpture when young. Her work as an avid gardener frequently drew praise from people passing by her home. She was a generous person who gave gifts to those around her until the end of her life. She was the beloved wife of James Coleman, whom she married in 1972. He was a professor of sociology at the University of Chicago and died in 1995. Survivors include her son, Daniel; stepsons, Thomas, John, and Stephen; brother, Andrew Walaszek; sister-in-law Camie Corbino-Walaszek; and sister, Miroslawa Walaszek. 1/3

FULLER--Lee M.,Jr., Esq., passed away at his home in New York City on the evening of January 4, 2016, after courageously battling a series of cancer related illnesses. His beloved wife and son were by his side. Born on March 14, 1938, Lee was the son of Eunice Peckinpaugh and Lee M. Fuller and grew up in Bronxville, NY. He graduated from Bronxville High School in 1956, Princeton University Woodrow Wilson School of International Affairs in 1960 and Columbia University Law School in 1965. He then worked on the Lindsay mayoral campaign before joining the law firm of Shearman & Sterling in Manhattan. In 1978, Lee started his own law firm specializing in U.S. Immigration which his son, Scott, carries on today as Fuller & Fuller LLP. He taught Immigration Law as an Adjunct Professor at Fordham University School of Law from 1981 to 2001. Commissioned into the ROTC program while at Princeton, Lee served on active duty in the Navy for two years aboard the USS ESSEX, seeing action in the Bay of Pigs. He then served for more than 30 years in the Navy Reserve, retiring as a Captain, Navy JAG Corps. From 1978 to present, he was a passionate and active member of The University Club. Lee was married to Anina Porter and they had three children. In December 2012, after 24 years of courtship, Lee married Victoria (Vicki) Sorrell. They cherished spending weekends in their home in Sag Harbor, NY. Lee is survived by his wife, Victoria Sorrell Fuller, sister, Gretchen Beers, children Scott Ruston Fuller, Lisa Gretchen Fuller, Kristina laCour Fuller, and grandchildren Nicolaas John ten Grotenhuis, Erin Campbell Fuller, Ethan Scott ten Grotenhuis, Aidan Porter Fuller, Lucy Fuller Barretto, Charlotte Anina Barretto, and Sonja Ellen ten Grotenhuis. 1/3

MAIMIN, David S.,on January 14, 2016. He attended Horace Mann School, Brown University and Columbia's Graduate School of Business, before serving as an army officer during the Korean War. He had a long and rewarding career with H. Maimin & Co., manufacturers of electric cutting machines. He leaves his beloved wife and best friend, Sybil, sons Daniel (Mark) and Michael (Rachel) and twin grandsons, William and Charles, born during the last year of his life. Funeral services at Plaza Funeral Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, January 17, 11am. Donations may be made in his memory to The City Congregation for Humanistic Judaism or Central Park Conservancy. 1/3

WALDEN--Marvin Eugene, 80, of Elk Grove, CA passed away on January 9, 2016. He was born in Parsons, KS on May 7, 1935 to Mamie Lavon Walden. Marvin was raised by his aunt Mary Anne Clark and uncle Wayne Thomas Clark in Clawson, MI. He graduated from Clawson High School, and received BS, MS, and PhD degrees in Mathematics from Wayne State University. Marvin met the love of his life, beloved Olga Lucille Walden, in the Math Club at Wayne State. Marvin is survived by his children Katherine, Gerald, and Eugene, and grandchildren Anna, Charlotte, and Julia. 1/3
SPOKOJNY--Dr. Artur. May 10, 1955-January 7,2014. Shabbat Bo, 1/15-16, is Artur's 2nd yartzeit. Time cannot erase our love, dear Artur. 1/3

HERZOG--Diana E. The Board of Directors and Staff of INCLUDEnyc (formerly Resources for Children with Special Needs) mourn our former board chair, board member, and long- time supporter. Diana's commitment, warmth, passion, and friendship will be deeply missed. 1/3

LIEBER--Constance. The faculty and staff of the Lieber Institute for Brain Development and the Maltz Research Laboratories at the Johns Hopkins Medical Campus mourn the loss of their inspirational and beloved Founder and Director, Constance Lieber. For more than 30 years, she led an international movement to bring research about behavioral brain disorders to the forefront of biomedical science. Connie Lieber's vision, her determination, and her historic generosity launched thousands of scientific careers. In 2010, she established the Lieber Institute for Brain Development because she was convinced that a new strategy was needed to accelerate progress and to find cures for developmental brain disorders. As she said: "This is our dream, to find out what causes these disorders, and we felt it had to be a concerted effort, to study the brain and how it develops, and this is what the Institute is all about." The world of behavioral and developmental neuroscience has lost one of its strongest advocates and supporters. Connie is always in our hearts and minds. In honor of her passion and commitment, we will work tirelessly to achieve the mission she empowered us to pursue. 1/3

BERNARD--Herbert C.,Congregation Emanu-EI of the City of New York records with an admixture of sorrow and gratitude the passing of Herbert C. Bernard in his 104th year: sorrow that his unique presence is no longer ours to experience, and gratitude for the extraordinary length of his years. His devotion to our Congregation was made manifest in many ways over multiple decades. His active presence on our Board of Trustees for more than fifty years was almost without precedent, and his service as Secretary to the Congregation was the longest in the Temple's history. Mr. Bernard's generosity of spirit was treasured while he lived and never to be forgotten will be his gift and that of his late beloved wife in making possible the creation of the Herbert and Eileen Bernard Museum of Judaica at Temple Emanu-EI. To his cherished children, Migs and Lewis, and their families, we extend our heartfelt understanding. May his memory forever be a blessing. The Family of Temple Emanu-EI 1/3

ADES--Alan Maxwell, died on January 17, 2016. He was 90 years old. He leaves his loving wife, of 57 years, Joan, two daughters, Jane Ades and Susan Ades and her husband, Stephen Lawlor and five grandchildren, Benjamin, Raphi, Kirya, Olivia and Isabelle. He graduated Townsend Harris High School in three years and joined the army at 17 where he became part of the Corps of Engineers. He rose to the position of staff sergeant soon afterwards. After the war, he attended and graduated from CCNY. He founded and was president of Auburn Label and Tag, Co. He loved classical music from the time he was a teenager, when he first worked concessions at Carnegie Hall and extended and embraced that passion by serving on the Board of Directors of The Metropolitan Opera. Additionally, he served on the Board of Trustees of The Manhattan School of Music and of Central Synagogue in New York, where he was also confirmed. While at MSM, he and Joan founded the Ades Vocal Competition and built The Joan Taub Ades and Alan M. Ades Performance Space, as well. He was an avid sailor and skier. Services will take place at 11:00am on Tuesday, January 19, 2016 at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Ave., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to The Metropolitan Opera or The Manhattan School of Music. 1/3

LIEBER--Constance E. March 2, 1924 - January 15, 2016. Constance Lieber transformed her family's experience with significant mental illness into a life suffused with meaning, purpose, and extraordinary effectiveness. Few people could imagine the breadth and depth of her interests, ranging from the most creative modern art to inspiring architecture, exhilarating music, and insightful studies of neuroscience and human behavior. Guided by her compassion, dedication, and curiosity - as well as her personal relationships with scores of leading psychiatrists and neuroscientists - Constance informally advised thousands of parents who were desperately seeking better treatments and cures for their mentally ill children. During their sixty-five year marriage, Constance and her husband Stephen A. Lieber shared enduring love and intense intellectual insights to transform the field of basic and clinical research into the origins of schizophrenia and other mental illnesses. Since 1980, Constance and Steve have been among the leading public advocates and philanthropic supporters of schizophrenia and depression research in the US and around the globe. Their efforts included the creation of significant clinical and scientific institutions to support emerging discoveries in the fields of biological psychiatry and patient services. For over twenty-five years, they gave exemplary leadership to the Brain and Behavior Research Foundation (formerly NARSAD), the world's largest private funder of mental health research. Constance served as President from 1989 to 2007. In 2014, their activities were honored by the American Psychiatric Association with a Special Presidential Commendation, stating "Constance and Steve have provided unwavering moral and material support to unravel the mysteries of the brain, and to better understand and treat mental illness." In 1987, the Liebers established an annual award for outstanding achievements in schizophrenia research. To date, two Lieber Prize winners have gone on to win Nobel Prizes. At Columbia University, they founded two centers of excellence - the Lieber Recovery and Rehabilitation Clinic for Psychotic Disorders and the Lieber Schizophrenic Clinic. At Williams College, they were the founders of the undergraduate neuroscience program. In 2011, they created the Lieber Institute for Brain Development, affiliated with the Johns Hopkins University, to integrate new discoveries in developmental neurobiology and genetics in order to achieve clinical advances that can change lives. Constance was a graduate of Brooklyn College and attended Columbia University for her post-graduate studies. She received honorary doctorates from Williams College and Brooklyn College. She received over two dozen awards to recognize her outstanding leadership, including: the Brooke Astor Award for Outstanding Contribution to the Advancement of Science, the Women in Science Award from The Rockefeller University, the Distinguished Service Award from the Yale University's Department of Psychiatry, and the Humanitarian Award from the Society of Biological Psychiatry. Survivors include her beloved husband Stephen, her children Janice and Sam (Mary Rubin), her devoted grandson, her sister Beverly, and several nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her honor to the Brain and Behavior Research Foundation, 90 Park Avenue, 16th Floor, New York, New York 10016. A service will be held at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, on Tuesday, January 19th at 11:30am. Burial will be private. The family will receive visitors at the family home in Mamaroneck on Wednesday and Thursday from seven to nine o'clock in the evening. At a future time, a memorial service to celebrate Connie's extraordinary life will be held in Manhattan. Please contact the Brain and Behavior Research Foundation for details. 1/3

LIEBER--Constance E. The Brain & Behavior Research Foundation, formerly the National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression (NARSAD), deeply mourns the passing of its visionary leader and President Emeritus, Constance E. Lieber. Connie, who served as President of the Foundation from 1989 to 2007, felt that research was the best avenue to find meaningful and lasting solutions to alleviate the suffering caused by mental illness. In her role as President Emeritus, she continued to offer her vision and guidance to the Foundation on a regular basis. Connie, along with her husband Stephen, passionately believed in the need to seed the field of neuropsychiatric research with as many talented scientists as possible to make a substantive impact on the broad spectrum of mental health research, which she fervently understood holds our best hope for ending the immense suffering caused by mental illness. Since 1980, Connie and Steve have served as extraordinary philanthropic supporters and leading public advocates of schizophrenia and depression research. Connie worked tirelessly for the cause and grew our grants program to a total of $342 million and was helpful to so many families who were desperately seeking help for their children. We recognize that she enhanced the lives of so many through her work for Brain & Behavior Research Foundation and by supporting scientists throughout the world and have the deepest gratitude to both Connie and Steve. Their generosity in supporting research on mental illness is a great model for all of us. Our deepest sympathies to Connie's beloved husband Steve, their daughter Janice, their son Sam and daughter-in-law Mary, their grandson, and to all of their loved ones. Connie was our leader and guiding light, providing inspiration and motivation to all who ever had the honor and privilege of knowing and working with her. Jeffrey Borenstein, M.D., President & CEO, The Brain & Behavior Research Foundation Herbert A. Pardes, M.D., President of the Foundation's Scientific Council 1/3

BERNARD--Herbert C. Our father Herbert C. Bernard passed away at home on January 16, 2016. He was 103 years old. He loved New York City. As the owner of a manufacturing business, he had clients throughout the City and watched neighborhoods change. He remembered horse drawn carriages filled the street and veterans of the Civil War parading in their uniforms on Memorial Day. His father survived the 1918 influenza and his uncle was gassed in World War I. Dad received an excellent public school education and graduated with highest honors from his high school while working for the Brooklyn Eagle covering sports. He entered Columbia in 1928 but to his great regret, had to leave to contribute to the support of his family. He made up for this perceived shortcoming by visiting libraries and museums. He became a connoisseur of drawings and paintings with a small collection. His deep commitment to the City was expressed in community service. Our father was the longest serving trustee of Congregation Emanu-El; he chaired many of its committees and he and our mother endowed its museum of Judaica. They were both actively involved in a number of charitable organizations. For Dad it included Montefiore Medical Center and UJA-Federation. He also was particularly proud of his service to his industry. For many years he was a board member of the Paperboard Packaging Council and served a term as its non-executive President. In addition to us he is survived by grandchildren, Geoffrey Dann, Deborah Fields, Adam Bernard and Claire Bernard, and great-grandchildren, Rebecca Dann, Emily Dann, and Lion Bernard De Rham. There will be a private family funeral service. Contributions in his honor may be made to the Herbert and Eileen Bernard Museum Judaica Fund at Congregation Emanu-El. Migs Woodside and Lewis Bernard 1/3

KRESS--Alan Howard, an entertainment attorney who represented legendary musicians and performers, died on January 17th in New York City. He was 69. Mr. Kress was Vice President of Legal and Business Affairs for RCA Records, BMG International, BMG Classics and Warner Home Video. Subsequently, he founded an independent law firm representing artists, songwriters, music publishers, and producers. He served as a longtime member of the American Bar Association's Entertainment Law and Copyright Law Committees, and as a member of the Copyright Society of the United States. His work as editor of the discipline's main treatise, "Entertainment Industry Contracts," served as the foundation for a generation of entertainment lawyers. He is survived by his beloved wife of 40 years Marilyn, his daughter Marielle, his sister June, and his son-in-law Eric Goldstein. In lieu of flowers, donations are welcome to the Race for Hope, Washington, D.C. 1/3

ISSELBACHER--Marga (nee Schiff). Born in Oberthulba, Germany June 6, 1927, passed away on January 17, 2016 surrounded by family in New York City. Doting mother and grandmother of Jesse, Tina, Kassidy, Samantha and Haley. She loved her family, Bob and Marjory Schiff, Carmen and Audrey Isselbacher, Gail Berney, Jonathan and Amie Schiff. She sorely missed the love of her life, Henry. Graveside service on Tuesday, January 19; Shiva at her home. 1/3

FELDMAN--Elaine Kram. Born December 24, 1928 in Manhattan, died suddenly in her home in Mill Neck, NY January 15, 2016. Raised in Manhattan, attended Ethical Culture Fieldston School, graduated from Adelphi University. Worked for WNEW, Harper's Bazaar, eventually working in real estate sales. A beloved mother, wife, lover of animals, she's survived by her devoted husband of 60 years Dr. Gilbert Jay Feldman; daughter Melissa Feldman, of Manhattan; son John Harris Feldman and daughter-in-law Terri Behrens Feldman; grandchildren Tiarr Behrens Dahlen and Merrik Dahlen, all of St. Paul, Minnesota. The family asks donations be made to Cove Animal Rescue, Glen Cove, NY. 1/3

BERNARD--Herbert C. Our father Herbert C. Bernard passed away at home on January 16, 2016. He was 103 years old. He loved New York City. As the owner of a manufacturing business, he had clients throughout the City and watched neighborhoods change. He remembered horse drawn carriages filled the street and veterans of the Civil War parading in their uniforms on Memorial Day. His father survived the 1918 influenza and his uncle was gassed in World War I. Dad received an excellent public school education and graduated with highest honors from his high school while working for the Brooklyn Eagle covering sports. He entered Columbia in 1928 but to his great regret, had to leave to contribute to the support of his family. He made up for this perceived shortcoming by visiting libraries and museums. He became a connoisseur of drawings and paintings with a small collection. His deep commitment to the City was expressed in community service. Our father was the longest serving trustee of Congregation Emanu-El; he chaired many of its committees and he and our mother endowed its museum of Judaica. They were both actively involved in a number of charitable organizations. For Dad it included Montefiore Medical Center and UJA-Federation. He also was particularly proud of his service to his industry. For many years he was a board member of the Paperboard Packaging Council and served a term as its non-executive President. In addition to us he is survived by grandchildren, Geoffrey Dann, Deborah Fields, Adam Bernard and Claire Bernard, and great-grandchildren, Rebecca Dann, Emily Dann, and Lion Bernard De Rham. There will be a private family funeral service. Contributions in his honor may be made to the Herbert and Eileen Bernard Museum Judaica Fund at Congregation Emanu-El. Migs Woodside and Lewis Bernard 1/3

LEVINE--Lillian, 92, of Enfield, CT, on January 17, 2016. Wife of the late Irving, daughter of the late Julius and Minnie Sugarman, mother of Scott, Rabbi Robert, and Sheree, mother-in-law of Alice Geller and Gina (Stahl) Levine, grandmother of Kate, Sarah, William, Judah, Ezra, David and Maya, sister of the late Sidney, Esther, Frieda and Samuel. Favorite aunt and friend of many. Devoted fifth grade teacher for many years in Ludlow, MA, affectionately known as "Lillian Levine the Homework Queen." Much loved and loving. Wise counsel to us all. Courageous in life and in death. Will be incredibly missed. 1/3

GARIBALDI--Justice Marie L.,of Weehawken, NJ, passed on January 15, 2016. Justice Garibaldi was born November 26, 1934, in Jersey City to Dr. Louis and Marie S. Garibaldi. As an only child, she lived most of her life in Hudson County. The Garibaldis raised their daughter with a strong belief in equal opportunity for women and encouraged her to pursue a nontraditional career path. She was a pioneer and role model to so many. She is survived by loving cousins, adoring godchildren and many cherished friends and colleagues. As a child, Justice Garibaldi attended Stevens Hoboken Academy through 12th grade. She graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree with honors in economics and a political science minor from Connecticut College (New London, CT) in 1956. With an intent to follow in her grandfather's footsteps and attend business school, Justice Garibaldi learned first-hand women weren't accepted. Instead, she enrolled in Columbia Law School as a pathway into the business world and graduated in 1959. In 1963, Justice Garibaldi earned her Master of Laws degree in tax law from New York University School of Law. She was a member of the New Jersey, New York, and District of Columbia Bars and the first woman to serve as president of the New Jersey State Bar Association. Justice Garibaldi began her legal career with the New York Regional Counsel in the Internal Revenue Service. She received extensive trial experience in Tax Court. The Hatch Act restricted government employees from political speech-making and article-writing which ultimately caused Justice Garibaldi to make her next career move. She briefly worked at a firm now known as Riker, Danzig, Scherer, Hyland & Perretti (Riker, Danzig)-within three years she was made a partner which was virtually unheard of at that time. While at Riker, Danzig, Justice Garibaldi also served as a municipal court judge in Weehawken, NJ, from 1973 to 1975, writing the majority of opinion in several cases affecting women. Justice Garibaldi was introduced to Republican Thomas H. Kean by a Riker, Danzig partner. This ultimately led Justice Garibaldi to serve as co-chair of his gubernatorial campaign. Once elected, Governor Thomas H. Kean nominated Justice Garibaldi to the New Jersey Supreme Court. In 1982, Justice Garibaldi became the first woman appointed to the New Jersey Supreme Court- she served as Associate Justice of New Jersey's highest court until she retired in 2000. She authored more than 225 opinions while on the Supreme Court and was known for her advocacy of complementary dispute resolution. She chaired the Supreme Court's committee on that subject, and in 1998, the American Inns of Court Foundation established the Justice Marie L. Garibaldi American Inn of Court for Alternative Dispute Resolution. Justice Garibaldi was the recipient of many awards, including the Medal of Excellence from the Columbia University School of Law. She received honorary degrees from St. John's University Law School, Seton Hall University Law School, Fairleigh Dickinson University, Drew University, Upsala College, St. Peter's College, Caldwell College, and the College of Saint Elizabeth. Justice Garibaldi joined the Hackensack University Medical Center in 2001 and served as vice chair of Hackensack University Medical Center's Board of Governors. She also served on the Hackensack University Health Network's Board of Trustees, as chair of the Executive Compensation Committee and on the Hackensack University Medical Center Foundation's Board of Trustees. She chaired the Hudson Riverfront Performing Arts Center and served as a member of the Board of Directors of the National Italian American Foundation. Justice Garibaldi also served as a director of Crown Holdings, Inc. from 2000 to 2007. She also served as a member of the New Jersey Council on Local Mandates. In addition, Justice Garibaldi served as the secretary of the American Association Order of Malta, USA and executive vice president of the American Society of the Italian Legions of Merit. She also served as a director of the State Chamber of Commerce, New Jersey Bell Telephone Co., and the Washington Savings Bank. She also was a trustee of St. Peter's College. Justice Garibaldi truly enjoyed traveling, reading mysteries, and dinner and dancing with friends. She will be greatly missed by friends, loved ones and colleagues. Justice Marie L. Garibaldi was predeceased by her parents-her father, Dr. Louis Garibaldi passed away in 1975 and her mother, Marie S. Garibaldi passed away in 2013 at the age of 103. The funeral will be on Thursday, January 21 at 9am from the Leber Funeral Home in Union City then to St. Augustine Church where, at 10am, a Mass will be offered. Visitation will be on Tuesday, January 19 from 7 to 9pm, Wednesday, January 20 from 2 to 5pm and 7 to 9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Hackensack University Medical Center Foundation, Hackensack, NJ; St. Augustine's School, Union City, NJ; Hudson Riverfront Performing Arts Center, Weehawken, NJ. 1/3

LIEBER--Constance. The faculty and staff of the Lieber Institute for Brain Development and the Maltz Research Laboratories at the Johns Hopkins Medical Campus mourn the loss of their inspirational and beloved Founder and Director, Constance Lieber. For more than 30 years, she led an international movement to bring research about behavioral brain disorders to the forefront of biomedical science. Connie Lieber's vision, her determination, and her historic generosity launched thousands of scientific careers. In 2010, she established the Lieber Institute for Brain Development because she was convinced that a new strategy was needed to accelerate progress and to find cures for developmental brain disorders. As she said: "This is our dream, to find out what causes these disorders, and we felt it had to be a concerted effort, to study the brain and how it develops, and this is what the Institute is all about." The world of behavioral and developmental neuroscience has lost one of its strongest advocates and supporters. Connie is always in our hearts and minds. In honor of her passion and commitment, we will work tirelessly to achieve the mission she empowered us to pursue. 1/3

ABRAMSON--Richard. Age 70, of Hewlett Bay Park and Manhattan, passed away peacefully at home on January 17, 2016 after a long and brave battle with Multiple Myeloma. Loving husband of Lorraine, beloved father of Gregg and Jill, father-in-Iaw of Lauren and Jake and proud grandpa to Emma, Leah, Miles and Sadie. Richard was Senior Vice President and Senior Managing Director at Alliance Bernstein for 37 years, President of The Washington Institute for Near East Policy and served on the investment committees of North Shore-LIJ Health System, The Association of Graduates of The Air Force Academy and the Legacy Heritage Fund. He was a board member of The American Friends of The Hebrew University. Richard initiated and funded a program at The Auschwitz Jewish Center, where cadets from the Air Force, West Point and The Naval Academies go to Auschwitz to study the Holocaust. He supported The Israel Sports Center for the Disabled, AIPAC and UJA-Federation. Richard was an avid swimmer, winning a gold and silver medal at the Maccabi Games in 1961 and met his wife Lorraine at the Maccabi Games in 1965. His passion for swimming led him and his swimming buddies to swim the English Channel in 2008 and they did a relay swim around Manhattan Island in 2013 to raise money for Multiple Myeloma. He received a Bachelor of Science degree from the U.S. Air Force Academy and a Masters in Business Administration from Babson College. He was a CFA (Chartered Financial Analyst) charterholder. Richard's optimism throughout his illness was an inspiration to us all. Funeral services will be held at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68th Street, New York, NY 10023 on Wednesday, January 20 at 10am. Donations may be made to: The Ichan School of Medicine at Mt. Sinai, Multiple Myeloma Research, Mt. Sinai Development Office, One Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1049, New York, NY 10029. 1/3

ABRAMSON--Richard S. The Washington Institute extends its deepest condolences to the family of our beloved president, Richard S. Abramson, on his passing at age 70. A longstanding Institute officer, Richard is remembered by those whose lives he touched as a friend, partner, mentor, and inspirational leader. In life and in death, he was fearless, facing great challenges with remarkable courage, boundless energy and infectious good humor. May his memory be for a true and lasting blessing. Martin J. Gross, Chairman Robert B. Satloff, Executive Director 1/3

LIEBER--Constance. The faculty and staff of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons and its Department of Psychiatry, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, and the New York State Psychiatric Institute deeply mourn the passing of our beloved and dear friend, Connie Lieber. Connie and her husband, Steve, were generous supporters and inspirational leaders in the field of psychiatry. In the early 1980s, the Liebers joined the fledgling National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression, now the Brain and Behavior Research Foundation. Their support and eventual leadership made BBRF the major source of private funding for research on mental illness. In addition to psychiatric research, the Liebers generously supported other programs at Columbia University over a 20-year period; their philanthropy benefited the training of M.D. and Ph.D. students, established the Lieber Center for Schizophrenia Research, and funded the Lieber Clinic for Recovery from Mental Illness. In 2014, Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons honored the Liebers with the Crown Award. The entire Columbia community extends its deepest condolences to the Lieber Family. Lee Goldman, M.D. Harold and Margaret Hatch Professor Executive Vice President, Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine, and Chief Executive of Columbia University Medical Center Steven Corwin, M.D. President and Chief Executive Officer NewYork- Presbyterian Hospital Jeffrey Lieberman, M.D. Chairman of Psychiatry, Psychiatrist-in-Chief, and Lawrence C. Kolb Professor at Columbia University Medical Center and NewYork- Presbyterian Hospital, and Director at New York State Psychiatric Institute Herbert Pardes, M.D. Executive Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees at NewYork- Presbyterian Hospital 1/3

MURPHY--Arthur W.,93, Professor Emeritus of Columbia Law School, died on January 16th. He was a graduate of Boston Latin School, Harvard University, and Columbia Law School (Class of 1948). A veteran of the 17th Airborne Division in WWII, he joined the faculty of Columbia Law School in 1963 after stints at the U.S. Department of Justice and in private practice. Professor Murphy taught until four years ago, becoming, at 89, the oldest active professor in the history of the Law School. Survived by wife Jean, children Lois, Rachel, and Paul; sons- in-law Peter and James; grandchildren Matthew, Elizabeth, Keith, Julia, Alexander, and Nicholas; and great- grandchildren Kayla, Autumn, and Zoe. A memorial at Columbia Law School will be announced as soon as plans are completed. 1/3

ADES--Alan M. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Alan M. Ades, a loyal and devoted friend of the Met, who was a distinguished member of the Board for almost 25 years. On behalf of everyone at the Met, we extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Member of the Association Joan Taub Ades, his daughters Jane and Susan Ades, and his family and friends. GIOVANNIELLO--Margaret Montgomery Torr, of Cedarhurst on January 17, 2016. Devoted wife, mother, attorney, administrative law judge and bar association leader. Born on May 23, 1927, in Terre Haute, Indiana, a graduate of the University of Wisconsin and Brooklyn Law School. After marriage to husband Joseph on June 10, 1951, they attended law school together at night while working full-time, then practiced law as Giovanniello & Giovanniello. Later, an administrative law judge with the New York State Department of Labor, she was a leader of the bar, serving as president of the Brooklyn Women's Bar Association, the New York Association of Administrative Law Judges and the National Association of Administrative Law Judiciary. Judge Giovanniello is survived by her sister Helen Exton; four sons: Rocco, Raymond, Joseph Jr., and Earle and six grandchildren, Lauren, Ray Jr., Rachel, Daniel, Sarah and Elizabeth. Family will receive friends at Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, 34 Hempstead Avenue, Lynbrook, NY, Wednesday, January 20, 2016 from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale on Thursday, January 21, 2016 at 11am. For further information, please visit www.flinchand bruns.com. 1/3

YANKAUER--Margaret Bonny, 80, of Ramsey, NJ, succumbed peacefully to cancer on January 15, 2016 with her sons by her side. Ms. Yankauer was born on April 12, 1935 in New York City to Eva (Slifka) and Leonard Berger. She attended Bronx High School of Science and Smith College. Known to her family and friends as Bonny, she was an expert collector and purveyor of fine vintage costume jewelry such as Trifari, Haskel, and Hollycraft. She was a frequent exhibitor at the Triple Pier antique show in Manhattan and was sought out by a wide range of domestic and international buyers from Europe and Asia. Her former husband, Theodore Yankauer III, preceded her in death. She is survived by her son Jeff and his partner Elaina Caola; son Stephen; daughter-in-law Rachel Schnoll and her three beloved grandchildren Sarah, Theodore and Benjamin. She is also survived by her partner and dear friend Dr. Jack Block with whom she shared the last years of her life. A service was held on Sunday, January 17, 2016 at 2pm at Feeney Funeral Home in Ridgewood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you consider donations to the American Cancer Society. 1/3

ZALK--Richard, 72, of Manhattan, died January 15 after a long illness. Richard was the devoted son of the late Joseph and Lee Zalk, protective and caring brother of Connie, much-loved uncle to David, husband of the late Sue Rosenberg Zalk and adoring nephew of Milton and Estelle Zalk and the late Martin and Judith Bloomberg and Hy and Sylvia Plotkin. For more than fifty years, he maintained a steadfast dedication to his legal practice and his clients, while his sharp wit, irreverence, and passion for photography, flying and astronomy helped define his life. He cherished his affiliation with the SoHo Photo Gallery, a co-op for photographers, for more than thirty years, serving as President for four. His loyalty to so many long-standing friends kept him ever-charming, attentive, creative, and warm even in his years of illness. Memorial celebration to be held Saturday, January 30th at 11am at the SoHo Photo Gallery, 15 White Street, New York, NY. Donations can be made to the SoHo Photo Gallery in his memory. 1/3

ADES--Alan M. (1925-2016). Manhattan School of Music and its Board of Trustees are profoundly saddened by the passing of Alan M. Ades, a successful entrepreneur and deeply committed philanthropist who was a great friend to MSM and an influential force for progress at the School. A Trustee Emeritus who served as a member of the School's Board of Trustees for 21 years between 1990 and 2011, Mr. Ades, along with his wife Joan Taub Ades, made many profound contributions to MSM over the years, ensuring the School's advancement as one of the world's leading independent music conservatories. In addition to his important service as a member of MSM's Board, Mr. Ades' stewardship was reflected in his active commitment to the many MSM committees of which he was a member and by the generous leadership contributions he and Mrs. Ades made to the School, often by way of the Joan and Alan Ades-Taub Family Foundation. Many of Mr. Ades' most significant contributions to MSM were guided by his love of opera (he also served as a director at the Met Opera and Santa Fe Opera). In addition to providing generous support to MSM scholarships for classical vocalists, the Ades Family Foundation established and continues to fund the School's prestigious Alan M. and Joan Taub Ades Vocal Competition, an annual event that is judged by an esteemed panel of opera professionals and awards significant cash prizes to winning students. Perhaps most significant, Mr. and Mrs. Ades led the capital campaign for, and ultimately named, one of MSM's key performance and rehearsal spaces, an indispensable, flexible black-box space that not only accommodates full-scale opera and orchestral rehearsals, but also seats audiences of up to 200 for a wide variety of performances. This key addition to MSM's facility-the Alan M. and Joan Taub Ades Performance Space-opened its doors in 2007 and stands as a lively testament to the visionary leadership and generosity made to MSM by this prominent leader in business and philanthropy and his wife, Joan Taub Ades. Our Board of Trustees, Administration, Faculty, Alumni, and Current Students are united in expressing the MSM Community's sorrow at the passing of this singular individual. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Ades, whose continuing friendship we so highly cherish, and to the Ades family; we know that Alan's long, rich, accomplished life and the many wonderful memories it inspires will be a source of comfort and joy in the days and years ahead. Lorraine Gallard, Board Chair James Gandre, President 1/3

LIEBER--Constance E. The Brain & Behavior Research Foundation, formerly the National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression (NARSAD), deeply mourns the passing of its visionary leader and President Emeritus, Constance E. Lieber. Connie, who served as President of the Foundation from 1989 to 2007, felt that research was the best avenue to find meaningful and lasting solutions to alleviate the suffering caused by mental illness. In her role as President Emeritus, she continued to offer her vision and guidance to the Foundation on a regular basis. Connie, along with her husband Stephen, passionately believed in the need to seed the field of neuropsychiatric research with as many talented scientists as possible to make a substantive impact on the broad spectrum of mental health research, which she fervently understood holds our best hope for ending the immense suffering caused by mental illness. Since 1980, Connie and Steve have served as extraordinary philanthropic supporters and leading public advocates of schizophrenia and depression research. Connie worked tirelessly for the cause and grew our grants program to a total of $342 million and was helpful to so many families who were desperately seeking help for their children. We recognize that she enhanced the lives of so many through her work for Brain & Behavior Research Foundation and by supporting scientists throughout the world and have the deepest gratitude to both Connie and Steve. Their generosity in supporting research on mental illness is a great model for all of us. Our deepest sympathies to Connie's beloved husband Steve, their daughter Janice, their son Sam and daughter-in-law Mary, their grandson, and to all of their loved ones. Connie was our leader and guiding light, providing inspiration and motivation to all who ever had the honor and privilege of knowing and working with her. Jeffrey Borenstein, M.D., President & CEO, The Brain & Behavior Research Foundation Herbert A. Pardes, M.D., President of the Foundation's Scientific Council 1/3

HARNETT--Ruth. Age 91, passed away peacefully at her home in Boca Raton, Florida on January 10, 2016. She was predeceased on October 1, 2015 by her loving husband of 71 years, Bertram, a lawyer and retired New York State Supreme Court Judge. She is survived by her children, Andrea, a lawyer and retired Magistrate Judge in Washington, DC and her husband, Benjamin Fisherow; David, a psychiatrist in Medford, Massachusetts and his wife, Dr. Vivian Halfin; James, a lawyer in Madison, Wisconsin and his wife, Marsha Harnett; six grandchildren; and one great granddaughter. Ruth Harnett grew up in Far Rockaway, New York, and graduated from Brooklyn College. She later resided in Great Neck, New York, and in Manhattan. She served as the Director of the Nassau County, New York, Vocational Center for Women in the 1970's. She had many talents: she was an accomplished cook, a talented knitter and quilter, and a speaker of Italian. She read and travelled extensively. She was a beautiful, gentle, generous, elegant, and kind woman, beloved by all who knew her. Most of all, she was intensely loyal to her family, whom she loved as immensely, as we loved her. We will miss her greatly. A funeral was held on January 13, at Temple Beth-el in Boca Raton, Florida. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Planned Parenthood or to the charity of your choice. 1/3

GIOVANNIELLO--Margaret Montgomery Torr, of Cedarhurst on January 17, 2016. Devoted wife, mother, attorney, administrative law judge and bar association leader. Born on May 23, 1927, in Terre Haute, Indiana, a graduate of the University of Wisconsin and Brooklyn Law School. After marriage to husband Joseph on June 10, 1951, they attended law school together at night while working full-time, then practiced law as Giovanniello & Giovanniello. Later, an administrative law judge with the New York State Department of Labor, she was a leader of the bar, serving as president of the Brooklyn Women's Bar Association, the New York Association of Administrative Law Judges and the National Association of Administrative Law Judiciary. Judge Giovanniello is survived by her sister Helen Exton; four sons: Rocco, Raymond, Joseph Jr., and Earle and six grandchildren, Lauren, Ray Jr., Rachel, Daniel, Sarah and Elizabeth. Family will receive friends at Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, 34 Hempstead Avenue, Lynbrook, NY, Wednesday, January 20, 2016 from 2-4 and 7-9pm. MENDELSON--Solomon. The Cantors Assembly sadly notes the passing of its distinguished past president, Hazzan Solomon Mendelson. Sol was a visionary with the capacity to realize many of his dreams, teaching his colleagues to reach well beyond the roles most often associated with a Cantor. In particular, he was a prolific commissioner of new Jewish music, persuading the finest contemporary composers to become his collaborators. He will be deeply missed. The Cantors Assembly extends its condolences to Sol's wife, Emma, his children Keith and Lauren, their spouses, his grandchildren, sister Betty, and his brother, our revered colleague, Hazzan Jacob Mendelson. Alberto Mizrahi, President Stephen J. Stein, Exec. V.P. 1/3

FRANKEL--Mickey (Muriel), 73, of Scarsdale, NY, passed away peacefully at home on January 18, 2016, and is remembered lovingly by her family. Wife for over 53 years to Steven; mother of Jill, Pamela and Wendy, mother-in-law to Steven, Jon and Adam; loving and adoring grandmother of Hannah, Jeffrey, Jacob, Eliot, Benjamin, Abigail, Ethan and Brooke; sister of Louis Morris and daughter of the late Harold and Edythe Morris. Mickey graduated from Scarsdale High School and the University of Pennsylvania and throughout her life was a dedicated and caring volunteer. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be private. Contributions in Mickey's memory can be made to Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY. 1/3

ABRAMSON--Richard S. American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem are saddened by the passing of our friend and colleague, Richard Abramson. Richard was a leader in the financial services industry and a humanitarian who was dedicated to Israel, the Jewish community and the cause of higher education. Richard served on AFHU's national board and its Investment Committee, helping to foster pioneering academic and research pursuits. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Lorraine and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, President American Friends of The Hebrew University Michael S. Kurtz, Chairman Daniel I. Schlessinger, President Beth Asnien McCoy, National Executive Director 1/3

ROSENTHAL--J. Robert, M.D. New York Eye and Ear Infirmary of Mount Sinai notes with sorrow the passing of our dear friend and colleague J. Robert Rosenthal, M.D., a dedicated member of our community for more than 55 years. A renowned cornea surgeon, Dr. Rosenthal was also the hospital's first Medical Director and went on to serve as Senior Vice President for Medical Affairs and Chief Medical Officer before stepping down in 2014. He was a champion of quality service, advanced research, and excellence in physician training. Dr. Rosenthal was the member of a distinguished family of pioneering ophthalmologists at New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. In 2013, he received the John Kearney Rodgers Physician of the Year Award for his commitment to the hospital. New York Eye and Ear Infirmary of Mount Sinai and the Mount Sinai Health System extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Gladys and the entire Rosenthal family. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and Chief Executive Officer, Mount Sinai Health System 1

FRANKEL--Mickey. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime, devoted member and former trustee and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Helene K. Gray, President Jonathan E. Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor 1/3

MARKS--Richard M.,M.D., aged 80, died peacefully at home on January 14, 2016, surrounded by family. Richard will be especially missed by his wife, Judith, his four children, Andrew, Gigi, Elisabeth and Matthew, seven grandchildren, innumerable close family members and longtime friends. Richard was a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst in New York City, where he practiced for more than five decades. Richard grew up in Brooklyn and graduated from Midwood High School. He went to Columbia University and then onto SUNY Downstate College of Medicine, graduating in 1961. A lifetime New Yorker, Richard was a psychiatrist in the Air Force, based in Texas, before returning to New York City to finish his training at Albert Einstein Medical Center in the Bronx and the New York Psychoanalytic Institute. An Attending Clinical Professor in the department of Psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Assistant Attending Psychiatrist at Montefiore Medical Center and senior supervisor in the Consult Liaison Service at Montefiore Medical Center, Richard co-authored "Undertreatment of Medical Inpatients with Narcotic Analgesics," in the Annals of Internal Medicine, an influential article that has been cited more than 1,000 times in academic papers. Richard was an avid reader of history and The New York Times, a devotee of opera, classical music, and art. Richard loved traveling with his wife-together, they visited 43 countries. More than anything, he loved spending time with his family. He will be deeply missed by all of us. 1/3

FRANKEL--Mickey. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Mickey Frankel, and extend sincere condolences to her family. James Dreyfus, President 1/3

ABRAMSON--Richard. The staff and trustees of Northwell Health (formerly North Shore-LIJ Health System) mourn the loss of Trustee Richard Abramson. A dedicated benefactor, co-chairman of the Investment Committee and a member of the Finance, Audit and Executive Committees, Richard and his wife Lorraine supported many programs at Long Island Jewish Medical Center. Thanks to the Abramsons' generosity and commitment to raising the standard of health care for our community, the Richard and Lorraine Abramson Clinical Center at the LIJ Hearing and Speech Center was established. Richard's friendship, philanthropic support and dedication helped Northwell Health become a regional and national leader in health care. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lorraine; children Gregg Abramson and Jill Manczyk; and grandchildren Emma, Leah, Miles and Sadie. Mark L. Claster, Chairman, Board of Trustees, Northwell Health Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, Northwell Health 1/3

WHITMAN--Helen (nee Samson), age 89 of Westport, CT, passed away January 15, 2016. Wife of her cherished Edward for 70 years- living a love usually reserved for poets and dreamers; sister of Gloria Levinson; mother, grandmother, aunt, and great-aunt. Helen was a person of extraordinary character and quality always shining a light of joy, class, kindness, and inspiration that nurtured her family. Loved and admired by the people who knew her, she was the unequivocal proof that one person can make a difference, and she did so in the most beautiful way. 1/3

MAYER--Willa-Ann, age 77. (April 29, 1938-January 19, 2016). Born in the Bronx to Harry and Sylvia Greenhouse and survived by her beloved husband John and heartbroken daughter Jonill. Willa's art degree from Pratt led to a career in fashion, where she dressed stars/friends like Nina Simone and commissioned shoe drawings from Andy Warhol. A dancer, artist, publicist, world-traveler, and teacher for 20 years with a Masters degree from NYU, Willa lived many lives. Cute as a button at under 95 pounds, she impressed all who met her and will be forever missed. Willa-Ann will be celebrated Thursday, January 21, 2016 at 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

BAILLIERE--Thomas Henry Gaither, Jr. On January 17, 2016, Thomas Henry Gaither Bailliere, Jr., of Poplar Hill, MD, beloved husband of Anne (nee Dobbin) Bailliere; devoted father of Elisabeth Bailliere Dean and her husband Christopher, Alexandra Bailliere and her husband Allan Treadwell; loving grandfather of Eliza, Diana and Nicholas Dean, Thomas, James and William Treadwell. LARSON--Rev. Dr. Lawrence A.A.,died on January 16, 2016 at the age of 81. Born on December 27, 1934 to Julia and Adolph Larson in Chicago, IL. He became ordained as an Episcopal priest in 1968 and served at James Church in Great Barrington, MA, and rector of Christ Church in Ansonia, CT and St. Andrew's Church in Brewster, NY. His 50 years of ministry were marked by commitment to social justice. His first wife Dorothy predeceased him. He married Patricia Anderson in 1983. "Father" Larry is survived by his wife Pat, children Dr. Heidi Larson, L. Jeffrey Larson, Arlan Bussell, Merryl Dimaio, Lindsey Anderson, Jevan Anderson, eight grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and his sister Merryl Sanchez. Visitation will be held on January 24th from 1pm-3pm and 6pm-8pm. A service will be held at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Brewster, on January 25 at 11am. Services by Beecher Funeral Home, Brewster, NY. 845-279-3615. 1/3

ADES--Alan Maxwell, died on January 17, 2016. He was 90 years old. He leaves his loving wife, of 57 years, Joan, two daughters, Jane Ades and Susan Ades and her husband, Stephen Lawlor and five grandchildren, Benjamin, Raphi, Kirya, Olivia and Isabelle. He graduated Townsend Harris High School in three years and joined the army at 17 where he became part of the Corps of Engineers. He rose to the position of staff sergeant soon afterwards. After the war, he attended and graduated from CCNY. He founded and was president of Auburn Label and Tag, Co. He loved classical music from the time he was a teenager, when he first worked concessions at Carnegie Hall and extended and embraced that passion by serving on the Board of Directors of The Metropolitan Opera. Additionally, he served on the Board of Trustees of The Manhattan School of Music and of Central Synagogue in New York, where he was also confirmed. While at MSM, he and Joan founded the Ades Vocal Competition and built The Joan Taub Ades and Alan M. Ades Performance Space, as well. He was an avid sailor and skier. Services will take place at 11:00am on Tuesday, January 19, 2016 at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Ave., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to The Metropolitan Opera or The Manhattan School of Music. 1/3

COLBY--Dr. Marvelle S. The entire Marymount Manhattan College community mourns the loss of one of our most dedicated faculty members, Professor Emerita, Dr. Marvelle S. Colby. A leader in the business and entrepreneurial fields, Dr. Colby served Marymount Manhattan College for 21 years as a member of the Business Management and Accounting Division, during which time she also served as the Division Chair. In 2007, a number of Dr. Marvelle S. Colby's former students, colleagues, faculty, and staff joined together to create the Dr. Marvelle S. Colby Endowed Scholarship Fund to ensure that her legacy will live on at the College for years to come. Dr. Colby was a valued member of the Marymount Manhattan College community and we mourn this loss and share our condolences with her family. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY, Friday, January 22nd at 11:15am. The services will be followed by burial at Woodlawn Cemetery. Kerry Walk, Ph.D., President, Marymount Manhattan College; Hope Knight, Chairperson of the Board of Trustees, Marymount Manhattan College 1/3

ISSELBACHER--Marga Schiff, (June 6, 1927-January 17, 2016). Loving mother of Tina and Jesse Isselbacher and grandmother of Kassidy Isselbacher Marino, Haley Singleton and Samantha Isselbacher. Devoted widow of Henry Isselbacher and sister to Robert (Bob) Schiff. Born in Oberthulba, she immigrated to the United States from Badkissingen at the age of nine, when she was sent by her parents alone to escape Nazi Germany. Her life was filled with the joys of marriage, parenthood and friendship and she gave of herself without reservation and with deep affection. She will be sorely missed by her immediate family and her sisters-in-law and nieces and nephews as well as the numerous friends for whom she cared so much during her full life. 1/3

MEYERS--Donald I. Dr. Donald I. Meyers, a leader of the post-war generation of American psychoanalysts, renowned teacher and therapist, and beloved husband, father and grandfather, died on January 13, 2016. An exceptional researcher, teacher and doctor, Don, in loving partnership with his wife of 49 years, Helen, was an influential presence in the psychoanalytic world and a mentor to generations of psychiatrists and psychoanalysts. He was an accomplished therapist, specializing in child analysis, with one of the best reputations in NYC and around the world. As a Clinical Professor of Psychiatry and Training & Supervising Psychoanalyst, he was a pillar of the Columbia Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, Don had a significant impact on American psychoanalysis through his leadership at the American Psychoanalytic Association, where he opened the Association to a broader and more inclusive spectrum of ideas and practitioners. His academic work was in child psychiatry and child analysis. He was Director of Experimental Psychiatry at the Henry Ittleson Center for Child Research. Don was a loving husband, father, uncle and grandfather, and a beloved, loyal friend. He was devoted to his wife, Helen, who passed in 2010. He was universally loved for his sweet demeanor, generous spirit, silent strength, mischievous humor, encyclopedic musical knowledge, and uncommon empathy. All who knew him found understanding and comfort in his embrace. As a good friend has said, Don was all love. He is survived by his son Andrew, partner Fronda, sister Pat, granddaughters Rennie and Maddie, and nieces and nephews Erica, Lizzie, Jonathan, Peter, Ann, Skip, Janice, Sandy, Ken, Benjy, Susie and Judy. Services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 11:30am on Monday, January 25th. Donations may be sent to the APA Helen Meyers Traveling Scholar Committee, 309 East 49th St, NY, NY 10017. 1/3

ANDERSON--Jeanne. The community of West End Synagogue, A Reconstructionist Congregation, has lost a courageous role model. Determined, she remained active and relevant, totally committed to social and racial justice. Fittingly, she took her last breath on Martin Luther King, Jr. Day. LEWIN--Estelle Weinberg. Born April 19, 1920, died January 19, 2016, three months short of her 96th birthday. Daughter of Benjamin and Mary Weinberg, Estelle was part of a loving family. She was predeceased by both her parents and her only brother, Michael Wayne. In 1941, she met the love of her life, Harry Lewin. They married on March 21, 1942 and lived together in wedded bliss. They were married for more than 64 years when Harry died in June 2006. Together they had two daughters, Linda Taub and Blylee Gardiner Bernstein. Linda's husband David passed away in November 2012. Estelle is survived by her daughters Linda and Blylee and Blylee's husband David Bernstein; three grandsons and their wives, Andrew and Suzanne Taub, Marc and Sandy Taub and Joshua and Lisa Taub. She had six great-grandchildren, Jake, Trevor, Chloe, Camille, Asher and Matthew. Funeral services will be held on Friday, January 22, 2016 at 12:00 noon. They will be conducted at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury, NY. 1/3

GREENBERG--Dr. Herb, of Princeton, NJ, passed away after a courageous fight against cancer on Tuesday, January 19, 2016, at home surrounded by his loving family. Herb was the founder and CEO of Caliper Corporation. A lifelong Democrat and supporter of progressive causes, Herb fought for equal rights for minorities, women, and returning veterans, as well as abused animals. Herb lost his eyesight at the age of 10. He held multiple degrees from CCNY and a Ph.D. from NYU. Son of the late Harry and Helen Greenberg, Herb is survived by his two sisters, five children; Gary, Mark, Holly, Alex, and Sally; and one grandchild, Sarah. Donations can be made to Learning Ally, Helen Keller International, or SAVE, A Friend to Homeless Animals. 1/3

PIERMONT--Donald K.,92, of Fair Lawn, NJ passed on Tuesday, January 19, 2016 at home with his loving wife by his side. Born and raised in New York, he resided in Venice, FL for 27 years before returning to Fair Lawn where he had lived for many years. An avid golfer, he served as an officer of the Preakness Hills Country Club in Wayne. A very charitable man especially to the military, Humane Society and American Cancer Society, Don was a loyal and knowledgeable New York Yankees fan, and enjoyed travelling and time spent at the beach. Prior to retiring in 1988, he owned and operated Dave Stern Tires in Paterson and Morristown for 43 years. Beloved husband of Barbara (Stern) Piermont. Loving and devoted father of Donald Piermont, Jr. and wife Barbara, Jack Piermont and wife Marilyn and Sally Gillenson and husband Josh. Cherished grandfather of six and great grandfather of four. The family will receive relatives and friends Thursday, 7-9pm at Vander Plaat-Caggiano Funeral Home, 13-31 Saddle River Road, Fair Lawn, NJ, 201-797-3500. A Funeral Mass is planned for Friday, January 22, 2016, 10:30am at St. Anne R.C. Church, 15-05 St. Anne Street, Fair Lawn, NJ. Entombment will follow at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery in Totowa, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to a charity of choice would be appreciated. For additional information, please visit www.vpfairlawn.com. 1/3

POLLNER--Martin. The family of Martin Pollner mourns the passing of its devoted husband, father, grandfather and brother. In addition to his service to his family, Martin provided more than half a century of service to his country and to the legal profession, serving several United States presidents. He held senior positions with the United States government, including Deputy Attorney General under Robert F. Kennedy and Deputy Assistant of the Treasury and Director of Law Enforcement under Secretaries of the Treasury David Kennedy, John Connally and George Schultz. He helped develop civil rights legislation and developed and coordinated law enforcement policy within the Treasury Department, including the IRS, Customs, Secret Service and Interpol. In addition to service on various Cabinet committees, Martin headed the U.S. Delegation to several Interpol General Assemblies and, after returning to private practice, he was appointed by Secretary of State William P. Rogers as the U.S. representative to the International Narcotics Control Board of the United Nations, a position he held for several years. Over the years, Martin received numerous honors and awards, including the Townsend Harris Medal in 2005 and the Ellis Island Medal of Honor in 2007. After serving as an Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, Martin, in private practice, advised and represented individuals, including CEO's of major corporations as well as numerous luminaries, and companies; investigated corporate misconduct; and untangled complex tax issues, workouts and bankruptcies. Notwithstanding a stellar legal career, nothing delighted him more than his family. He is survived by his wife Valerie, his sons Daniel and Richard, and their spouses, Melissa and Deb, granddaughters Gabriella, Rebakah and Lexi, and his brother Philip. He was entirely unique, and we will miss him. For those who wish to honor his memory, we ask that donations be made to The Rogosin Institute, www.rogosin.org/donate, The Hebrew Home at Riverdale, or Cardiovascular Institute Fund of Mt. Sinai. Service Thursday, January 21, 2016, 12 noon at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. 1/3

FEINBERG--Jacob. Bone Marrow Registry co-Founder Jacob Feinberg dies at 87. The Feinberg Family and the Gift of Life Bone Marrow Foundation mourn the loss of the organization's co-founder, Jacob Feinberg. A CPA with Brout and Company and BDO, Jack later became a pioneer with his wife Arlene advancing the cause of bone marrow donor registration throughout the United States and abroad for the benefit of patients battling blood cancer. His efforts made possible bone marrow transplants for thousands of patients in need. The world is a better place thanks to Jack, a true hero, and his memory will live on through the lives he and Arlene saved together. He was the loving father of Jay, Steven, Edward of blessed memory and daughter-in-law Sheryl; loving grandfather of Shauna, Michelle and Skylar; brother of Robert and sister-in-law of Marty. Jack will be missed by the entire Gift of Life organization that he and Arlene created, and his countless friends and loving family. Contributions in Jack's memory may be made at www.giftoflife.org. 1/3

ISSELBACHER--Marga Schiff, (June 6, 1927-January 17, 2016). Loving mother of Tina and Jesse Isselbacher and grandmother of Kassidy Isselbacher Marino, Haley Singleton and Samantha Isselbacher. Devoted widow of Henry Isselbacher and sister to Robert (Bob) Schiff. Born in Oberthulba, she immigrated to the United States from Badkissingen at the age of nine, when she was sent by her parents alone to escape Nazi Germany. Her life was filled with the joys of marriage, parenthood and friendship and she gave of herself without reservation and with deep affection. She will be sorely missed by her immediate family and her sisters-in-law and nieces and nephews as well as the numerous friends for whom she cared so much during her full life. 1/3
