MEYERS--Donald I. Dr. Donald I. Meyers, a leader of the post-war generation of American psychoanalysts, renowned teacher and therapist, and beloved husband, father and grandfather, died on January 13, 2016. An exceptional researcher, teacher and doctor, Don, in loving partnership with his wife of 49 years, Helen, was an influential presence in the psychoanalytic world and a mentor to generations of psychiatrists and psychoanalysts. He was an accomplished therapist, specializing in child analysis, with one of the best reputations in NYC and around the world. As a Clinical Professor of Psychiatry and Training & Supervising Psychoanalyst, he was a pillar of the Columbia Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, Don had a significant impact on American psychoanalysis through his leadership at the American Psychoanalytic Association, where he opened the Association to a broader and more inclusive spectrum of ideas and practitioners. His academic work was in child psychiatry and child analysis. He was Director of Experimental Psychiatry at the Henry Ittleson Center for Child Research. Don was a loving husband, father, uncle and grandfather, and a beloved, loyal friend. He was devoted to his wife, Helen, who passed in 2010. He was universally loved for his sweet demeanor, generous spirit, silent strength, mischievous humor, encyclopedic musical knowledge, and uncommon empathy. All who knew him found understanding and comfort in his embrace. As a good friend has said, Don was all love. He is survived by his son Andrew, partner Fronda, sister Pat, granddaughters Rennie and Maddie, and nieces and nephews Erica, Lizzie, Jonathan, Peter, Ann, Skip, Janice, Sandy, Ken, Benjy, Susie and Judy. Services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 11:30am on Monday, January 25th. Donations may be sent to the APA Helen Meyers Traveling Scholar Committee, 309 East 49th St, NY, NY 10017. 1/3

DAYTON--Robert. Robert Dayton, whose career spanned decades in support of a vibrant downtown Minneapolis, MN, died on January 17th. He was 73 years old. A great-grandson of the founder of Daytons, Bob carried on the family retail and community-oriented legacy. After graduating from Yale in 1964, Bob joined what was to become Dayton Hudson and then Target, rising to become General Merchandise Manager and then Vice President of Stores. While with Daytons, Bob attended the Program for Management Development at Harvard Business School. A merchandiser at heart, Bob became recognized for his deftness in identifying and supporting designers such as Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren early in their careers. In 1977 Bob left Daytons and purchased Harold, an upscale specialty store for women. Working together with his wife Joanie, Bob restored its iconic status as a Minneapolis retail institution. In 1984 Bob spearheaded the development of The Conservatory, the first enclosed shopping complex in Minneapolis. Throughout his career Bob advocated for a thriving downtown and worked to strengthen the Twin Cities as a major league community through efforts to bring Superbowl XXVI to Minneapolis, keep the Timberwolves, and secure funding for a new outdoor Twins stadium. Bob served on several corporate boards including Northwestern National Bank, First American Funds, and Williams Sonoma. In 1992 Bob became CEO of Okabena, helping transform the Dayton family office into a nationally recognized leader in the then-nascent family office industry. Fiercely loyal to and enormously proud of the people and places he loved, Bob was committed to serving his community. He worked tirelessly on behalf of many non-profits including the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, Abbott Northwestern Hospital, the United Way, and Westminster Presbyterian Church. In addition, Bob served as a Trustee of the Blake School, Carlton College, and the University of Minnesota Foundation. In 1994 Bob founded and was later named Chair Emeritus of the Mentoring Partnership of Minnesota. Bob grew up in Wayzata, Minnesota and attended Blake, Eaglebrook, and Taft. While at Yale, Bob met his wife Joanie, then attending Skidmore College, on a blind date at the Dartmouth Winter Carnival. They were married in 1964 and had three boys. Bob enjoyed a number of hobbies, but none more so than golf. Beginning at Woodhill Country Club, his passion eventually extended east to Pine Valley and west to Cypress Point. He cofounded Spring Hill Golf Club and enjoyed playing in the U.S. Seniors. Bob will always be remembered for his warm heart, wonderful smile, infectious laughter, fantastic sense of humor, and tremendous spirit. He is survived by Joanie, his wife of 51 years, two brothers, three sons, and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on February 18th at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Minneapolis. 1/3

IMMERMAN--Robert M.,76, died peacefully at home in Larchmont, NY on January 21, 2016, having miraculously survived brain cancer for 20 years. Loving and beloved husband of Minna for 50 years, proud father to daughters Gaby and Suzanne and "Papa" to grandson Emmet. Services will be held at Larchmont Temple on Monday, January 25 at 10am. Interment at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. 1/3

ZIELENZIGER--Dr. Ruth, who helped change how Conservative Jews in America are taught the Bible, and inspired some of Israel's most enduring poetry of love while a young woman, died Thursday at the RiverWalk independent living facility of the Hebrew Home in the Bronx, one day shy of her 93rd birthday. Awarded her Doctorate of Hebrew Literature at age 66, Dr. Zielenziger was instrumental in creating the curriculum for teaching the books of Genesis and Exodus in Conservative Judaism at the Melton Research Center of the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York City. The Melton program emphasized critical inquiry and the study of Bible for character education. She was a proponent of studying the creation myths and texts of other Middle Eastern cultures in order to better understand the context in which the Bible was written. Born in London, the daughter of Leo and Lola Herrmann, ardent Zionists, she grew up in Jerusalem before the founding of the Jewish state, and served as an ambulance driver and chauffeur in the British Army during World War II, where her fluency in Hebrew, English and German was invaluable. After the War, she attended the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, where she met a German emigre and fellow student, Yehuda Pfeuffer, whom she renamed Yehuda Amichai. Amichai went on to become Israel's most celebrated poet, and the first drafts of many of his most enduring poems were composed as letters exchanged between the two. Amichai's letters to Dr. Zielenziger are now archived at Ben Gurion University in Israel. She moved to New York in 1947, to study at the Teachers Institute of the Seminary. While in New York she met and subsequently married Eric W. Zielenziger, a German Jewish survivor of the Holocaust who escaped the Nazis by living underground in Amsterdam for more than two years. They had two children. For 34 years, Dr. Zielenziger taught education at the Jewish Theological Seminary, after teaching for many years in Hebrew schools in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island. Before relocating to Riverdale in their later years the Zielenzigers lived primarily in Freeport and Great Neck, NY. She is survived by her sons David, of Great Neck, and Michael (Diane Abt) of Oakland, CA and Manhattan and a brother, Dr. Gabriel Herrmann of Jerusalem. Services will be held Friday at 11am at Riverside Nassau North, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. 1/3

LEWIN--Estelle Weinberg. Born April 19, 1920, died January 19, 2016, three months short of her 96th birthday. Daughter of Benjamin and Mary Weinberg, Estelle was part of a loving family. She was predeceased by both her parents and her only brother, Michael Wayne. In 1941, she met the love of her life, Harry Lewin. They married on March 21, 1942 and lived together in wedded bliss. They were married for more than 64 years when Harry died in June 2006. Together they had two daughters, Linda Taub and Blylee Gardiner Bernstein. Linda's husband David passed away in November 2012. Estelle is survived by her daughters Linda and Blylee and Blylee's husband David Bernstein; three grandsons and their wives, Andrew and Suzanne Taub, Marc and Sandy Taub and Joshua and Lisa Taub. She had six great-grandchildren, Jake, Trevor, Chloe, Camille, Asher and Matthew. Funeral services will be held on Friday, January 22, 2016 at 12:00 noon. They will be conducted at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury, NY. 1/3

ROTHSTEIN--Harold Jay, of Teaneck, NJ died on Wednesday, January 20, 2016, two weeks after being diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and one week before his 70th birthday. Carole Rothstein, his wife of 46 years had her head on his chest when he took his last breath. He was born on January 26, 1946 in the Bronx and was the youngest child of Rose and Milton Rothstein. He graduated from City College with a degree in sociology. He went on to complete his Master's in Education and "ABD" (all but his dissertation) for his PhD both from the New School. Starting out as a teacher in the late 1960s, Harold dedicated his life to education. He taught science until the mid- 1970s becoming an administrator in the 1980s and 1990s. Since retiring from the Board of Education he was an educational consultant mentoring students and teachers who wanted to become principals. He was proud of being involved in both Teach for America and the New York City Fellowship Program. Always the life of the party Harold lived every minute with passion. An avid photographer and world traveler he visited his 106th country in December. His life was filled with culture, music and art that he shared with his family and friends. Harold is survived by his wife of 46 years, Carole Rothstein, his sons Gabriel and Adam, his daughter and son-in-law Jessica and Randall Berman, his granddaughter Rachel Rose, his brother and sister-in-law Joel and Barbara Rothstein, and many nieces, nephews and cousins. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Harold J. Rothstein can be made to The Institute for Educational Advancement or the Lustgarten Foundation. Services will be 1pm today at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, NJ. Burial will follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, New Jersey. 1/3

COLBY--Dr. Marvelle S. The entire Marymount Manhattan College community mourns the loss of one of our most dedicated faculty members, Professor Emerita, Dr. Marvelle S. Colby. A leader in the business and entrepreneurial fields, Dr. Colby served Marymount Manhattan College for 21 years as a member of the Business Management and Accounting Division, during which time she also served as the Division Chair. In 2007, a number of Dr. Marvelle S. Colby's former students, colleagues, faculty, and staff joined together to create the Dr. Marvelle S. Colby Endowed Scholarship Fund to ensure that her legacy will live on at the College for years to come. Dr. Colby was a valued member of the Marymount Manhattan College community and we mourn this loss and share our condolences with her family. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY, Friday, January 22nd at 11:15am. The services will be followed by burial at Woodlawn Cemetery. Kerry Walk, Ph.D., President, Marymount Manhattan College; Hope Knight, Chairperson of the Board of Trustees, Marymount Manhattan College 1/3

DAYTON--Robert. Robert Dayton, whose career spanned decades in support of a vibrant downtown Minneapolis, MN, died on January 17th. He was 73 years old. A great-grandson of the founder of Daytons, Bob carried on the family retail and community-oriented legacy. After graduating from Yale in 1964, Bob joined what was to become Dayton Hudson and then Target, rising to become General Merchandise Manager and then Vice President of Stores. While with Daytons, Bob attended the Program for Management Development at Harvard Business School. A merchandiser at heart, Bob became recognized for his deftness in identifying and supporting designers such as Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren early in their careers. In 1977 Bob left Daytons and purchased Harold, an upscale specialty store for women. Working together with his wife Joanie, Bob restored its iconic status as a Minneapolis retail institution. In 1984 Bob spearheaded the development of The Conservatory, the first enclosed shopping complex in Minneapolis. Throughout his career Bob advocated for a thriving downtown and worked to strengthen the Twin Cities as a major league community through efforts to bring Superbowl XXVI to Minneapolis, keep the Timberwolves, and secure funding for a new outdoor Twins stadium. Bob served on several corporate boards including Northwestern National Bank, First American Funds, and Williams Sonoma. In 1992 Bob became CEO of Okabena, helping transform the Dayton family office into a nationally recognized leader in the then-nascent family office industry. Fiercely loyal to and enormously proud of the people and places he loved, Bob was committed to serving his community. He worked tirelessly on behalf of many non-profits including the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, Abbott Northwestern Hospital, the United Way, and Westminster Presbyterian Church. In addition, Bob served as a Trustee of the Blake School, Carlton College, and the University of Minnesota Foundation. In 1994 Bob founded and was later named Chair Emeritus of the Mentoring Partnership of Minnesota. Bob grew up in Wayzata, Minnesota and attended Blake, Eaglebrook, and Taft. While at Yale, Bob met his wife Joanie, then attending Skidmore College, on a blind date at the Dartmouth Winter Carnival. They were married in 1964 and had three boys. Bob enjoyed a number of hobbies, but none more so than golf. Beginning at Woodhill Country Club, his passion eventually extended east to Pine Valley and west to Cypress Point. He cofounded Spring Hill Golf Club and enjoyed playing in the U.S. Seniors. HAINES--Daniel W.,died January 11, 2016, age 78. Husband of Brynne, father of Gordon and Laurel, retired Professor of Engineering at Manhattan College and University of South Carolina. Greatly interested in music, substitutes for wood in musical instruments, history of New Jersey and of White Plains, NY. Consider donations to ALS Association - Greater NY Chapter. 1/3

MISSETT--Barbara Thatcher. 77 years old, died peacefully at her home in West Palm Beach, FL, on January 20, 2016, surrounded by her family. Barbara was born on May 25, 1938 in Washington, DC to Herbert and Virginia Thatcher. Barbara graduated from Rosemont College in Philadelphia in 1960 where she obtained her bachelor's degree in English. In 1980, she co-founded VIART Corporation, an art management firm based in New York City. During its twenty-nine years of operation VIART provided art advisory services to over 100 Fortune 500 companies, financial institutions, law firms, and private individuals including the acquisition of American, European, African and Asian art in all mediums and all periods. Barbara was a member of the Everglades Club in Palm Beach, FL, The Meadow Club of Southampton, and the Bathing Corporation of Southampton. Barbara was preceded in death by her parents and younger brother Denis Thatcher. Surviving are her sons Joseph Missett IV and Stephen Missett, her grandson Santiago Missett, and her siblings Judy O'Donnell, Sheila Taylor, Stephen Thatcher, Joyce Thatcher and Herbert Thatcher II. Family and friends will be received on Thursday, January 28, 2016, from 4-6pm at Quattlebaum's Funeral Home, 6411 Parker Avenue, West Pam Beach, FL. Funeral Liturgy with Mass will be celebrated on Friday, January 29, 2016 at 11am at St. Edward's Catholic Church, 144 North County Road, Palm Beach. A reception in her honor at the Everglades Club will follow. Entombment will be at a later date at the convenience of the family. Memorial contributions may be made to a charity of your choice. 1/3

TIPSON--Lynn Baird, died on January 18 in Basking Ridge, New Jersey, at the age of 96. He was a retired business executive and a 1941 graduate of Princeton University. He also attended the Hill School and later received an MBA from NYU. Tipson served in the Army Air Corps during WWII and piloted eleven missions in a B-24 bomber until he was shot down, hospitalized, and sent to a German prison camp until liberation. He is survived by his wife of 74 years, Yvonne Gaston Tipson, four children, Lynn Jr. of Gettysburg, PA, Frederick of Moorestown, NJ, David of Glenside, PA, and Suzy Hall of Milford, OH, as well as eleven grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Tipson was born in Westfield, NJ, where his father was Mayor in 1928-29, and resided there, except for the war years, until 1967. A funeral service will be held at 2pm on January 30 at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Basking Ridge with burial at Fairview Cemetery in Westfield. 1/3

CHASIN--Dr. Mark, 73. On January 22, 2016 of Monroe, NJ, formerly of Manalapan, NJ. Pre-deceased by his wife Rena in 2003, now beloved husband to Reva SternChasin, amazing father to Jeff (Lisa), Larry (Andrea), and Marni (Lee) and adored grandfather of Shelby Chasin, Samara Chasin, Jake Garfinkle, Jack Chasin, William Chasin and Ryan Garfinkle. Mark grew up in Merrick, NY, graduated from Cornell University (B.S.) and Michigan State (PhD) and dedicated his life to developing new medicines and drug delivery methods. Our world is forever changed. 1/3

BOTTNER--Harold, 88, of Tampa, FL formerly of Mamaroneck NY, died peacefully on January 15, 2016 after a long illness. He will be dearly missed by his beloved wife of 64 years, Dorothy, and their children, Jane, Andy, and Karen (Noel). He also leaves behind grandchildren Ben, Carolyn, Rosie and Emma. Harold will be remembered for his entrepreneurial spirit, having started HMB, Inc., a successful commercial sweater manufacturing business. His easy manner, dry wit and huge sense of humor, always accompanied by a big smile and a catchy tune, endeared him to all who knew him. Above all, Harold's honesty, kindness and generosity to others were perhaps his most lasting and loving legacy. A memorial service will be held in New York in the spring. Memorial donations can be made to Myasthenia Gravis Foundation of America, myasthenia.org or the charity of your choice. 1/3

VAN NESS--John R.,known as "Jack," 70, of Ossining, NY, died peacefully with his wife at his side, January 19, 2016, at Rosary Hill Home after a short, courageous struggle with cancer. Jack was born in New York City, December 24, 1945, later preferring to tell folks he grew up on a small island off the coast of New Jersey. He studied at Stephens Institute of Technology and later earned his BS degree at Long Island University. Taking pre-med courses, he planned to follow in the footsteps of his deceased father, who was a NYC physician. All that changed when he took a summer job at Thomas J. Lipton company where he discovered the many faceted world of food science. His enthusiasm for food science never diminished. During his 20 year corporate career, he worked at a number of leading food companies including Best Food and Chesebrough Ponds. He gained experienced in every aspect of food processing, plant production, food safety, product development and federal filing regulations and practices. He was a trained taster who could recognize the individual spices in any combination presented, much to the surprise of restaurant chefs, a number of whom he advised and befriended over the years. As his career evolved, his focus centered on canned foods and he became one of New York's foremost food processing authorities. As such, he was a consultant who was recognized and worked with the United States Department of Agriculture and food processing. An avid sailor and scuba diver since his teens, Jack left the corporate world behind to sail from New York City to the Caribbean with a sailor buddy, exploring practically every island there during their six month cruise. Soon after his return, he formed his own company, Van Ness Food Technologies, which he operated while living aboard his 37 foot sailboat, "Cruzin," docked at City Island, NY. In 1992, he found "the love he had been waiting for" when he met Carolyn, another enthusiastic scuba diver. They married in 2001 aboard a yacht in New York harbor. Throughout their years together, they traveled the world, lured by possible dive adventures in the Caribbean, Bora Bora, Europe, Mexico and the Red Sea. One of Jack's favorite sea stories was about his transatlantic sail aboard a 42 foot sailboat from Bermuda to Malaga, Spain. "Sailing across the Pond is on every sailor's bucket list and I couldn't be happier or more satisfied because I got to do it," said Jack. Jack loved being with friends and sharing sea stories based on his experiences sailing with Carolyn up and down Long Island Sound, always on the lookout for a new raft up spot and seafood restaurant. For almost 30 years, Jack's consulting business worked with international clients in Canada, Greece, Israel and Korea. He was a featured lecturer at the First Food Safety Conference held in Bangalore, India, where he taught Indian food scientists how to implement Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point safety principles. Jack was a hands on expert who knew how to build and manage a food plant from its conception to the time the canned food product was on the pallet ready to go to market. He was known for his strong sense of integrity and absolute dedication to ensuring the safety of any food product under his production management. He was a charter member of IFTPS, participating in annual food conferences in the US and abroad. Jack was more than generous in passing along his wealth of knowledge to his many clients, interspersed with updates about his latest sailing or diving adventures. His genuine enjoyment of life was contagious. It enabled Jack to engage in lively conversations and make friends with young and old alike. With the wind at his back, he has charted his course, leaving us with memories of an unforgettable personality, sharp wit, brilliant mind and smile. Besides his beloved wife, Carolyn, he leaves behind a worldwide group of business associates and longtime friends, whose many lives he touched. At his request, his ashes are to be scattered over the area waters that gave him so much pleasure. There will be a celebration of Jack's life during the coming sailing season. 1/3

WASHINGTON--Bryan R.,professor of late 19th and 20th century American literature and cultural studies, and a man of considerable wit, humor, style, elegance, and charm, with a passion for the beauty and joy of some of life's most abundant and finest offerings, died of cancer on December 31, 2015. He was 57. The son of Dr. Joseph R. Washington, Jr. and the late Sophia M. Washington, Bryan was born in Boston, Massachusetts. During his formative years, Bryan lived in numerous towns and cities in Wisconsin, Virginia, California, and Pennsylvania, where he attended the University of Pennsylvania. At UPenn, Bryan was a Benjamin Franklin Scholar; he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree (with honors) in General Literature in 1980. UPenn served as a catalyst for Bryan's graduate studies, which led him to complete his Master's Degree in English Literature at Christ Church, Oxford University in 1982 through Penn's Thouron Award, a British-American exchange program. Bryan received his second Master's Degree in English and American Language at Harvard University in 1985. He was also a Minority Prize Fellow from 1982-1987. Bryan received his Ph.D. in English and American Literature and Language from Harvard in 1989. Bryan launched his academic career as an instructor at Lafayette College in 1987 and was promoted to Assistant Professor in 1989. He served as a Ford Foundation Postdoctoral Fellow at Princeton University from 1991-1992. In 1994, Bryan was promoted to Associate Professor with full tenure. Bryan's scholarly work includes the publication of a book entitled "The Politics of Exile: The Ideology in Henry James, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and James Baldwin" in 1995. The book was well received and widely cited. It is considered by many to be one of the first works to position James Baldwin alongside white canonical American authors. Bryan also authored several articles and reviews, including: "Paris Blues(s)," an essay on James Baldwin; and "WASP Mischief: Martha Stewart and the Racial Status Quo." He was in the process of writing two books before he became ill. Throughout his career at Lafayette, which spanned over a quarter century, Bryan received numerous honors, including the Student Government Superior Teaching Award in 1989-1990 and 1992-1993, which is rare for a professor to receive twice. Bryan delivered presentations at Lafayette on topics such as "Blacks in Popular Culture" and "Black Writers in the Classroom." In May 2014, Bryan delivered "The Last Lecture" to graduating seniors; this was, sadly, Bryan's last lecture and last professional engagement. The title of the lecture was: "In the Course of It All: Life is Words;" this honor, along with the two student government teaching awards, suggests how deeply he was loved by his students- his courses were always over-enrolled. Students described him as inspiring, exciting, funny, and extremely smart. Bryan once described his teaching in the following terms: "If asked what I aim to accomplish in the classroom, I would say I am trying for a good conversation. For in all my courses dialogue is a primary emphasis. I enjoy lecturing, but my class presentations, generally, are designed to provoke dissuasion. Whether just beginning college work or about to finish, undergraduates (I believe) have something to teach me." As a resident of Doylestown, PA, Bryan's life included jazz and the American songbook as a joy, metaphor and interpretation of his many passions: writing, literary criticism, food, art, "beautiful things," and, of course, Paris. During evenings, he would often play his stereo or the piano and sing to Carmen McRae, Shirley Horn or other great jazz artists, while duck was in the oven (or some other scrumptious dish) along with a plate of pate and wine at the ready, all for the evening's feast to be shared with Russell Clinton, his husband and life partner for 23 years, and, on many occasions, close friends. During his stay fighting cancer in various hospitals and healthcare facilities, Bryan often said that the rooms that he was in were "simply awful", and "he wants to go out in style" - of course his care and room assignments were, in fact, top notch! But, we all know Bryan and his desire to be surrounded by beauty. So, what did he do to dress up his room(s)? He buys a beautifully designed Simon Pearce lamp for only a brief stay. And, at Christmas, even though he was unable to eat solid foods or drink, he had a bounty of epicurean delights delivered from Dean and Deluca for him to taste and smell, including his favorite wines and brandy, all for the decadence of it all, and to celebrate his favorite holiday in abundance with his dear Russell. In addition to his husband Russell, Bryan is survived by his father, Joseph; father and mother-in-law, Bill and Ruthann; brother, David, and his partner, Christine; Russell's sister, Debbie and her children Calvin, Travis and Kiara and numerous other family members and friends. A celebration of Bryan's life will be held at 4pm, Friday, January 29, 2016 at Buckingham Friends School, 5684 York Road, Lahaska, PA. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania Annual Fund, Penn Medicine Development, 3535 Market Street, Suite 750, Philadelphia, PA 19104 or online at https://www.cancer. pennmedicine.org. Reed and Steinbach Funeral Home, Doylestown www.reedand steinbach.com 1/3

REED--Howard, 90, of Wellington, Florida, died peacefully with his family in Dresher, Pennsylvania on January 21, 2016. Howard was a devoted and loving husband for 66 years to his beautiful wife, Dolores, who died just 23 days before, and a loving father to his children, Janet and Rob, their spouses Dan and Julie, and his grandchildren, Lindsay, Ben, and Michael. Howard was born in 1925 in Brooklyn, NY. At 17, he became a radio broadcaster for WBAX and later at WNYC, where at 19, he broadcast General Eisenhower's triumphant ticker-tape parade down 5th Avenue. When he enlisted in the Army/Air Force, he became a broadcaster for Armed Forces Radio in Berlin. Howard entered the publishing field in his 20's, and was the publisher for more than 50 magazines in a career that spanned over 50 years in New York and Stamford in fields as diverse as electronics, entertainment, floor covering, and education. A gifted speaker and storyteller, after his retirement from publishing, Howard was a regular lecturer for Palm Beach College on politics, economics, and the media. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, January 26th at 11:00am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue, in Manhattan. DAYTON--Robert. Robert Dayton, whose career spanned decades in support of a vibrant downtown Minneapolis, MN, died on January 17th. He was 73 years old. A great-grandson of the founder of Daytons, Bob carried on the family retail and community-oriented legacy. After graduating from Yale in 1964, Bob joined what was to become Dayton Hudson and then Target, rising to become General Merchandise Manager and then Vice President of Stores. While with Daytons, Bob attended the Program for Management Development at Harvard Business School. A merchandiser at heart, Bob became recognized for his deftness in identifying and supporting designers such as Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren early in their careers. In 1977 Bob left Daytons and purchased Harold, an upscale specialty store for women. Working together with his wife Joanie, Bob restored its iconic status as a Minneapolis retail institution. In 1984 Bob spearheaded the development of The Conservatory, the first enclosed shopping complex in Minneapolis. Throughout his career Bob advocated for a thriving downtown and worked to strengthen the Twin Cities as a major league community through efforts to bring Superbowl XXVI to Minneapolis, keep the Timberwolves, and secure funding for a new outdoor Twins stadium. Bob served on several corporate boards including Northwestern National Bank, First American Funds, and Williams Sonoma. In 1992 Bob became CEO of Okabena, helping transform the Dayton family office into a nationally recognized leader in the then-nascent family office industry. Fiercely loyal to and enormously proud of the people and places he loved, Bob was committed to serving his community. He worked tirelessly on behalf of many non-profits including the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, Abbott Northwestern Hospital, the United Way, and Westminster Presbyterian Church. In addition, Bob served as a Trustee of the Blake School, Carlton College, and the University of Minnesota Foundation. In 1994 Bob founded and was later named Chair Emeritus of the Mentoring Partnership of Minnesota. Bob grew up in Wayzata, Minnesota and attended Blake, Eaglebrook, and Taft. While at Yale, Bob met his wife Joanie, then attending Skidmore College, on a blind date at the Dartmouth Winter Carnival. They were married in 1964 and had three boys. Bob enjoyed a number of hobbies, but none more so than golf. Beginning at Woodhill Country Club, his passion eventually extended east to Pine Valley and west to Cypress Point. He cofounded Spring Hill Golf Club and enjoyed playing in the U.S. Seniors. Bob will always be remembered for his warm heart, wonderful smile, infectious laughter, fantastic sense of humor, and tremendous spirit. He is survived by Joanie, his wife of 51 years, two brothers, three sons, and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on February 18th at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Minneapolis. 1/3

LAMONT--Austin. Austin Lamont, peacefully on January 16, age 79, of Belmont, MA and formerly of Santa Fe, NM, brother of Lavinia Rosenthal, Nicholas Lamont, and Nancy Sullivan; father of Carrie, Helen, Owen and Nathan Lamont; eight grandchildren and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Austin Lamont was born in Baltimore and graduated from Oberlin College in 1960 and from Boston University in 1962. He worked in documentary film production in the Boston area until he left to teach at Ohio University from 1967-69; he produced Film Comment magazine from 1968-73, co-founded Boston Film/Video Foundation in 1971 and co-produced "Conversations with Willard Van Dyke" in 1981. WEIDENFELD--Lord George. The World Jewish Congress mourns the passing of a giant, a committed philanthropist, world-renowned publisher of authors including Vladimir Nabokov, articulate advocate of the Jewish people and fearless defender of the Jewish State of Israel. George Weidenfeld grew up in Vienna and fled Austria after the Nazi takeover in 1938. Because he was saved by a Christian family, George never forgot that his life was spared by Christians and just last year, he created a foundation to rescue thousands of persecuted Christians in the Middle East. This man never forgot his debts and always repaid them. As an immigrant during World War II, George became an integral part of the BBC World Service and broadcast reports in several languages. In 1969, Queen Elizabeth acknowledged Britain's appreciation and knighted him, followed by a life peerage in the House of Lords in 1976. Last April, at the age of 95, Lord Weidenfeld was awarded the WJC's Theodor Herzl Award in London and became an honorary vice-president of the World Jewish Congress. There are few people in the entire world who have spoken out with more courage against injustice. Our dear friend George was one. He was one of the most inspiring and accomplished figures of the 20th and 21st centuries. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Annabelle, daughter Laura, grandchildren and great grandchildren. We will miss him deeply. World Jewish Congress President Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman of the Governing Board David de Rothschild, Treasurer Chella Safra 1/3

He was predeceased by his beloved wife Estelle Covel Borowitz and is survived by his children Lisa Borowitz, Drucy Borowitz and Philip Glick, and Nan and Andrew Langowitz; their children Zoey Glick and Matthew Swerdlin, Zachary Glick, Noah Langowitz and Monikah Schuschu, Emily Langowitz, and Joshua Langowitz; and great-grandson Lewis Swerdlin. ZIELENZIGER--Dr. Ruth, who helped change how Conservative Jews in America are taught the Bible, and inspired some of Israel's most enduring poetry of love while a young woman, died Thursday at the RiverWalk independent living facility of the Hebrew Home in the Bronx, one day shy of her 93rd birthday. Awarded her Doctorate of Hebrew Literature at age 66, Dr. Zielenziger was instrumental in creating the curriculum for teaching the books of Genesis and Exodus in Conservative Judaism at the Melton Research Center of the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York City. The Melton program emphasized critical inquiry and the study of Bible for character education. She was a proponent of studying the creation myths and texts of other Middle Eastern cultures in order to better understand the context in which the Bible was written. Born in London, the daughter of Leo and Lola Herrmann, ardent Zionists, she grew up in Jerusalem before the founding of the Jewish state, and served as an ambulance driver and chauffeur in the British Army during World War II, where her fluency in Hebrew, English and German was invaluable. After the War, she attended the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, where she met a German emigre and fellow student, Yehuda Pfeuffer, whom she renamed Yehuda Amichai. Amichai went on to become Israel's most celebrated poet, and the first drafts of many of his most enduring poems were composed as letters exchanged between the two. Amichai's letters to Dr. Zielenziger are now archived at Ben Gurion University in Israel. She moved to New York in 1947, to study at the Teachers Institute of the Seminary. While in New York she met and subsequently married Eric W. Zielenziger, a German Jewish survivor of the Holocaust who escaped the Nazis by living underground in Amsterdam for more than two years. They had two children. For 34 years, Dr. Zielenziger taught education at the Jewish Theological Seminary, after teaching for many years in Hebrew schools in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island. Before relocating to Riverdale in their later years the Zielenzigers lived primarily in Freeport and Great Neck, NY. She is survived by her sons David, of Great Neck, and Michael (Diane Abt) of Oakland, CA and Manhattan and a brother, Dr. Gabriel Herrmann of Jerusalem. 1/3

KADISON--Rhoda, 95, daughter of Hyman and Sylvia Gechter, residing in Laguna Woods, formerly of Whitestone, NY. She was the beloved wife of Herbert for 70 years, adored mother of Eric and Jeffrey, loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Services will be in California. 1/3

WASHBURN--Seth H. Seth Harwood Washburn, executive, musician, fly fisherman, civil rights advocate and beloved patriarch, died on January 17 in Bath, Maine. He was 94. Seth was born in Kansas City, MO on October 24, 1921, the son of Henrietta DeSelding and Rt. Reverend Benjamin Washburn, bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark. He married Janet Higginbotham in 1944. Seth attended Dartmouth College, and earned BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from MIT. After serving in the Navy during World War ll, Seth joined Bell Laboratories where he spent his entire career and co-authored "The Design of Switching Circuits," a seminal text in his field. Seth was a fierce advocate for civil rights and fair housing. He was recognized by the Association of Black Laboratories Employees as a "visionary executive, skillful leader, and man of dignity and grace." In 1984, Seth and Janet fulfilled their love for the ocean and the working coast of New England by retiring to Bath. Janet died in 1987. Seth was an accomplished musician, playing piano, flute, and recorder, and had a passion for jazz. His life-long devotion to fly-fishing included tying his own flies for over 70 years. He loved his Newfies, Labs, and Maine Coon cats - and a strong martini and a good cigar. He is survived by five children, ten grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. Seth Washburn was an extraordinary man and will be deeply missed by all who knew him. 1/3

VANDERSALL--Thornton M.D. The Department of Psychiatry at North Shore University Hospital mourns the passing of our former Chairman, Thornton Vandersall MD on January 8, 2016. From 1974 to 1988, Dr. Vandersall's leadership was characterized by a commitment to resident education, sensitive patient care and faculty development. A board-certified pediatrician, psychiatrist and child psychiatrist, he also initiated a Child Psychiatry Division at North Shore. Dr. Vandersall received his MD degree from Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia, his pediatric training at Bellevue and New York Hospitals, and his psychiatry and child psychiatry training at St. Luke's Medical Center. He achieved the rank of Emeritus Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at Cornell University Medical College. Engaged in both his local medical community and national psychiatry organizations, Dr. Vandersall was recognized as a life member of the Nassau County Medical Society, the Medical Society of the State of New York, and the American Medical Association; and as a Distinguished Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association and the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry. He influenced the careers of many psychiatrists and the lives of countless patients and families through his high clinical standards, his strong physician values, and his thoughtful gentlemanliness. John M. Kane, M.D. Chairman, Department of Psychiatry North Shore University Hospital/ Long Island Jewish Medical Center/ Hofstra Northwell School of Medicine 1/3

POLLNER--Martin. The family of Martin Pollner mourns the passing of its devoted husband, father, grandfather and brother. In addition to his service to his family, Martin provided more than half a century of service to his country and to the legal profession, serving several United States presidents. He held senior positions with the United States government, including Deputy Attorney General under Robert F. Kennedy and Deputy Assistant of the Treasury and Director of Law Enforcement under Secretaries of the Treasury David Kennedy, John Connally and George Schultz. He helped develop civil rights legislation and developed and coordinated law enforcement policy within the Treasury Department, including the IRS, Customs, Secret Service and Interpol. In addition to service on various Cabinet committees, Martin headed the U.S. Delegation to several Interpol General Assemblies and, after returning to private practice, he was appointed by Secretary of State William P. Rogers as the U.S. representative to the International Narcotics Control Board of the United Nations, a position he held for several years. Over the years, Martin received numerous honors and awards, including the Townsend Harris Medal in 2005 and the Ellis Island Medal of Honor in 2007. After serving as an Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, Martin, in private practice, advised and represented individuals, including CEO's of major corporations as well as numerous luminaries, and companies; investigated corporate misconduct; and untangled complex tax issues, workouts and bankruptcies. Notwithstanding a stellar legal career, nothing delighted him more than his family. He is survived by his wife Valerie, his sons Daniel and Richard, and their spouses, Melissa and Deb, granddaughters Gabriella, Rebekah and Lexi, and his brother Philip. He was entirely unique, and we will miss him. For those who wish to honor his memory, we ask that donations be made to The Rogosin Institute, www.rogosin.org/donate, The Hebrew Home at Riverdale, or Cardiovascular Institute Fund of Mt. Sinai. 1/3

EPPLER--Jerome C. Investment professional, passed away on December 16, 2015 at his home in Denver, Colorado. He was born on March 16, 1924 in Englewood, New Jersey, to William E. and Aileen V. Eppler and was a 50 year resident of Morris County, NJ. He was educated at the Peck School, Berkshire School, Rice University, Texas A&M and graduated with an MBA from Wharton (University of Pennsylvania) in 1949. Prior to attending Wharton, Jerry served in the US Navy as a Lieutenant JG on USS La Porte, and later served on the staff of Admiral Louis Denfeld (Chief of Naval Operations) in Washington, DC. Jerry began his investment career at Equitable Securities in Houston before joining the New York brokerage firm of Cyrus J. Lawrence & Sons in 1952, where he became their youngest partner. In 1961 Jerry created Eppler & Company as a private, independent advisory and investment firm focused on managing portfolio assets for a number of family groups including the Bass and Richardson families of Wichita Falls, the Harrington family of Amarillo, the Murchison family of Dallas, and the Vickers family of Wichita and Denver. Eppler & Company advised its clients on both control and non-control investments in numerous public and private companies, including venture capital investments, leveraged buyouts and proxy contests as an activist investor in an era when many of these investment strategies were not widely deployed. Through his work at Eppler & Company, Jerry was active in the management and governance of some of America's major companies. In the transportation sector, he played a role in the establishment of the New York Central Railroad and later served as a director of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad (1965-1969). In addition, Jerry helped to found US Airways through the acquisition of regional carriers including Mohawk Airlines and Lake Central Airlines. Jerry was a longstanding director of Swift & Company and had an important role in the transformation of Swift into Esmark, Inc. between 1965 - 1990, creating one of America's leading conglomerates with a business portfolio that included: Swift Meats, International Playtex, Avis Rent a Car, Vickers Energy and Trans Ocean Oil. Jerry was a director of Recognition Equipment Company, inventor of the bar code and digital reading technology as well as Tessco Technologies Inc. a major electronics distribution company (1982-2007). In the entertainment world, Jerry was the chairman of United Screen Arts from 1966-1973. In finance, Jerry was Chairman and CEO of ISI Corporation (1967-1977), owner of the Life Insurance Company of California (innovator of the universal life insurance product), Windsor Life (U.K), and World Wide Life Assurance Co. (U.K.) which, together, were later sold to EF Hutton. Jerry was a long serving director of Telecredit Inc., a technology-enabler of the credit card industry (later acquired by Equifax) and was a director of the First National Iron Bank of Morristown New Jersey. Jerry was a limited partner of Alex Brown & Sons (Baltimore, MD) from 1982-1984, and a principal in Olympic Capital Partners, a Seattle based investment group (1995-2000). In addition to his corporate efforts, Jerry was an active philanthropist, particularly supporting education and the arts. Jerry would remain active with Wharton throughout his career and served as the first head of Wharton's Alumni Association (1972-1986). In addition, he was a co-founder of the New York Society of Security Analysts. He was a lifelong supporter of Middlebury College in Vermont and served as a trustee of Drew University (Madison, NJ) from 1966-1967. He was a longtime board member of the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences (Morristown, NJ, 1954-1976) and served on the Board of the Metropolitan Opera Association (New York City, 1980-1982). Jerry was a member of the Industrial Advisory Committee of the University of California (San Diego, 1978-1993) and served on the Board of the Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation (La Jolla, CA). In his later years, he was the founding Chairman of the Global Leadership Council in the College of Business at Colorado State University, serving as its first Chairman (2002-2004) and as a member (2002-2012). Jerry will be remembered by his many friends and family as a quintessential venture capitalist with a keen business vision and strong entrepreneurial spirit. Jerry is survived by his wife, Debora Nye Eppler, his five children (Stephen, Randy, Margaret, Elizabeth Vidmar and Edward), eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He will be laid to rest in a family plot in Mendham, New Jersey. Share your memories of Jerry by visiting the guestbook link. - See more at: www.horancares.com 1/3

GANZ--Arnold R.,age 90, a resident of Westport, CT, passed away peacefully at his home on January 21, 2016. Mr. Ganz was born in New York City, son of the late William and Irene Ganz, and was a United States Army Veteran who served during World War II. He was a recipient of a Purple Heart and Bronze Star. He attended Biarritz American University and NYU majoring in business administration. Mr. Ganz was President of Pervel Ind., a subsidiary of Bemis Corporation, until his retirement in 1990. He is survived by his beloved wife of 64 years, Enid W. Ganz, his devoted children; Austin (Cheryl), Harrison (Heidi), and Andrea (Robert Vogel), and adored grandchildren Evan, Bradford, and Jordan. Mr. Ganz was predeceased by his sister, Lenore Epstein. Funeral services will take place on Monday, January 25, 2016 at 11am at Temple Israel 14 Coleytown Road Westport, CT with interment at Temple Israel Cemetery, Richards Avenue in Norwalk. Memorials to the American Liver Foundation. 1/3

MURPHY--Arthur W.,93, Professor Emeritus of Columbia Law School, died on January 16th. He was a graduate of Boston Latin School, Harvard University, and Columbia Law School (Class of 1948). A veteran of the 17th Airborne Division in WWII, he joined the faculty of Columbia Law School in 1963 after stints at the U.S. Department of Justice and in private practice. Professor Murphy taught until four years ago, becoming, at 89, the oldest active professor in the history of the Law School. Survived by wife Jean, children Lois, Rachel, and Paul; sons- in-law Peter and James; grandchildren Matthew, Elizabeth, Keith, Julia, Alexander, and Nicholas; and great- grandchildren Kayla, Autumn, and Zoe. A memorial at Columbia Law School will be announced as soon as plans are completed. 1/3

RABINOVITCH--Ralph D. MD. January 17, 1917, died February 23, 2015. Trained at Bellevue in Child Psychiatry under pioneer Lauretta Bender along with late wife Dr Sara Dubo. They co-founded Children's Psychiatric Hospital University of Michigan and Hawthorn Center for State of Michigan, an innovative and nationally renowned institution. Wrote influential papers on autism, dyslexia, graphic art in Psychiatry. His film "Stevie's Light Bulb" won Blue Ribbon at American Film Festival. Memorial Service January 31, 12:00. irakaufman.com 1/3

SIDEROW--Neil, beloved father, grandfather, business partner and friend, passed away peacefully at home on December 4th, 2015. He is survived by his sons Stephen, Brad and Josh, his daughters-in-law Saskia and Vanessa, and his six grandchildren, Abigail, Nathaniel, Sofia, Liam, Eli and Mia. Above all, Neil was a mensch. We will miss his charm, his enthusiasm for life and his boundless love for family, the Jewish people and the State of Israel. 1/3

RYAN--Dr. James H.,85. Pioneering psychiatrist, and long time Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at the Columbia College of Physicians & Surgeons, died at home in East Hampton on December 28th. Dr. Ryan played a key role in introducing the use of video to psychiatric education, helping to shape the curriculum for several generations of New York State medical residents. Over his nearly 60 year career, Ryan also maintained an active private practice, first in New York, and then too in East Hampton. Born in 1930 in Albion, NY, Ryan didn't fit the typical mold of psychotherapist. He rode high school football stardom to Yale, where he started as quarterback in his senior year, and also punter and kick-off receiver. Invited to training camp with the Cleveland Browns, Ryan opted instead for Harvard Medical School, and a life beyond football. In addition to former students, patients, and colleagues, Ryan is survived by his loving family: Wife Lisa Eyer Ryan, daughter Justine Ryan, sons Maxwell and Oliver Ryan, and granddaughter Ursula, as well as by his brother Maury Ryan of Providence, RI. 1/3

GERSTEL--Joel. The American Parkinson Disease Association mourns the passing of Mr. Joel Gerstel, its former President and CEO who passionately served the organization and the Parkinson's community as a national board member and then as its Chief Staff leader for over 30 years. We send our love and condolences to his family on behalf of all the families he faithfully served. 1/3

FREDENBURGH--Harold, architect of emblematic tall buildings on skylines across the country, died on January 21, 2016 after a year-long battle with cancer. He was 82 years old. After earning a Master of Architecture degree from Yale University, Fredenburgh worked for a quarter century at I.M. Pei & Partners, where he was an associate partner and design principal. He established his own office, Fredenburgh Wegierska-Mutin Architects, in 1990. In his work with the Pei firm and in independent practice, each of his buildings marked its setting with iconic forms and distinctive public spaces, from a master planned waterfront promenade in Dubai to the iconic CenTrust Tower in Miami, Texas Commerce Tower in Houston, and First Interstate World Center, the tallest building west of Chicago, which provides a memorable centerpoint to the vast horizontal landscape of Los Angeles. Harold Fredenburgh also made major contributions to the design of the John Hancock Tower in Boston. Fredenburgh's efforts in landmark preservation and planning policy contributed to shaping New York City. For two decades his leadership in planning and design review in his home community of Bronxville, New York, was instrumental in preserving the unique character of a landmark residential village while allowing it to meet the challenges of contemporary needs. He was a guiding voice on the Scholarship and Brunner Award Committees of the American Institute of Architects/New York Chapter, a member of the Planning and Urban Design Committee, and a founding member of the Society of Architectural Historians. An unusually well read and scholarly architect, he was an accomplished international lecturer on design and urban planning issues, and was widely regarded in both the university and in the office as a dedicated teacher and ardent advocate of young professionals. As a consequence of his experience with the design of tall buildings, in 1998 he was elected one of four American members of the Russian Academy of Architecture and Building Sciences. He was elevated to Fellowship in the American Institute of Architects in 2014. Harold Fredenburgh will be very missed by his daughter Audrey Mateer, son-in-law Robert Williams, Anna Mutin, friends and colleagues. 1/3

WEIDENFELD--Lord George The America-Israel Friendship League expresses its great sorrow at the passing of Lord George Weidenfeld. His wisdom, experience, good will and warm friendship can never be replaced and will never be forgotten. His activities in support of efforts to resolve the challenges of international affairs involved intimate contact with world leaders at the highest levels. He will especially be remembered for guiding the renewal of German participation in world affairs which accelerated Germany's acceptance in the councils of peace and constructive dialogue. His commitment to the survival and success of Israel in world affairs can be matched by few participants in international diplomacy. We send our sincere condolences to Lady Weidenfeld and his adoring family. Mortimer B. Zuckerman, Honorary President; Kenneth J. Bialkin, Chairman; Ambassador Dan Gillerman, Chairman of Israel Board; Daniella Rilov, Executive Director; Ruby Shamir, Executive Director, AIFL Israel and Director of International Operations; Dr. Charlotte K. Frank, Chair, Executive Committee; Ira J. Greenblatt, Treasurer; Peter J. Halasz, Secretary James S. Tisch 1

FITZSIMONS--John Joseph, passed away peacefully in his Manhattan home Friday, January 22 surrounded by his devoted wife of 39 years Diane, daughters Elizabeth, Bronwen, and Gael, their husbands, and his grandson Jack. He was 73. Born at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan to parents Teresa Fitzsimons (nee Collum) and John P. Fitzsimons, "John Joe" was raised in Woodside, Queens. Predeceased by his sister Maureen 33 years to the day, John is survived by his brother, Cornelius. John was founder and Chairman of Data Systems Computer Centre. John was Vice Chairman of the New York City St. Patrick's Day Parade, for which he would annually paint the green line along the 5th Avenue parade route. He was the Almoner of the Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, a member of the Board of Directors of the St. Patrick's Day Foundation, and also an active member of the Ireland US Council, the Knights of St. Patrick, and the American Ireland Fund. 1/3
